Conclusion: MAGIC-Talk provides a robust, customizable, and temporally stable one-shot solution for talking-face generation, addressing core challenges in identity preservation, lip-sync, and long-form coherence; it reduces the need for multiple references or fine-tuning and enables text-driven editing.

Abstract: Audio-driven talking face generation has gained significant attention for
applications in digital media and virtual avatars. While recent methods improve
audio-lip synchronization, they often struggle with temporal consistency,
identity preservation, and customization, especially in long video generation.
To address these issues, we propose MAGIC-Talk, a one-shot diffusion-based
framework for customizable and temporally stable talking face generation.
MAGIC-Talk consists of ReferenceNet, which preserves identity and enables
fine-grained facial editing via text prompts, and AnimateNet, which enhances
motion coherence using structured motion priors. Unlike previous methods
requiring multiple reference images or fine-tuning, MAGIC-Talk maintains
identity from a single image while ensuring smooth transitions across frames.
Additionally, a progressive latent fusion strategy is introduced to improve
long-form video quality by reducing motion inconsistencies and flickering.
Extensive experiments demonstrate that MAGIC-Talk outperforms state-of-the-art
methods in visual quality, identity preservation, and synchronization accuracy,
offering a robust solution for talking face generation.

</details>


### [134] [FairJudge: MLLM Judging for Social Attributes and Prompt Image Alignment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22827)
*Zahraa Al Sahili,Maryam Fetanat,Maimuna Nowaz,Ioannis Patras,Matthew Purver*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: FairJudge is a lightweight protocol that uses instruction-following multimodal LLMs as fair, evidence-grounded judges to evaluate how well T2I systems align with prompts and respects attributes, with abstention when cues are insufficient. It outperforms face-centric and CLIP baselines across diverse datasets and supports reproducible fairness audits, aided by a new DIVERSIFY corpus.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current T2I evaluation proxies (face classifiers, contrastive similarity) are biased, uncalibrated, and miss sensitive attributes (religion, culture, disability). There is a need for accountable, explainable, and abstention-capable evaluation that can handle visible attributes and profession accuracy.

Method: A lightweight protocol where instruction-following multimodal LLMs act as judges. Judgments are mapped to an explanation-oriented rubric in [-1,1], constrained to a closed label set, with evidence grounded in visible content and abstention if cues are insufficient. Evaluations span datasets (FairFace, PaTA, FairCoT; religion, culture, disability; IdenProf, FairCoT-Professions, DIVERSIFY-Professions) and include a new DIVERSIFY image corpus. Judge models are compared to contrastive and face-centric baselines; professions accuracy is tracked.

Result: Judges outperform contrastive and face-centric baselines in demographic prediction and achieve higher mean alignment while preserving high profession accuracy, enabling more reliable fairness audits across multiple datasets.

Conclusion: FairJudge provides accountable, evidence-aware evaluations that do not alter generators, enhancing reproducibility and fairness auditing in T2I systems. The work also contributes datasets (DIVERSIFY) and broadens the scope of fairness evaluation to diverse attributes and professions.

Abstract: Text-to-image (T2I) systems lack simple, reproducible ways to evaluate how
well images match prompts and how models treat social attributes. Common
proxies -- face classifiers and contrastive similarity -- reward surface cues,
lack calibrated abstention, and miss attributes only weakly visible (for
example, religion, culture, disability). We present FairJudge, a lightweight
protocol that treats instruction-following multimodal LLMs as fair judges. It
scores alignment with an explanation-oriented rubric mapped to [-1, 1];
constrains judgments to a closed label set; requires evidence grounded in the
visible content; and mandates abstention when cues are insufficient. Unlike
CLIP-only pipelines, FairJudge yields accountable, evidence-aware decisions;
unlike mitigation that alters generators, it targets evaluation fairness. We
evaluate gender, race, and age on FairFace, PaTA, and FairCoT; extend to
religion, culture, and disability; and assess profession correctness and
alignment on IdenProf, FairCoT-Professions, and our new DIVERSIFY-Professions.
We also release DIVERSIFY, a 469-image corpus of diverse, non-iconic scenes.
Across datasets, judge models outperform contrastive and face-centric baselines
on demographic prediction and improve mean alignment while maintaining high
profession accuracy, enabling more reliable, reproducible fairness audits.

</details>


### [135] [LLM-based Fusion of Multi-modal Features for Commercial Memorability Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22829)
*Aleksandar Pramov*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A multimodal fusion approach for predicting commercial memorability uses a Gemma-3 LLM backbone to integrate pre-extracted Vision (ViT) and Text (E5) features via multi-modal projections, with LoRA adaptation and LLM-generated rationale prompts; it outperforms a tuned gradient-boosted trees baseline in robustness and generalization on the final test set (code available).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Memorability prediction for commercials is a cross-modal task where both visual and textual cues contribute. Leveraging an LLM-driven rationale and expert-derived memorability aspects aims to improve generalization across unseen data and provide interpretable guidance for fusion.

Method: A multimodal fusion system with a Gemma-3 LLM backbone integrates pre-computed ViT visual features and E5 textual features using multi-modal projections. The LLM is LoRA-adapted for efficient fine-tuning. An ensemble of gradient-boosted trees serves as a heavily-tuned baseline. A key novelty is generating rationale prompts from the LLM, grounded in expert-derived memorability aspects, to steer the fusion model.

Result: The LLM-based fusion system demonstrates greater robustness and generalization on the final test set compared to the baseline gradient-boosted trees ensemble.

Conclusion: LLM-guided multimodal fusion with rationale prompts and LoRA adaptation improves commercial memorability prediction and generalization, with an open-source codebase available at the provided GitHub link.

Abstract: This paper addresses the prediction of commercial (brand) memorability as
part of "Subtask 2: Commercial/Ad Memorability" within the "Memorability:
Predicting movie and commercial memorability" task at the MediaEval 2025
workshop competition. We propose a multimodal fusion system with a Gemma-3 LLM
backbone that integrates pre-computed visual (ViT) and textual (E5) features by
multi-modal projections. The model is adapted using Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA).
A heavily-tuned ensemble of gradient boosted trees serves as a baseline. A key
contribution is the use of LLM-generated rationale prompts, grounded in
expert-derived aspects of memorability, to guide the fusion model. The results
demonstrate that the LLM-based system exhibits greater robustness and
generalization performance on the final test set, compared to the baseline.
  The paper's codebase can be found at
https://github.com/dsgt-arc/mediaeval-2025-memorability

</details>


### [136] [Semantic-Preserving Cross-Style Visual Reasoning for Robust Multi-Modal Understanding in Large Vision-Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22838)
*Aya Nakayama,Brian Wong,Yuji Nishimura,Kaito Tanaka*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: SP-CSVR proposes a cross-style reasoning framework for LVLMs to maintain stable semantics across diverse visual styles, using CSFE, SAICD, and ASCM; achieves state-of-the-art results on multi-style tasks including captioning, VQA, and in-context style adaptation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The 'style trap' impedes robust semantic understanding in large vision-language models across heterogeneous visual styles; current methods struggle to decouple style from content, limiting generalization.

Method: Introduce Cross-Style Feature Encoder (CSFE) for style-content disentanglement; Semantic-Aligned In-Context Decoder (SAICD) for efficient few-shot style adaptation; Adaptive Semantic Consistency Module (ASCM) using multi-task contrastive learning to enforce cross-style semantic invariance.

Result: Extensive experiments on a challenging multi-style dataset demonstrate state-of-the-art performance across visual captioning, visual question answering, and in-context style adaptation; ablations and generalization analyses verify robustness, generalization, and efficiency across diverse visual styles.

Conclusion: SP-CSVR effectively enhances robustness, generalization, and efficiency in cross-style visual reasoning and semantic understanding, demonstrating strong adaptability to diverse visual styles while preserving semantic integrity.

Abstract: The "style trap" poses a significant challenge for Large Vision-Language
Models (LVLMs), hindering robust semantic understanding across diverse visual
styles, especially in in-context learning (ICL). Existing methods often fail to
effectively decouple style from content, hindering generalization. To address
this, we propose the Semantic-Preserving Cross-Style Visual Reasoner (SP-CSVR),
a novel framework for stable semantic understanding and adaptive cross-style
visual reasoning. SP-CSVR integrates a Cross-Style Feature Encoder (CSFE) for
style-content disentanglement, a Semantic-Aligned In-Context Decoder (SAICD)
for efficient few-shot style adaptation, and an Adaptive Semantic Consistency
Module (ASCM) employing multi-task contrastive learning to enforce cross-style
semantic invariance. Extensive experiments on a challenging multi-style dataset
demonstrate SP-CSVR's state-of-the-art performance across visual captioning,
visual question answering, and in-context style adaptation. Comprehensive
evaluations, including ablation studies and generalization analysis, confirm
SP-CSVR's efficacy in enhancing robustness, generalization, and efficiency
across diverse visual styles.

</details>


### [137] [FastJAM: a Fast Joint Alignment Model for Images](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22842)
*Omri Hirsch,Ron Shapira Weber,Shira Ifergane,Oren Freifeld*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: FastJAM is a fast graph-based joint alignment method that uses pairwise keypoint matches, rapid nonparametric clustering, and a graph neural network to predict per-image homographies with an inverse-compositional loss, achieving better alignment quality in seconds compared to slower JA methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Joint alignment of multiple images is computationally intensive, requiring long training times, large models, and extensive hyperparameter tuning. There is a need for a fast, accurate JA method that minimizes hyperparameter dependence.

Method: Construct a graph from pairwise keypoint matches (intra- and inter-image relations) using an off-the-shelf image matcher, apply rapid nonparametric clustering, and propagate/aggregate information with a graph neural network. Predict per-image homographies via image-level pooling. Use an inverse-compositional loss to avoid a regularization term over the transformations, removing the need for hyperparameter tuning.

Result: Experiments on several benchmarks show that FastJAM achieves alignment quality better than existing modern JA methods while reducing computation time from hours or minutes to seconds.

Conclusion: FastJAM delivers rapid and effective joint alignment without the need for regularization hyperparameters, and code is available on the project webpage for reproducibility.

Abstract: Joint Alignment (JA) of images aims to align a collection of images into a
unified coordinate frame, such that semantically-similar features appear at
corresponding spatial locations. Most existing approaches often require long
training times, large-capacity models, and extensive hyperparameter tuning. We
introduce FastJAM, a rapid, graph-based method that drastically reduces the
computational complexity of joint alignment tasks. FastJAM leverages pairwise
matches computed by an off-the-shelf image matcher, together with a rapid
nonparametric clustering, to construct a graph representing intra- and
inter-image keypoint relations. A graph neural network propagates and
aggregates these correspondences, efficiently predicting per-image homography
parameters via image-level pooling. Utilizing an inverse-compositional loss,
that eliminates the need for a regularization term over the predicted
transformations (and thus also obviates the hyperparameter tuning associated
with such terms), FastJAM performs image JA quickly and effectively.
Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that FastJAM achieves
results better than existing modern JA methods in terms of alignment quality,
while reducing computation time from hours or minutes to mere seconds. Our code
is available at our project webpage, https://bgu-cs-vil.github.io/FastJAM/

</details>


### [138] [Semantic Surgery: Zero-Shot Concept Erasure in Diffusion Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22851)
*Lexiang Xiong,Chengyu Liu,Jingwen Ye,Yan Liu,Yuecong Xu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A training-free, zero-shot framework (Semantic Surgery) for erasing target concepts in text-to-image diffusion by per-prompt embedding subtraction, augmented with co-occurrence encoding and a visual feedback loop; claims high erasure quality with preserved image quality.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Harmful or explicit content in text-to-image diffusion requires safe generation without sacrificing image quality. Existing methods often rely on training or address single concepts, lacking prompt-adaptive, robust solutions with locality preservation.

Method: Estimate the presence of target concepts in prompts dynamically; perform calibrated vector subtraction on text embeddings to neutralize their influence before diffusion; Co-Occurrence Encoding module enables robust multi-concept erasure; visual feedback loop mitigates latent persistence of concepts; training-free and per-prompt adaptive.

Result: Outperforms state-of-the-art across object, explicit content, artistic style, and multi-celebrity erasure tasks. Reports high erasure completeness and robustness while preserving locality and image quality. Notable metrics include 93.58 H-score for object erasure, explicit content reduced to 1 instance, and 8.09 H_a for style erasure with no quality degradation.

Conclusion: Semantic Surgery offers a practical, prompt-adaptive safety mechanism for safe text-to-image generation. It enables robust concept erasure without training, maintains locality and image quality, and can function as a built-in threat detection system.

Abstract: Concept erasure in text-to-image diffusion models is crucial for mitigating
harmful content, yet existing methods often compromise generative quality. We
introduce Semantic Surgery, a novel training-free, zero-shot framework for
concept erasure that operates directly on text embeddings before the diffusion
process. It dynamically estimates the presence of target concepts in a prompt
and performs a calibrated vector subtraction to neutralize their influence at
the source, enhancing both erasure completeness and locality. The framework
includes a Co-Occurrence Encoding module for robust multi-concept erasure and a
visual feedback loop to address latent concept persistence. As a training-free
method, Semantic Surgery adapts dynamically to each prompt, ensuring precise
interventions. Extensive experiments on object, explicit content, artistic
style, and multi-celebrity erasure tasks show our method significantly
outperforms state-of-the-art approaches. We achieve superior completeness and
robustness while preserving locality and image quality (e.g., 93.58 H-score in
object erasure, reducing explicit content to just 1 instance, and 8.09 H_a in
style erasure with no quality degradation). This robustness also allows our
framework to function as a built-in threat detection system, offering a
practical solution for safer text-to-image generation.

</details>


### [139] [Seeing the Unseen: Towards Zero-Shot Inspection for Wind Turbine Blades using Knowledge-Augmented Vision Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22868)
*Yang Zhang,Qianyu Zhou,Farhad Imani,Jiong Tang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A zero-shot, RAG-grounded VLM framework for wind turbine blade damage detection using a multimodal knowledge base and a hybrid retriever; achieves data-efficient, explainable detection and can generalize to unseen defects, with perfect accuracy on a small test set vs weaker baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Tackle data scarcity and labeling requirements in drone-based blade inspection and enable detection of rare or evolving damage types without task-specific training.

Method: Build a multimodal knowledge base (technical documents, representative reference images, domain guidelines). Use a hybrid text-image retriever with keyword-aware reranking to assemble relevant context and condition a Vision-Language Model at inference, foregoing task-specific fine-tuning. Evaluate on 30 labeled blade images covering multiple defect types; compare to open-vocabulary baselines; report Clopper-Pearson confidence intervals and perform ablations to assess explainability and generalizability.

Result: RAG-grounded VLM correctly classified all 30 samples; non-retrieval VLM underperformed in accuracy and precision. Outperformed open-vocabulary baselines. Uncertainty intervals were used to account for small sample size. Ablations indicate the main advantage is grounded reasoning via retrieved references, enabling detection of previously unseen defects.

Conclusion: Proposes a data-efficient, explainable inspection framework for industrial blades that reduces reliance on large labeled datasets and leverages domain knowledge to improve generalization and unseen defect detection.

Abstract: Wind turbine blades operate in harsh environments, making timely damage
detection essential for preventing failures and optimizing maintenance.
Drone-based inspection and deep learning are promising, but typically depend on
large, labeled datasets, which limit their ability to detect rare or evolving
damage types. To address this, we propose a zero-shot-oriented inspection
framework that integrates Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) with
Vision-Language Models (VLM). A multimodal knowledge base is constructed,
comprising technical documentation, representative reference images, and
domain-specific guidelines. A hybrid text-image retriever with keyword-aware
reranking assembles the most relevant context to condition the VLM at
inference, injecting domain knowledge without task-specific training. We
evaluate the framework on 30 labeled blade images covering diverse damage
categories. Although the dataset is small due to the difficulty of acquiring
verified blade imagery, it covers multiple representative defect types. On this
test set, the RAG-grounded VLM correctly classified all samples, whereas the
same VLM without retrieval performed worse in both accuracy and precision. We
further compare against open-vocabulary baselines and incorporate uncertainty
Clopper-Pearson confidence intervals to account for the small-sample setting.
Ablation studies indicate that the key advantage of the framework lies in
explainability and generalizability: retrieved references ground the reasoning
process and enable the detection of previously unseen defects by leveraging
domain knowledge rather than relying solely on visual cues. This research
contributes a data-efficient solution for industrial inspection that reduces
dependence on extensive labeled datasets.

</details>


### [140] [Estimating Pasture Biomass from Top-View Images: A Dataset for Precision Agriculture](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22916)
*Qiyu Liao,Dadong Wang,Rebecca Haling,Jiajun Liu,Xun Li,Martyna Plomecka,Andrew Robson,Matthew Pringle,Rhys Pirie,Megan Walker,Joshua Whelan*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A comprehensive, multi-modal pasture biomass dataset (1,162 images) from 19 Australian sites, with biomass components, height, and NDVI, released on Kaggle to advance ML-based biomass estimation and precision grazing.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable accurate pasture biomass estimation for better stocking-rate decisions, reducing overgrazing, and promoting pasture health by providing a large, diverse, annotated dataset that fuses visual, spectral, and structural information.

Method: Collected top-view images of 70 cm × 30 cm quadrats (1,162 images) across seasons and temperate pasture species from 19 locations. On-ground measurements include biomass by green, dead, and legume fractions, vegetation height, and NDVI from Active Optical Sensors. The dataset is released as a Kaggle competition.

Result: A dataset of 1,162 annotated images from 19 locations, providing multi-modal data (images, biomass components, height, NDVI) to support development and evaluation of ML models for pasture biomass estimation; publicly available via Kaggle.

Conclusion: The dataset offers a valuable resource for advancing precision grazing management by enabling ML models that fuse visual, spectral, and structural cues to accurately estimate biomass and inform stocking decisions.

Abstract: Accurate estimation of pasture biomass is important for decision-making in
livestock production systems. Estimates of pasture biomass can be used to
manage stocking rates to maximise pasture utilisation, while minimising the
risk of overgrazing and promoting overall system health. We present a
comprehensive dataset of 1,162 annotated top-view images of pastures collected
across 19 locations in Australia. The images were taken across multiple seasons
and include a range of temperate pasture species. Each image captures a 70cm *
30cm quadrat and is paired with on-ground measurements including biomass sorted
by component (green, dead, and legume fraction), vegetation height, and
Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) from Active Optical Sensors
(AOS). The multidimensional nature of the data, which combines visual,
spectral, and structural information, opens up new possibilities for advancing
the use of precision grazing management. The dataset is released and hosted in
a Kaggle competition that challenges the international Machine Learning
community with the task of pasture biomass estimation. The dataset is available
on the official Kaggle webpage:
https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/csiro-biomass

</details>


### [141] [Gen-LangSplat: Generalized Language Gaussian Splatting with Pre-Trained Feature Compression](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22930)
*Pranav Saxena*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Gen-LangSplat replaces the scene-specific autoencoder in LangSplat with a generalized autoencoder pretrained on ScanNet, enabling a fixed, compact latent space for language features across new scenes. This removes per-scene training bottlenecks while preserving or improving open-vocabulary querying in 3D. 


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LangSplat relies on a scene-specific language autoencoder to compress features for open-v vocabulary 3D fields, which introduces a costly per-scene optimization bottleneck hindering scalable deployment. A generalized autoencoder promises scene-agnostic compression with broader data support.

Method: Replace the per-scene autoencoder with a generalized autoencoder pretrained on a large-scale dataset (ScanNet). Use a fixed latent space for CLIP-like language features across scenes. Conduct ablations to select latent dimension and measure fidelity via mean squared error and cosine similarity between original and reprojected 512-d CLIP embeddings.

Result: The approach achieves an efficiency boost by removing scene-specific training while delivering querying performance that matches or exceeds LangSplat. Ablation studies quantify optimal latent dimension and demonstrate faithful representation through MSE and cosine similarity metrics.

Conclusion: Generalized embeddings enable efficient, scalable open-vocabulary querying in novel 3D scenes without scene-specific training, supporting real-time interactive 3D AI applications.

Abstract: Modeling open-vocabulary language fields in 3D is essential for intuitive
human-AI interaction and querying within physical environments.
State-of-the-art approaches, such as LangSplat, leverage 3D Gaussian Splatting
to efficiently construct these language fields, encoding features distilled
from high-dimensional models like CLIP. However, this efficiency is currently
offset by the requirement to train a scene-specific language autoencoder for
feature compression, introducing a costly, per-scene optimization bottleneck
that hinders deployment scalability. In this work, we introduce Gen-LangSplat,
that eliminates this requirement by replacing the scene-wise autoencoder with a
generalized autoencoder, pre-trained extensively on the large-scale ScanNet
dataset. This architectural shift enables the use of a fixed, compact latent
space for language features across any new scene without any scene-specific
training. By removing this dependency, our entire language field construction
process achieves a efficiency boost while delivering querying performance
comparable to, or exceeding, the original LangSplat method. To validate our
design choice, we perform a thorough ablation study empirically determining the
optimal latent embedding dimension and quantifying representational fidelity
using Mean Squared Error and cosine similarity between the original and
reprojected 512-dimensional CLIP embeddings. Our results demonstrate that
generalized embeddings can efficiently and accurately support open-vocabulary
querying in novel 3D scenes, paving the way for scalable, real-time interactive
3D AI applications.

</details>


### [142] [Positional Preservation Embedding for Multimodal Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22936)
*Mouxiao Huang,Borui Jiang,Dehua Zheng,Hailin Hu,Kai Han,Xinghao Chen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: PPE (Positional Preservation Embedding) preserves spatiotemporal structure during visual token compression in multimodal LLMs. It uses a parameter-free, disentangled 3D positional encoding in the token dimension, enabling cascade clustering, and is plug-and-play with existing token merging methods, yielding consistent 2-5% gains on vision-language benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce visual token redundancy in multimodal LLMs without breaking spatial/temporal relationships. Existing token merging harms structure; PPE aims to preserve positional cues to maintain reasoning quality while compressing tokens.

Method: Introduce PPE: a parameter-free encoding operator that disentangles 3D positions in the token dimension, so each compressed token represents multiple original positions. Supports cascade clustering (progressive token compression). Plug-and-play with existing token merging frameworks without adjustments.

Result: Across benchmarks MMBench, TextVQA, and VideoMME, PPE yields consistent improvements in performance by about 2% to 5%. Demonstrates the importance of preserving positional cues for efficient and effective MLLM reasoning.

Conclusion: Preserving spatiotemporal positional information during token compression is critical for MLLM efficiency and accuracy. PPE provides a generic, plug-and-play solution that can boost various token merging methods without additional parameters.

Abstract: Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) have achieved strong performance on
vision-language tasks, yet often suffer from inefficiencies due to redundant
visual tokens. Existing token merging methods reduce sequence length but
frequently disrupt spatial layouts and temporal continuity by disregarding
positional relationships. In this work, we propose a novel encoding operator
dubbed as \textbf{P}ositional \textbf{P}reservation \textbf{E}mbedding
(\textbf{PPE}), which has the main hallmark of preservation of spatiotemporal
structure during visual token compression. PPE explicitly introduces the
disentangled encoding of 3D positions in the token dimension, enabling each
compressed token to encapsulate different positions from multiple original
tokens. Furthermore, we show that PPE can effectively support cascade
clustering -- a progressive token compression strategy that leads to better
performance retention. PPE is a parameter-free and generic operator that can be
seamlessly integrated into existing token merging methods without any
adjustments. Applied to state-of-the-art token merging framework, PPE achieves
consistent improvements of $2\%\sim5\%$ across multiple vision-language
benchmarks, including MMBench (general vision understanding), TextVQA (layout
understanding) and VideoMME (temporal understanding). These results demonstrate
that preserving positional cues is critical for efficient and effective MLLM
reasoning.

</details>


### [143] [Bi-Encoder Contrastive Learning for Fingerprint and Iris Biometrics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22937)
*Matthew So,Judah Goldfeder,Mark Lis,Hod Lipson*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Biometric data for the same person are correlated, challenging the common independence assumption; iris shows strong intra-subject correlation (ROC AUC 91), fingerprints show similar intra-subject signals, while cross-modal fingerprint-iris matching is weak; study uses Bi-Encoder variants (ResNet-50, ViT) with contrastive loss across three tasks; data-intensive results suggest expanding analysis to more biometrics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Questioning the long-standing assumption that biometric traits are statistically independent; using Bi-Encoder architectures to quantify intra- and inter-subject correlations across fingerprint and iris data (including cross-modal) on a large dataset to assess independence of biometrics.

Method: Bi-Encoder networks with ResNet-50 and Vision Transformer backbones trained with contrastive loss to minimize distances for same-subject image pairs across three tasks: iris-iris, fingerprint-fingerprint, and fingerprint-iris cross-modal. Dataset: 274 subjects, ~100k fingerprint images, ~7k iris images. Evaluation via ROC AUC (iris-iris primarily; cross-modal challenging). Code released.

Result: Iris-iris matching reaches 91 ROC AUC, indicating left-right iris correlation within individuals. Fingerprint models show positive intra-subject correlation consistent with prior work. Cross-modal fingerprint-to-iris matching performs only slightly above chance, suggesting insufficient data/pipeline for strong cross-modal signals. This is reportedly the first use of Vision Transformers for this matching task.

Conclusion: The results challenge the independence/uncorrelated biometrics assumption, at least within iris and fingerprint traits. The authors plan to extend to additional biometrics. Cross-modal performance requires more data and a more sophisticated pipeline to yield compelling results; code is available for replication.

Abstract: There has been a historic assumption that the biometrics of an individual are
statistically uncorrelated. We test this assumption by training Bi-Encoder
networks on three verification tasks, including fingerprint-to-fingerprint
matching, iris-to-iris matching, and cross-modal fingerprint-to-iris matching
using 274 subjects with $\sim$100k fingerprints and 7k iris images. We trained
ResNet-50 and Vision Transformer backbones in Bi-Encoder architectures such
that the contrastive loss between images sampled from the same individual is
minimized. The iris ResNet architecture reaches 91 ROC AUC score for
iris-to-iris matching, providing clear evidence that the left and right irises
of an individual are correlated. Fingerprint models reproduce the positive
intra-subject suggested by prior work in this space. This is the first work
attempting to use Vision Transformers for this matching. Cross-modal matching
rises only slightly above chance, which suggests that more data and a more
sophisticated pipeline is needed to obtain compelling results. These findings
continue challenge independence assumptions of biometrics and we plan to extend
this work to other biometrics in the future. Code available:
https://github.com/MatthewSo/bio_fingerprints_iris.

</details>


### [144] [Switchable Token-Specific Codebook Quantization For Face Image Compression](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22943)
*Yongbo Wang,Haonan Wang,Guodong Mu,Ruixin Zhang,Jiaqi Chen,Jingyun Zhang,Jun Wang,Yuan Xie,Zhizhong Zhang,Shouhong Ding*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Switchable Token-Specific Codebook Quantization for face image compression improves low-bpp performance by using token-specific, category-aware codebooks, enabling more codebooks under the same bpp and better reconstruction; demonstrated on face datasets with ~93.51% accuracy at 0.05 bpp.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Global codebook-based quantization overlooks category-specific correlations and semantic differences among tokens in face images, causing suboptimal reconstruction at low bit-per-pixel; a token-specific, category-aware approach seeks to address this bottleneck.

Method: Train distinct codebook groups for different image categories and assign an independent codebook to each token. Record the codebook group with a few bits per token. This allows more codebooks under a constrained bpp and can be integrated into any existing codebook-based representation learning framework.

Result: Demonstrated effectiveness on face recognition datasets, achieving an average accuracy of 93.51% for reconstructed images at 0.05 bpp.

Conclusion: The switchable token-specific codebook approach enhances expressive capacity and reconstruction quality at low bitrates and is generalizable to existing codebook-based methods.

Abstract: With the ever-increasing volume of visual data, the efficient and lossless
transmission, along with its subsequent interpretation and understanding, has
become a critical bottleneck in modern information systems. The emerged
codebook-based solution utilize a globally shared codebook to quantize and
dequantize each token, controlling the bpp by adjusting the number of tokens or
the codebook size. However, for facial images, which are rich in attributes,
such global codebook strategies overlook both the category-specific
correlations within images and the semantic differences among tokens, resulting
in suboptimal performance, especially at low bpp. Motivated by these
observations, we propose a Switchable Token-Specific Codebook Quantization for
face image compression, which learns distinct codebook groups for different
image categories and assigns an independent codebook to each token. By
recording the codebook group to which each token belongs with a small number of
bits, our method can reduce the loss incurred when decreasing the size of each
codebook group. This enables a larger total number of codebooks under a lower
overall bpp, thereby enhancing the expressive capability and improving
reconstruction performance. Owing to its generalizable design, our method can
be integrated into any existing codebook-based representation learning approach
and has demonstrated its effectiveness on face recognition datasets, achieving
an average accuracy of 93.51% for reconstructed images at 0.05 bpp.

</details>


### [145] [LightBagel: A Light-weighted, Double Fusion Framework for Unified Multimodal Understanding and Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22946)
*Zeyu Wang,Zilong Chen,Chenhui Gou,Feng Li,Chaorui Deng,Deyao Zhu,Kunchang Li,Weihao Yu,Haoqin Tu,Haoqi Fan,Cihang Xie*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A double-fusion approach that interleaves multimodal self-attention into preexisting generation and understanding blocks, enabling efficient unified multimodal models trained on ~35B tokens with strong benchmark performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce training cost and resource demands for unified multimodal models by leveraging publicly available specialized components and a fusion mechanism that preserves strengths while enabling cross-modal collaboration.

Method: Retain original model blocks; interleave multimodal self-attention blocks across both generation and understanding encoders; train with approximately 35B tokens; release code, weights, and datasets; evaluate on multiple benchmarks.

Result: Achieves strong benchmarks: GenEval 0.91 (compositional text-to-image generation), DPG-Bench 82.16 (complex text-to-image generation), GEditBench 6.06, ImgEdit-Bench 3.77 for image editing.

Conclusion: Demonstrates that systematic double fusion enables rich cross-modal fusion while preserving base-model strengths, offering an efficient and practical path to unified multimodal modeling with broad release to the community.

Abstract: Unified multimodal models have recently shown remarkable gains in both
capability and versatility, yet most leading systems are still trained from
scratch and require substantial computational resources. In this paper, we show
that competitive performance can be obtained far more efficiently by
strategically fusing publicly available models specialized for either
generation or understanding. Our key design is to retain the original blocks
while additionally interleaving multimodal self-attention blocks throughout the
networks. This double fusion mechanism (1) effectively enables rich multi-modal
fusion while largely preserving the original strengths of the base models, and
(2) catalyzes synergistic fusion of high-level semantic representations from
the understanding encoder with low-level spatial signals from the generation
encoder. By training with only ~ 35B tokens, this approach achieves strong
results across multiple benchmarks: 0.91 on GenEval for compositional
text-to-image generation, 82.16 on DPG-Bench for complex text-to-image
generation, 6.06 on GEditBench, and 3.77 on ImgEdit-Bench for image editing. By
fully releasing the entire suite of code, model weights, and datasets, we hope
to support future research on unified multimodal modeling.

</details>


### [146] [FAME: Fairness-aware Attention-modulated Video Editing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22960)
*Zhangkai Wu,Xuhui Fan,Zhongyuan Xie,Kaize Shi,Zhidong Li,Longbing Cao*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: FAME mitigates profession-related gender bias in training-free video editing by injecting debiasing tokens into the text encoder and fairness-aware attention modulation, preserving prompt alignment and temporal coherence on the FairVE benchmark.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address gender stereotypes in training-free VE models when rendering profession-related prompts, ensuring fairness without sacrificing semantic fidelity or temporal stability.

Method: 1) Derive fairness embeddings from minority representations; 2) softly inject debiasing tokens into the text encoder; 3) modulate temporal self-attention with a region-constrained mask and time decay to boost intra-region coherence; 4) reweight cross-attention tokens using fairness-sensitive similarity masks derived from debiasing prompt embeddings; 5) evaluate on a new FairVE benchmark and compare to VE baselines.

Result: FAME achieves stronger fairness alignment and semantic fidelity than existing VE baselines, with improved temporal coherence and reduced motion corruption on the FairVE benchmark.

Conclusion: FAME is an effective training-free fairness-aware video editing framework that reduces profession-related gender biases while preserving prompt fidelity and temporal consistency.

Abstract: Training-free video editing (VE) models tend to fall back on gender
stereotypes when rendering profession-related prompts. We propose \textbf{FAME}
for \textit{Fairness-aware Attention-modulated Video Editing} that mitigates
profession-related gender biases while preserving prompt alignment and temporal
consistency for coherent VE. We derive fairness embeddings from existing
minority representations by softly injecting debiasing tokens into the text
encoder. Simultaneously, FAME integrates fairness modulation into both temporal
self attention and prompt-to-region cross attention to mitigate the motion
corruption and temporal inconsistency caused by directly introducing fairness
cues. For temporal self attention, FAME introduces a region constrained
attention mask combined with time decay weighting, which enhances intra-region
coherence while suppressing irrelevant inter-region interactions. For cross
attention, it reweights tokens to region matching scores by incorporating
fairness sensitive similarity masks derived from debiasing prompt embeddings.
Together, these modulations keep fairness-sensitive semantics tied to the right
visual regions and prevent temporal drift across frames. Extensive experiments
on new VE fairness-oriented benchmark \textit{FairVE} demonstrate that FAME
achieves stronger fairness alignment and semantic fidelity, surpassing existing
VE baselines.

</details>


### [147] [Survey of Multimodal Geospatial Foundation Models: Techniques, Applications, and Challenges](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22964)
*Liling Yang,Ning Chen,Jun Yue,Yidan Liu,Jiayi Ma,Pedram Ghamisi,Antonio Plaza,Leyuan Fang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A comprehensive survey of multimodal geospatial foundation models (GFMs) for remote sensing, detailing modality-driven design, alignment/integration, benchmarks, and real-world applications, plus challenges and future directions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Foundation models enable powerful generalization and transfer in remote sensing data, which are inherently multimodal, multi-resolution, and multi-temporal. This motivates a dedicated review to address modality heterogeneity, distribution shifts, and semantic gaps in geospatial contexts.

Method: Modality-driven review across five core visual and vision-language modalities; analyze imaging physics and data representation to understand interaction design; synthesize techniques for alignment, integration, and knowledge transfer; evaluate training paradigms, architectures, and task-specific adaptation strategies; survey emerging benchmarks; assess across ten downstream tasks and real-world case studies.

Result: Synthesizes current methods and benchmarks for multimodal GFMs in remote sensing; provides insights into architectures, performance, and application scenarios; demonstrates practical potential in land cover mapping, agricultural monitoring, disaster response, climate studies, and geospatial intelligence; identifies key gaps and effective strategies for cross-modal learning and domain adaptation.

Conclusion: GFMs hold transformative potential for remote sensing, enabling robust cross-modal analysis and transfer learning, but face challenges in domain generalization, interpretability, efficiency, and privacy. Future work should emphasize improved generalization, scalable training, privacy-preserving techniques, and domain-specific adaptation to maximize real-world impact.

Abstract: Foundation models have transformed natural language processing and computer
vision, and their impact is now reshaping remote sensing image analysis. With
powerful generalization and transfer learning capabilities, they align
naturally with the multimodal, multi-resolution, and multi-temporal
characteristics of remote sensing data. To address unique challenges in the
field, multimodal geospatial foundation models (GFMs) have emerged as a
dedicated research frontier. This survey delivers a comprehensive review of
multimodal GFMs from a modality-driven perspective, covering five core visual
and vision-language modalities. We examine how differences in imaging physics
and data representation shape interaction design, and we analyze key techniques
for alignment, integration, and knowledge transfer to tackle modality
heterogeneity, distribution shifts, and semantic gaps. Advances in training
paradigms, architectures, and task-specific adaptation strategies are
systematically assessed alongside a wealth of emerging benchmarks.
Representative multimodal visual and vision-language GFMs are evaluated across
ten downstream tasks, with insights into their architectures, performance, and
application scenarios. Real-world case studies, spanning land cover mapping,
agricultural monitoring, disaster response, climate studies, and geospatial
intelligence, demonstrate the practical potential of GFMs. Finally, we outline
pressing challenges in domain generalization, interpretability, efficiency, and
privacy, and chart promising avenues for future research.

</details>


### [148] [VALA: Learning Latent Anchors for Training-Free and Temporally Consistent](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22970)
*Zhangkai Wu,Xuhui Fan,Zhongyuan Xie,Kaize Shi,Longbing Cao*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: VALA introduces a variational alignment module that adaptively selects key frames and compresses their latents into semantic anchors for stable, training-free video editing, boosting inversion fidelity, editing quality, and temporal consistency with improved efficiency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current training-free video editing methods rely on heuristic frame selection during DDIM inversion, causing manual bias and poor scalability. A unified, learning-based approach is needed to preserve content and temporal coherence without training.

Method: Propose VALA: a variational alignment module that (i) adaptively selects key frames; (ii) compresses their latent features into semantic anchors; (iii) uses a variational objective with contrastive learning to learn meaningful cross-frame assignments; (iv) integrates into training-free text-to-image video editing pipelines.

Result: VALA achieves state-of-the-art inversion fidelity, editing quality, and temporal consistency on real-world video editing benchmarks, with improved efficiency over prior methods.

Conclusion: VALA provides a scalable, end-to-end, training-free solution for temporally consistent video editing by transforming cross-frame latents into compact anchors via variational alignment and contrastive learning.

Abstract: Recent advances in training-free video editing have enabled lightweight and
precise cross-frame generation by leveraging pre-trained text-to-image
diffusion models. However, existing methods often rely on heuristic frame
selection to maintain temporal consistency during DDIM inversion, which
introduces manual bias and reduces the scalability of end-to-end inference. In
this paper, we propose~\textbf{VALA} (\textbf{V}ariational \textbf{A}lignment
for \textbf{L}atent \textbf{A}nchors), a variational alignment module that
adaptively selects key frames and compresses their latent features into
semantic anchors for consistent video editing. To learn meaningful assignments,
VALA propose a variational framework with a contrastive learning objective.
Therefore, it can transform cross-frame latent representations into compressed
latent anchors that preserve both content and temporal coherence. Our method
can be fully integrated into training-free text-to-image based video editing
models. Extensive experiments on real-world video editing benchmarks show that
VALA achieves state-of-the-art performance in inversion fidelity, editing
quality, and temporal consistency, while offering improved efficiency over
prior methods.

</details>


### [149] [Scaling Up Occupancy-centric Driving Scene Generation: Dataset and Method](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22973)
*Bohan Li,Xin Jin,Hu Zhu,Hongsi Liu,Ruikai Li,Jiazhe Guo,Kaiwen Cai,Chao Ma,Yueming Jin,Hao Zhao,Xiaokang Yang,Wenjun Zeng*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Introduces UniScene, a unified framework for semantic occupancy, multi-view video, and LiDAR synthesis built on Nuplan-Occ; achieves high-fidelity, scalable generation with a spatio-temporal disentangled architecture, Gaussian splatting rendering, and sensor-aware LiDAR embeddings, enabling strong downstream utility.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Occupancy-centric driving scene generation is powerful but hindered by the scarcity of annotated occupancy data. A large, diverse dataset and a unified cross-modal generator are needed to improve fidelity and enable downstream tasks.

Method: Proposes a spatio-temporal disentangled architecture that jointly synthesizes semantic occupancy, multi-view videos, and LiDAR point clouds. Introduces a Gaussian splatting-based sparse point map rendering strategy to enhance multi-view video generation and a sensor-aware embedding approach that models LiDAR sensor properties for realistic multi-LiDAR simulations. Trains on the Nuplan-Occ dataset to support 4D dynamic occupancy forecasting and spatial expansion.

Result: The approach achieves superior generation fidelity and scalability compared with existing methods, and demonstrates practical value for downstream autonomous driving tasks.

Conclusion: By providing a large-scale semantic occupancy dataset and a unified, cross-modal generative framework with novel rendering and sensor-aware techniques, the work advances occupancy-centric driving scene generation and its applicability to real-world downstream applications.

Abstract: Driving scene generation is a critical domain for autonomous driving,
enabling downstream applications, including perception and planning evaluation.
Occupancy-centric methods have recently achieved state-of-the-art results by
offering consistent conditioning across frames and modalities; however, their
performance heavily depends on annotated occupancy data, which still remains
scarce. To overcome this limitation, we curate Nuplan-Occ, the largest semantic
occupancy dataset to date, constructed from the widely used Nuplan benchmark.
Its scale and diversity facilitate not only large-scale generative modeling but
also autonomous driving downstream applications. Based on this dataset, we
develop a unified framework that jointly synthesizes high-quality semantic
occupancy, multi-view videos, and LiDAR point clouds. Our approach incorporates
a spatio-temporal disentangled architecture to support high-fidelity spatial
expansion and temporal forecasting of 4D dynamic occupancy. To bridge modal
gaps, we further propose two novel techniques: a Gaussian splatting-based
sparse point map rendering strategy that enhances multi-view video generation,
and a sensor-aware embedding strategy that explicitly models LiDAR sensor
properties for realistic multi-LiDAR simulation. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that our method achieves superior generation fidelity and
scalability compared to existing approaches, and validates its practical value
in downstream tasks. Repo:
https://github.com/Arlo0o/UniScene-Unified-Occupancy-centric-Driving-Scene-Generation/tree/v2

</details>


### [150] [VoMP: Predicting Volumetric Mechanical Property Fields](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22975)
*Rishit Dagli,Donglai Xiang,Vismay Modi,Charles Loop,Clement Fuji Tsang,Anka He Chen,Anita Hu,Gavriel State,David I. W. Levin,Maria Shugrina*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: VoMP is a voxel-wise material predictor that uses multi-view features and a Geometry Transformer to output physically plausible per-voxel material codes (E, ν, ρ) for 3D shapes, learned from real data, achieving superior accuracy and speed over prior work.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Physical simulation requires spatially varying mechanical properties, which are laboriously hand-crafted. A data-driven method to predict volumetric material properties can automate this and ensure material validity.

Method: Per-voxel multi-view features are aggregated and fed into a Geometry Transformer to predict per-voxel material latent codes. Latents lie on a learned manifold of physically plausible materials, ensuring valid decoded materials. Training data is assembled via an annotation pipeline combining segmented 3D datasets, material databases, and a vision-language model, plus a new benchmark.

Result: VoMP yields accurate volumetric property estimates and significantly outperforms prior art in accuracy and speed.

Conclusion: VoMP provides a scalable, fast, and physically plausible approach to voxel-level material prediction for 3D shapes, enabling realistic simulations with less manual engineering and generalizing across renderable voxelized representations.

Abstract: Physical simulation relies on spatially-varying mechanical properties, often
laboriously hand-crafted. VoMP is a feed-forward method trained to predict
Young's modulus ($E$), Poisson's ratio ($\nu$), and density ($\rho$) throughout
the volume of 3D objects, in any representation that can be rendered and
voxelized. VoMP aggregates per-voxel multi-view features and passes them to our
trained Geometry Transformer to predict per-voxel material latent codes. These
latents reside on a manifold of physically plausible materials, which we learn
from a real-world dataset, guaranteeing the validity of decoded per-voxel
materials. To obtain object-level training data, we propose an annotation
pipeline combining knowledge from segmented 3D datasets, material databases,
and a vision-language model, along with a new benchmark. Experiments show that
VoMP estimates accurate volumetric properties, far outperforming prior art in
accuracy and speed.

</details>


### [151] [SceneDecorator: Towards Scene-Oriented Story Generation with Scene Planning and Scene Consistency](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22994)
*Quanjian Song,Donghao Zhou,Jingyu Lin,Fei Shen,Jiaze Wang,Xiaowei Hu,Cunjian Chen,Pheng-Ann Heng*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: SceneDecorator introduces a training-free framework for scene-oriented story generation, combining VLM-guided scene planning (global-to-local) with Long-Term Scene-Sharing Attention to ensure narrative coherence across scenes and long-term consistency across stories.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current text-to-image models excel at character consistency but often ignore scene-level coherence, limiting storytelling creativity. There is a need for scene-aware generation and cross-story consistency to support arts, films, and games.

Method: SceneDecorator comprises two key components: (1) VLM-Guided Scene Planning that guides narrative construction across scenes in a global-to-local manner to enforce scene-level coherence, and (2) Long-Term Scene-Sharing Attention that maintains long-term scene consistency and subject diversity across multiple stories, all in a training-free framework.

Result: Experimental evaluations demonstrate superior performance in achieving scene-level narrative coherence and cross-story consistency, outperforming baselines and showcasing enhanced creativity potential across arts, films, and games.

Conclusion: SceneDecorator enables training-free, scene-aware story generation with robust cross-scene coherence and long-term consistency, unlocking new creative possibilities in multimedia storytelling.

Abstract: Recent text-to-image models have revolutionized image generation, but they
still struggle with maintaining concept consistency across generated images.
While existing works focus on character consistency, they often overlook the
crucial role of scenes in storytelling, which restricts their creativity in
practice. This paper introduces scene-oriented story generation, addressing two
key challenges: (i) scene planning, where current methods fail to ensure
scene-level narrative coherence by relying solely on text descriptions, and
(ii) scene consistency, which remains largely unexplored in terms of
maintaining scene consistency across multiple stories. We propose
SceneDecorator, a training-free framework that employs VLM-Guided Scene
Planning to ensure narrative coherence across different scenes in a
``global-to-local'' manner, and Long-Term Scene-Sharing Attention to maintain
long-term scene consistency and subject diversity across generated stories.
Extensive experiments demonstrate the superior performance of SceneDecorator,
highlighting its potential to unleash creativity in the fields of arts, films,
and games.

</details>


### [152] [LoMix: Learnable Weighted Multi-Scale Logits Mixing for Medical Image Segmentation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22995)
*Md Mostafijur Rahman,Radu Marculescu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: LoMix is a differentiable, plug-and-play module that learns to fuse multi-scale logits in U-shaped networks, enabling mixed-scale supervision without extra inference cost and improving segmentation Dice with data efficiency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In standard U-shaped decoders, logits from different scales are supervised in isolation or with uniform weights, missing complementary cues from coarse and fine scales. LoMix aims to exploit these cues by learning how to mix scales during training.

Method: Introduce LoMix, a NAS-inspired, differentiable module that creates new mixed-scale outputs by fusing multi-scale decoder logits using four lightweight operators (addition, multiplication, concatenation, attention-based fusion). Each original or mixed map gets a softplus loss weight that is jointly optimized with network parameters, effectively performing a one-step architecture search for useful scales, mixtures, and operators. The module plugs into existing U-shaped architectures (e.g., PVT-V2-B2 backbone with EMCAD decoder) and is evaluated on Synapse 8-organ dataset, with ablations across baselines.

Result: LoMix yields Dice improvements of +4.2% over single-output supervision, +2.2% over deep supervision, and +1.5% over equally weighted additive fusion; with scarce labeled data (one or two scans) the advantage grows to +9.23%. Across four benchmarks and diverse U-shaped networks, Dice improves by up to +13.5% over single-output supervision. Notably, there is zero inference overhead at test time, and code is released.

Conclusion: Learnable, weighted mixed-scale fusion via LoMix generalizes across architectures and datasets, is data-efficient, interpretable, and incurs no inference cost, offering a broadly applicable improvement for U-shaped networks.

Abstract: U-shaped networks output logits at multiple spatial scales, each capturing a
different blend of coarse context and fine detail. Yet, training still treats
these logits in isolation - either supervising only the final,
highest-resolution logits or applying deep supervision with identical loss
weights at every scale - without exploring mixed-scale combinations.
Consequently, the decoder output misses the complementary cues that arise only
when coarse and fine predictions are fused. To address this issue, we introduce
LoMix (Logits Mixing), a NAS-inspired, differentiable plug-and-play module that
generates new mixed-scale outputs and learns how exactly each of them should
guide the training process. More precisely, LoMix mixes the multi-scale decoder
logits with four lightweight fusion operators: addition, multiplication,
concatenation, and attention-based weighted fusion, yielding a rich set of
synthetic mutant maps. Every original or mutant map is given a softplus loss
weight that is co-optimized with network parameters, mimicking a one-step
architecture search that automatically discovers the most useful scales,
mixtures, and operators. Plugging LoMix into recent U-shaped architectures
(i.e., PVT-V2-B2 backbone with EMCAD decoder) on Synapse 8-organ dataset
improves DICE by +4.2% over single-output supervision, +2.2% over deep
supervision, and +1.5% over equally weighted additive fusion, all with zero
inference overhead. When training data are scarce (e.g., one or two labeled
scans), the advantage grows to +9.23%, underscoring LoMix's data efficiency.
Across four benchmarks and diverse U-shaped networks, LoMiX improves DICE by up
to +13.5% over single-output supervision, confirming that learnable weighted
mixed-scale fusion generalizes broadly while remaining data efficient, fully
interpretable, and overhead-free at inference. Our code is available at
https://github.com/SLDGroup/LoMix.

</details>


### [153] [CoMo: Compositional Motion Customization for Text-to-Video Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23007)
*Youcan Xu,Zhen Wang,Jiaxin Shi,Kexin Li,Feifei Shao,Jun Xiao,Yi Yang,Jun Yu,Long Chen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: CoMo enables compositional, multi-motion control in text-to-video by decoupling motion from appearance in a two-phase framework: learning a motion-specific module for a single motion, then composing multiple motions without extra training via a divide-and-merge mechanism that isolates motion influence during denoising; accompanied by a new benchmark and metric for multi-motion fidelity and blending.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current text-to-video models struggle with precise, multi-subject motion control; single-motion customization methods fail in compositional scenarios due to motion-appearance entanglement and ineffective multi-motion blending.

Method: Two-phase approach: (1) single-motion learning with a static-dynamic decoupled tuning to disentangle motion from appearance and learn a motion-specific module; (2) multi-motion composition using a plug-and-play divide-and-merge strategy that spatially isolates each motion's influence during the denoising process, enabling composition without additional training.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on multi-motion generation; introduces a new benchmark and evaluation metric for multi-motion fidelity and blending; extensive experiments demonstrate improved controllable video generation.

Conclusion: CoMo advances compositional motion customization in text-to-video generation, enabling creation of videos with multiple distinct motions within a single clip and providing resources to spur further research; project page available.

Abstract: While recent text-to-video models excel at generating diverse scenes, they
struggle with precise motion control, particularly for complex, multi-subject
motions. Although methods for single-motion customization have been developed
to address this gap, they fail in compositional scenarios due to two primary
challenges: motion-appearance entanglement and ineffective multi-motion
blending. This paper introduces CoMo, a novel framework for
$\textbf{compositional motion customization}$ in text-to-video generation,
enabling the synthesis of multiple, distinct motions within a single video.
CoMo addresses these issues through a two-phase approach. First, in the
single-motion learning phase, a static-dynamic decoupled tuning paradigm
disentangles motion from appearance to learn a motion-specific module. Second,
in the multi-motion composition phase, a plug-and-play divide-and-merge
strategy composes these learned motions without additional training by
spatially isolating their influence during the denoising process. To facilitate
research in this new domain, we also introduce a new benchmark and a novel
evaluation metric designed to assess multi-motion fidelity and blending.
Extensive experiments demonstrate that CoMo achieves state-of-the-art
performance, significantly advancing the capabilities of controllable video
generation. Our project page is at https://como6.github.io/.

</details>


### [154] [UGAE: Unified Geometry and Attribute Enhancement for G-PCC Compressed Point Clouds](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23009)
*Pan Zhao,Hui Yuan,Chongzhen Tian,Tian Guo,Raouf Hamzaoui,Zhigeng Pan*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Unified geometry- and attribute-enhancement for lossy point-cloud compression, achieving major quality and bitrate gains across geometry and attributes via PoGE/PAE/PoAE with DA-KNN recoloring and W-MSE residuals.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address irreversible distortion in geometry and attribute information caused by lossy compression and preserve high-frequency details while improving compression efficiency.

Method: Three-component framework: PoGE uses a Transformer-based sparse convolutional U-Net to reconstruct geometry by predicting voxel occupancy; PAE introduces a geometry-guided recoloring strategy with DA-KNN before attribute compression to preserve details; PoAE uses an attribute residual prediction network with weighted MSE loss to improve high-frequency attribute regions.

Result: Outperforms the latest G-PCC test model (TMC13v29) on 8iVFB, Owlii, MVUB: geometry BD-PSNR gain ~9.98 dB with 90.98% BD-bitrate savings; attributes: BD-PSNR gain ~3.67 dB with 56.88% BD-bitrate savings; perceptual quality improvements noted.

Conclusion: UGAE provides substantial improvements in both geometry and attributes across benchmark datasets, offering strong compression efficiency and better preservation of high-frequency details.

Abstract: Lossy compression of point clouds reduces storage and transmission costs;
however, it inevitably leads to irreversible distortion in geometry structure
and attribute information. To address these issues, we propose a unified
geometry and attribute enhancement (UGAE) framework, which consists of three
core components: post-geometry enhancement (PoGE), pre-attribute enhancement
(PAE), and post-attribute enhancement (PoAE). In PoGE, a Transformer-based
sparse convolutional U-Net is used to reconstruct the geometry structure with
high precision by predicting voxel occupancy probabilities. Building on the
refined geometry structure, PAE introduces an innovative enhanced
geometry-guided recoloring strategy, which uses a detail-aware K-Nearest
Neighbors (DA-KNN) method to achieve accurate recoloring and effectively
preserve high-frequency details before attribute compression. Finally, at the
decoder side, PoAE uses an attribute residual prediction network with a
weighted mean squared error (W-MSE) loss to enhance the quality of
high-frequency regions while maintaining the fidelity of low-frequency regions.
UGAE significantly outperformed existing methods on three benchmark datasets:
8iVFB, Owlii, and MVUB. Compared to the latest G-PCC test model (TMC13v29),
UGAE achieved an average BD-PSNR gain of 9.98 dB and 90.98% BD-bitrate savings
for geometry under the D1 metric, as well as a 3.67 dB BD-PSNR improvement with
56.88% BD-bitrate savings for attributes on the Y component. Additionally, it
improved perceptual quality significantly.

</details>


### [155] [M$^{3}$T2IBench: A Large-Scale Multi-Category, Multi-Instance, Multi-Relation Text-to-Image Benchmark](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23020)
*Huixuan Zhang,Xiaojun Wan*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: M^3T2IBench introduces a large-scale, multi-category, multi-instance, multi-relation benchmark with an object-detection-based AlignScore metric that correlates highly with human judgments; it reveals current open-source text-to-image models struggle with complex prompts, and presents a training-free Revise-Then-Enforce post-editing method that improves image-text alignment across diffusion models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing evaluations for text-to-image alignment are either overly simplistic or fail to correlate with human judgment, especially for prompts involving multiple instances of the same category. A challenging, human-aligned benchmark is needed to rigorously assess and improve image-text alignment.

Method: Construct M^3T2IBench with multiple categories, instances, and relational relationships; develop AlignScore based on object detection to quantify alignment with prompts; empirically evaluate open-source diffusion models; propose Revise-Then-Enforce as a training-free post-editing technique to enhance alignment across models.

Result: AlignScore shows high alignment with human evaluation and reveals that current open-source T2I models perform poorly on the benchmark; Revise-Then-Enforce improves image-text alignment across a broad range of diffusion models, demonstrating its effectiveness as a non-training-based post-editing method.

Conclusion: The study exposes a gap in current T2I models on complex, multi-relationship prompts and offers a practical, training-free post-editing solution to enhance alignment, with code and data to be released publicly.

Abstract: Text-to-image models are known to struggle with generating images that
perfectly align with textual prompts. Several previous studies have focused on
evaluating image-text alignment in text-to-image generation. However, these
evaluations either address overly simple scenarios, especially overlooking the
difficulty of prompts with multiple different instances belonging to the same
category, or they introduce metrics that do not correlate well with human
evaluation. In this study, we introduce M$^3$T2IBench, a large-scale,
multi-category, multi-instance, multi-relation along with an
object-detection-based evaluation metric, $AlignScore$, which aligns closely
with human evaluation. Our findings reveal that current open-source
text-to-image models perform poorly on this challenging benchmark.
Additionally, we propose the Revise-Then-Enforce approach to enhance image-text
alignment. This training-free post-editing method demonstrates improvements in
image-text alignment across a broad range of diffusion models. \footnote{Our
code and data has been released in supplementary material and will be made
publicly available after the paper is accepted.}

</details>


### [156] [UniAIDet: A Unified and Universal Benchmark for AI-Generated Image Content Detection and Localization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23023)
*Huixuan Zhang,Xiaojun Wan*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A unified benchmark (UniAIDet) for detecting AI-generated content across both photographic and artistic images, spanning multiple generation/editing models and end-to-end editing, with comprehensive evaluation and insights on generalization and localization relations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current benchmarks are narrow, often covering limited model types or image domains, and rarely address end-to-end editing or artistic content. A unified, diverse benchmark is needed to robustly assess detector generalization and guide future research.

Method:  introduce UniAIDet—covering text-to-image, image-to-image, inpainting, editing, and deepfake models, with both photographic and artistic images. Conduct wide-ranging evaluations of existing detection methods and analyze three research questions about generalization and the link between detection and localization.

Result:  UniAIDet enables a broad comparison of detectors, reveals varying generalization capabilities across models and image domains, highlights challenges in end-to-end editing and artistic images, and provides actionable insights for designing detectors with better cross-domain performance and localization behavior.

Conclusion: The benchmark offers a robust, extensible foundation for future AI-generated image detection research, encouraging methods that generalize across models and image types and clarifying how detection signals relate to localization tasks.

Abstract: With the rapid proliferation of image generative models, the authenticity of
digital images has become a significant concern. While existing studies have
proposed various methods for detecting AI-generated content, current benchmarks
are limited in their coverage of diverse generative models and image
categories, often overlooking end-to-end image editing and artistic images. To
address these limitations, we introduce UniAIDet, a unified and comprehensive
benchmark that includes both photographic and artistic images. UniAIDet covers
a wide range of generative models, including text-to-image, image-to-image,
image inpainting, image editing, and deepfake models. Using UniAIDet, we
conduct a comprehensive evaluation of various detection methods and answer
three key research questions regarding generalization capability and the
relation between detection and localization. Our benchmark and analysis provide
a robust foundation for future research.

</details>


### [157] [Nested AutoRegressive Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23028)
*Hongyu Wu,Xuhui Fan,Zhangkai Wu,Longbing Cao*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: NestAR introduces a nested autoregressive architecture for image generation, achieving O(log n) token generation and improved diversity, using multi-scale AR modules and flow-matching losses.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: AR-based image generators suffer from high computational cost (O(n)) and limited sample diversity; existing methods like VAR may trade off diversity or quality. NestAR aims to reduce complexity while increasing diversity by hierarchical, multi-scale autoregressive generation and continuous-token training.

Method: Build hierarchical multi-scale AR modules where larger-scale components are conditioned on earlier, smaller-scale outputs. Within each module, use an autoregressive structure to generate token 'patches'. Train with flow-matching losses to handle continuous tokens and include objectives to coordinate all modules during training, achieving a complexity reduction from O(n) to O(log n).

Result: NestAR achieves competitive image generation performance at significantly lower computational cost and with improved sample diversity compared to baseline AR methods.

Conclusion: Nested autoregressive architectures with multi-scale, patch-level AR generation and flow-based continuous-token training offer a scalable approach for efficient, diverse image synthesis, matching or approaching diffusion-like quality with reduced computation.

Abstract: AutoRegressive (AR) models have demonstrated competitive performance in image
generation, achieving results comparable to those of diffusion models. However,
their token-by-token image generation mechanism remains computationally
intensive and existing solutions such as VAR often lead to limited sample
diversity. In this work, we propose a Nested AutoRegressive~(NestAR) model,
which proposes nested AutoRegressive architectures in generating images. NestAR
designs multi-scale modules in a hierarchical order. These different scaled
modules are constructed in an AR architecture, where one larger-scale module is
conditioned on outputs from its previous smaller-scale module. Within each
module, NestAR uses another AR structure to generate ``patches'' of tokens. The
proposed nested AR architecture reduces the overall complexity from
$\mathcal{O}(n)$ to $\mathcal{O}(\log n)$ in generating $n$ image tokens, as
well as increases image diversities. NestAR further incorporates flow matching
loss to use continuous tokens, and develops objectives to coordinate these
multi-scale modules in model training. NestAR achieves competitive image
generation performance while significantly lowering computational cost.

</details>


### [158] [HieraMamba: Video Temporal Grounding via Hierarchical Anchor-Mamba Pooling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23043)
*Joungbin An,Kristen Grauman*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: HieraMamba, a hierarchical video-temporal grounding model using Anchor-MambaPooling (AMP) blocks to create multi-scale anchor tokens, guided by anchor-conditioned and segment-pooled contrastive losses, achieves state-of-the-art results on long untrimmed-video benchmarks (Ego4D-NLQ, MAD, TACoS).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Localizing the start and end of a natural language query in long, untrimmed videos requires preserving both global context and fine-grained temporal detail; existing methods tend to downsample too aggressively or rely on fixed windows, harming temporal fidelity.

Method: Introduce HieraMamba architecture with AMP (Anchor-MambaPooling) blocks that leverage Mamba's selective scanning to produce compact anchor tokens summarizing content at multiple temporal granularities. Two contrastive losses are used: anchor-conditioned contrastive loss to retain local detail in anchors, and segment-pooled contrastive loss to maintain global discriminativeness across segments; architecture is hierarchical to preserve temporal structure across scales.

Result: Achieves new state-of-the-art performance on Ego4D-NLQ, MAD, and TACoS benchmarks, demonstrating precise and temporally faithful localization in long, untrimmed videos.

Conclusion: A hierarchical, anchor-based design with multi-scale tokens and complementary contrastive objectives effectively preserves temporal fidelity and semantic richness, enabling accurate long-video temporal grounding.

Abstract: Video temporal grounding, the task of localizing the start and end times of a
natural language query in untrimmed video, requires capturing both global
context and fine-grained temporal detail. This challenge is particularly
pronounced in long videos, where existing methods often compromise temporal
fidelity by over-downsampling or relying on fixed windows. We present
HieraMamba, a hierarchical architecture that preserves temporal structure and
semantic richness across scales. At its core are Anchor-MambaPooling (AMP)
blocks, which utilize Mamba's selective scanning to produce compact anchor
tokens that summarize video content at multiple granularities. Two
complementary objectives, anchor-conditioned and segment-pooled contrastive
losses, encourage anchors to retain local detail while remaining globally
discriminative. HieraMamba sets a new state-of-the-art on Ego4D-NLQ, MAD, and
TACoS, demonstrating precise, temporally faithful localization in long,
untrimmed videos.

</details>


### [159] [Strategies for Robust Deep Learning Based Deformable Registration](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23079)
*Joel Honkamaa,Pekka Marttinen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Transforming inputs to MIND feature space with a simple ensembling strategy improves robustness of DL deformable registration to unseen contrasts/modalties in LUMIR Learn2Reg 2025.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: DL-based deformable registration often fails to generalize beyond training data distributions; LUMIR 2025 specifically evaluates performance across contrasts/modalities not seen during training, highlighting the need for robust methods.

Method: Preprocess images into MIND feature space before feeding them into the registration model and apply a simple ensembling strategy to combine outputs, aiming to boost robustness with minimal architectural changes.

Result: The approach yields a small but consistent improvement in robustness/generalization to unseen contrasts/modalities.

Conclusion: A lightweight, feature-space transformation (MIND) combined with ensembling can modestly improve generalization in DL deformable registration, offering a practical, low-cost robustness boost.

Abstract: Deep learning based deformable registration methods have become popular in
recent years. However, their ability to generalize beyond training data
distribution can be poor, significantly hindering their usability. LUMIR brain
registration challenge for Learn2Reg 2025 aims to advance the field by
evaluating the performance of the registration on contrasts and modalities
different from those included in the training set. Here we describe our
submission to the challenge, which proposes a very simple idea for
