sense that it allows the combination and tuning of other linear discriminant
embedding methods. According to the experiments conducted on several datasets
including faces, objects, and digits, the proposed method was able to
outperform competing methods in most cases.

</details>


### [240] [Adversarial Déjà Vu: Jailbreak Dictionary Learning for Stronger Generalization to Unseen Attacks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21910)
*Mahavir Dabas,Tran Huynh,Nikhil Reddy Billa,Jiachen T. Wang,Peng Gao,Charith Peris,Yao Ma,Rahul Gupta,Ming Jin,Prateek Mittal,Ruoxi Jia*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: ASCoT: unseen jailbreaks are sparse compositions of prior adversarial skills; train on diverse skill combinations to boost robustness, with skill-coverage expansion key.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Adversarial training struggles against novel jailbreaks and difficult threat models; a compositional, skill-centric paradigm may better defend against unseen attacks.

Method: Analyze 32 attack papers to extract a sparse dictionary of adversarial skills; use LLMs to describe primitives; demonstrate that unseen attacks are sparse compositions of earlier skills; propose Adversarial Skill Compositional Training (ASCoT) trained on diverse skill compositions; evaluate on unseen multi-turn jailbreaks and measure over-refusal.

Result: Unseen jailbreaks are effectively explained as sparse compositions of known skills; ASCoT substantially improves robustness to unseen attacks, including multi-turn jailbreaks, with low over-refusal rates; expanding adversarial skill coverage outperforms mere data scale.

Conclusion: Focusing on compositional adversarial skills and broad skill coverage yields stronger defense against novel jailbreaks and may generalize to other safety tasks.

Abstract: Large language models remain vulnerable to jailbreak attacks that bypass
safety guardrails to elicit harmful outputs. Defending against novel jailbreaks
represents a critical challenge in AI safety. Adversarial training -- designed
to make models robust against worst-case perturbations -- has been the dominant
paradigm for adversarial robustness. However, due to optimization challenges
and difficulties in defining realistic threat models, adversarial training
methods often fail on newly developed jailbreaks in practice. This paper
proposes a new paradigm for improving robustness against unseen jailbreaks,
centered on the Adversarial D\'ej\`a Vu hypothesis: novel jailbreaks are not
fundamentally new, but largely recombinations of adversarial skills from
previous attacks. We study this hypothesis through a large-scale analysis of 32
attack papers published over two years. Using an automated pipeline, we extract
and compress adversarial skills into a sparse dictionary of primitives, with
LLMs generating human-readable descriptions. Our analysis reveals that unseen
attacks can be effectively explained as sparse compositions of earlier skills,
with explanatory power increasing monotonically as skill coverage grows. Guided
by this insight, we introduce Adversarial Skill Compositional Training (ASCoT),
which trains on diverse compositions of skill primitives rather than isolated
attack instances. ASCoT substantially improves robustness to unseen attacks,
including multi-turn jailbreaks, while maintaining low over-refusal rates. We
also demonstrate that expanding adversarial skill coverage, not just data
scale, is key to defending against novel attacks.
\textcolor{red}{\textbf{Warning: This paper contains content that may be
harmful or offensive in nature.

</details>


### [241] [Joint Score-Threshold Optimization for Interpretable Risk Assessment Under Partial Supervision](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21934)
*Fardin Gankhanloo,Emmett Springer,Erik H. Hoyer,Daniel L. Young,Kimia Ghobadi*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A mixed-integer programming framework optimizes risk-scoring weights and ordinal thresholds under partial supervision and asymmetric costs, with softplus-based relaxation for efficiency and governance constraints to ensure practical deployability in clinical workflows.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Risk scoring tools in healthcare traditionally use point-based mappings to ordinal risk categories. EHR data offers data-driven improvements but faces two core issues: (i) intervention-censored outcomes yielding partial labels (only extreme categories reliably labeled), and (ii) asymmetric misclassification costs that grow with ordinal distance. These challenges hinder standard supervised learning.

Method: Joint optimization of scoring weights and category thresholds via mixed-integer programming. Handles partial supervision with per-instance feasible label sets, and incorporates asymmetric distance-aware objectives. Prevents middle-category collapse by enforcing minimum threshold gaps. Introduces a CSO relaxation using softplus losses to preserve ordinal structure while enabling efficient optimization. Supports governance constraints such as sign restrictions, sparsity, and minimal modifications to incumbent tools for practical deployment.

Result: A unified optimization framework that ensures feasible, interpretable, and deployable risk scoring rules under complex supervision and cost structures. The approach retains ordinal integrity, reduces misclassification risk across adjacent categories, and can be integrated with existing tools with limited changes.

Conclusion: The proposed MIP framework and its CSO relaxation offer a practical, data-driven path to tailor ordinal risk scores in healthcare, accommodating partial labels and asymmetric costs while satisfying governance constraints to ease adoption in clinical workflows.

Abstract: Risk assessment tools in healthcare commonly employ point-based scoring
systems that map patients to ordinal risk categories via thresholds. While
electronic health record (EHR) data presents opportunities for data-driven
optimization of these tools, two fundamental challenges impede standard
supervised learning: (1) partial supervision arising from intervention-censored
outcomes, where only extreme categories can be reliably labeled, and (2)
asymmetric misclassification costs that increase with ordinal distance. We
propose a mixed-integer programming (MIP) framework that jointly optimizes
scoring weights and category thresholds under these constraints. Our approach
handles partial supervision through per-instance feasible label sets,
incorporates asymmetric distance-aware objectives, and prevents middle-category
collapse via minimum threshold gaps. We further develop a CSO relaxation using
softplus losses that preserves the ordinal structure while enabling efficient
optimization. The framework supports governance constraints including sign
restrictions, sparsity, and minimal modifications to incumbent tools, ensuring
practical deployability in clinical workflows.

</details>


### [242] [AutoSciDACT: Automated Scientific Discovery through Contrastive Embedding and Hypothesis Testing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21935)
*Samuel Bright-Thonney,Christina Reissel,Gaia Grosso,Nathaniel Woodward,Katya Govorkova,Andrzej Novak,Sang Eon Park,Eric Moreno,Philip Harris*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces AutoSciDACT, a unified pipeline for novelty detection in science that combines contrastive pre-training to obtain expressive low-dimensional embeddings with a statistically rigorous two-sample test (NPLM) to quantify deviations from a reference distribution.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Scientific datasets are noisy and high-dimensional, and there is a need for outputs that support formal scientific discovery claims. Current anomaly detection methods often lack rigorous statistical interpretability; a general, statistically grounded pipeline for novelty detection in science is desirable.

Method: Use contrastive pre-training to create expressive low-dimensional representations by leveraging simulated data and principled data augmentation; apply the New Physics Learning Machine (NPLM) two-sample test on embeddings to detect and quantify deviations from a null distribution; evaluate across astronomical, physical, biological, image, and synthetic datasets.

Result: Demonstrates strong sensitivity to small injections of anomalous data across a diverse set of domains, indicating the pipeline can reliably detect novelty and quantify deviations in observed data.

Conclusion: Presents a first step toward a unified, statistically rigorous novelty-detection workflow for scientific data, enabling principled discovery claims by quantifying deviations relative to a reference distribution.

Abstract: Novelty detection in large scientific datasets faces two key challenges: the
noisy and high-dimensional nature of experimental data, and the necessity of
making statistically robust statements about any observed outliers. While there
is a wealth of literature on anomaly detection via dimensionality reduction,
most methods do not produce outputs compatible with quantifiable claims of
scientific discovery. In this work we directly address these challenges,
presenting the first step towards a unified pipeline for novelty detection
adapted for the rigorous statistical demands of science. We introduce
AutoSciDACT (Automated Scientific Discovery with Anomalous Contrastive
Testing), a general-purpose pipeline for detecting novelty in scientific data.
AutoSciDACT begins by creating expressive low-dimensional data representations
using a contrastive pre-training, leveraging the abundance of high-quality
simulated data in many scientific domains alongside expertise that can guide
principled data augmentation strategies. These compact embeddings then enable
an extremely sensitive machine learning-based two-sample test using the New
Physics Learning Machine (NPLM) framework, which identifies and statistically
quantifies deviations in observed data relative to a reference distribution
(null hypothesis). We perform experiments across a range of astronomical,
physical, biological, image, and synthetic datasets, demonstrating strong
sensitivity to small injections of anomalous data across all domains.

</details>


### [243] [Generalization Bounds for Rank-sparse Neural Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21945)
*Antoine Ledent,Rodrigo Alves,Yunwen Lei*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Exploits an empirically observed bottleneck low-rank structure in deep networks to derive generalization bounds via Schatten p-quasi-norms; for small p the bounds scale with the product of width, depth squared, and the latent rank, while larger p yields norm-like bounds.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how the observed approximate low-rank (bottleneck) structure in weights/activations affects generalization and to formalize this via data-dependent complexity bounds.

Method: Derives generalization bounds for neural networks by leveraging the approximate low-rank structure of weight matrices using Schatten p-quasi-norms. Analyzes how the bounds depend on network width W, depth L, and rank r, and studies the transition of the bound behavior as p increases.

Result: The bounds show sample complexity scaling as ~O~(W r L^2) for small p (r is the rank of weight matrices). As p increases, the bound transitions toward traditional norm-based bounds, i.e., less favorable when r is not small or when p is large.

Conclusion: If the weight matrices are effectively low-rank (small r) and p is small, the generalization can be better controlled than with standard norm-based bounds. This provides theoretical support for exploiting low-rank regularization and aligns with observed bottleneck phenomena, while highlighting the trade-off as p grows.

Abstract: It has been recently observed in much of the literature that neural networks
exhibit a bottleneck rank property: for larger depths, the activation and
weights of neural networks trained with gradient-based methods tend to be of
approximately low rank. In fact, the rank of the activations of each layer
converges to a fixed value referred to as the ``bottleneck rank'', which is the
minimum rank required to represent the training data. This perspective is in
line with the observation that regularizing linear networks (without
activations) with weight decay is equivalent to minimizing the Schatten $p$
quasi norm of the neural network. In this paper we investigate the implications
of this phenomenon for generalization. More specifically, we prove
generalization bounds for neural networks which exploit the approximate low
rank structure of the weight matrices if present. The final results rely on the
Schatten $p$ quasi norms of the weight matrices: for small $p$, the bounds
exhibit a sample complexity $ \widetilde{O}(WrL^2)$ where $W$ and $L$ are the
width and depth of the neural network respectively and where $r$ is the rank of
the weight matrices. As $p$ increases, the bound behaves more like a norm-based
bound instead.

</details>


### [244] [Revisiting Orbital Minimization Method for Neural Operator Decomposition](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21952)
*J. Jon Ryu,Samuel Zhou,Gregory W. Wornell*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Reintroduces the orbital minimization method (OMM) for eigenfunction learning, proves its consistency, and adapts it to train neural nets to decompose positive semidefinite operators, showing empirical and theoretical benefits for ML and numerical simulation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridge classical optimization with modern neural methods for spectral decomposition to enable scalable, principled learning of eigenfunctions and applications to dynamical systems and PDEs.

Method: Provide a simple linear-algebraic proof of the OMM objective's consistency, connect OMM to ideas across domains, and adapt the OMM framework to train neural networks to decompose positive semidefinite operators.

Result: Demonstrates practical advantages of the OMM-based training across benchmark tasks and argues that revisiting classical numerical methods yields principled and scalable tools for ML and numerical simulation.

Conclusion: Revisiting classical numerical methods within modern theory can broaden applicability in ML, with OMM offering a principled, scalable approach to spectral learning for PSD operators.

Abstract: Spectral decomposition of linear operators plays a central role in many areas
of machine learning and scientific computing. Recent work has explored training
neural networks to approximate eigenfunctions of such operators, enabling
scalable approaches to representation learning, dynamical systems, and partial
differential equations (PDEs). In this paper, we revisit a classical
optimization framework from the computational physics literature known as the
\emph{orbital minimization method} (OMM), originally proposed in the 1990s for
solving eigenvalue problems in computational chemistry. We provide a simple
linear-algebraic proof of the consistency of the OMM objective, and reveal
connections between this method and several ideas that have appeared
independently across different domains. Our primary goal is to justify its
broader applicability in modern learning pipelines. We adapt this framework to
train neural networks to decompose positive semidefinite operators, and
demonstrate its practical advantages across a range of benchmark tasks. Our
results highlight how revisiting classical numerical methods through the lens
of modern theory and computation can provide not only a principled approach for
deploying neural networks in numerical simulation, but also effective and
scalable tools for machine learning.

</details>


### [245] [Transformer Based Linear Attention with Optimized GPU Kernel Implementation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21956)
*Armin Gerami,Ramani Duraiswami*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A novel forward/backward linear-attention (LA) with an optimized CUDA implementation achieves 3.3x speedups and 3.6x memory savings over regular softmax attention, enabling training of a 1.4B-parameter language model with comparable expressivity on reasoning benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Quadratic time and memory cost of standard softmax attention hinders scalability; although linear-attention promises O(ND^2) complexity, practical performance lags behind its theoretical efficiency. The work aims to close this gap and make LA practical for large-scale training and inference.

Method: Introduce a new forward and backward pass for linear attention and implement a highly optimized CUDA kernel. Validate in both single-layer and end-to-end settings, including training a 1.4B-parameter language model to compare expressivity with regular attention on major reasoning benchmarks.

Result: Outperforms state-of-the-art linear-attention methods by ~3.3x in speed and ~3.6x in memory usage. End-to-end training of a 1.4B-parameter language model demonstrates expressivity comparable to regular attention on major reasoning benchmarks.

Conclusion: The proposed LA design and CUDA optimizations bring linear attention closer to the practicality of regular attention, enabling efficient training and inference for large transformers with comparable performance.

Abstract: The original softmax-based attention mechanism (regular attention) in the
extremely successful Transformer architecture computes attention between $N$
tokens, each embedded in a $D$-dimensional head, with a time complexity of
$O(N^2D)$. Given the success of Transformers, improving their runtime during
both training and inference is a popular research area. One such approach is
the introduction of the linear attention (LA) mechanisms, which offers a linear
time complexity of $O(ND^2)$ and have demonstrated comparable accuracy to
regular attention. However, LA in practice lags behind its theoretical
efficiency. We propose a novel method for LA's forward and backward passes,
along with a highly-optimized CUDA implementation. Our approach outperforms the
state-of-the-art by 3.3 times in speed and reduces memory consumption by 3.6
times. We validate these improvements in both single-layer and end-to-end
settings by training a 1.4 billion parameter language model, which demonstrates
similar expressivity to regular attention on major reasoning benchmarks.

</details>


### [246] [Parallel Sampling from Masked Diffusion Models via Conditional Independence Testing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21961)
*Iskander Azangulov,Teodora Pandeva,Niranjani Prasad,Javier Zazo,Sushrut Karmalkar*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PUNT is a model-agnostic sampler for masked diffusion models that improves parallel unmasking by selecting independent, high-confidence token updates, yielding better accuracy/compute trade-offs and revealing an emergent hierarchical generation pattern.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable fast, parallel discrete text generation with masked diffusion models while maintaining correctness: independent updates and high confidence; current conflict reduces parallelism.

Method: Identify token dependencies using approximate conditional independence testing; remove lower-confidence tokens from conflicting groups; produce unmasking index sets that satisfy independence and confidence; model-agnostic work; flexible hyperparameters.

Result: On IFEval, up to 16% higher accuracy than baselines including left-to-right generation; better compute-accuracy trade-offs, especially for long sequences; robust across hyperparameters; evidence of planning-like hierarchical generation.

Conclusion: PUNT reconciles independence and confidence for parallel sampling, enabling faster generation without sacrificing accuracy; suggests emergent hierarchical planning and improved alignment; reduces brittle tuning.

Abstract: Masked diffusion models (MDMs) offer a compelling alternative to
autoregressive models (ARMs) for discrete text generation because they enable
parallel token sampling, rather than sequential, left-to-right generation. This
means potentially much faster inference. However, effective parallel sampling
faces two competing requirements: (i) simultaneously updated tokens must be
conditionally independent, and (ii) updates should prioritise high-confidence
predictions. These goals conflict because high-confidence predictions often
cluster and depend on each other, opportunities for parallel updates.
  We present PUNT, a model-agnostic sampler that reconciles this trade-off. Our
method identifies token dependencies and removes lower-confidence tokens from
conflicting groups. This produces sets of indices for unmasking that satisfy
both independence and confidence criteria. Our approach ensures improved
parallel unmasking through approximate conditional independence testing.
  Our experiments show that PUNT delivers a superior trade-off between accuracy
and compute when compared to other strong training-free baselines, especially
for generation of longer sequences. On the IFEval benchmark, it achieves up to
16\% higher accuracy over baseline methods, including sequential generation
(one-by-one). These gains hold across different values of hyperparameters,
mitigating the need for brittle hyperparameter tuning. Moreover, we observe
that PUNT induces an emergent hierarchical generation strategy, where the model
first establishes high-level paragraph structure before local refinement,
suggesting a planning-like generation process that contributes to strong
alignment performance.

</details>


### [247] [Deep Jump Gaussian Processes for Surrogate Modeling of High-Dimensional Piecewise Continuous Functions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21974)
*Yang Xu,Chiwoo Park*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: DJGP introduces a two-layer deep GP for high-dimensional, piecewise continuous functions by adding a locally linear projection layer to Jump GPs. A GP prior on the projection matrices enforces smooth subspace evolution; a variational inference algorithm jointly learns projections and GP hyperparameters, yielding better accuracy and uncertainty quantification.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: High-dimensional piecewise continuous functions are challenging for existing Jump GPs. Conventional approaches struggle with scalability and capturing local subspace structure; there is a need for a scalable method that models local linear subspaces and provides reliable uncertainty estimates.

Method: Introduce a locally linear projection layer with region-specific projection matrices to capture local subspace structure, governed by a GP prior to promote smooth variation across input space. Projected inputs are modeled with Jump GP to capture piecewise continuity. Develop scalable variational inference to jointly learn projection matrices and JGP hyperparameters.

Result: DJGP achieves superior predictive accuracy and more reliable uncertainty quantification on synthetic and benchmark datasets compared with existing approaches, demonstrating effective high-dimensional surrogate modeling of piecewise continuous functions.

Conclusion: DJGP offers a scalable, two-layer GP-based framework that handles high-dimensional, piecewise continuous functions by learning local subspace projections and combining with Jump GP, with strong empirical performance and uncertainty quantification.

Abstract: We introduce Deep Jump Gaussian Processes (DJGP), a novel method for
surrogate modeling of high-dimensional piecewise continuous functions. DJGP
overcomes the limitations of conventional Jump Gaussian Processes in
high-dimensional input spaces by adding a locally linear projection layer to
Jump Gaussian Processes. This projection uses region-specific matrices to
capture local subspace structures, naturally complementing the localized nature
of JGP, a variant of local Gaussian Processes. To control model complexity, we
place a Gaussian Process prior on the projection matrices, allowing them to
evolve smoothly across the input space. The projected inputs are then modeled
with a JGP to capture piecewise continuous relationships with the response.
This yields a distinctive two-layer deep learning of GP/JGP. We further develop
a scalable variational inference algorithm to jointly learn the projection
matrices and JGP hyperparameters. Experiments on synthetic and benchmark
datasets demonstrate that DJGP delivers superior predictive accuracy and more
reliable uncertainty quantification compared to existing approaches.

</details>


### [248] [Beyond Reasoning Gains: Mitigating General Capabilities Forgetting in Large Reasoning Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21978)
*Hoang Phan,Xianjun Yang,Kevin Yao,Jingyu Zhang,Shengjie Bi,Xiaocheng Tang,Madian Khabsa,Lijuan Liu,Deren Lei*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: RECAP: a dynamic replay strategy that reweights RL-based post-training objectives to preserve general knowledge and improve reasoning in RLVR pipelines, using online short-horizon signals to adapt focus without extra models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: RLVR can cause capability regression when lengthy post-training shifts neglect core skills; regularization like KL-divergence helps but does not guarantee broad knowledge across tasks; heterogeneous experience replay makes objective allocation tricky.

Method: Online, short-horizon signals of convergence and instability drive dynamic reweighting of training objectives, shifting emphasis away from saturated tasks toward underperforming or volatile ones. End-to-end and compatible with existing RLVR pipelines; no extra models or heavy tuning required.

Result: Experiments on Qwen2.5-VL-3B and Qwen2.5-VL-7B demonstrate preserved general capabilities and improved reasoning by enabling flexible trade-offs among in-task rewards.

Conclusion: RECAP provides effective general-knowledge preservation during RLVR, offering a practical, end-to-end approach to balance objectives without additional training burdens.

Abstract: Reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR) has delivered
impressive gains in mathematical and multimodal reasoning and has become a
standard post-training paradigm for contemporary language and vision-language
models. However, the RLVR recipe introduces a significant risk of capability
regression, where models forget foundational skills after prolonged training
without employing regularization strategies. We empirically confirm this
concern, observing that open-source reasoning models suffer performance
degradation on core capabilities such as perception and faithfulness. While
imposing regularization terms like KL divergence can help prevent deviation
from the base model, these terms are calculated on the current task, thus they
do not guarantee broader knowledge. Meanwhile, commonly used experience replay
across heterogeneous domains makes it nontrivial to decide how much training
focus each objective should receive. To address this, we propose RECAP-a replay
strategy with dynamic objective reweighting for general knowledge preservation.
Our reweighting mechanism adapts in an online manner using short-horizon
signals of convergence and instability, shifting the post-training focus away
from saturated objectives and toward underperforming or volatile ones. Our
method is end-to-end and readily applicable to existing RLVR pipelines without
training additional models or heavy tuning. Extensive experiments on benchmarks
based on Qwen2.5-VL-3B and Qwen2.5-VL-7B demonstrate the effectiveness of our
method, which not only preserves general capabilities but also improves
reasoning by enabling more flexible trade-offs among in-task rewards.

</details>


### [249] [Boltzmann Graph Ensemble Embeddings for Aptamer Libraries](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21980)
*Starlika Bauskar,Jade Jiao,Narayanan Kannan,Alexander Kimm,Justin M. Baker,Matthew J. Tyler,Andrea L. Bertozzi,Anne M. Andrews*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Thermodynamically parameterized ERGM embedding models molecules as Boltzmann-weighted ensembles of interaction graphs, improving robustness to SELEX biases and aiding detection/explanation of aptamer affinity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Single-graph (MFE) representations may miss ensemble effects and are vulnerable to experimental biases; a thermodynamics-informed ensemble model can better capture true binding signals and support interpretable analyses.

Method: Define an exponential-family random graph (ERGM) embedding parameterized by thermodynamic quantities; represent molecules as Boltzmann-weighted ensembles over interaction graphs rather than a single structure; apply to SELEX data with known biases; perform community detection and subgraph-level explanations to infer aptamer affinity.

Result: The embedding enables robust community detection and interpretable subgraph-level explanations for aptamer–ligand affinity even under biased observations, aiding identification of meaningful binders.

Conclusion: This thermodynamic ERGM framework can help identify low-abundance, true-binding aptamer candidates from noisy SELEX data and may extend to other molecular graph representations and spectra.

Abstract: Machine-learning methods in biochemistry commonly represent molecules as
graphs of pairwise intermolecular interactions for property and structure
predictions. Most methods operate on a single graph, typically the minimal free
energy (MFE) structure, for low-energy ensembles (conformations) representative
of structures at thermodynamic equilibrium. We introduce a thermodynamically
parameterized exponential-family random graph (ERGM) embedding that models
molecules as Boltzmann-weighted ensembles of interaction graphs. We evaluate
this embedding on SELEX datasets, where experimental biases (e.g., PCR
amplification or sequencing noise) can obscure true aptamer-ligand affinity,
producing anomalous candidates whose observed abundance diverges from their
actual binding strength. We show that the proposed embedding enables robust
community detection and subgraph-level explanations for aptamer ligand
affinity, even in the presence of biased observations. This approach may be
used to identify low-abundance aptamer candidates for further experimental
evaluation.

</details>


### [250] [Deep Learning on Real-World Graphs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21994)
*Emanuele Rossi*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A thesis presenting five specialized GNNs—SIGN, TGN, Dir-GNN, Feature Propagation, and NuGget—to address scalability, temporality, directionality/heterophily, missing node features, and structural uncertainty in real-world graphs, enabling industrial-scale applicability of GNNs in social and recommender systems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: GNNs are powerful on graphs but struggle with real-world issues: scalability to large graphs, time-evolving data, directed and heterophilic relationships, incomplete features, and uncertain structure. Academic benchmarks do not reflect industrial-scale graphs, hindering deployment.

Method: Proposes a suite of models: SIGN for scalable graph learning on large graphs; TGN for temporal graphs; Dir-GNN for directed and heterophilic networks; Feature Propagation (FP) for learning with missing node features; NuGget for game-theoretic structural inference. Collectively, these components form a toolkit to adapt GNNs to more realistic, industry-scale graph settings.

Result: The integrated approach aims to bridge the gap between benchmark graphs and industrial-scale graphs, enabling the use of GNNs in real-world domains such as social networks and recommender systems by improving scalability, temporal handling, directionality, handling missing data, and structural inference.

Conclusion: With these specialized models, GNNs can be deployed more broadly in real-world systems, closing the gap between theory and practice and unlocking practical benefits in domains requiring scalable, temporally aware, and robust graph learning.

Abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have become a central tool for learning on
graph-structured data, yet their applicability to real-world systems remains
limited by key challenges such as scalability, temporality, directionality,
data incompleteness, and structural uncertainty. This thesis introduces a
series of models addressing these limitations: SIGN for scalable graph
learning, TGN for temporal graphs, Dir-GNN for directed and heterophilic
networks, Feature Propagation (FP) for learning with missing node features, and
NuGget for game-theoretic structural inference. Together, these contributions
bridge the gap between academic benchmarks and industrial-scale graphs,
enabling the use of GNNs in domains such as social and recommender systems.

</details>


### [251] [Is Temporal Difference Learning the Gold Standard for Stitching in RL?](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21995)
*Michał Bortkiewicz,Władysław Pałucki,Mateusz Ostaszewski,Benjamin Eysenbach*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MC and TD can both enable experience stitching with function approximation; scaling up critic capacity reduces the generalization gap, diminishing the need for a TD bias.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To empirically test whether the stitching capability attributed to temporal difference methods persists when function approximation is used, and whether Monte Carlo can also achieve stitching.

Method: An empirical study in RL with function approximation, comparing MC and TD methods across tasks; systematically varying critic capacity (network size) and assessing stitching/generalization gaps on long-horizon-like behavior, including simple tasks; references to a project website.

Result: Monte Carlo methods can achieve experience stitching; TD methods are slightly stronger but the gap narrows substantially with larger networks. Increasing critic capacity reduces the generalization gap for both MC and TD, suggesting scale-driven generalization can enable stitching.

Conclusion: The traditional TD inductive bias for stitching may be less essential in the era of large models; stitching may arise from scaling rather than specialized algorithms, indicating that MC methods can effectively stitch experience under function approximation when models are large.

Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) promises to solve long-horizon tasks even when
training data contains only short fragments of the behaviors. This experience
stitching capability is often viewed as the purview of temporal difference (TD)
methods. However, outside of small tabular settings, trajectories never
intersect, calling into question this conventional wisdom. Moreover, the common
belief is that Monte Carlo (MC) methods should not be able to recombine
experience, yet it remains unclear whether function approximation could result
in a form of implicit stitching. The goal of this paper is to empirically study
whether the conventional wisdom about stitching actually holds in settings
where function approximation is used. We empirically demonstrate that Monte
Carlo (MC) methods can also achieve experience stitching. While TD methods do
achieve slightly stronger capabilities than MC methods (in line with
conventional wisdom), that gap is significantly smaller than the gap between
small and large neural networks (even on quite simple tasks). We find that
increasing critic capacity effectively reduces the generalization gap for both
the MC and TD methods. These results suggest that the traditional TD inductive
bias for stitching may be less necessary in the era of large models for RL and,
in some cases, may offer diminishing returns. Additionally, our results suggest
that stitching, a form of generalization unique to the RL setting, might be
achieved not through specialized algorithms (temporal difference learning) but
rather through the same recipe that has provided generalization in other
machine learning settings (via scale). Project website:
https://michalbortkiewicz.github.io/golden-standard/

</details>


### [252] [From Black-box to Causal-box: Towards Building More Interpretable Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21998)
*Inwoo Hwang,Yushu Pan,Elias Bareinboim*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Formalizes causal interpretability for counterfactual queries, showing that standard models (blackbox and concept-based) are not causally interpretable in general. It provides a complete graphical criterion to determine when a model supports counterfactual queries, reveals a fundamental tradeoff between causal interpretability and predictive accuracy, and identifies a unique maximal set of features yielding both interpretability and expressiveness. Experiments corroborate the theory.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable reliable reasoning about model predictions via counterfactuals in high-stakes settings. Existing black-box and concept-based models do not guarantee causal interpretability, creating a gap between explanation and causation.

Method: Define causal interpretability formally; analyze two model classes (blackbox and concept-based predictors); derive a complete graphical criterion for when a model architecture supports a given counterfactual query; characterize the tradeoff and identify the unique maximal feature set that yields an interpretable model with maximal predictive expressiveness; empirical validation.

Result: The paper shows that neither blackbox nor concept-based predictors are causally interpretable in general. It provides a graphical criterion to assess interpretability of a given model architecture for specific counterfactual queries and proves a unique maximal set of features that achieves interpretability with maximal predictive expressiveness. Experiments corroborate the theoretical findings.

Conclusion: A principled framework for designing causally interpretable models is established, clarifying the tradeoff between interpretability and predictive power and offering concrete guidelines and empirical support for model design.

Abstract: Understanding the predictions made by deep learning models remains a central
challenge, especially in high-stakes applications. A promising approach is to
equip models with the ability to answer counterfactual questions --
hypothetical ``what if?'' scenarios that go beyond the observed data and
provide insight into a model reasoning. In this work, we introduce the notion
of causal interpretability, which formalizes when counterfactual queries can be
evaluated from a specific class of models and observational data. We analyze
two common model classes -- blackbox and concept-based predictors -- and show
that neither is causally interpretable in general. To address this gap, we
develop a framework for building models that are causally interpretable by
design. Specifically, we derive a complete graphical criterion that determines
whether a given model architecture supports a given counterfactual query. This
leads to a fundamental tradeoff between causal interpretability and predictive
accuracy, which we characterize by identifying the unique maximal set of
features that yields an interpretable model with maximal predictive
expressiveness. Experiments corroborate the theoretical findings.

</details>


### [253] [Optimal Detection for Language Watermarks with Pseudorandom Collision](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22007)
*T. Tony Cai,Xiang Li,Qi Long,Weijie J. Su,Garrett G. Wen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A principled statistical framework for watermark detection under imperfect pseudorandomness using minimal units and a minimax hypothesis testing approach, yielding optimal rules for Gumbel-max and inverse-transform watermarks and improved detection power with controlled Type I error.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing watermarking methods assume perfect pseudorandomness; in practice, repetition in generated text induces structured dependence, breaking Type I error control and invalidating standard analyses.

Method: Introduce a hierarchical two-layer partition with minimal units—small groups treated as independent across units but allowing dependence within units. Define a non-asymptotic efficiency measure and cast watermark detection as a minimax hypothesis testing problem. Derive closed-form optimal rules for Gumbel-max and inverse-transform watermarks.

Result: Shows why discarding repeated statistics can improve performance, and that within-unit dependence must be addressed unless degenerate. Theory and experiments report improved detection power with rigorous Type I error control.

Conclusion: Provides the first principled foundation for watermark detection under imperfect pseudorandomness, offering both theoretical insight and practical guidance for reliable tracing of model outputs.

Abstract: Text watermarking plays a crucial role in ensuring the traceability and
accountability of large language model (LLM) outputs and mitigating misuse.
While promising, most existing methods assume perfect pseudorandomness. In
practice, repetition in generated text induces collisions that create
structured dependence, compromising Type I error control and invalidating
standard analyses.
  We introduce a statistical framework that captures this structure through a
hierarchical two-layer partition. At its core is the concept of minimal units
-- the smallest groups treatable as independent across units while permitting
dependence within. Using minimal units, we define a non-asymptotic efficiency
measure and cast watermark detection as a minimax hypothesis testing problem.
  Applied to Gumbel-max and inverse-transform watermarks, our framework
produces closed-form optimal rules. It explains why discarding repeated
statistics often improves performance and shows that within-unit dependence
must be addressed unless degenerate. Both theory and experiments confirm
improved detection power with rigorous Type I error control. These results
provide the first principled foundation for watermark detection under imperfect
pseudorandomness, offering both theoretical insight and practical guidance for
reliable tracing of model outputs.

</details>


### [254] [A Multimodal Human Protein Embeddings Database: DeepDrug Protein Embeddings Bank (DPEB)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22008)
*Md Saiful Islam Sajol,Magesh Rajasekaran,Hayden Gemeinhardt,Adam Bess,Chris Alvin,Supratik Mukhopadhyay*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: DPEB provides a curated, multi-modal embedding resource for human proteins by integrating AlphaFold2-derived structures, BioEmbeddings, ESM-2 patterns, and ProtVec; GraphSAGE with BioEmbedding achieves top PPI performance; also strong in enzyme and protein family classification; supports multiple GNN methods for PPI prediction and enables systems biology applications.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the lack of integrated, multimodal protein representations to improve PPI prediction and downstream tasks; provide access to AlphaFold2-derived embeddings to complement publicly available structures.

Method: Assemble 22,043 human proteins; generate/collect four embeddings: AlphaFold2 structural embeddings, BioEmbeddings transformer-based sequence embeddings, ESM-2 contextual amino acid pattern embeddings, ProtVec n-gram statistics; evaluate multiple graph neural network methods for PPI prediction; benchmark on PPI prediction and classification tasks.

Result: Best PPI performance achieved by GraphSAGE with BioEmbedding: AUROC 87.37%, accuracy 79.16%; enzyme classification accuracy 77.42%; protein family classification accuracy 86.04%. DPEB enables various GNN methods for PPI prediction.

Conclusion: DPEB provides a unified, multimodal resource to facilitate PPI prediction and downstream analyses (drug target identification, pathway analysis, disease mechanisms) and supports multiple GNN approaches for flexibility in modeling.

Abstract: Computationally predicting protein-protein interactions (PPIs) is challenging
due to the lack of integrated, multimodal protein representations. DPEB is a
curated collection of 22,043 human proteins that integrates four embedding
types: structural (AlphaFold2), transformer-based sequence (BioEmbeddings),
contextual amino acid patterns (ESM-2: Evolutionary Scale Modeling), and
sequence-based n-gram statistics (ProtVec]). AlphaFold2 protein structures are
available through public databases (e.g., AlphaFold2 Protein Structure
Database), but the internal neural network embeddings are not. DPEB addresses
this gap by providing AlphaFold2-derived embeddings for computational modeling.
Our benchmark evaluations show GraphSAGE with BioEmbedding achieved the highest
PPI prediction performance (87.37% AUROC, 79.16% accuracy). The framework also
achieved 77.42% accuracy for enzyme classification and 86.04% accuracy for
protein family classification. DPEB supports multiple graph neural network
methods for PPI prediction, enabling applications in systems biology, drug
target identification, pathway analysis, and disease mechanism studies.

</details>


### [255] [Cost-Sensitive Evaluation for Binary Classifiers](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22016)
*Pierangelo Lombardo,Antonio Casoli,Cristian Cingolani,Shola Oshodi,Michele Zanatta*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Weighted Accuracy (WA) for binary classifiers; a cost-aligned metric to minimize Total Classification Cost (TCC); a framework for handling class imbalance in cost-sensitive settings; guidance on when rebalancing helps or hurts; procedure to estimate WA's weight; empirical validation of WA's robustness.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is no universally accepted evaluation metric and a misconception about balancing datasets; TCC is the ultimate objective; WA is proposed to align evaluation with cost minimization and enable cross-dataset comparisons.

Method: Define WA as a weighted version of accuracy; develop a conceptual framework to handle class imbalance in cost-sensitive contexts; apply to any linear combination metric; analyze scenarios where rebalancing techniques align or conflict with TCC minimization; propose a method to estimate WA's weight when UCCs are not fully specified; empirically assess WA's robustness via correlation with TCC in example-dependent settings.

Result: The framework provides guidance on when to apply or avoid rebalancing in cost-sensitive classification; WA correlates with TCC across example-dependent scenarios; demonstrates robustness; offers a practical procedure to estimate the WA weight.

Conclusion: WA offers a coherent, interpretable metric tied to TCC; supports cross-dataset comparisons and informed decisions about rebalancing; provides procedures to estimate weights and understand when rebalancing is beneficial, ultimately aiding classifier optimization.

Abstract: Selecting an appropriate evaluation metric for classifiers is crucial for
model comparison and parameter optimization, yet there is not consensus on a
universally accepted metric that serves as a definitive standard. Moreover,
there is often a misconception about the perceived need to mitigate imbalance
in datasets used to train classification models. Since the final goal in
classifier optimization is typically maximizing the return of investment or,
equivalently, minimizing the Total Classification Cost (TCC), we define
Weighted Accuracy (WA), an evaluation metric for binary classifiers with a
straightforward interpretation as a weighted version of the well-known accuracy
metric, coherent with the need of minimizing TCC. We clarify the conceptual
framework for handling class imbalance in cost-sensitive scenarios, providing
an alternative to rebalancing techniques. This framework can be applied to any
metric that, like WA, can be expressed as a linear combination of
example-dependent quantities and allows for comparing the results obtained in
different datasets and for addressing discrepancies between the development
dataset, used to train and validate the model, and the target dataset, where
the model will be deployed. It also specifies in which scenarios using
UCCs-unaware class rebalancing techniques or rebalancing metrics aligns with
TCC minimization and when it is instead counterproductive. Finally, we propose
a procedure to estimate the WA weight parameter in the absence of fully
specified UCCs and demonstrate the robustness of WA by analyzing its
correlation with TCC in example-dependent scenarios.

</details>


### [256] [Do You Trust the Process?: Modeling Institutional Trust for Community Adoption of Reinforcement Learning Policies](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22017)
*Naina Balepur,Xingrui Pei,Hari Sundaram*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Trust-aware reinforcement learning for resource allocation under uncertain organizational goals; models institutional trust to improve fairness and community well-being; analyzes private trust reporting and external quota intervention.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the gap where citizens may not follow AI-informed policies without trusted institutions; apply trust-aware RL to humanitarian resource distribution.

Method: Use Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient to learn resource allocation policies; simulate allocations and model changes in institutional trust; analyze private trust values; assess policy performance with/without trust; examine a quota intervention from an external actor.

Result: Incorporating trust can yield better outcomes when organizational goals are uncertain; conservative trust estimates increase fairness and community trust but can reduce organizational success; quota intervention can improve fairness and trust in some cases but may lower organizational utility.

Conclusion: Institutional trust is crucial in policy-design; there is a tension between maximizing organizational success and safeguarding community well-being; trust-aware RL should be coupled with governance mechanisms to ensure fair distribution.

Abstract: Many governmental bodies are adopting AI policies for decision-making. In
particular, Reinforcement Learning has been used to design policies that
citizens would be expected to follow if implemented. Much RL work assumes that
citizens follow these policies, and evaluate them with this in mind. However,
we know from prior work that without institutional trust, citizens will not
follow policies put in place by governments. In this work, we develop a
trust-aware RL algorithm for resource allocation in communities. We consider
the case of humanitarian engineering, where the organization is aiming to
distribute some technology or resource to community members. We use a Deep
Deterministic Policy Gradient approach to learn a resource allocation that fits
the needs of the organization. Then, we simulate resource allocation according
to the learned policy, and model the changes in institutional trust of
community members. We investigate how this incorporation of institutional trust
affects outcomes, and ask how effectively an organization can learn policies if
trust values are private. We find that incorporating trust into RL algorithms
can lead to more successful policies, specifically when the organization's
goals are less certain. We find more conservative trust estimates lead to
increased fairness and average community trust, though organization success
suffers. Finally, we explore a strategy to prevent unfair outcomes to
communities. We implement a quota system by an external entity which decreases
the organization's utility when it does not serve enough community members. We
find this intervention can improve fairness and trust among communities in some
cases, while decreasing the success of the organization. This work underscores
the importance of institutional trust in algorithm design and implementation,
and identifies a tension between organization success and community well-being.

</details>


### [257] [K-DAREK: Distance Aware Error for Kurkova Kolmogorov Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22021)
*Masoud Ataei,Vikas Dhiman,Mohammad Javad Khojasteh*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: K-DAREK introduces distance-aware error bounds for Kurkova-Kolmogorov networks (KKANs), enabling efficient, interpretable function approximation with uncertainty quantification; it outperforms ensembles of KANs and Gaussian-process baselines in safe control tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address scalability and uncertainty quantification in function approximation. Neural networks are powerful but opaque and large; Gaussian processes are Bayesian but computationally expensive; KKANs offer a semi-parametric, structured approach with spline layers, but require robust error control. The goal is a fast, scalable, and reliable method with uncertainty estimates for dynamical-system modeling.

Method: Develop the K-DAREK (distance-aware error for Kurkova-Kolmogorov networks) framework by deriving distance-sensitive error bounds and integrating them into KKANs (which use Chebyshev layers and MLPs to map inputs into higher-dimensional spaces before spline-based transformations). Provide uncertainty quantification, robust bound guarantees, and improved convergence stability, then validate on a safe control task.

Result: K-DAREK achieves ~4× speed and ~10× computational efficiency gains over Ensemble of KANs, scales ~8.6× better than Gaussian processes with larger data, and is ~50% safer than the prior DAREK method, while maintaining robust distance-aware error bounds.

Conclusion: Distance-aware error bounds for KKANs yield efficient, scalable, and safer function approximation with uncertainty quantification. The K-DAREK framework enhances KKANs for operator estimation and dynamical-system modeling, offering practical advantages over KAN ensembles and GP baselines.

Abstract: Neural networks are parametric and powerful tools for function approximation,
and the choice of architecture heavily influences their interpretability,
efficiency, and generalization. In contrast, Gaussian processes (GPs) are
nonparametric probabilistic models that define distributions over functions
using a kernel to capture correlations among data points. However, these models
become computationally expensive for large-scale problems, as they require
inverting a large covariance matrix. Kolmogorov- Arnold networks (KANs),
semi-parametric neural architectures, have emerged as a prominent approach for
modeling complex functions with structured and efficient representations
through spline layers. Kurkova Kolmogorov-Arnold networks (KKANs) extend this
idea by reducing the number of spline layers in KAN and replacing them with
Chebyshev layers and multi-layer perceptrons, thereby mapping inputs into
higher-dimensional spaces before applying spline-based transformations.
Compared to KANs, KKANs perform more stable convergence during training, making
them a strong architecture for estimating operators and system modeling in
dynamical systems. By enhancing the KKAN architecture, we develop a novel
learning algorithm, distance-aware error for Kurkova-Kolmogorov networks
(K-DAREK), for efficient and interpretable function approximation with
uncertainty quantification. Our approach establishes robust error bounds that
are distance-aware; this means they reflect the proximity of a test point to
its nearest training points. Through case studies on a safe control task, we
demonstrate that K-DAREK is about four times faster and ten times higher
computationally efficiency than Ensemble of KANs, 8.6 times more scalable than
GP by increasing the data size, and 50% safer than our previous work
distance-aware error for Kolmogorov networks (DAREK).

</details>


### [258] [Normalization in Attention Dynamics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22026)
*Nikita Karagodin,Shu Ge,Yury Polyanskiy,Philippe Rigollet*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Normalization in deep transformers acts as speed regulation of token representations; a sphere-particle model yields a unified view of LN variants, with Peri-LN emerging as particularly effective.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how different normalization schemes influence the dynamics of token representations, clustering, and potential collapse across layers in deep transformers.

Method: Model token representations as interacting particles on the unit sphere and analyze the dynamical effects of various normalization schemes (Post-LN, Pre-LN, Mix-LN, Peri-LN, nGPT, LN-Scaling) to derive a unified framework.

Result: A unified framework linking normalization schemes to representation dynamics, clarifying their impact on clustering behavior and representation evolution across layers; identifies Peri-LN as a particularly effective option.

Conclusion: Peri-LN is highlighted as a notably effective normalization scheme; the framework provides a principled basis for comparing LN variants and can guide design choices for normalization in deep transformers.

Abstract: We study the effect of normalization schemes on token representations in deep
transformers. Modeling their evolution as interacting particles on the sphere,
we show that normalization acts as a form of speed regulation. This perspective
enables a unified analysis of several schemes -- including Post-LN, Pre-LN,
Mix-LN, Peri-LN, nGPT, and LN-Scaling -- revealing how they influence
clustering dynamics and representation collapse. Our framework clarifies how
different schemes shape token representations across layers and provides a
principled basis for comparing them, identifying Peri-LN as a particularly
effective choice.

</details>


### [259] [Online Optimization for Offline Safe Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22027)
*Yassine Chemingui,Aryan Deshwal,Alan Fern,Thanh Nguyen-Tang,Janardhan Rao Doppa*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a minimax Offline Safe RL (OSRL) method that blends offline RL with online no-regret optimization, with approximate optimality guarantees and a practical approximation that avoids offline policy evaluation; validated on the DSRL benchmark showing strong safety under tight cost budgets while achieving high rewards; code released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The OSRL setting seeks to maximize cumulative reward while satisfying a cumulative cost constraint using fixed offline data, demanding safety guarantees when data is limited or restrictive.

Method: Frame the OSRL problem as a minimax objective and solve by combining an offline RL oracle with online optimization (no-regret) algorithms. Provide a practical approximation that can pair with any offline RL algorithm and removes the need for offline policy evaluation.

Result: Theoretical result: approximate optimality when integrated with an approximate offline RL oracle and no-regret online optimization. Empirical result: on the DSRL benchmark, the method reliably enforces safety under stringent cost budgets and achieves high rewards.

Conclusion: The proposed minimax OSRL framework is both effective and practical, offering safety guarantees with strong performance; the approach is compatible with existing offline RL methods and comes with a code release.

Abstract: We study the problem of Offline Safe Reinforcement Learning (OSRL), where the
goal is to learn a reward-maximizing policy from fixed data under a cumulative
cost constraint. We propose a novel OSRL approach that frames the problem as a
minimax objective and solves it by combining offline RL with online
optimization algorithms. We prove the approximate optimality of this approach
when integrated with an approximate offline RL oracle and no-regret online
optimization. We also present a practical approximation that can be combined
with any offline RL algorithm, eliminating the need for offline policy
evaluation. Empirical results on the DSRL benchmark demonstrate that our method
reliably enforces safety constraints under stringent cost budgets, while
achieving high rewards. The code is available at
https://github.com/yassineCh/O3SRL.

</details>


### [260] [Differentiable Constraint-Based Causal Discovery](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22031)
*Jincheng Zhou,Mengbo Wang,Anqi He,Yumeng Zhou,Hessam Olya,Murat Kocaoglu,Bruno Ribeiro*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes differentiable d-separation scores via percolation theory and soft logic to enable gradient-based causal discovery, achieving strong performance in low-sample regimes and releasing code/data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridge the gap between constraint-based and score-based causal discovery by introducing differentiable conditional-independence criteria, addressing small-sample limitations, and enabling optimization-based discovery.

Method: Introduce differentiable d-separation scores using percolation theory and soft logic; implement gradient-based optimization of conditional independence constraints for causal discovery; provide code for reproducibility.

Result: Empirical evaluations show robust performance in low-sample regimes, surpassing traditional constraint-based and score-based baselines on a real-world dataset.

Conclusion: Differentiable d-separation via soft logic enables gradient-based optimization of independence constraints, offering strong performance in limited-data scenarios; code and data are publicly available.

Abstract: Causal discovery from observational data is a fundamental task in artificial
intelligence, with far-reaching implications for decision-making, predictions,
and interventions. Despite significant advances, existing methods can be
broadly categorized as constraint-based or score-based approaches.
Constraint-based methods offer rigorous causal discovery but are often hindered
by small sample sizes, while score-based methods provide flexible optimization
but typically forgo explicit conditional independence testing. This work
explores a third avenue: developing differentiable $d$-separation scores,
obtained through a percolation theory using soft logic. This enables the
implementation of a new type of causal discovery method: gradient-based
optimization of conditional independence constraints. Empirical evaluations
demonstrate the robust performance of our approach in low-sample regimes,
surpassing traditional constraint-based and score-based baselines on a
real-world dataset. Code and data of the proposed method are publicly available
at https://github$.$com/PurdueMINDS/DAGPA.

</details>


### [261] [Linearized Optimal Transport for Analysis of High-Dimensional Point-Cloud and Single-Cell Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22033)
*Tianxiang Wang,Yingtong Ke,Dhananjay Bhaskar,Smita Krishnaswamy,Alexander Cloninger*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Adapts Linear Optimal Transport (LOT) to irregular single-cell point clouds, embedding them into a fixed-dimensional space that preserves transport geometry, enabling interpretable classification, direct patient-to-patient registration, and generative modeling (synthetic data and barycenters) for immune-state analysis and organoid data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Single-cell data are high-dimensional and form irregular point clouds per patient, making direct comparison challenging. Nonlinear predictive methods offer accuracy but lack interpretability. A linear, distribution-preserving embedding could provide both performance and biological insight.

Method: Extend LOT to irregular point clouds by embedding each patient's cell distribution into a fixed-dimensional Euclidean space while preserving optimal transport structure. Use the embedding as a linear representation for downstream tasks, facilitate registration between patients, and enable interpretable classification (weights map to markers/spatial regions) and synthetic data generation via LOT barycenters for averaged cellular profiles.

Result: Demonstrates accurate and interpretable classification of COVID-19 patient states with classifier weights traceable to specific markers/spatial regions. Shows synthetic data generation for patient-derived organoids and the use of LOT barycenters to represent averaged cellular profiles for drug interaction testing. Overall, LOT provides a unified framework linking predictive performance, interpretability, and generative capabilities in high-dimensional biological systems.

Conclusion: LOT embedding of irregular single-cell point clouds creates a traceable, linear space that preserves distributional structure, enabling interpretable prediction, direct cross-patient comparisons, and generative analyses. This approach has potential to advance understanding of immune variation and treatment effects in complex biological systems.

Abstract: Single-cell technologies generate high-dimensional point clouds of cells,
enabling detailed characterization of complex patient states and treatment
responses. Yet each patient is represented by an irregular point cloud rather
than a simple vector, making it difficult to directly quantify and compare
biological differences between individuals. Nonlinear methods such as kernels
and neural networks achieve predictive accuracy but act as black boxes,
offering little biological interpretability.
  To address these limitations, we adapt the Linear Optimal Transport (LOT)
framework to this setting, embedding irregular point clouds into a
fixed-dimensional Euclidean space while preserving distributional structure.
This embedding provides a principled linear representation that preserves
optimal transport geometry while enabling downstream analysis. It also forms a
registration between any two patients, enabling direct comparison of their
cellular distributions. Within this space, LOT enables: (i) \textbf{accurate
and interpretable classification} of COVID-19 patient states, where classifier
weights map back to specific markers and spatial regions driving predictions;
and (ii) \textbf{synthetic data generation} for patient-derived organoids,
exploiting the linearity of the LOT embedding. LOT barycenters yield averaged
cellular profiles representing combined conditions or samples, supporting drug
interaction testing.
  Together, these results establish LOT as a unified framework that bridges
predictive performance, interpretability, and generative modeling. By
transforming heterogeneous point clouds into structured embeddings directly
traceable to the original data, LOT opens new opportunities for understanding
immune variation and treatment effects in high-dimensional biological systems.

</details>


### [262] [Generalized Top-k Mallows Model for Ranked Choices](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22040)
*Shahrzad Haddadan,Sara Ahmadian*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Generalizes Mallows to top-k lists; introduces sampling, efficient probability computation, and active learning for parameter estimation; validated on synthetic and real data; shows improved predictive power over MNL for top-k lists.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Users often focus on a limited subset of preferred items and are indifferent to the rest, which standard Mallows models fail to capture. The top-k Mallows extension and related methods aim to better model buyer choices and support practical decision-making.

Method: (1) A novel sampling scheme tailored to generalized top-k Mallows models; (2) An efficient algorithm for computing choice probabilities under this model; (3) An active learning algorithm to estimate model parameters from observed choice data. The paper also provides rigorous mathematical analysis of algorithm performance.

Result: Empirical results demonstrate scalability and accuracy on synthetic and real-world data. The work also compares the predictive power of Mallows models for top-k lists against the simpler Multinomial Logit model.

Conclusion: The work provides new tools for analysis and prediction in decision-making scenarios by extending Mallows to generalized top-k lists, enabling better modeling of buyer choices and practical deployment.

Abstract: The classic Mallows model is a foundational tool for modeling user
preferences. However, it has limitations in capturing real-world scenarios,
where users often focus only on a limited set of preferred items and are
indifferent to the rest. To address this, extensions such as the top-k Mallows
model have been proposed, aligning better with practical applications. In this
paper, we address several challenges related to the generalized top-k Mallows
model, with a focus on analyzing buyer choices. Our key contributions are: (1)
a novel sampling scheme tailored to generalized top-k Mallows models, (2) an
efficient algorithm for computing choice probabilities under this model, and
(3) an active learning algorithm for estimating the model parameters from
observed choice data. These contributions provide new tools for analysis and
prediction in critical decision-making scenarios. We present a rigorous
mathematical analysis for the performance of our algorithms. Furthermore,
through extensive experiments on synthetic data and real-world data, we
demonstrate the scalability and accuracy of our proposed methods, and we
compare the predictive power of Mallows model for top-k lists compared to the
simpler Multinomial Logit model.

</details>


### [263] [Fast Non-Log-Concave Sampling under Nonconvex Equality and Inequality Constraints with Landing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22044)
*Kijung Jeon,Michael Muehlebach,Molei Tao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Overdamped Langevin with LAnding (OLLA) to sample from distributions constrained by both equality and inequality constraints without explicit projections, proving exponential convergence in W2 and showing empirical efficiency vs projection-based methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Constrained sampling is fundamental in Bayesian stats, chemistry, and physics. Existing projection-based methods struggle with nonconvex constraint sets and typically handle only one constraint type (either equality or inequality). A unified approach with convergence guarantees is sought.

Method: OLLA builds overdamped Langevin dynamics that inherently satisfy both equality and inequality constraints by deterministic correction along the constraint surface normals, eliminating explicit projections and enabling a unified treatment of mixed constraints.

Result: The authors prove exponential convergence in Wasserstein-2 distance to the constrained target density and demonstrate in experiments that OLLA is computationally cheaper and offers reasonable empirical mixing compared with projection-based constrained Langevin algorithms and slack-variable variants.

Conclusion: OLLA provides a unified, projection-free framework for sampling from nonconvex constrained distributions with mixed constraint types, offering rigorous convergence guarantees and practical efficiency advantages.

Abstract: Sampling from constrained statistical distributions is a fundamental task in
various fields including Bayesian statistics, computational chemistry, and
statistical physics. This article considers the cases where the constrained
distribution is described by an unconstrained density, as well as additional
equality and/or inequality constraints, which often make the constraint set
nonconvex. Existing methods for nonconvex constraint set $\Sigma \subset
\mathbb{R}^d$ defined by equality or inequality constraints commonly rely on
costly projection steps. Moreover, they cannot handle equality and inequality
constraints simultaneously as each method only specialized in one case. In
addition, rigorous and quantitative convergence guarantee is often lacking. In
this paper, we introduce Overdamped Langevin with LAnding (OLLA), a new
framework that can design overdamped Langevin dynamics accommodating both
equality and inequality constraints. The proposed dynamics also
deterministically corrects trajectories along the normal direction of the
constraint surface, thus obviating the need for explicit projections. We show
that, under suitable regularity conditions on the target density and $\Sigma$,
OLLA converges exponentially fast in $W_2$ distance to the constrained target
density $\rho_\Sigma(x) \propto \exp(-f(x))d\sigma_\Sigma$. Lastly, through
experiments, we demonstrate the efficiency of OLLA compared to projection-based
constrained Langevin algorithms and their slack variable variants, highlighting
its favorable computational cost and reasonable empirical mixing.

</details>


### [264] [PF$Δ$: A Benchmark Dataset for Power Flow under Load, Generation, and Topology Variations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22048)
*Ana K. Rivera,Anvita Bhagavathula,Alvaro Carbonero,Priya Donti*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PFDelta is a large, multi-size, contingency-aware PF benchmark with ~860k solved instances, designed to evaluate traditional solvers and GNN-based PF methods under diverse conditions, including near-feasible and near-infeasible cases.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-time grid operations require fast, robust power-flow (PF) calculations across contingencies and uncertain conditions. ML-based solvers promise speedups but currently lack benchmarks that reflect real-world variability; PFDelta provides a diverse, large-scale dataset to systematically benchmark methods.

Method: Construct PFDelta with six bus-system sizes, 859,800 solved PF instances, spanning N, N-1, and N-2 contingencies, including near steady-state voltage stability limits. The study benchmarks traditional solvers and GNN-based approaches, and provides data generation scripts and model implementations. Public availability: dataset on HuggingFace and code on GitHub.

Result: Empirical evaluation identifies where traditional solvers and GNN methods struggle, highlighting gaps and open problems for future research. The benchmark enables systematic performance comparison and analysis across sizes, contingencies, and near-infeasible cases.

Conclusion: PFDelta offers a comprehensive, scalable benchmark for evaluating PF methods under realistic variability, supporting development of faster and more robust solvers. Data and code are publicly accessible for the community: HuggingFace PFDelta dataset and MOSSLab MIT codebase.

Abstract: Power flow (PF) calculations are the backbone of real-time grid operations,
across workflows such as contingency analysis (where repeated PF evaluations
assess grid security under outages) and topology optimization (which involves
PF-based searches over combinatorially large action spaces). Running these
calculations at operational timescales or across large evaluation spaces
remains a major computational bottleneck. Additionally, growing uncertainty in
power system operations from the integration of renewables and climate-induced
extreme weather also calls for tools that can accurately and efficiently
simulate a wide range of scenarios and operating conditions. Machine learning
methods offer a potential speedup over traditional solvers, but their
performance has not been systematically assessed on benchmarks that capture
real-world variability. This paper introduces PF$\Delta$, a benchmark dataset
for power flow that captures diverse variations in load, generation, and
topology. PF$\Delta$ contains 859,800 solved power flow instances spanning six
different bus system sizes, capturing three types of contingency scenarios (N ,
N -1, and N -2), and including close-to-infeasible cases near steady-state
voltage stability limits. We evaluate traditional solvers and GNN-based
methods, highlighting key areas where existing approaches struggle, and
identifying open problems for future research. Our dataset is available at
https://huggingface.co/datasets/pfdelta/pfdelta/tree/main and our code with
data generation scripts and model implementations is at
https://github.com/MOSSLab-MIT/pfdelta.

</details>


### [265] [Automatic Assessment of Students' Classroom Engagement with Bias Mitigated Multi-task Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22057)
*James Thiering,Tarun Sethupat Radha Krishna,Dylan Zelkin,Ashis Kumer Biswas*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: An automated system for detecting online student engagement using attribute-orthogonal regularization on a split-model classifier to reduce reliance on gender and improve interpretability; code available on GitHub.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: With the rise of online/virtual learning, there is a need to monitor and improve student engagement while avoiding reliance on sensitive attributes (e.g., gender). The work aims to develop ethical, interpretable engagement predictions in virtual environments.

Method: Introduce an attribute-orthogonal regularization technique applied to a split-model classifier that employs multiple transfer learning strategies. The training discourages predicting or leveraging gender, improving fairness and interpretability. Disparity across sensitivity groups is evaluated with Pearson correlation. The approach is demonstrated on an e-learning engagement task.

Result: The mitigated model shows a marked change in disparity metrics (Pearson correlation with respect to sensitivity groups moves from 0.897 in the unmitigated model to 0.999 in the mitigated model) and enhanced interpretability, with source code provided on GitHub.

Conclusion: The proposed training method advances ethical and interpretable engagement prediction in online learning by reducing reliance on sensitive attributes and making model decisions more transparent.

Abstract: With the rise of online and virtual learning, monitoring and enhancing
student engagement have become an important aspect of effective education.
Traditional methods of assessing a student's involvement might not be
applicable directly to virtual environments. In this study, we focused on this
problem and addressed the need to develop an automated system to detect student
engagement levels during online learning. We proposed a novel training method
which can discourage a model from leveraging sensitive features like gender for
its predictions. The proposed method offers benefits not only in the
enforcement of ethical standards, but also to enhance interpretability of the
model predictions. We applied an attribute-orthogonal regularization technique
to a split-model classifier, which uses multiple transfer learning strategies
to achieve effective results in reducing disparity in the distribution of
prediction for sensitivity groups from a Pearson correlation coefficient of
0.897 for the unmitigated model, to 0.999 for the mitigated model. The source
code for this project is available on
https://github.com/ashiskb/elearning-engagement-study .

</details>


### [266] [Pruning and Quantization Impact on Graph Neural Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22058)
*Khatoon Khedri,Reza Rawassizadeh,Qifu Wen,Mehdi Hosseinzadeh*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: The paper studies pruning and quantization for graph neural networks (GNNs) across graph classification, node classification, and link prediction tasks on Cora, Proteins, and BBBP. It finds that unstructured fine-grained and global pruning can shrink models by about 50% in size while preserving or improving accuracy after fine-tuning, while quantization yields varied impacts on accuracy, latency, and size depending on the dataset.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: GNNs deliver high accuracy on graph-structured data but incur high computational and memory costs. Neural network compression (pruning and quantization) is pursued to reduce model size and inference costs while maintaining acceptable accuracy.
