TL;DR: DenseNet121 on 2D chemical structure images with Grad-CAM yields competitive toxicology predictions on Tox21 and enhanced interpretability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Predict chemical toxicity reliably using scalable models; address the need for interpretability in toxicology predictions; leverage image-based representations and explainable AI to aid cheminformatics.

Method: Proposes an image-based pipeline using DenseNet121 on 2D depictions of chemical structures; trains on the Tox21 dataset; applies Grad-CAM to localize toxicophores and explain predictions; compares architectures across performance, robustness, and interpretability.

Result: Achieves competitive performance compared with traditional models; Grad-CAM highlights molecular regions contributing to toxicity, demonstrating the viability of deep CNNs and explainable AI in cheminformatics.

Conclusion: Image-based CNNs combined with explainability techniques offer improved accuracy and transparency for toxicology predictions, supporting the potential of deep learning in cheminformatics.

Abstract: The task here is to predict the toxicological activity of chemical compounds
based on the Tox21 dataset, a benchmark in computational toxicology.
  After a domain-specific overview of chemical toxicity, we discuss current
computational strategies, focusing on machine learning and deep learning.
Several architectures are compared in terms of performance, robustness, and
interpretability.
  This research introduces a novel image-based pipeline based on DenseNet121,
which processes 2D graphical representations of chemical structures.
Additionally, we employ Grad-CAM visualizations, an explainable AI technique,
to interpret the model's predictions and highlight molecular regions
contributing to toxicity classification. The proposed architecture achieves
competitive results compared to traditional models, demonstrating the potential
of deep convolutional networks in cheminformatics. Our findings emphasize the
value of combining image-based representations with explainable AI methods to
improve both predictive accuracy and model transparency in toxicology.

</details>


### [320] [Optimal Anytime Algorithms for Online Convex Optimization with Adversarial Constraints](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22579)
*Dhruv Sarkar,Abhishek Sinha*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: An anytime online learning algorithm for adversarial convex costs with adversarial convex constraints achieves sqrt(t) regret and sqrt(t) constraint violation without knowledge of horizon, using time-varying Lyapunov functions instead of the fixed-horizon approach.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Provide non-trivial performance guarantees at every time step without requiring prior knowledge of the time horizon, while handling constraints in an adversarial online setting and avoiding the practical drawbacks of the doubling trick.

Method: Develop an online algorithm that employs time-varying Lyapunov functions to monitor constraint violations and derives regret and violation bounds. The analysis overcomes challenges due to non-monotonic properties of time-varying Lyapunov functions. Extend to dynamic regret and an adaptive optimistic variant.

Result: Achieves O(sqrt(t)) regret and ~O(sqrt(t)) cumulative constraint violation for any t≥1. Dynamic regret scales with the comparator's path length without horizon knowledge. An adaptive optimistic version scales with cumulative prediction error. Numerical experiments on online shortest path illustrate practicality.

Conclusion: The proposed time-varying-Lyapunov approach yields optimal-or-near-optimal online performance guarantees for learning under adversarial costs and constraints without horizon knowledge, and adapts to changing targets and prediction quality.

Abstract: We propose an anytime online algorithm for the problem of learning a sequence
of adversarial convex cost functions while approximately satisfying another
sequence of adversarial online convex constraints. A sequential algorithm is
called \emph{anytime} if it provides a non-trivial performance guarantee for
any intermediate timestep $t$ without requiring prior knowledge of the length
of the entire time horizon $T$. Our proposed algorithm achieves optimal
performance bounds without resorting to the standard doubling trick, which has
poor practical performance due to multiple restarts. Our core technical
contribution is the use of time-varying Lyapunov functions to keep track of
constraint violations. This must be contrasted with prior works that used a
fixed Lyapunov function tuned to the known horizon length $T$. The use of
time-varying Lyapunov function poses unique analytical challenges as
properties, such as \emph{monotonicity}, on which the prior proofs rest, no
longer hold. By introducing a new analytical technique, we show that our
algorithm achieves $O(\sqrt{t})$ regret and $\tilde{O}(\sqrt{t})$ cumulative
constraint violation bounds for any $t\geq 1$.
  We extend our results to the dynamic regret setting, achieving bounds that
adapt to the path length of the comparator sequence without prior knowledge of
its total length. We also present an adaptive algorithm in the optimistic
setting, whose performance gracefully scales with the cumulative prediction
error. We demonstrate the practical utility of our algorithm through numerical
experiments involving the online shortest path problem.

</details>


### [321] [Prediction-Powered Semi-Supervised Learning with Online Power Tuning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22586)
*Noa Shoham,Ron Dorfman,Shalev Shaer,Kfir Y. Levy,Yaniv Romano*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Extends Prediction-Powered Inference to SSL by introducing an unbiased gradient estimator and online-tuned interpolation between labeled and pseudo-labeled data, improving performance over standard SSL baselines and offline-PPI tuning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Unlabeled data helps SSL only if pseudo-labels are reliable; biased pseudo-labels can hurt training. There is a need for an unbiased gradient estimator that safely combines labeled and pseudo-labeled data and can adapt the mix during training.

Method: Develop an unbiased gradient estimator inspired by PPI for SSL; introduce an interpolation parameter controlling contributions from labeled vs pseudo-labeled data; jointly optimize this parameter and the model via a one-dimensional online learning algorithm that updates on the fly.

Result: Empirical evaluation on synthetic and real datasets shows improved performance over classical SSL baselines and PPI methods that tune the interpolation parameter offline.

Conclusion: Online, data-driven tuning of the mix between labeled and pseudo-labeled data with an unbiased gradient estimator offers a practical boost for SSL and validates the PPI-based approach in semi-supervised training.

Abstract: Prediction-Powered Inference (PPI) is a recently proposed statistical
inference technique for parameter estimation that leverages pseudo-labels on
both labeled and unlabeled data to construct an unbiased, low-variance
estimator. In this work, we extend its core idea to semi-supervised learning
(SSL) for model training, introducing a novel unbiased gradient estimator. This
extension addresses a key challenge in SSL: while unlabeled data can improve
model performance, its benefit heavily depends on the quality of pseudo-labels.
Inaccurate pseudo-labels can introduce bias, leading to suboptimal models.To
balance the contributions of labeled and pseudo-labeled data, we utilize an
interpolation parameter and tune it on the fly, alongside the model parameters,
using a one-dimensional online learning algorithm. We verify the practical
advantage of our approach through experiments on both synthetic and real
datasets, demonstrating improved performance over classic SSL baselines and PPI
methods that tune the interpolation parameter offline.

</details>


### [322] [A roadmap for curvature-based geometric data analysis and learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22599)
*Yasharth Yadav,Kelin Xia*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A comprehensive survey of discrete curvature models across graphs, simplicial/cubical complexes, and point clouds, detailing mathematical foundations, computational formulations, pipelines, algorithms, and applications in supervised and unsupervised learning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Curvature is a key, interpretable descriptor of intrinsic geometry that enables robust geometric learning. With many discrete curvature models across data representations, there is a need for a unified, state-of-the-art overview, methodological guidance, and practical roadmap.

Method: Systematic literature review of discrete curvature models for various data representations (graphs, simplicial/cubical complexes, and point clouds). Analyzes mathematical foundations from Riemannian and metric geometry, compares computational formulations, outlines a data-analysis pipeline, surveys algorithms, and summarizes applications in data analysis and learning.

Result: Provides a conceptual and practical roadmap for curvature-driven data analysis, with detailed comparisons across representations and algorithms, and a synthesis of state-of-the-art applications in supervised and unsupervised learning.

Conclusion: Discrete curvature is a fundamental tool for geometric understanding and learning; the survey equips researchers with a comprehensive framework, highlights gaps, and guides future work in curvature-based data analysis.

Abstract: Geometric data analysis and learning has emerged as a distinct and rapidly
developing research area, increasingly recognized for its effectiveness across
diverse applications. At the heart of this field lies curvature, a powerful and
interpretable concept that captures intrinsic geometric structure and underpins
numerous tasks, from community detection to geometric deep learning. A wide
range of discrete curvature models have been proposed for various data
representations, including graphs, simplicial complexes, cubical complexes, and
point clouds sampled from manifolds. These models not only provide efficient
characterizations of data geometry but also constitute essential components in
geometric learning frameworks. In this paper, we present the first
comprehensive review of existing discrete curvature models, covering their
mathematical foundations, computational formulations, and practical
applications in data analysis and learning. In particular, we discuss discrete
curvature from both Riemannian and metric geometry perspectives and propose a
systematic pipeline for curvature-driven data analysis. We further examine the
corresponding computational algorithms across different data representations,
offering detailed comparisons and insights. Finally, we review state-of-the-art
applications of curvature in both supervised and unsupervised learning. This
survey provides a conceptual and practical roadmap for researchers to gain a
better understanding of discrete curvature as a fundamental tool for geometric
understanding and learning.

</details>


### [323] [CLEANet: Robust and Efficient Anomaly Detection in Contaminated Multivariate Time Series](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22619)
*Songhan Zhang,Yuanhao Lai,Pengfei Zheng,Boxi Yu,Xiaoying Tang,Qiuai Fu,Pinjia He*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: CLEANet tackles contaminated training data in multivariate time series anomaly detection with a contamination-resilient training framework (CRTF) and a lightweight conjugate MLP, achieving robustness and faster inference; CRTF improves F1 and reduces runtime across datasets and enhances existing models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Unsupervised multivariate time series anomaly detection assumes clean training data, but real-world data are often contaminated with noise and hidden anomalies, distorting learned patterns and harming detection accuracy. There is a need for robust training and efficient inference for deployment.

Method: Introduce Contamination-Resilient Training Framework (CRTF) that uses adaptive reconstruction weighting and clustering-guided contrastive learning to mitigate corrupted samples. Develop a lightweight conjugate MLP that disentangles temporal and cross-feature dependencies to reduce overfitting and improve efficiency. Evaluate on five public MTS datasets; show gains when CRTF is integrated into existing models.

Result: CLEANet achieves up to 73.04% higher F1 and 81.28% lower runtime compared with ten state-of-the-art baselines. Integrating CRTF into three advanced models yields an average 5.35% F1 gain, indicating strong generalizability.

Conclusion: CLEANet offers a robust and efficient solution for anomaly detection in contaminated MTS. The CRTF framework improves robustness to data contamination and generalizes across models, enabling practical deployment with reduced inference time and better detection performance.

Abstract: Multivariate time series (MTS) anomaly detection is essential for maintaining
the reliability of industrial systems, yet real-world deployment is hindered by
two critical challenges: training data contamination (noises and hidden
anomalies) and inefficient model inference. Existing unsupervised methods
assume clean training data, but contamination distorts learned patterns and
degrades detection accuracy. Meanwhile, complex deep models often overfit to
contamination and suffer from high latency, limiting practical use. To address
these challenges, we propose CLEANet, a robust and efficient anomaly detection
framework in contaminated multivariate time series. CLEANet introduces a
Contamination-Resilient Training Framework (CRTF) that mitigates the impact of
corrupted samples through an adaptive reconstruction weighting strategy
combined with clustering-guided contrastive learning, thereby enhancing
robustness. To further avoid overfitting on contaminated data and improve
computational efficiency, we design a lightweight conjugate MLP that
disentangles temporal and cross-feature dependencies. Across five public
datasets, CLEANet achieves up to 73.04% higher F1 and 81.28% lower runtime
compared with ten state-of-the-art baselines. Furthermore, integrating CRTF
into three advanced models yields an average 5.35% F1 gain, confirming its
strong generalizability.

</details>


### [324] [FastVLM: Self-Speculative Decoding for Fast Vision-Language Model Inference](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22641)
*Divya Jyoti Bajpai,Manjesh Kumar Hanawal*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: FastVLM introduces Self-Speculative Decoding using a lightweight draft model and a full non-autoregressive verifier to speed up vision-language model decoding with minimal accuracy loss.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Autoregressive decoding in vision-language models is computationally heavy and slow; need a faster inference method without sacrificing performance.

Method: Train a lightweight draft model to generate tokens autoregressively; the full model verifies tokens non-autoregressively; accepted tokens pass, rejected tokens are corrected by full model and guide draft model refinement; an imitation network integrates deep insights from full model; draft model trained to preserve full-model performance.

Result: Inference speedup of 1.55-1.85x relative to the final layer with minimal performance loss; maintains performance integrity of full model.

Conclusion: Imitation-learning-based Self-Speculative Decoding offers a practical approach to accelerate VLMs with negligible accuracy trade-offs, achieving efficient inference while preserving quality.

Abstract: Vision-language Models (VLMs) have made significant strides in visual
understanding and query response generation, but often face challenges of high
computational cost and inference latency due to autoregressive decoding. In
this work, we introduce an imitation-learning-based Self-Speculative Decoding
(SSD) framework, named FastVLM, to address these limitations. Our approach
employs a lightweight draft model for token generation in an autoregressive
manner, while a full model verifies these tokens non-autoregressively. Accepted
tokens proceed seamlessly, while rejected tokens are corrected by the full
model and used to guide the draft model's refinement. Through an imitation
network, FastVLM enhances the draft model by integrating deeper level insights
from the full model's architecture. Also, it maintains the performance
integrity of the full model while training the draft model, achieving a balance
between efficiency and accuracy. Our method speeds up the inference process by
1.55-1.85x as compared to the final layer with minimal loss in performance.

</details>


### [325] [Enhancing Graph Classification Robustness with Singular Pooling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22643)
*Sofiane Ennadir,Oleg Smirnov,Yassine Abbahaddou,Lele Cao,Johannes F. Lutzeyer*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Robust Singular Pooling (RS-Pool) for graph classification to enhance adversarial robustness of pooling; provides theoretical bounds for standard pooling; demonstrates empirical robustness gains with competitive accuracy and releases code.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Pooling layers in GNNs (sum/avg/max) are underexplored for robustness and may be vulnerable to adversarial perturbations, motivating a robust pooling design.

Method: Theoretically derive upper bounds on adversarial risk for flat pooling; propose RS-Pool that uses the dominant singular vector of the node embedding matrix to form the graph representation; implementable via power iteration; model-agnostic (though analyzed for GCNs).

Result: RS-Pool shows superior robustness under state-of-the-art adversarial attacks compared to standard pooling, while maintaining competitive clean accuracy on real-world benchmarks.

Conclusion: RS-Pool provides a principled, efficient, and transferable robust pooling operation; underpins improved robustness in graph classification and invites further exploration of spectral pooling strategies.

Abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved strong performance across a range
of graph representation learning tasks, yet their adversarial robustness in
graph classification remains underexplored compared to node classification.
While most existing defenses focus on the message-passing component, this work
investigates the overlooked role of pooling operations in shaping robustness.
We present a theoretical analysis of standard flat pooling methods (sum,
average and max), deriving upper bounds on their adversarial risk and
identifying their vulnerabilities under different attack scenarios and graph
structures. Motivated by these insights, we propose \textit{Robust Singular
Pooling (RS-Pool)}, a novel pooling strategy that leverages the dominant
singular vector of the node embedding matrix to construct a robust graph-level
representation. We theoretically investigate the robustness of RS-Pool and
interpret the resulting bound leading to improved understanding of our proposed
pooling operator. While our analysis centers on Graph Convolutional Networks
(GCNs), RS-Pool is model-agnostic and can be implemented efficiently via power
iteration. Empirical results on real-world benchmarks show that RS-Pool
provides better robustness than the considered pooling methods when subject to
state-of-the-art adversarial attacks while maintaining competitive clean
accuracy. Our code is publicly available
at:\href{https://github.com/king/rs-pool}{https://github.com/king/rs-pool}.

</details>


### [326] [Variational Polya Tree](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22651)
*Lu Xu,Tsai Hor Chan,Kwok Fai Lam,Lequan Yu,Guosheng Yin*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: We introduce the variational Polya tree (VPT), a scalable Bayesian nonparametric density estimator using stochastic variational inference, achieving competitive performance and improved uncertainty quantification and interpretability compared to deep learning-based density estimators.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bayesian nonparametric methods like the Polya tree address interpretability and uncertainty in density estimation but suffer from MCMC scalability. There is a need to integrate BNP priors into deep learning with scalable inference.

Method: Develop VPT with a Polya tree prior and stochastic variational inference to compute posteriors; utilize joint distribution likelihood to obtain a tighter variational posterior than mean-field; optimize with stochastic gradient methods; applicable to real data and images; code release at the cited repository.

Result: Empirical results show VPT competitive with state-of-the-art deep density estimators on real data and images; demonstrates improved interpretability and uncertainty quantification.

Conclusion: VPT provides a flexible, scalable BNP prior for deep density estimation, enabling better uncertainty estimates and interpretability while remaining compatible with SGD-based training; code available at the cited repository.

Abstract: Density estimation is essential for generative modeling, particularly with
the rise of modern neural networks. While existing methods capture complex data
distributions, they often lack interpretability and uncertainty quantification.
Bayesian nonparametric methods, especially the \polya tree, offer a robust
framework that addresses these issues by accurately capturing function behavior
over small intervals. Traditional techniques like Markov chain Monte Carlo
(MCMC) face high computational complexity and scalability limitations,
hindering the use of Bayesian nonparametric methods in deep learning. To tackle
this, we introduce the variational \polya tree (VPT) model, which employs
stochastic variational inference to compute posterior distributions. This model
provides a flexible, nonparametric Bayesian prior that captures latent
densities and works well with stochastic gradient optimization. We also
leverage the joint distribution likelihood for a more precise variational
posterior approximation than traditional mean-field methods. We evaluate the
model performance on both real data and images, and demonstrate its
competitiveness with other state-of-the-art deep density estimation methods. We
also explore its ability in enhancing interpretability and uncertainty
quantification. Code is available at
https://github.com/howardchanth/var-polya-tree.

</details>


### [327] [If You Want to Be Robust, Be Wary of Initialization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22652)
*Sofiane Ennadir,Johannes F. Lutzeyer,Michalis Vazirgiannis,El Houcine Bergou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Initialization strategies and training hyper-parameters significantly influence GNN adversarial robustness; a theoretical framework links initialization to vulnerability, with empirical validation showing robustness gains (up to ~50%) over other initializations and extending to Deep Neural Networks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address gaps in adversarial robustness research by examining how weight initialization and training regime affect GNN vulnerabilities, complementing existing defenses focused on preprocessing and message-passing.

Method: Develop a theoretical framework that connects initialization strategies to robustness against adversarial perturbations; derive an upper bound applicable to Deep Neural Networks; conduct extensive experiments across diverse GNN models, real-world datasets, and various attacks, comparing different initializations and training epochs.

Result: There is a direct relationship between initial weights, training epochs, and vulnerability; appropriate initialization improves both clean performance and robustness to adversarial perturbations; robustness gains observed up to ~50% over alternative initializations; the framework generalizes with a broad upper bound for DNNs.

Conclusion: Initialization and training configuration are practical levers for enhancing adversarial robustness in GNNs, offering insights beyond conventional defenses and providing a general bound that extends to broader neural architectures.

Abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have demonstrated remarkable performance across
a spectrum of graph-related tasks, however concerns persist regarding their
vulnerability to adversarial perturbations. While prevailing defense strategies
focus primarily on pre-processing techniques and adaptive message-passing
schemes, this study delves into an under-explored dimension: the impact of
weight initialization and associated hyper-parameters, such as training epochs,
on a model's robustness. We introduce a theoretical framework bridging the
connection between initialization strategies and a network's resilience to
adversarial perturbations. Our analysis reveals a direct relationship between
initial weights, number of training epochs and the model's vulnerability,
offering new insights into adversarial robustness beyond conventional defense
mechanisms. While our primary focus is on GNNs, we extend our theoretical
framework, providing a general upper-bound applicable to Deep Neural Networks.
Extensive experiments, spanning diverse models and real-world datasets
subjected to various adversarial attacks, validate our findings. We illustrate
that selecting appropriate initialization not only ensures performance on clean
datasets but also enhances model robustness against adversarial perturbations,
with observed gaps of up to 50\% compared to alternative initialization
approaches.

</details>


### [328] [UCB-type Algorithm for Budget-Constrained Expert Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22654)
*Ilgam Latypov,Alexandra Suvorikova,Alexey Kroshnin,Alexander Gasnikov,Yuriy Dorn*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: M-LCB is a UCB-style meta-algorithm for dynamically selecting and training up to M out of K adaptive experts online; it achieves regret bounded by ~ sqrt(KT/M) + (K/M)^{1-rac{	ext{alpha}}{}} T^α under per-round budget constraints, assuming each expert has internal regret ~ T^α.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In modern systems, multiple self-learning agents must be coordinated online under limited per-round training resources. This creates a need for regret guarantees when several adaptive experts are trained simultaneously. The work aims to provide anytime regret guarantees and a practical algorithm to manage such resources.

Method: Propose M-LCB, a computationally efficient UCB-style meta-algorithm that builds confidence intervals from realized losses (no extra optimization) and reflects the convergence properties of the underlying experts. The method handles per-round budget M by updating at most M experts per round and gives regret bounds in a stochastic setting given experts with internal regret ≤ T^α.

Result: Derives a regret bound for M-LCB: Õ( sqrt(KT/M) + (K/M)^{1-α} T^α ), where α governs the per-expert regret. This is claimed to be the first result providing regret guarantees when multiple adaptive experts are trained under per-round budget constraints. The approach is illustrated on (i) online parametric models with stochastic losses and (ii) experts that are themselves multi-armed bandit algorithms.

Conclusion: Extends the classical bandit framework to coordinating stateful, self-learning experts under limited per-round resources; provides anytime regret guarantees and practical applicability to model selection in streaming, finance, and orchestrating cascaded RL/ bandit agents.

Abstract: In many modern applications, a system must dynamically choose between several
adaptive learning algorithms that are trained online. Examples include model
selection in streaming environments, switching between trading strategies in
finance, and orchestrating multiple contextual bandit or reinforcement learning
agents. At each round, a learner must select one predictor among $K$ adaptive
experts to make a prediction, while being able to update at most $M \le K$ of
them under a fixed training budget.
  We address this problem in the \emph{stochastic setting} and introduce
\algname{M-LCB}, a computationally efficient UCB-style meta-algorithm that
provides \emph{anytime regret guarantees}. Its confidence intervals are built
directly from realized losses, require no additional optimization, and
seamlessly reflect the convergence properties of the underlying experts. If
each expert achieves internal regret $\tilde O(T^\alpha)$, then \algname{M-LCB}
ensures overall regret bounded by $\tilde O\!\Bigl(\sqrt{\tfrac{KT}{M}} \;+\;
(K/M)^{1-\alpha}\,T^\alpha\Bigr)$.
  To our knowledge, this is the first result establishing regret guarantees
when multiple adaptive experts are trained simultaneously under per-round
budget constraints. We illustrate the framework with two representative cases:
(i) parametric models trained online with stochastic losses, and (ii) experts
that are themselves multi-armed bandit algorithms. These examples highlight how
\algname{M-LCB} extends the classical bandit paradigm to the more realistic
scenario of coordinating stateful, self-learning experts under limited
resources.

</details>


### [329] [Learning Without Augmenting: Unsupervised Time Series Representation Learning via Frame Projections](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22655)
*Berken Utku Demirel,Christian Holz*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Self-supervised learning without heavy augmentations by using orthonormal bases and overcomplete frames to generate views; exploits distinct manifolds from different representation spaces; yields up to 15–20% gains on temporal sequence tasks across nine datasets; code at GitHub.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current SSL relies on hand-crafted augmentations that inject biases and limit generalization. There is a need for augmentation-free or augmentation-agnostic representations; this work proposes leveraging the geometry of alternative representation spaces to create views.

Method: Represent data in orthonormal bases and in overcomplete frames to generate views; learn embeddings in both spaces and exploit their complementary geometry; evaluate on nine datasets spanning five temporal sequence tasks.

Result: Embeddings reside on distinct manifolds shaped by the representation space; jointly leveraging the two manifolds yields superior performance; gains of 15–20% over existing SSL methods; robust across datasets; no reliance on augmentation diversity.

Conclusion: Frame-based projections offer an augmentation-free path to strong SSL; geometry of representation spaces is a key factor; method demonstrates cross-domain effectiveness; code available at GitHub.

Abstract: Self-supervised learning (SSL) has emerged as a powerful paradigm for
learning representations without labeled data. Most SSL approaches rely on
strong, well-established, handcrafted data augmentations to generate diverse
views for representation learning. However, designing such augmentations
requires domain-specific knowledge and implicitly imposes representational
invariances on the model, which can limit generalization. In this work, we
propose an unsupervised representation learning method that replaces
augmentations by generating views using orthonormal bases and overcomplete
frames. We show that embeddings learned from orthonormal and overcomplete
spaces reside on distinct manifolds, shaped by the geometric biases introduced
by representing samples in different spaces. By jointly leveraging the
complementary geometry of these distinct manifolds, our approach achieves
superior performance without artificially increasing data diversity through
strong augmentations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method on nine
datasets across five temporal sequence tasks, where signal-specific
characteristics make data augmentations particularly challenging. Without
relying on augmentation-induced diversity, our method achieves performance
gains of up to 15--20\% over existing self-supervised approaches. Source code:
https://github.com/eth-siplab/Learning-with-FrameProjections

</details>


### [330] [FlowCritic: Bridging Value Estimation with Flow Matching in Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22686)
*Shan Zhong,Shutong Ding,He Diao,Xiangyu Wang,Kah Chan Teh,Bei Peng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: FlowCritic uses flow matching to model value distributions in RL, offering a generative alternative to point-estimate ensembles and discretized/quantile distributional RL.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing RL value estimation methods either rely on multi-critic ensembles (which miss distributional info) or distributional RL with discretization/quantile regression (which limits expressiveness). A flow-based approach can model richer value distributions and support sampling-based estimation.

Method: Apply flow matching to learn a flow-based model of the value distribution, generating samples for value estimation rather than predicting single deterministic values; integrate a flow-based objective to fit the value distribution induced by the RL task.

Result: Abstract does not report empirical results or specific performance metrics.

Conclusion: FlowCritic introduces a novel generative, flow-based framework for value estimation in RL that potentially improves reliability by capturing complex value distributions and enabling sample-based estimation.

Abstract: Reliable value estimation serves as the cornerstone of reinforcement learning
(RL) by evaluating long-term returns and guiding policy improvement,
significantly influencing the convergence speed and final performance. Existing
works improve the reliability of value function estimation via multi-critic
ensembles and distributional RL, yet the former merely combines multi point
estimation without capturing distributional information, whereas the latter
relies on discretization or quantile regression, limiting the expressiveness of
complex value distributions. Inspired by flow matching's success in generative
modeling, we propose a generative paradigm for value estimation, named
FlowCritic. Departing from conventional regression for deterministic value
prediction, FlowCritic leverages flow matching to model value distributions and
generate samples for value estimation.

</details>


### [331] [Identification of Causal Direction under an Arbitrary Number of Latent Confounders](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22711)
*Wei Chen,Linjun Peng,Zhiyi Huang,Haoyue Dai,Zhifeng Hao,Ruichu Cai,Kun Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Identifiability of causal structure with latent confounders in linear non-Gaussian models using rank properties of joint higher-order cumulants; non-iterative.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Observed variables may be influenced by multiple latent confounders; existing methods rely on strong, untestable assumptions and fail in general; need a method that handles arbitrary latent confounding.

Method: Construct a joint higher-order cumulant matrix of observed variables in a specific way; analyze rank deficiency to detect causal asymmetry; prove identifiability; non-iterative.

Result: Identifiability results established; method provides direct identification without iteration; empirical experiments show effectiveness and asymptotic correctness.

Conclusion: Introduces a cumulant-based, non-iterative approach that identifies causal direction under latent confounding in linear non-Gaussian settings and handles arbitrary numbers of latent variables; supported by experiments.

Abstract: Recovering causal structure in the presence of latent variables is an
important but challenging task. While many methods have been proposed to handle
it, most of them require strict and/or untestable assumptions on the causal
structure. In real-world scenarios, observed variables may be affected by
multiple latent variables simultaneously, which, generally speaking, cannot be
handled by these methods. In this paper, we consider the linear, non-Gaussian
case, and make use of the joint higher-order cumulant matrix of the observed
variables constructed in a specific way. We show that, surprisingly, causal
asymmetry between two observed variables can be directly seen from the rank
deficiency properties of such higher-order cumulant matrices, even in the
presence of an arbitrary number of latent confounders. Identifiability results
are established, and the corresponding identification methods do not even
involve iterative procedures. Experimental results demonstrate the
effectiveness and asymptotic correctness of our proposed method.

</details>


### [332] [S-Chain: Structured Visual Chain-of-Thought For Medicine](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22728)
*Khai Le-Duc,Duy M. H. Nguyen,Phuong T. H. Trinh,Tien-Phat Nguyen,Nghiem T. Diep,An Ngo,Tung Vu,Trinh Vuong,Anh-Tien Nguyen,Mau Nguyen,Van Trung Hoang,Khai-Nguyen Nguyen,Hy Nguyen,Chris Ngo,Anji Liu,Nhat Ho,Anne-Christin Hauschild,Khanh Xuan Nguyen,Thanh Nguyen-Tang,Pengtao Xie,Daniel Sonntag,James Zou,Mathias Niepert,Anh Totti Nguyen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces S-Chain, a large-scale multilingual medical visual reasoning dataset with 12k expert-annotated images, bounding boxes, and structured visual CoT (SV-CoT) linking regions to reasoning steps; enables benchmarking and improves grounding in medical VLMs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To achieve faithful, transparent reasoning in medical vision-language models by aligning textual rationales with precise visual evidence, addressing the lack of expert-level, stepwise and grounded datasets, while supporting multilingual VQA.

Method: Create S-Chain with 12,000 expert-annotated medical images, bounding boxes, and SV-CoT; supports 16 languages and 700k VQA pairs. Benchmark state-of-the-art medical VLMs (ExGra-Med, LLaVA-Med) and general-purpose VLMs (Qwen2.5-VL, InternVL2.5); study synergy with retrieval-augmented generation; propose a mechanism to strengthen alignment between visual evidence and reasoning.

Result: SV-CoT supervision significantly improves interpretability, grounding fidelity, and robustness of medical VLMs; demonstrates benefits across expert and general VLMs; reveals productive interactions between domain knowledge, visual grounding, and autoregressive reasoning when combined with retrieval-augmented generation; multilingual applicability via 16 languages and a 700k VQA-pair base.

Conclusion: S-Chain establishes a new benchmark for grounded medical reasoning and advances towards more trustworthy, explainable medical VLMs by enabling precise visual–rationale alignment and scalable multilingual evaluation.

Abstract: Faithful reasoning in medical vision-language models (VLMs) requires not only
accurate predictions but also transparent alignment between textual rationales
and visual evidence. While Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting has shown promise
in medical visual question answering (VQA), no large-scale expert-level dataset
has captured stepwise reasoning with precise visual grounding. We introduce
S-Chain, the first large-scale dataset of 12,000 expert-annotated medical
images with bounding boxes and structured visual CoT (SV-CoT), explicitly
linking visual regions to reasoning steps. The dataset further supports 16
languages, totaling over 700k VQA pairs for broad multilingual applicability.
Using S-Chain, we benchmark state-of-the-art medical VLMs (ExGra-Med,
LLaVA-Med) and general-purpose VLMs (Qwen2.5-VL, InternVL2.5), showing that
SV-CoT supervision significantly improves interpretability, grounding fidelity,
and robustness. Beyond benchmarking, we study its synergy with
retrieval-augmented generation, revealing how domain knowledge and visual
grounding interact during autoregressive reasoning. Finally, we propose a new
mechanism that strengthens the alignment between visual evidence and reasoning,
improving both reliability and efficiency. S-Chain establishes a new benchmark
for grounded medical reasoning and paves the way toward more trustworthy and
explainable medical VLMs.

</details>


### [333] [Centrum: Model-based Database Auto-tuning with Minimal Distributional Assumptions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22734)
*Yuanhao Lai,Pengfei Zheng,Chenpeng Ji,Yan Li,Songhan Zhang,Rutao Zhang,Zhengang Wang,Yunfei Du*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Centrum is a distribution-free, gradient-boosting ensemble–based Bayesian optimizer for DBMS auto-tuning, integrating conformal prediction to provide calibrated uncertainty and outperforming 21 state-of-the-art methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: GP-BO assumptions are widely violated in DBMS performance tuning, and while tree-ensemble BOs avoid some pitfalls, they impose unrealistic uncertainty distributions. There is a need for distribution-free, well-calibrated uncertainty and stronger surrogate models—areas where gradient boosting and conformal inference offer promise but have been underutilized in DBMS auto-tuning.

Method: A two-phase learning procedure for stochastic gradient boosting ensembles to improve point and interval estimates, combined with generalized SGBE-estimated locally adaptive conformal prediction to yield distribution-free uncertainty estimates. The approach is integrated into Bayesian optimization (Centrum), claimed to be the first auto-tuner to fuse gradient boosting ensembles with conformal inference in BO.

Result: Extensive physical and simulation experiments on two DBMSs and three workloads show Centrum outperforms 21 state-of-the-art methods.

Conclusion: Centrum achieves distribution-freeness in surrogate modeling and uncertainty estimation, enhancing the practicality of BO for DBMS auto-tuning. It is the first to fuse gradient boosting ensembles with conformal inference in BO, achieving superior tuning efficiency and effectiveness across multiple workloads.

Abstract: Gaussian-Process-based Bayesian optimization (GP-BO), is a prevailing
model-based framework for DBMS auto-tuning. However, recent work shows
GP-BO-based DBMS auto-tuners significantly outperformed auto-tuners based on
SMAC, which features random forest surrogate models; such results motivate us
to rethink and investigate the limitations of GP-BO in auto-tuner design. We
find the fundamental assumptions of GP-BO are widely violated when modeling and
optimizing DBMS performance, while tree-ensemble-BOs (e.g., SMAC) can avoid the
assumption pitfalls and deliver improved tuning efficiency and effectiveness.
Moreover, we argue that existing tree-ensemble-BOs restrict further advancement
in DBMS auto-tuning. First, existing tree-ensemble-BOs can only achieve
distribution-free point estimates, but still impose unrealistic distributional
assumptions on uncertainty estimates, compromising surrogate modeling and
distort the acquisition function. Second, recent advances in gradient boosting,
which can further enhance surrogate modeling against vanilla GP and random
forest counterparts, have rarely been applied in optimizing DBMS auto-tuners.
To address these issues, we propose a novel model-based DBMS auto-tuner,
Centrum. Centrum improves distribution-free point and interval estimation in
surrogate modeling with a two-phase learning procedure of stochastic gradient
boosting ensembles. Moreover, Centrum adopts a generalized SGBE-estimated
locally-adaptive conformal prediction to facilitate a distribution-free
uncertainty estimation and acquisition function. To our knowledge, Centrum is
the first auto-tuner to realize distribution-freeness, enhancing BO's
practicality in DBMS auto-tuning, and the first to seamlessly fuse gradient
boosting ensembles and conformal inference in BO. Extensive physical and
simulation experiments on two DBMSs and three workloads show Centrum
outperforms 21 SOTA methods.

</details>


### [334] [Distributionally Robust Optimization via Diffusion Ambiguity Modeling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22757)
*Jiaqi Wen,Jianyi Yang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces a diffusion-based ambiguity set for DRO, enabling robust yet tractable optimization; D-DRO achieves stationary convergence and better out-of-distribution generalization in ML tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: DRO requires ambiguity sets that are diverse yet consistent with the nominal distribution and yield tractable solutions. Existing sets may be limited in support or computational complexity. A diffusion-based design can expand the support to capture adversarial scenarios while remaining anchored to the nominal distribution.

Method: Design a diffusion-based ambiguity set and propose Diffusion-based DRO (D-DRO) that optimizes over a parametric diffusion model space. Develop an inner-maximization solver for the diffusion parameters, establish stationary convergence guarantees, and validate performance on ML tasks with emphasis on out-of-distribution generalization.

Result: The paper provides theoretical stationary convergence guarantees for D-DRO and demonstrates empirically that it yields superior out-of-distribution generalization in a machine learning prediction task.

Conclusion: D-DRO offers a principled, tractable DRO framework with flexible, diffusion-based ambiguity sets that can better capture adversarial distributions beyond the nominal support, improving OOD generalization; the approach shows promise for broader robustness applications.

Abstract: This paper studies Distributionally Robust Optimization (DRO), a fundamental
framework for enhancing the robustness and generalization of statistical
learning and optimization. An effective ambiguity set for DRO must involve
distributions that remain consistent with the nominal distribution while being
diverse enough to account for a variety of potential scenarios. Moreover, it
should lead to tractable DRO solutions. To this end, we propose a
diffusion-based ambiguity set design that captures various adversarial
distributions beyond the nominal support space while maintaining consistency
with the nominal distribution. Building on this ambiguity modeling, we propose
Diffusion-based DRO (D-DRO), a tractable DRO algorithm that solves the inner
maximization over the parameterized diffusion model space. We formally
establish the stationary convergence performance of D-DRO and empirically
demonstrate its superior Out-of-Distribution (OOD) generalization performance
in a ML prediction task.

</details>


### [335] [TELL-TALE: Task Efficient LLMs with Task Aware Layer Elimination](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22767)
*Omar Naim,Krish Sharma,Nicholas Asher*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: TALE prunes entire Transformer layers at inference by optimizing task-specific validation performance, achieving accuracy gains with lower compute, without retraining; benefits extend to finetuning and offers interpretability insights.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reducing the computational cost of large language models during deployment without sacrificing (or even improving) accuracy. Existing pruning often requires retraining; TALE achieves this by directly optimizing validation performance at inference time and allows task-adaptive layer removal.

Method: At inference, TALE selects and removes whole transformer layers to optimize a task-specific validation metric. It does not require retraining. The approach is evaluated on 9 tasks across 5 models (e.g., LLaMA 3.1 8B, Qwen 2.5 variants, Mistral 7B, Lucie 7B) in zero-shot and few-shot settings. It can also be applied during finetuning for extra gains.

Result: TALE consistently improves task accuracy while reducing computation across benchmarks, across zero-shot and few-shot settings. It also yields faster fine-tuning. It provides a tunable trade-off between accuracy and efficiency. Mutual information analysis identifies bottleneck layers, and removing those layers yields smaller, faster, more accurate models with interpretability insights.

Conclusion: TALE offers a practical, inference-time, no-retraining pruning mechanism that enhances accuracy and efficiency, with added benefits during finetuning and interpretability. It enables flexible control over accuracy-efficiency trade-offs and reveals which layers bottleneck task-relevant representations.

Abstract: In this paper we introduce Tale, Task-Aware Layer Elimination, an
inference-time algorithm that prunes entire transformer layers in an LLM by
directly optimizing task-specific validation performance. We evaluate TALE on 9
tasks and 5 models, including LLaMA 3.1 8B, Qwen 2.5 7B, Qwen 2.5 0.5B, Mistral
7B, and Lucie 7B, under both zero-shot and few-shot settings. Unlike prior
approaches, TALE requires no retraining and consistently improves accuracy
while reducing computational cost across all benchmarks. Furthermore, applying
TALE during finetuning leads to additional performance gains. Finally, TALE
provides flexible user control over trade-offs between accuracy and efficiency.
Mutual information analysis shows that certain layers act as bottlenecks,
degrading task-relevant representations. Tale's selective layer removal
remedies this problem, producing smaller, faster, and more accurate models that
are also faster to fine-tune while offering new insights into transformer
interpretability.

</details>


### [336] [SeeDNorm: Self-Rescaled Dynamic Normalization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22777)
*Wenrui Cai,Defa Zhu,Qingjie Liu,Qiyang Min*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SeeDNorm is a dynamic normalization layer for transformers that adapts the scaling coefficient based on the input, preserving input norm and improving performance over RMSNorm, LayerNorm, and DyT with minimal parameter overhead.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: RMSNorm discards input norm and uses a static scaling factor, which limits adaptability to varying inputs and distributional shifts, especially in zero-shot scenarios common to large language models.

Method: Introduce SeeDNorm: a data-dependent, input-aware scaling gamma that preserves input norm in the forward pass; retain dynamic gradient adjustment during backprop; provide training optimization analysis and instability mitigation; validate across large language model pre-training and supervised/unsupervised computer vision tasks with minimal parameter additions.

Result: SeeDNorm yields consistently superior performance across model sizes and tasks, outperforming RMSNorm, LayerNorm, and DyT, with negligible impact on efficiency.

Conclusion: SeeDNorm enhances model representational capacity through data-dependent normalization, offering robust performance gains with low overhead and stable training across LLM pretraining and CV tasks.

Abstract: Normalization layer constitutes an essential component in neural networks. In
transformers, the predominantly used RMSNorm constrains vectors to a unit
hypersphere, followed by dimension-wise rescaling through a learnable scaling
coefficient $\gamma$ to maintain the representational capacity of the model.
However, RMSNorm discards the input norm information in forward pass and a
static scaling factor $\gamma$ may be insufficient to accommodate the wide
variability of input data and distributional shifts, thereby limiting further
performance improvements, particularly in zero-shot scenarios that large
language models routinely encounter. To address this limitation, we propose
SeeDNorm, which enhances the representational capability of the model by
dynamically adjusting the scaling coefficient based on the current input,
thereby preserving the input norm information and enabling data-dependent,
self-rescaled dynamic normalization. During backpropagation, SeeDNorm retains
the ability of RMSNorm to dynamically adjust gradient according to the input
norm. We provide a detailed analysis of the training optimization for SeedNorm
and proposed corresponding solutions to address potential instability issues
that may arise when applying SeeDNorm. We validate the effectiveness of
SeeDNorm across models of varying sizes in large language model pre-training as
well as supervised and unsupervised computer vision tasks. By introducing a
minimal number of parameters and with neglligible impact on model efficiency,
SeeDNorm achieves consistently superior performance compared to previously
commonly used normalization layers such as RMSNorm and LayerNorm, as well as
element-wise activation alternatives to normalization layers like DyT.

</details>


### [337] [Inductive Transfer Learning for Graph-Based Recommenders](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22799)
*Florian Grötschla,Elia Trachsel,Luca A. Lanzendörfer,Roger Wattenhofer*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: NBF-Rec enables inductive transfer for graph-based recommendations by computing embeddings at inference time without retraining, achieving competitive zero-shot performance across seven real-world datasets and benefiting from lightweight fine-tuning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Transductive graph-based recommender systems limit applicability to new users, items, or datasets. There is a need for inductive transfer across disjoint domains and for avoiding retraining for each domain.

Method: NBF-Rec computes node embeddings dynamically at inference time and uses interaction-level message passing across graphs to generalize across datasets with disjoint user/item sets, enabling zero-shot transfer and lightweight fine-tuning.

Result: Evaluated on seven real-world datasets spanning movies, music, e-commerce, and location check-ins; achieves competitive performance in zero-shot settings with no target-domain data, and shows further improvements with lightweight fine-tuning.

Conclusion: Inductive transfer is feasible in graph-based recommendation. Interaction-level message passing enables cross-dataset generalization without requiring aligned users or items, and dynamic inference-time embeddings support cross-domain recommendations.

Abstract: Graph-based recommender systems are commonly trained in transductive
settings, which limits their applicability to new users, items, or datasets. We
propose NBF-Rec, a graph-based recommendation model that supports inductive
transfer learning across datasets with disjoint user and item sets. Unlike
conventional embedding-based methods that require retraining for each domain,
NBF-Rec computes node embeddings dynamically at inference time. We evaluate the
method on seven real-world datasets spanning movies, music, e-commerce, and
location check-ins. NBF-Rec achieves competitive performance in zero-shot
settings, where no target domain data is used for training, and demonstrates
further improvements through lightweight fine-tuning. These results show that
inductive transfer is feasible in graph-based recommendation and that
interaction-level message passing supports generalization across datasets
without requiring aligned users or items.

</details>


### [338] [A Theory of the Mechanics of Information: Generalization Through Measurement of Uncertainty (Learning is Measuring)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22809)
*Christopher J. Hazard,Michael Resnick,Jacob Beel,Jack Xia,Cade Mack,Dominic Glennie,Matthew Fulp,David Maze,Andrew Bassett,Martin Koistinen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A model-free, surprisal-based information-theoretic framework for learning and inference directly from raw data that avoids explicit distribution modeling, emphasizes interpretability and updatability, and delivers competitive performance across diverse tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Traditional ML relies on explicit models and domain assumptions, which can limit flexibility, interpretability, and safe data updates. There is a need for a universal, transparent framework that supports traceable decision making and easy edits/deletions of training data.

Method: Use surprisal (information-theoretic uncertainty) to quantify relevance and drive inferences directly from raw data, without modeling data distributions. The approach enables generative inference, causal discovery, anomaly detection, and time-series forecasting, emphasizes traceability and interpretability, and yields a unified information-physics perspective applicable to missing data.

Result: Achieves at or near state-of-the-art performance across common ML tasks, with strong generalization across tasks. Demonstrates efficient updates, including edits and deletion of training data, and broad applicability to various data types. Empirical results support the viability of a model-free alternative to neural networks while preserving human-understandable mechanics.

Conclusion: Proposes a unified, human-understandable ML framework based on information surprisal that can serve as a scalable alternative to neural networks, maintaining interpretability and applicability to diverse data types, including missing data.

Abstract: Traditional machine learning relies on explicit models and domain
assumptions, limiting flexibility and interpretability. We introduce a
model-free framework using surprisal (information theoretic uncertainty) to
directly analyze and perform inferences from raw data, eliminating distribution
modeling, reducing bias, and enabling efficient updates including direct edits
and deletion of training data. By quantifying relevance through uncertainty,
the approach enables generalizable inference across tasks including generative
inference, causal discovery, anomaly detection, and time series forecasting. It
emphasizes traceability, interpretability, and data-driven decision making,
offering a unified, human-understandable framework for machine learning, and
achieves at or near state-of-the-art performance across most common machine
learning tasks. The mathematical foundations create a ``physics'' of
information, which enable these techniques to apply effectively to a wide
variety of complex data types, including missing data. Empirical results
indicate that this may be a viable alternative path to neural networks with
regard to scalable machine learning and artificial intelligence that can
maintain human understandability of the underlying mechanics.

</details>


### [339] [Distributed Multi-Agent Bandits Over Erdős-Rényi Random Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22811)
*Jingyuan Liu,Hao Qiu,Lin Yang,Mengfan Xu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A distributed algorithm for heterogeneous rewards in multi-agent MAB over time-varying Erdős–Rényi networks achieves logarithmic regret, with an interpretable extra term capturing network connectivity and communication probability; establishes a lower bound and validates scaling via experiments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address distributed learning with multiple agents, where rewards vary by agent and communication graphs are random and time-varying; there is a need to understand how network connectivity and communication affect regret and to design a fully distributed, scalable algorithm.

Method: Combine an arm-elimination strategy with a random gossip protocol to operate in a fully distributed manner over the evolving random graph. The analysis derives a regret upper bound of order log T that decomposes into the centralized optimal term plus network- and graph-dependent overhead terms; a nearly optimal lower bound is also established.

Result: Regret upper bound of order log T, matching the centralized term plus additional terms O(N^2 log T / (p lambda_{N-1}(Lap(G))) + KN^2 log T / p). The extra terms quantify the impact of graph connectivity (via Laplacian eigenvalue) and link probability p. A nearly optimal regret lower bound is shown. Numerical experiments demonstrate superior performance and confirm the theoretical scaling.

Conclusion: There is a fundamental trade-off between communication efficiency and regret: higher connectivity and link probability reduce regret overhead, while the proposed distributed algorithm achieves near-optimal regret scaling in this challenging heterogeneous, time-varying-network setting. The approach outperforms benchmarks and validates the theoretical insights.

Abstract: We study the distributed multi-agent multi-armed bandit problem with
heterogeneous rewards over random communication graphs. Uniquely, at each time
step $t$ agents communicate over a time-varying random graph $G_t$ generated by
applying the Erd\H{o}s-R\'enyi model to a fixed connected base graph $G$ (for
classical Erd\H{o}s-R\'enyi graphs, $G$ is a complete graph), where each
potential edge in $G$ is randomly and independently present with the link
probability $p$. Notably, the resulting random graph is not necessarily
connected at each time step. Each agent's arm rewards follow time-invariant
distributions, and the reward distribution for the same arm may differ across
agents. The goal is to minimize the cumulative expected regret relative to the
global mean reward of each arm, defined as the average of that arm's mean
rewards across all agents. To this end, we propose a fully distributed
algorithm that integrates the arm elimination strategy with the random gossip
algorithm. We theoretically show that the regret upper bound is of order $\log
T$ and is highly interpretable, where $T$ is the time horizon. It includes the
optimal centralized regret $O\left(\sum_{k: \Delta_k>0} \frac{\log
T}{\Delta_k}\right)$ and an additional term $O\left(\frac{N^2 \log T}{p
\lambda_{N-1}(Lap(G))} + \frac{KN^2 \log T}{p}\right)$ where $N$ and $K$ denote
the total number of agents and arms, respectively. This term reflects the
impact of $G$'s algebraic connectivity $\lambda_{N-1}(Lap(G))$ and the link
probability $p$, and thus highlights a fundamental trade-off between
communication efficiency and regret. As a by-product, we show a nearly optimal
regret lower bound. Finally, our numerical experiments not only show the
superiority of our algorithm over existing benchmarks, but also validate the
theoretical regret scaling with problem complexity.

</details>


### [340] [Air Quality Prediction Using LOESS-ARIMA and Multi-Scale CNN-BiLSTM with Residual-Gated Attention](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22818)
*Soham Pahari,Sandeep Chand Kumain*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A robust hybrid LOESS-ARIMA-CNN-BiLSTM framework for AQI forecasting in Indian megacities, achieving 5-8% lower MSE and R^2 > 0.94 across PM2.5, O3, CO, and NOx.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Air pollution in megacities shows linear trends, seasonal cycles, and nonlinear volatility; accurate AQI forecasting is essential for timely interventions.

Method: Decompose AQI with LOESS into trend, seasonal, and residuals; model trend/seasonal with ARIMA; capture residual volatility with a multi-scale CNN-BiLSTM network using a residual-gated attention mechanism; tune hyperparameters with Unified Adaptive Multi-Stage Metaheuristic Optimizer (UAMMO); evaluate on 2021-2023 CPCB AQI data for Delhi, Kolkata, Mumbai across PM2.5, O3, CO, NOx.

Result: The proposed hybrid framework outperforms statistical, deep learning, and other hybrid baselines across pollutants and cities, achieving 5-8% lower MSE and R^2 > 0.94 for all pollutants.

Conclusion: The framework is robust and sensitive to sudden pollution events, and is applicable to urban air quality management in megacities.

Abstract: Air pollution remains a critical environmental and public health concern in
Indian megacities such as Delhi, Kolkata, and Mumbai, where sudden spikes in
pollutant levels challenge timely intervention. Accurate Air Quality Index
(AQI) forecasting is difficult due to the coexistence of linear trends,
seasonal variations, and volatile nonlinear patterns. This paper proposes a
hybrid forecasting framework that integrates LOESS decomposition, ARIMA
modeling, and a multi-scale CNN-BiLSTM network with a residual-gated attention
mechanism. The LOESS step separates the AQI series into trend, seasonal, and
residual components, with ARIMA modeling the smooth components and the proposed
deep learning module capturing multi-scale volatility in the residuals. Model
hyperparameters are tuned via the Unified Adaptive Multi-Stage Metaheuristic
Optimizer (UAMMO), combining multiple optimization strategies for efficient
convergence. Experiments on 2021-2023 AQI datasets from the Central Pollution
Control Board show that the proposed method consistently outperforms
statistical, deep learning, and hybrid baselines across PM2.5, O3, CO, and NOx
in three major cities, achieving up to 5-8% lower MSE and higher R^2 scores
(>0.94) for all pollutants. These results demonstrate the framework's
robustness, sensitivity to sudden pollution events, and applicability to urban
air quality management.

</details>


### [341] [Last Iterate Analyses of FTRL in Stochasitc Bandits](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22819)
*Jingxin Zhan,Yuze Han,Zhihua Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: The paper analyzes last-iterate convergence for FTRL-based bandit algorithms with Best-of-Both-Worlds property, showing a t^{-1/2} decay in the Bregman divergence from the optimal arm distribution to the current distribution.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how last-iterate (simple regret) convergence behaves in bandits under FTRL with BOBW, bridging regret guarantees (logarithmic regret in stochastic settings) with actual decision evolution.

Method: Theoretical analysis of Bregman divergence defined by Psi(p) = -4 sum sqrt(p_i) for the 1/2-Tsallis-INF BOBW-FTRL algorithm; derive decay rate of divergence between the optimal-arm point mass and the current distribution.

Result: Bregman divergence decays at rate t^{-1/2} over iterations.

Conclusion: Supports a partial alignment with the intuition that low regret relates to fast last-iterate convergence, but the rate is t^{-1/2} (not t^{-1}) for the divergence; motivates further study on last-iterate rates for bandit FTRL.

Abstract: The convergence analysis of online learning algorithms is central to machine
learning theory, where last-iterate convergence is particularly important, as
it captures the learner's actual decisions and describes the evolution of the
learning process over time. However, in multi-armed bandits, most existing
algorithmic analyses mainly focus on the order of regret, while the
last-iterate (simple regret) convergence rate remains less explored --
especially for the widely studied Follow-the-Regularized-Leader (FTRL)
algorithms. Recently, a growing line of work has established the
Best-of-Both-Worlds (BOBW) property of FTRL algorithms in bandit problems,
showing in particular that they achieve logarithmic regret in stochastic
bandits. Nevertheless, their last-iterate convergence rate has not yet been
studied. Intuitively, logarithmic regret should correspond to a $t^{-1}$
last-iterate convergence rate. This paper partially confirms this intuition
through theoretical analysis, showing that the Bregman divergence, defined by
the regular function $\Psi(p)=-4\sum_{i=1}^{d}\sqrt{p_i}$ associated with the
BOBW FTRL algorithm $1/2$-Tsallis-INF (arXiv:1807.07623), between the point
mass on the optimal arm and the probability distribution over the arm set
obtained at iteration $t$, decays at a rate of $t^{-1/2}$.

</details>


### [342] [Logical GANs: Adversarial Learning through Ehrenfeucht Fraisse Games](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22824)
*Mirco A. Mannucci*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LOGAN applies depth-k EF game-style constraints to GANs, bounding the discriminator and guiding the generator to produce verifiable samples with interpretable failures, showing strong simulation and real-training gains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To reconcile GAN indistinguishability with verifiable, interpretable generation under a bounded logical observer by using logic-based verification and a controllable depth budget.

Method: Replace the standard discriminator with a depth-k Ehrenfeucht–Fraïssé (EF) Opponent that seeks small, legible faults; the generator acts as a Builder producing samples that admit a k-round matching to a target theory T. Provide an EF-probe simulator and MSO-style graph checkers; introduce a logical loss combining budgeted EF resilience with certificate terms; four experiments including real PyTorch training; a curriculum on depth for learning control.

Result: Simulation validation reports 92%-98% property satisfaction (Exp.3); real neural GAN training shows 5%-14% improvements on challenging properties and 98% connectivity satisfaction (via matching simulation) through adversarial learning (Exp.4). LOGAN is compact, reproducible, and provides dials for depth-controlled generation with interpretable failures and demonstrated effectiveness in both simulated and real settings.

Conclusion: LOGAN offers a practical path toward logic-bounded generation with interpretable failure modes, validated by simulations and real training, and provides controllable tools for property-based verification in GANs.

Abstract: GANs promise indistinguishability, logic explains it. We put the two on a
budget: a discriminator that can only ``see'' up to a logical depth $k$, and a
generator that must look correct to that bounded observer. \textbf{LOGAN}
(LOGical GANs) casts the discriminator as a depth-$k$ Ehrenfeucht--Fra\"iss\'e
(EF) \emph{Opponent} that searches for small, legible faults (odd cycles,
nonplanar crossings, directed bridges), while the generator plays
\emph{Builder}, producing samples that admit a $k$-round matching to a target
theory $T$. We ship a minimal toolkit -- an EF-probe simulator and MSO-style
graph checkers -- and four experiments including real neural GAN training with
PyTorch. Beyond verification, we score samples with a \emph{logical loss} that
mixes budgeted EF round-resilience with cheap certificate terms, enabling a
practical curriculum on depth. Framework validation demonstrates $92\%$--$98\%$
property satisfaction via simulation (Exp.~3), while real neural GAN training
achieves $5\%$--$14\%$ improvements on challenging properties and $98\%$
satisfaction on connectivity (matching simulation) through adversarial learning
(Exp.~4). LOGAN is a compact, reproducible path toward logic-bounded generation
with interpretable failures, proven effectiveness (both simulated and real
training), and dials for control.

</details>


### [343] [Clustering by Denoising: Latent plug-and-play diffusion for single-cell data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22835)
*Dominik Meier,Shixing Yu,Sagnik Nandy,Promit Ghosal,Kyra Gan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A diffusion-based latent-space denoising framework with input-space steering via Gibbs sampling improves scRNA-seq clustering and uncertainty estimation, with better alignment to cell types.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Clustering scRNA-seq is hampered by measurement noise and biological variability; standard latent spaces can mix cell types, reducing clustering accuracy. There is a need for denoising that preserves data structure, provides uncertainty estimates, and generalizes from clean reference data.

Method: A plug-and-play diffusion approach that separates observation and denoising spaces. Uses a Gibbs sampling procedure where the learned diffusion prior acts in a low-dimensional latent space to denoise, while reintroducing noise into the high-dimensional observation space (input-space steering). Features adaptive noise balance between prior and data, principled uncertainty estimates for downstream analysis, and leverages clean reference data (and averaging) to improve denoising beyond training data.

Result: On synthetic data, clustering accuracy improves across varied noise levels and dataset shifts. On real scRNA-seq data, clustering shows greater biological coherence, with boundaries aligning better to known cell-type markers and developmental trajectories.

Conclusion: The approach delivers adaptive noise handling, principled uncertainty quantification, and generalizable denoising by leveraging clean references and averaging, yielding more accurate and biologically coherent cell-type clusters in noisy single-cell data.

Abstract: Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) enables the study of cellular
heterogeneity. Yet, clustering accuracy, and with it downstream analyses based
on cell labels, remain challenging due to measurement noise and biological
variability. In standard latent spaces (e.g., obtained through PCA), data from
different cell types can be projected close together, making accurate
clustering difficult. We introduce a latent plug-and-play diffusion framework
that separates the observation and denoising space. This separation is
operationalized through a novel Gibbs sampling procedure: the learned diffusion
prior is applied in a low-dimensional latent space to perform denoising, while
to steer this process, noise is reintroduced into the original high-dimensional
observation space. This unique "input-space steering" ensures the denoising
trajectory remains faithful to the original data structure. Our approach offers
three key advantages: (1) adaptive noise handling via a tunable balance between
prior and observed data; (2) uncertainty quantification through principled
uncertainty estimates for downstream analysis; and (3) generalizable denoising
by leveraging clean reference data to denoise noisier datasets, and via
averaging, improve quality beyond the training set. We evaluate robustness on
both synthetic and real single-cell genomics data. Our method improves
clustering accuracy on synthetic data across varied noise levels and dataset
shifts. On real-world single-cell data, our method demonstrates improved
biological coherence in the resulting cell clusters, with cluster boundaries
that better align with known cell type markers and developmental trajectories.

</details>


### [344] [Self-induced stochastic resonance: A physics-informed machine learning approach](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22848)
*Divyesh Savaliya,Marius E. Yamakou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A physics-informed neural network model predicts self-induced stochastic resonance (SISR) in the stochastic FitzHugh-Nagumo neuron by embedding SDE dynamics and Kramers-based barrier constraints, yielding accurate, data-efficient predictions of spike-coherence versus noise, excitability, and timescale separation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the challenge of understanding and predicting noise-induced coherence in multiscale stochastic systems, providing an interpretable and data-efficient surrogate model for SISR.

Method: A Physics-Informed Neural Network (PINN) with a Noise-Augmented State Predictor architecture that integrates the stochastic differential equations, SISR-specific timescale-matching constraints, and barrier-based constraints from Kramers' escape theory into a composite loss: data fidelity, dynamical residuals, and barrier constraints.

Result: The trained PINN reproduces how spike-train coherence depends on noise intensity, excitability, and timescale separation, closely matching direct stochastic simulations with greater accuracy and generalization than pure data-driven methods, while reducing computational cost.

Conclusion: The framework yields a data-efficient, interpretable surrogate for simulating and analyzing noise-induced coherence in multiscale stochastic systems, enabling robust modeling of SISR without external forcing.

Abstract: Self-induced stochastic resonance (SISR) is the emergence of coherent
oscillations in slow-fast excitable systems driven solely by noise, without
external periodic forcing or proximity to a bifurcation. This work presents a
physics-informed machine learning framework for modeling and predicting SISR in
the stochastic FitzHugh-Nagumo neuron. We embed the governing stochastic
differential equations and SISR-asymptotic timescale-matching constraints
directly into a Physics-Informed Neural Network (PINN) based on a
Noise-Augmented State Predictor architecture. The composite loss integrates
data fidelity, dynamical residuals, and barrier-based physical constraints
derived from Kramers' escape theory. The trained PINN accurately predicts the
dependence of spike-train coherence on noise intensity, excitability, and
timescale separation, matching results from direct stochastic simulations with
substantial improvements in accuracy and generalization compared with purely
data-driven methods, while requiring significantly less computation. The
framework provides a data-efficient and interpretable surrogate model for
simulating and analyzing noise-induced coherence in multiscale stochastic
systems.

</details>


### [345] [Encoder-Decoder Diffusion Language Models for Efficient Training and Inference](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22852)
*Marianne Arriola,Yair Schiff,Hao Phung,Aaron Gokaslan,Volodymyr Kuleshov*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes Efficient Encoder-Decoder Diffusion (E2D2) for discrete diffusion models to accelerate inference by decoupling clean-token representation from denoising, using an encoder for clean tokens and a lightweight decoder for iterative refinement. Extends to block diffusion for better training and faster inference, achieving better quality-throughput trade-offs on summarization, translation, and math reasoning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce computation and improve inference speed of discrete diffusion models by separating the tasks of representing clean tokens and denoising corrupted tokens; enable faster training and inference for block diffusion and diffusion-language-model-like tasks.

Method: Introduce an encoder-decoder architecture for discrete diffusion (E2D2): an encoder represents clean tokens while a lightweight decoder iteratively refines a noised sequence; develop specialized training and sampling algorithms; apply block diffusion to partition sequences for better quality; provide training-time and inference-time optimizations.

Result: Demonstrates superior trade-offs between generation quality and inference throughput on tasks including summarization, translation, and mathematical reasoning; shows faster generation with competitive quality and scalable training/architecture; provides code and model weights.

Conclusion: E2D2 offers an efficient, scalable encoder-decoder diffusion framework that decouples clean-token representation from denoising, enabling faster inference and training for discrete diffusion models and related diffusion-language tasks.

Abstract: Discrete diffusion models enable parallel token sampling for faster inference
than autoregressive approaches. However, prior diffusion models use a
decoder-only architecture, which requires sampling algorithms that invoke the
full network at every denoising step and incur high computational cost. Our key
insight is that discrete diffusion models perform two types of computation: 1)
representing clean tokens and 2) denoising corrupted tokens, which enables us
to use separate modules for each task. We propose an encoder-decoder
architecture to accelerate discrete diffusion inference, which relies on an
encoder to represent clean tokens and a lightweight decoder to iteratively
refine a noised sequence. We also show that this architecture enables faster
training of block diffusion models, which partition sequences into blocks for
better quality and are commonly used in diffusion language model inference. We
introduce a framework for Efficient Encoder-Decoder Diffusion (E2D2),
consisting of an architecture with specialized training and sampling
algorithms, and we show that E2D2 achieves superior trade-offs between
generation quality and inference throughput on summarization, translation, and
mathematical reasoning tasks. We provide the code, model weights, and blog post
