on the project page: https://m-arriola.com/e2d2

</details>


### [346] [A Review of End-to-End Precipitation Prediction Using Remote Sensing Data: from Divination to Machine Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22855)
*Yugong Zeng,Jonathan Wu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A historical survey of precipitation forecasting tracing its evolution from divination and empirical methods to modern numerical weather prediction (NWP) and AI-based end-to-end models, emphasizing neural networks, interpretability, and hybrid physics–data approaches, with future directions for next-generation forecasting systems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To synthesize the evolution of precipitation forecasting across historical, physical, statistical, and AI-driven paradigms, and to identify enduring challenges and future research directions.

Method: Comprehensive literature survey spanning traditional/indigenous forecasting, physical modeling, statistical frameworks, NWP developments, and ML/DL approaches, including automated DL, interpretability-driven design, and hybrid physics–data models.

Result: A cohesive historical and methodological map of precipitation forecasting, highlighting milestones, current state-of-the-art ML-based end-to-end approaches, interpretability considerations, and hybrid models, along with identified gaps and future research directions.

Conclusion: End-to-end precipitation forecasting has evolved through multiple eras; future work should advance interpretability, physics-guided ML, automated model discovery, and seamless integration of ML with operational forecasting systems.

Abstract: Precipitation prediction has undergone a profound transformation -- from
early symbolic and empirical methods rooted in divination and observation, to
modern technologies based on atmospheric physics and artificial intelligence.
This review traces the historical and technological evolution of precipitation
forecasting, presenting a survey about end-to-end precipitation prediction
technologies that spans ancient practices, the foundations of meteorological
science, the rise of numerical weather prediction (NWP), and the emergence of
machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models. We first explore
traditional and indigenous forecasting methods, then describe the development
of physical modeling and statistical frameworks that underpin contemporary
operational forecasting. Particular emphasis is placed on recent advances in
neural network-based approaches, including automated deep learning,
interpretability-driven design, and hybrid physical-data models. By compositing
research across multiple eras and paradigms, this review not only depicts the
history of end-to-end precipitation prediction but also outlines future
directions in next generation forecasting systems.

</details>


### [347] [Guardian: Decoupling Exploration from Safety in Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22859)
*Kaitong Cai,Jusheng Zhang,Jing Yang,Keze Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: RLPD-GX decouples exploration and safety in hybrid offline-online RL, using a reward-seeking learner with a projection-based guardian and dynamic curricula to stabilize training; it converges under a guarded Bellman operator and achieves state-of-the-art Atari-100k performance with strong safety and stability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Hybrid offline-online RL suffers from distribution shift between offline and online data, leading to instability. There is a need to preserve online exploration while ensuring safe, reliable value backups and policy execution.

Method: Introduce RLPD-GX: a reward-seeking learner that explores freely paired with a projection-based guardian that enforces safety and safe backups. Use dynamic curricula to extend planning horizons and anneal offline-online data mixing. Prove convergence via a contraction property of the guarded Bellman operator.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on Atari-100k, with a normalized mean score of 3.02, about 45% higher than prior hybrid methods, along with stronger safety and stability. Ablations show gains across safety-critical and long-horizon tasks.

Conclusion: Decoupled safety enforcement offers a simple yet principled pathway to robust O2O RL, suggesting a general paradigm for reconciling exploration and safety in reinforcement learning.

Abstract: Hybrid offline--online reinforcement learning (O2O RL) promises both sample
efficiency and robust exploration, but suffers from instability due to
distribution shift between offline and online data. We introduce RLPD-GX, a
framework that decouples policy optimization from safety enforcement: a
reward-seeking learner explores freely, while a projection-based guardian
guarantees rule-consistent execution and safe value backups. This design
preserves the exploratory value of online interactions without collapsing to
conservative policies. To further stabilize training, we propose dynamic
curricula that gradually extend temporal horizons and anneal offline--online
data mixing. We prove convergence via a contraction property of the guarded
Bellman operator, and empirically show state-of-the-art performance on
Atari-100k, achieving a normalized mean score of 3.02 (+45\% over prior hybrid
methods) with stronger safety and stability. Beyond Atari, ablations
demonstrate consistent gains across safety-critical and long-horizon tasks,
underscoring the generality of our design. Extensive and comprehensive results
highlight decoupled safety enforcement as a simple yet principled route to
robust O2O RL, suggesting a broader paradigm for reconciling exploration and
safety in reinforcement learning.

</details>


### [348] [Long-Term PM2.5 Forecasting Using a DTW-Enhanced CNN-GRU Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22863)
*Amirali Ataee Naeini,Arshia Ataee Naeini,Fatemeh Karami Mohammadi,Omid Ghaffarpasand*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A DTW-guided, lightweight CNN-GRU framework enables stable long-horizon PM2.5 forecasting in sparse networks, achieving 0.91 R2 at 24h and 0.73 R2 at 240h, outperforming DL baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the challenge of maintaining forecast accuracy beyond 48 hours in cities with sparse monitoring networks and limited computational resources, enabling reliable PM2.5 early warnings in Isfahan, Iran.

Method: DTW-based historical sampling to identify similar pollution patterns across peer stations; a lightweight CNN-GRU architecture augmented with meteorological features; scalable design tailored for sparse networks; uses multi-year hourly data from eight stations; avoids transformers and external simulation tools.

Result: Achieves R^2 of 0.91 for 24-hour forecasts and 0.73 at 240 hours (10 days); demonstrates stable long-horizon PM2.5 forecasting without degradation and outperforms state-of-the-art deep learning methods; computationally efficient.

Conclusion: The framework is computationally efficient and independent from external tools, making it suitable for deployment in resource-constrained urban environments and for long-horizon PM2.5 early-warning systems.

Abstract: Reliable long-term forecasting of PM2.5 concentrations is critical for public
health early-warning systems, yet existing deep learning approaches struggle to
maintain prediction stability beyond 48 hours, especially in cities with sparse
monitoring networks. This paper presents a deep learning framework that
combines Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) for intelligent station similarity
selection with a CNN-GRU architecture to enable extended-horizon PM2.5
forecasting in Isfahan, Iran, a city characterized by complex pollution
dynamics and limited monitoring coverage. Unlike existing approaches that rely
on computationally intensive transformer models or external simulation tools,
our method integrates three key innovations: (i) DTW-based historical sampling
to identify similar pollution patterns across peer stations, (ii) a lightweight
CNN-GRU architecture augmented with meteorological features, and (iii) a
scalable design optimized for sparse networks. Experimental validation using
multi-year hourly data from eight monitoring stations demonstrates superior
performance compared to state-of-the-art deep learning methods, achieving R2 =
0.91 for 24-hour forecasts. Notably, this is the first study to demonstrate
stable 10-day PM2.5 forecasting (R2 = 0.73 at 240 hours) without performance
degradation, addressing critical early-warning system requirements. The
framework's computational efficiency and independence from external tools make
it particularly suitable for deployment in resource-constrained urban
environments.

</details>


### [349] [Limits of Generative Pre-Training in Structured EMR Trajectories with Irregular Sampling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22878)
*Nicholas I-Hsien Kuo,Blanca Gallego,Louisa Jorm*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Autoregressive patient-trajectory pre-training yields local realism but not cross-feature coherence; need domain-specific evaluation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Assess whether foundation-model-like pre-training on longitudinal health data yields clinically coherent representations, given risks of superficially realistic but incoherent embeddings.

Method: Train two autoregressive models (sequence-to-sequence LSTM and a reduced Transformer) on longitudinal ART datasets for HIV and Acute Hypotension; inject random inter-visit gaps to simulate irregular sampling during training; test sequences are complete; evaluate both distributional and correlational fidelity of synthesized trajectories.

Result: Models reproduce feature distributions but fail to preserve cross-feature correlations, indicating limited clinical coherence despite local realism; trajectory synthesis exposes this mismatch.

Conclusion: Domain-specific evaluation is essential for health trajectory models; trajectory-synthesis testing can be a practical probe before fine-tuning or deployment.

Abstract: Foundation models refer to architectures trained on vast datasets using
autoregressive pre-training from natural language processing to capture
intricate patterns and motifs. They were originally developed to transfer such
learned knowledge to downstream predictive tasks. Recently, however, some
studies repurpose these learned representations for phenotype discovery without
rigorous validation, risking superficially realistic but clinically incoherent
embeddings. To test this mismatch, we trained two autoregressive models -- a
sequence-to-sequence LSTM and a reduced Transformer -- on longitudinal ART for
HIV and Acute Hypotension datasets. Controlled irregularity was added during
training via random inter-visit gaps, while test sequences stayed complete.
Patient-trajectory synthesis evaluated distributional and correlational
fidelity. Both reproduced feature distributions but failed to preserve
cross-feature structure -- showing that generative pre-training yields local
realism but limited clinical coherence. These results highlight the need for
domain-specific evaluation and support trajectory synthesis as a practical
probe before fine-tuning or deployment.

</details>


### [350] [Learning Reconfigurable Representations for Multimodal Federated Learning with Missing Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22880)
*Duong M. Nguyen,Trong Nghia Hoang,Thanh Trung Huynh,Quoc Viet Hung Nguyen,Phi Le Nguyen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a federated learning framework for multimodal data with heterogeneous modalities and missing features by using learnable client-side embedding controls that encode data-missing patterns to align the global representation with local contexts. Embeddings can be aggregated across clients with similar missingness patterns to improve robustness. Shows up to 36.45% improvement under severe incompleteness with theoretical performance bounds and public code.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In real-world multimodal FL, clients have incomplete and heterogeneous data leading to misaligned local representations and poor aggregation. Existing work often assumes either different modality sets without missing inputs or a shared modality set with missing features, which is unrealistic. A general setting with per-client modality subsets and per-modality feature missingness motivates a new approach.

Method: Introduce locally adaptive representations via learnable client-side embedding controls that encode each client's data-missing patterns. These embeddings act as reconfiguration signals to align the globally aggregated representation with each client's local context. Embedding controls can be algorithmically aggregated across clients with similar data-missing patterns to reinforce robust reconfiguration signals and improve the global representation.

Result: Empirical results on multiple federated multimodal benchmarks with diverse data-missing patterns show significant gains, up to 36.45% improvement under severe data incompleteness. A theoretical analysis provides an explicit performance bound that matches the empirical observations.

Conclusion: The framework effectively mitigates representation misalignment in real-world FL with heterogeneous modalities and missing features. It introduces a scalable approach that leverages per-client missingness patterns and aggregation of embedding controls, backed by theoretical guarantees and public code.

Abstract: Multimodal federated learning in real-world settings often encounters
incomplete and heterogeneous data across clients. This results in misaligned
local feature representations that limit the effectiveness of model
aggregation. Unlike prior work that assumes either differing modality sets
without missing input features or a shared modality set with missing features
across clients, we consider a more general and realistic setting where each
client observes a different subset of modalities and might also have missing
input features within each modality. To address the resulting misalignment in
learned representations, we propose a new federated learning framework
featuring locally adaptive representations based on learnable client-side
embedding controls that encode each client's data-missing patterns.
  These embeddings serve as reconfiguration signals that align the globally
aggregated representation with each client's local context, enabling more
effective use of shared information. Furthermore, the embedding controls can be
algorithmically aggregated across clients with similar data-missing patterns to
enhance the robustness of reconfiguration signals in adapting the global
representation. Empirical results on multiple federated multimodal benchmarks
with diverse data-missing patterns across clients demonstrate the efficacy of
the proposed method, achieving up to 36.45\% performance improvement under
severe data incompleteness. The method is also supported by a theoretical
analysis with an explicit performance bound that matches our empirical
observations. Our source codes are provided at
https://github.com/nmduonggg/PEPSY

</details>


### [351] [Offline Preference Optimization via Maximum Marginal Likelihood Estimation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22881)
*Saeed Najafi,Alona Fyshe*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A simpler, stable preference alignment method MMPO that uses maximum marginal likelihood to optimize preferred outputs without an explicit reward model or entropy term, achieving competitive alignment while preserving base LM capabilities.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: RLHF-based alignment is complex and unstable; there is a need for a more tractable, stable approach that preserves general language skills.

Method: Formulate preference optimization as maximizing the marginal log-likelihood of preferred outputs using preference pairs as samples for approximation; forgoes an explicit reward model and entropy maximization; theoretically shows MMPO yields a weighted gradient that up-weights chosen responses; empirically evaluated from 135M to 8B parameter models across ablations.

Result: MMPO is more stable with respect to the hyperparameter beta than baselines; achieves competitive or superior preference alignment while better preserving the base model's general language capabilities; ablations indicate improvements arise from MMPO's implicit preference optimization within gradient updates.

Conclusion: MMPO offers a simple, effective alternative to RLHF by implicitly optimizing preferences via marginal likelihood, providing stability and strong alignment while maintaining base model quality.

Abstract: Aligning Large Language Models (LLMs) with human preferences is crucial, but
standard methods like Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) are
often complex and unstable. In this work, we propose a new, simpler approach
that recasts alignment through the lens of Maximum Marginal Likelihood (MML)
estimation. Our new MML based Preference Optimization (MMPO) maximizes the
marginal log-likelihood of a preferred text output, using the preference pair
as samples for approximation, and forgoes the need for both an explicit reward
model and entropy maximization. We theoretically demonstrate that MMPO
implicitly performs preference optimization, producing a weighted gradient that
naturally up-weights chosen responses over rejected ones. Across models ranging
from 135M to 8B parameters, we empirically show that MMPO: 1) is more stable
with respect to the hyperparameter $\beta$ compared to alternative baselines,
and 2) achieves competitive or superior preference alignment while better
preserving the base model's general language capabilities. Through a series of
ablation experiments, we show that this improved performance is indeed
attributable to MMPO's implicit preference optimization within the gradient
updates.

</details>


### [352] [AI based signage classification for linguistic landscape studies](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22885)
*Yuqin Jiang,Song Jiang,Jacob Algrim,Trevor Harms,Maxwell Koenen,Xinya Lan,Xingyu Li,Chun-Han Lin,Jia Liu,Jiayang Sun,Henry Zenger*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: AI-assisted linguistic landscape analysis using OCR achieved 79% accuracy on a 1,449-image dataset of Honolulu's Chinatown; shows potential to automate LL studies but notable mislabeling issues require human validation; recommends a hybrid AI-human workflow.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To automate linguistic landscape analysis by leveraging AI-powered OCR and language classification to reduce manual data collection and annotation effort, enabling larger-scale studies.

Method: Constructed a georeferenced photo dataset of 1,449 images in Honolulu Chinatown; applied AI OCR and language classification; performed manual validation; identified common mislabeling types and observed how AI processes peripheral text.

Result: Overall accuracy of 79%; five recurring mislabeling types: distortion, reflection, degraded surface, graffiti, and hallucination; AI tends to label peripheral/background text; hybrid workflow recommended due to limitations.

Conclusion: AI can augment LL research but cannot be fully trusted; advocate integrating AI automation with human validation for reliable and efficient LL analysis.

Abstract: Linguistic Landscape (LL) research traditionally relies on manual photography
and annotation of public signages to examine distribution of languages in urban
space. While such methods yield valuable findings, the process is
time-consuming and difficult for large study areas. This study explores the use
of AI powered language detection method to automate LL analysis. Using Honolulu
Chinatown as a case study, we constructed a georeferenced photo dataset of
1,449 images collected by researchers and applied AI for optical character
recognition (OCR) and language classification. We also conducted manual
validations for accuracy checking. This model achieved an overall accuracy of
79%. Five recurring types of mislabeling were identified, including distortion,
reflection, degraded surface, graffiti, and hallucination. The analysis also
reveals that the AI model treats all regions of an image equally, detecting
peripheral or background texts that human interpreters typically ignore.
Despite these limitations, the results demonstrate the potential of integrating
AI-assisted workflows into LL research to reduce such time-consuming processes.
However, due to all the limitations and mis-labels, we recognize that AI cannot
be fully trusted during this process. This paper encourages a hybrid approach
combining AI automation with human validation for a more reliable and efficient
workflow.

</details>


### [353] [Transforming volcanic monitoring: A dataset and benchmark for onboard volcano activity detection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22889)
*Darshana Priyasad,Tharindu Fernando,Maryam Haghighat,Harshala Gammulle,Clinton Fookes*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A volcanic activity dataset with binary anomaly annotations, benchmarks on state-of-the-art models, and an onboard detection demonstration using Movidius Myriad X for near-real-time satellite monitoring.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Natural disasters cause significant losses; lack of annotated volcanic datasets hinders robust detection; small-satellite constellations enable near-real-time monitoring and onboard processing; enabling onboard detection can reduce latency for early warning.

Method: Create a diverse volcanic activity dataset with binary annotations (temperature anomalies, eruptions, ash emissions); benchmark state-of-the-art models for detection; test onboard feasibility by deploying models on Intel Movidius Myriad X VPU.

Result: Provided baselines for volcanic anomaly detection; demonstrated onboard feasibility with reduced latency on Movidius Myriad X, enabling faster responses.

Conclusion: The dataset fills a critical gap in volcanic monitoring research; supports development of robust detection models and practical onboard processing for early warning systems; encourages further research into onboard monitoring technologies.

Abstract: Natural disasters, such as volcanic eruptions, pose significant challenges to
daily life and incur considerable global economic losses. The emergence of
next-generation small-satellites, capable of constellation-based operations,
offers unparalleled opportunities for near-real-time monitoring and onboard
processing of such events. However, a major bottleneck remains the lack of
extensive annotated datasets capturing volcanic activity, which hinders the
development of robust detection systems. This paper introduces a novel dataset
explicitly designed for volcanic activity and eruption detection, encompassing
diverse volcanoes worldwide. The dataset provides binary annotations to
identify volcanic anomalies or non-anomalies, covering phenomena such as
temperature anomalies, eruptions, and volcanic ash emissions. These annotations
offer a foundational resource for developing and evaluating detection models,
addressing a critical gap in volcanic monitoring research. Additionally, we
present comprehensive benchmarks using state-of-the-art models to establish
baselines for future studies. Furthermore, we explore the potential for
deploying these models onboard next-generation satellites. Using the Intel
Movidius Myriad X VPU as a testbed, we demonstrate the feasibility of volcanic
activity detection directly onboard. This capability significantly reduces
latency and enhances response times, paving the way for advanced early warning
systems. This paves the way for innovative solutions in volcanic disaster
management, encouraging further exploration and refinement of onboard
monitoring technologies.

</details>


### [354] [Charting the Design Space of Neural Graph Representations for Subgraph Matching](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22897)
*Vaibhav Raj,Indradyumna Roy,Ashwin Ramachandran,Soumen Chakrabarti,Abir De*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: First comprehensive analysis of neural graph matching design space; shows that exploring combinations across attention vs soft-permutation, node vs edge alignment, and scoring networks yields significant gains and reveals design principles.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Subgraph matching is crucial across domains (KG QA, molecule design, scene graphs, etc.). Neural methods are fragmented, occupying only narrow patches of a broad design space. A unified exploration can improve performance and yield general design principles.

Method: Define a unified design space for graph matching networks along axes such as (i) attention-based vs. soft permutation-based interaction between query and corpus graphs, (ii) aligning nodes vs. edges, and (iii) the form of the final scoring network. Conduct a first comprehensive exploration by surveying existing methods within this space and performing extensive experiments across combinations of choices to identify performance gains and general principles.

Result: The exploration shows that judicious, previously unexploited combinations of design choices yield large performance benefits. The study uncovers valuable insights and establishes general design principles for neural graph representation and interaction that can inform broader research in neural graph matching.

Conclusion: This work provides a principled framework for neural graph matching design, demonstrates substantial performance gains from exploring the design space, and offers design guidelines that may inform future research beyond the specific tasks studied.

Abstract: Subgraph matching is vital in knowledge graph (KG) question answering,
molecule design, scene graph, code and circuit search, etc. Neural methods have
shown promising results for subgraph matching. Our study of recent systems
suggests refactoring them into a unified design space for graph matching
networks. Existing methods occupy only a few isolated patches in this space,
which remains largely uncharted. We undertake the first comprehensive
exploration of this space, featuring such axes as attention-based vs. soft
permutation-based interaction between query and corpus graphs, aligning nodes
vs. edges, and the form of the final scoring network that integrates neural
representations of the graphs. Our extensive experiments reveal that judicious
and hitherto-unexplored combinations of choices in this space lead to large
performance benefits. Beyond better performance, our study uncovers valuable
insights and establishes general design principles for neural graph
representation and interaction, which may be of wider interest.

</details>


### [355] [On the Anisotropy of Score-Based Generative Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22899)
*Andreas Floros,Seyed-Mohsen Moosavi-Dezfooli,Pier Luigi Dragotti*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SADs are architecture-dependent directions in score-based models that reveal inductive biases and provide a pre-training predictor of generalization; they align with the architecture's output geometry and correlate with downstream performance measured by Wasserstein metrics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how network architecture shapes the inductive biases of score-based generative models, enabling prediction of generalization and behavior without full training.

Method: Define Score Anisotropy Directions (SADs) as architecture-dependent directional bases. Analyze how SADs align with the architecture's output geometry across models. Validate on synthetic data and standard image benchmarks. Assess correlation with downstream performance using Wasserstein metrics.

Result: SADs form adaptive bases aligned with the architecture's output geometry, capturing fine-grained model behavior. They correlate with downstream performance and can predict generalization before training.

Conclusion: SADs offer a principled lens to explain and predict directional biases in generative models. This framework could inform architecture design and provide pre-training indicators of expected performance.

Abstract: We investigate the role of network architecture in shaping the inductive
biases of modern score-based generative models. To this end, we introduce the
Score Anisotropy Directions (SADs), architecture-dependent directions that
reveal how different networks preferentially capture data structure. Our
analysis shows that SADs form adaptive bases aligned with the architecture's
output geometry, providing a principled way to predict generalization ability
in score models prior to training. Through both synthetic data and standard
image benchmarks, we demonstrate that SADs reliably capture fine-grained model
behavior and correlate with downstream performance, as measured by Wasserstein
metrics. Our work offers a new lens for explaining and predicting directional
biases of generative models.

</details>


### [356] [Towards Personalized Treatment Plan: Geometrical Model-Agnostic Approach to Counterfactual Explanations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22911)
*Daniel Sin,Milad Toutounchian*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces SSBA, a model-agnostic method for efficient, constraint-aware counterfactual explanations in high-dimensional spaces with improved closeness to the decision boundary and favorable runtime.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To obtain realistic, actionable counterfactual explanations that respect real-world constraints (immutable/categorical features) in high-dimensional settings, where existing methods struggle with distance efficiency and scalability.

Method: A four-step process: fit the dataset to a model, locate the decision boundary, impose feasible constraints, and compute the closest counterfactual. The key innovation is Segmented Sampling for Boundary Approximation (SSBA): discretize by sampling many boundary points via binary search on the boundary, then search for the closest feasible counterfactual among these points. This yields a model-agnostic approach with efficient runtime compared to grid-based methods.

Result: SSBA achieves 5%–50% reductions in L2 distance to the original input across four datasets of varying dimensionality, outperforming existing counterfactual generators. It also efficiently handles real-world constraints by restricting changes to immutable/categorical features, and maintains scalable runtimes (order-of-magnitude improvements vs grid search). Code and results are provided on GitHub.

Conclusion: SSBA provides a simple, effective, model-agnostic method for generating nearest feasible counterfactual explanations that respect practical constraints, making it suitable for real-world deployment and further research.

Abstract: In our article, we describe a method for generating counterfactual
explanations in high-dimensional spaces using four steps that involve fitting
our dataset to a model, finding the decision boundary, determining constraints
on the problem, and computing the closest point (counterfactual explanation)
from that boundary. We propose a discretized approach where we find many
discrete points on the boundary and then identify the closest feasible
counterfactual explanation. This method, which we later call $\textit{Segmented
Sampling for Boundary Approximation}$ (SSBA), applies binary search to find
decision boundary points and then searches for the closest boundary point.
Across four datasets of varying dimensionality, we show that our method can
outperform current methods for counterfactual generation with reductions in
distance between $5\%$ to $50\%$ in terms of the $L_2$ norm. Our method can
also handle real-world constraints by restricting changes to immutable and
categorical features, such as age, gender, sex, height, and other related
characteristics such as the case for a health-based dataset. In terms of
runtime, the SSBA algorithm generates decision boundary points on multiple
orders of magnitude in the same given time when we compare to a grid-based
approach. In general, our method provides a simple and effective model-agnostic
method that can compute nearest feasible (i.e. realistic with constraints)
counterfactual explanations. All of our results and our code can be found here
at this link:
$\href{https://github.com/dsin85691/SSBA_For_Counterfactuals}{https://github.com/
dsin85691/SSBA\_For\_Counterfactuals}$

</details>


### [357] [Simple Denoising Diffusion Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22926)
*Huaisheng Zhu,Zhengyu Chen,Shijie Zhou,Zhihui Xie,Yige Yuan,Zhimeng Guo,Siyuan Xu,Hangfan Zhang,Vasant Honavar,Teng Xiao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a simplified denoising loss for Uniform-state Diffusion Models (USDMs) that trains by optimizing only noise-replaced tokens, stabilizing training and matching ELBO-level performance, plus a self-supervised, contrastive-inspired variant that yields additional gains in generation quality.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: MDLMs show competitive performance but degrade in few-step inference and cannot easily leverage existing distillation methods; USDMs help but rely on complex loss formulations that hurt scalability.

Method: Introduce a denoising loss that focuses solely on noise-replaced tokens for USDMs, treating denoising as a self-supervised learning task; additionally incorporate a contrastive-inspired modification with negative gradients to further improve generation quality.

Result: Training stability is improved and performance matches ELBO-level benchmarks for USDMs; the contrastive-inspired variant provides additional gains in generation quality, making the approach more practical for scalable few-step generation.

Conclusion: A simpler, scalable denoising loss for USDMs enables efficient few-step language diffusion with competitive performance, and a practical self-supervised contrastive enhancement offers further quality improvements.

Abstract: Diffusion models have recently been extended to language generation through
Masked Diffusion Language Models (MDLMs), which achieve performance competitive
with strong autoregressive models. However, MDLMs tend to degrade in the
few-step regime and cannot directly adopt existing few-step distillation
methods designed for continuous diffusion models, as they lack the intrinsic
property of mapping from noise to data. Recent Uniform-state Diffusion Models
(USDMs), initialized from a uniform prior, alleviate some limitations but still
suffer from complex loss formulations that hinder scalability. In this work, we
propose a simplified denoising-based loss for USDMs that optimizes only
noise-replaced tokens, stabilizing training and matching ELBO-level
performance. Furthermore, by framing denoising as self-supervised learning, we
introduce a simple modification to our denoising loss with contrastive-inspired
negative gradients, which is practical and yield additional improvements in
generation quality.

</details>


### [358] [Diffuse to Detect: A Generalizable Framework for Anomaly Detection with Diffusion Models Applications to UAVs and Beyond](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22928)
*Mingze Gong,Juan Du,Jianbang You*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Diffuse to Detect (DTD) is a diffusion-based, single-step anomaly detector that uses Graph Neural Networks on dynamic sensor graphs to deliver fast, scalable, and interpretable anomaly detection across UAV data, multivariate time series, and images, outperforming existing methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Anomaly detection in high-dimensional sensor data (e.g., UAVs) is essential for safety but challenging due to limited sensitivity, poor scalability, and failing to capture intricate spatial-temporal dependencies. There is a need for fast, robust anomaly detection that leverages the data distribution and sensor relationships.

Method: DTD adapts diffusion models for anomaly detection with a single-step diffusion process to predict noise patterns, leveraging the connection between noise prediction and the data distribution's score function. Sensor relationships are modeled as dynamic graphs via Graph Neural Networks. The architecture has two branches: (i) parametric neural network-based energy scoring for scalability, and (ii) nonparametric statistical methods for interpretability.

Result: Extensive evaluations on UAV sensor data, multivariate time series, and images show DTD achieving superior performance compared with existing methods, demonstrating its generality across diverse data modalities.

Conclusion: DTD is a versatile, adaptable framework that offers flexible trade-offs between computational efficiency and interpretability, and holds potential as a transformative solution for safety-critical applications such as industrial monitoring and beyond.

Abstract: Anomaly detection in complex, high-dimensional data, such as UAV sensor
readings, is essential for operational safety but challenging for existing
methods due to their limited sensitivity, scalability, and inability to capture
intricate dependencies. We propose the Diffuse to Detect (DTD) framework, a
novel approach that innovatively adapts diffusion models for anomaly detection,
diverging from their conventional use in generative tasks with high inference
time. By comparison, DTD employs a single-step diffusion process to predict
noise patterns, enabling rapid and precise identification of anomalies without
reconstruction errors. This approach is grounded in robust theoretical
foundations that link noise prediction to the data distribution's score
function, ensuring reliable deviation detection. By integrating Graph Neural
Networks to model sensor relationships as dynamic graphs, DTD effectively
captures spatial (inter-sensor) and temporal anomalies. Its two-branch
architecture, with parametric neural network-based energy scoring for
scalability and nonparametric statistical methods for interpretability,
provides flexible trade-offs between computational efficiency and transparency.
Extensive evaluations on UAV sensor data, multivariate time series, and images
demonstrate DTD's superior performance over existing methods, underscoring its
generality across diverse data modalities. This versatility, combined with its
adaptability, positions DTD as a transformative solution for safety-critical
applications, including industrial monitoring and beyond.

</details>


### [359] [Robust Uncertainty Quantification for Self-Evolving Large Language Models via Continual Domain Pretraining](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22931)
*Xiaofan Zhou,Lu Cheng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Adaptive conformal prediction with domain-aware calibration for continual domain pretraining of LLMs, enabling abstention and improved reliability under domain shift.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Continual domain pretraining (CDP) introduces evolving, often unknown domain distributions that can invalidate standard conformal prediction guarantees. There is a need for reliability guarantees for LLMs under CDP, especially when test domains shift and high coverage leads to uninformative large prediction sets.

Method: Propose an adaptive rejection and non-exchangeable CP framework. Estimate the test-domain question distribution via transformer-based clustering, then reweight or resample the calibration data accordingly. Use adaptive rejection CP to allow the model to abstain when its confidence or competence shifts significantly.

Result: Extensive experiments show that the framework improves both the effectiveness and reliability of conformal prediction under CDP scenarios, yielding better calibration and useful abstention behavior.

Conclusion: The proposed adaptive CP framework makes reliability guarantees more practical for LLMs under continual domain pretraining, enabling reliable predictions and meaningful abstention in the presence of domain shift; code is released.

Abstract: Continual Learning (CL) is essential for enabling self-evolving large
language models (LLMs) to adapt and remain effective amid rapid knowledge
growth. Yet, despite its importance, little attention has been given to
establishing statistical reliability guarantees for LLMs under CL, particularly
in the setting of continual domain pretraining (CDP). Conformal Prediction (CP)
has shown promise in offering correctness guarantees for LLMs, but it faces
major challenges in CDP: testing data often stems from unknown or shifting
domain distributions, under which CP may no longer provide valid guarantees.
Moreover, when high coverage is required, CP can yield excessively large
prediction sets for unanswerable queries, reducing informativeness. To address
these challenges, we introduce an adaptive rejection and non-exchangeable CP
framework. Our method first estimates the distribution of questions across
domains in the test set using transformer-based clustering, then reweights or
resamples the calibration data accordingly. Building on this, adaptive
rejection CP allows the LLM to selectively abstain from answering when its
confidence or competence shifts significantly. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that our framework enhances both the effectiveness and reliability
of CP under CDP scenarios. Our code is available at:
https://anonymous.4open.science/r/CPCL-8C12/

</details>


### [360] [RL-AUX: Reinforcement Learning for Auxiliary Task Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22940)
*Judah Goldfeder,Matthew So,Hod Lipson*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: RL-based dynamic auxiliary-task generation for auxiliary learning; avoids Bi-Level optimization; can surpass human-labeled tasks and match strong baselines; learns per-sample auxiliary loss weights for added gains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Mitigate reliance on labeled auxiliary tasks and the computational burden of Bi-Level Optimization in Auxiliary Learning; enhance main-task performance and generalization with learned, task-adaptive auxiliary signals.

Method: Train an RL agent to select auxiliary labels for each data point; optionally learn per-sample weights for the auxiliary loss; evaluate on 20-Superclass CIFAR100 with VGG16; compare against human-labeled auxiliaries and Bi-Level methods; include Weight-Aware RL and weight-learning variants.

Result: RL approach outperforms human-labeled auxiliary tasks and matches/prominent Bi-Level optimization; weight-aware strategies significantly outperform benchmarks; example: 80.9% test accuracy vs 75.53% with human-labeled auxiliaries.

Conclusion: RL is a viable method for dynamically generating auxiliary tasks in Auxiliary Learning; per-sample auxiliary loss weighting can be learned concurrently with labels, yielding strong performance and reducing reliance on costly Bi-Level Optimization.

Abstract: Auxiliary Learning (AL) is a special case of Multi-task Learning (MTL) in
which a network trains on auxiliary tasks to improve performance on its main
task. This technique is used to improve generalization and, ultimately,
performance on the network's main task. AL has been demonstrated to improve
performance across multiple domains, including navigation, image
classification, and natural language processing. One weakness of AL is the need
for labeled auxiliary tasks, which can require human effort and domain
expertise to generate. Meta Learning techniques have been used to solve this
issue by learning an additional auxiliary task generation network that can
create helpful tasks for the primary network. The most prominent techniques
rely on Bi-Level Optimization, which incurs computational cost and increased
code complexity. To avoid the need for Bi-Level Optimization, we present an
RL-based approach to dynamically create auxiliary tasks. In this framework, an
RL agent is tasked with selecting auxiliary labels for every data point in a
training set. The agent is rewarded when their selection improves the
performance on the primary task. We also experiment with learning optimal
strategies for weighing the auxiliary loss per data point. On the 20-Superclass
CIFAR100 problem, our RL approach outperforms human-labeled auxiliary tasks and
performs as well as a prominent Bi-Level Optimization technique. Our weight
learning approaches significantly outperform all of these benchmarks. For
example, a Weight-Aware RL-based approach helps the VGG16 architecture achieve
80.9% test accuracy while the human-labeled auxiliary task setup achieved
75.53%. The goal of this work is to (1) prove that RL is a viable approach to
dynamically generate auxiliary tasks and (2) demonstrate that per-sample
auxiliary task weights can be learned alongside the auxiliary task labels and
can achieve strong results.

</details>


### [361] [Hazard-Responsive Digital Twin for Climate-Driven Urban Resilience and Equity](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22941)
*Zhenglai Shen,Hongyu Zhou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Hazard-Responsive Digital Twin (H-RDT) combines physics-informed neural networks, multimodal data fusion, and equity-aware risk analytics to model and mitigate compound climate hazards (wildfire outages, heatwaves) in cities. It demonstrates stability in indoor temperatures under partial sensor loss, adaptive data fusion via reinforcement learning, and equity-focused interventions that reduce thermal risk; the approach is claimed transferable to real cities.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Climate hazards are increasingly compound and equity-sensitive threats to urban resilience. There is a need for integrated, adaptive, data-driven decision-support at city scale that accounts for social vulnerability.

Method: Develop H-RDT by integrating physics-informed neural networks, multimodal data fusion with a reinforcement-learning–based fusion module that reweights IoT, UAV, and satellite inputs, and equity-aware risk analytics. Validate in a synthetic district with diverse buildings and populations under a wildfire-outage-heatwave cascade; test interventions such as preemptive cooling-center activation and microgrid sharing.

Result: H-RDT maintains stable indoor temperatures (~31–33°C) under partial sensor loss, reproduces outage-driven surges and recovery. The RL fusion preserves spatiotemporal coverage. Equity-aware mapping isolates high-vulnerability clusters (schools, clinics, low-income housing). Interventions reduce population-weighted thermal risk by 11–13%, shrink the 95th percentile tail risk by 7–17%, and cut overheating hours by up to 9%.

Conclusion: The framework offers a transferable foundation for real-city implementation, connecting physical hazard modeling with social equity and decision intelligence, advancing digital urban resilience toward adaptive, learning-based, equity-centered climate adaptation.

Abstract: Compounding climate hazards, such as wildfire-induced outages and urban
heatwaves, challenge the stability and equity of cities. We present a
Hazard-Responsive Digital Twin (H-RDT) that combines physics-informed neural
network modeling, multimodal data fusion, and equity-aware risk analytics for
urban-scale response. In a synthetic district with diverse building archetypes
and populations, a simulated wildfire-outage-heatwave cascade shows that H-RDT
maintains stable indoor temperature predictions (approximately 31 to 33 C)
under partial sensor loss, reproducing outage-driven surges and recovery. The
reinforcement learning based fusion module adaptively reweights IoT, UAV, and
satellite inputs to sustain spatiotemporal coverage, while the equity-adjusted
mapping isolates high-vulnerability clusters (schools, clinics, low-income
housing). Prospective interventions, such as preemptive cooling-center
activation and microgrid sharing, reduce population-weighted thermal risk by 11
to 13 percent, shrink the 95th-percentile (tail) risk by 7 to 17 percent, and
cut overheating hours by up to 9 percent. Beyond the synthetic demonstration,
the framework establishes a transferable foundation for real-city
implementation, linking physical hazard modeling with social equity and
decision intelligence. The H-RDT advances digital urban resilience toward
adaptive, learning-based, and equity-centered decision support for climate
adaptation.

</details>


### [362] [Hankel Singular Value Regularization for Highly Compressible State Space Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22951)
*Paul Schwerdtner,Jules Berman,Benjamin Peherstorfer*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Regularizing the sum of Hankel singular values of state-space models yields faster decay of HSVs and highly compressible yet accurate long-range sequence models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Long-range sequence tasks require powerful models that are also deployable. State-space models (SSMs) offer strong performance but are hard to compress post-training, limiting practicality. HSV regularization targets the model's effective complexity to enable compression.

Method: Introduce a regularizer that penalizes the sum of Hankel singular values of the SSM, and develop an algorithm to compute HSVs efficiently during training by exploiting the block-diagonal structure of the SSM matrices in their parametrization.

Result: Models with HSV regularization are up to 10× more compressible than standard SSM layers on Long Range Arena benchmarks while preserving high accuracy.

Conclusion: HSV-based regularization provides a scalable, effective path to compressible SSM-based neural networks for long-range sequence tasks without substantial accuracy loss.

Abstract: Deep neural networks using state space models as layers are well suited for
long-range sequence tasks but can be challenging to compress after training. We
use that regularizing the sum of Hankel singular values of state space models
leads to a fast decay of these singular values and thus to compressible models.
To make the proposed Hankel singular value regularization scalable, we develop
an algorithm to efficiently compute the Hankel singular values during training
iterations by exploiting the specific block-diagonal structure of the system
matrices that is we use in our state space model parametrization. Experiments
on Long Range Arena benchmarks demonstrate that the regularized state space
layers are up to 10$\times$ more compressible than standard state space layers
while maintaining high accuracy.

</details>


### [363] [Manifold Approximation leads to Robust Kernel Alignment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22953)
*Mohammad Tariqul Islam,Du Liu,Deblina Sarkar*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MKA extends CKA by incorporating manifold geometry into kernel alignment; provides theory and empirical evaluation; suggests more robust representation measurement and potential in representation learning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: CKA ignores manifold structure and is sensitive to data scale due to heuristics; a geometry-aware alignment is needed for robust representation comparison.

Method: Develop a theoretical framework for MKA that integrates manifold geometry into kernel alignment; perform empirical evaluations on synthetic and real-world datasets; compare with CKA and other methods.

Result: MKA offers a more robust alignment framework; empirical results characterize its behavior and demonstrate robustness relative to contemporaries.

Conclusion: Manifold-aware kernel alignment improves the robustness of representation measurement and has potential applications in representation learning.

Abstract: Centered kernel alignment (CKA) is a popular metric for comparing
representations, determining equivalence of networks, and neuroscience
research. However, CKA does not account for the underlying manifold and relies
on numerous heuristics that cause it to behave differently at different scales
of data. In this work, we propose Manifold approximated Kernel Alignment (MKA),
which incorporates manifold geometry into the alignment task. We derive a
theoretical framework for MKA. We perform empirical evaluations on synthetic
datasets and real-world examples to characterize and compare MKA to its
contemporaries. Our findings suggest that manifold-aware kernel alignment
provides a more robust foundation for measuring representations, with potential
applications in representation learning.

</details>


### [364] [SARNet: A Spike-Aware consecutive validation Framework for Accurate Remaining Useful Life Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22955)
*Junhao Fan,Wenrui Liang,Wei-Qiang Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SARNet is a spike-aware, physics-informed RUL forecasting framework that combines ModernTCN with adaptive spike validation, targeted feature engineering on fragile segments, and a stacked RF–LGBM regressor, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy while remaining lightweight and deployable.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current RUL models often fail at fault onset, are opaque to engineers, smooth out spikes, rely on fixed thresholds, and lack physics-based explanations. This motivates a spike-aware, interpretable framework that preserves informative transients and provides actionable features.

Method: 1) Modern Temporal Convolutional Network forecasts degradation indicators. 2) Adaptive consecutive threshold validators distinguish true spikes from noise. 3) Targeted feature engineering (spectral slopes, derivatives, energy ratios) on failure-prone segments. 4) Final RUL produced by a stacked RF–LGBM regressor. 5) Evaluation on benchmark-ported datasets using an event-triggered protocol.

Result: SARNet consistently lowers error against recent baselines on benchmark datasets, reporting RMSE = 0.0365 and MAE = 0.0204. The framework is lightweight, robust, and easy to deploy.

Conclusion: Spike-aware, physics-informed design improves interpretability and robustness of RUL forecasting without sacrificing accuracy, with a modular pipeline that can be adapted to various degradation scenarios and deployment contexts.

Abstract: Accurate prediction of remaining useful life (RUL) is essential to enhance
system reliability and reduce maintenance risk. Yet many strong contemporary
models are fragile around fault onset and opaque to engineers: short,
high-energy spikes are smoothed away or misread, fixed thresholds blunt
sensitivity, and physics-based explanations are scarce. To remedy this, we
introduce SARNet (Spike-Aware Consecutive Validation Framework), which builds
on a Modern Temporal Convolutional Network (ModernTCN) and adds spike-aware
detection to provide physics-informed interpretability. ModernTCN forecasts
degradation-sensitive indicators; an adaptive consecutive threshold validates
true spikes while suppressing noise. Failure-prone segments then receive
targeted feature engineering (spectral slopes, statistical derivatives, energy
ratios), and the final RUL is produced by a stacked RF--LGBM regressor. Across
benchmark-ported datasets under an event-triggered protocol, SARNet
consistently lowers error compared to recent baselines (RMSE 0.0365, MAE
0.0204) while remaining lightweight, robust, and easy to deploy.

</details>


### [365] [The Reasoning Trap: How Enhancing LLM Reasoning Amplifies Tool Hallucination](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22977)
*Chenlong Yin,Zeyang Sha,Shiwen Cui,Changhua Meng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Strengthening reasoning in LLMs causally increases tool hallucination; the effect scales with task performance and persists across training regimes and at inference-time; mitigation often reduces hallucination at the cost of utility.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To resolve the paradox that stronger reasoning can cause more tool hallucinations, and to systematically quantify and understand this trade-off for building reliable Agents.

Method: Controlled experiments using RL-based and other reasoning enhancements; measurement of tool hallucination under two failure modes (no tool or distractor tools); cross-task training (including non-tool domains); evaluation of mitigation strategies (Prompt Engineering, Direct Preference Optimization); representation analysis focusing on tool-reliability signals and late-layer residuals.

Result: 1) Causal link: stronger reasoning via RL increases tool hallucinations proportionally to task performance gains. 2) Effect persists beyond overfitting; non-tool task training still amplifies hallucination. 3) Effect is method-agnostic across supervision or inference-time prompting for step-by-step thinking. 4) Mitigations (Prompt Engineering, DPO) reduce hallucinations but degrade utility, revealing a reliability-capability trade-off. 5) Mechanism: reasoning enhancements collapse tool-reliability representations; hallucinations appear as amplified divergences in late-layer residual streams.

Conclusion: Current reasoning-enhancement methods inherently amplify tool hallucination, signaling a need for training objectives that jointly optimize capability and reliability; future work should focus on reliability-aware objectives and architectures to mitigate tool hallucinations without sacrificing performance.

Abstract: Enhancing the reasoning capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) is a key
strategy for building Agents that "think then act." However, recent
observations, like OpenAI's o3, suggest a paradox: stronger reasoning often
coincides with increased hallucination, yet no prior work has systematically
examined whether reasoning enhancement itself causes tool hallucination. To
address this gap, we pose the central question: Does strengthening reasoning
increase tool hallucination? To answer this, we introduce SimpleToolHalluBench,
a diagnostic benchmark measuring tool hallucination in two failure modes: (i)
no tool available, and (ii) only distractor tools available. Through controlled
experiments, we establish three key findings. First, we demonstrate a causal
relationship: progressively enhancing reasoning through RL increases tool
hallucination proportionally with task performance gains. Second, this effect
transcends overfitting - training on non-tool tasks (e.g., mathematics) still
amplifies subsequent tool hallucination. Third, the effect is method-agnostic,
appearing when reasoning is instilled via supervised fine-tuning and when it is
merely elicited at inference by switching from direct answers to step-by-step
thinking. We also evaluate mitigation strategies including Prompt Engineering
and Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), revealing a fundamental
reliability-capability trade-off: reducing hallucination consistently degrades
utility. Mechanistically, Reasoning RL disproportionately collapses
tool-reliability-related representations, and hallucinations surface as
amplified divergences concentrated in late-layer residual streams. These
findings reveal that current reasoning enhancement methods inherently amplify
tool hallucination, highlighting the need for new training objectives that
jointly optimize for capability and reliability.

</details>


### [366] [How Muon's Spectral Design Benefits Generalization: A Study on Imbalanced Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22980)
*Bhavya Vasudeva,Puneesh Deora,Yize Zhao,Vatsal Sharan,Christos Thrampoulidis*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Spectral gradient methods (SpecGD, as used by Muon/Shampoo) can outperform vanilla GD on imbalanced data because they learn all data components at equal rates rather than prioritizing the dominant components. This yields an early and persistent generalization advantage, amplified by depth, and validated both analytically (Gaussian mixture, linear/bilinear, deep linear models) and empirically on diverse imbalanced datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand when spectrum-aware matrix-valued optimizers generalize better than competitive algorithms, by formalizing SpecGD and analyzing its behavior on imbalanced data and simple models, then validating the theory empirically.

Method: Introduce simplifying abstractions: (1) use imbalanced data as a testbed; (2) analyze the canonical Spectral Gradient Descent (SpecGD) where each update is UV^T from the truncated SVD of the gradient; (3) derive a setting with a Gaussian mixture data model for linear, bilinear, and deep linear models; (4) compare against standard GD with/without normalization and Adam; (5) extend to deeper architectures and perform experiments on imbalanced datasets.

Result: Under SpecGD, all principal components are learned at equal rates, in contrast to GD which prioritizes dominant components. This leads to a growing gap in balanced accuracy in favor of SpecGD early in training, a gap that persists even when GD uses adaptive step-sizes (normalization). Depth amplifies these effects in deep linear models. Empirical experiments on various imbalanced datasets corroborate the theory, with spectral methods (Muon, Shampoo) outperforming Euclidean counterparts and Adam by promoting balanced learning of the data’s components.

Conclusion: Spectral optimizers can outperform standard Euclidean GD on imbalanced data by equalizing the learning rates across data components, with depth enhancing the advantage. Theoretical results align with empirical findings, supporting the practical use of spectral methods for improved generalization.

Abstract: The growing adoption of spectrum-aware matrix-valued optimizers such as Muon
and Shampoo in deep learning motivates a systematic study of their
generalization properties and, in particular, when they might outperform
competitive algorithms. We approach this question by introducing appropriate
simplifying abstractions as follows: First, we use imbalanced data as a
testbed. Second, we study the canonical form of such optimizers, which is
Spectral Gradient Descent (SpecGD) -- each update step is $UV^T$ where $U\Sigma
V^T$ is the truncated SVD of the gradient. Third, within this framework we
identify a canonical setting for which we precisely quantify when SpecGD
outperforms vanilla Euclidean GD. For a Gaussian mixture data model and both
linear and bilinear models, we show that unlike GD, which prioritizes learning
dominant principal components of the data first, SpecGD learns all principal
components of the data at equal rates. We demonstrate how this translates to a
growing gap in balanced accuracy favoring SpecGD early in training and further
show that the gap remains consistent even when the GD counterpart uses adaptive
step-sizes via normalization. By extending the analysis to deep linear models,
we show that depth amplifies these effects. We empirically verify our
theoretical findings on a variety of imbalanced datasets. Our experiments
compare practical variants of spectral methods, like Muon and Shampoo, against
their Euclidean counterparts and Adam. The results validate our findings that
these spectral optimizers achieve superior generalization by promoting a more
balanced learning of the data's underlying components.

</details>


### [367] [QoSGMAA: A Robust Multi-Order Graph Attention and Adversarial Framework for Sparse QoS Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22982)
*Guanchen Du,Jianlong Xu,Mingtong Li,Ruiqi Wang,Qianqing Guo,Caiyi Chen,Qingcao Dai,Yuxiang Zeng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A new QoS prediction model QoSMGAA combines multi-order attention, adversarial autoregressive learning on transformed interaction matrices, and Gumbel-Softmax-based negative sampling to improve QoS prediction under sparse/noisy data, outperforming baselines on real datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: QoS prediction is essential for reliable service selection and user satisfaction. Existing methods struggle with extreme data sparsity and structural noise and fail to exploit rich contextual information and higher-order user–service interactions.

Method: QoSMGAA architecture integrates a multi-order attention mechanism to aggregate extensive contextual data and predict missing QoS values. It uses adversarial neural networks to perform autoregressive supervised learning on transformed interaction matrices. A discrete sampling technique based on the Gumbel-Softmax generates informative negative samples to capture higher-order user–service interactions.

Result: Extensive experiments on large-scale real-world datasets show that QoSMGAA significantly outperforms existing baselines, demonstrating robustness to sparsity and noise and strong potential for practical deployment in service selection and recommendation scenarios.

Conclusion: QoSMGAA provides an effective solution for QoS prediction in complex noisy environments, achieving higher accuracy and better generalization, with practical implications for service discovery and recommendations.

Abstract: With the rapid advancement of internet technologies, network services have
become critical for delivering diverse and reliable applications to users.
However, the exponential growth in the number of available services has
resulted in many similar offerings, posing significant challenges in selecting
optimal services. Predicting Quality of Service (QoS) accurately thus becomes a
fundamental prerequisite for ensuring reliability and user satisfaction.
However, existing QoS prediction methods often fail to capture rich contextual
information and exhibit poor performance under extreme data sparsity and
structural noise. To bridge this gap, we propose a novel architecture, QoSMGAA,
specifically designed to enhance prediction accuracy in complex and noisy
network service environments. QoSMGAA integrates a multi-order attention
mechanism to aggregate extensive contextual data and predict missing QoS values
effectively. Additionally, our method incorporates adversarial neural networks
to perform autoregressive supervised learning based on transformed interaction
matrices. To capture complex, higher-order interactions among users and
services, we employ a discrete sampling technique leveraging the Gumbel-Softmax
method to generate informative negative samples. Comprehensive experimental
validation conducted on large-scale real-world datasets demonstrates that our
proposed model significantly outperforms existing baseline methods,
highlighting its strong potential for practical deployment in service selection
and recommendation scenarios.

</details>


### [368] [Equivariant Neural Networks for General Linear Symmetries on Lie Algebras](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22984)
*Chankyo Kim,Sicheng Zhao,Minghan Zhu,Tzu-Yuan Lin,Maani Ghaffari*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Reductive Lie Neurons (ReLNs), a neural network architecture exactly equivariant to general linear group (GL(n)) symmetries on Lie algebras and matrix-valued inputs, via an adjoint-invariant bilinear layer that stabilizes equivariance without subgroup-specific redesign; demonstrated on algebraic SL(3) and SP(4) benchmarks, Lorentz-equivariant particle physics tasks, and 3D drone state estimation with geometric uncertainty.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: General purpose equivariant learning for broad linear transformations (GL(n)) and matrix-valued data, beyond simple rotations or compact groups; addresses scientific domains where Lie-algebra features and matrices are central.

Method: Proposes Reductive Lie Neurons (ReLNs) that are exactly equivariant to GL(n) symmetries. Introduces an adjoint-invariant bilinear layer to preserve equivariance for Lie-algebra features and matrix inputs, enabling stable learning without redesign for subgroups; operates directly on n×n matrices and Lie-algebra representations.

Result: Outperforms existing equivariant methods on algebraic benchmarks with sl(3) and sp(4) symmetries; achieves competitive results on a Lorentz-equivariant particle physics task; in 3D drone state estimation with geometric uncertainty, jointly processes velocities and covariances to improve trajectory accuracy.

Conclusion: ReLNs offer a practical, general framework for learning with broad linear group symmetries on Lie algebras and matrix-valued data, extending equivariant networks beyond compact groups and enabling broader scientific application.

Abstract: Encoding symmetries is a powerful inductive bias for improving the
generalization of deep neural networks. However, most existing equivariant
models are limited to simple symmetries like rotations, failing to address the
broader class of general linear transformations, GL(n), that appear in many
scientific domains. We introduce Reductive Lie Neurons (ReLNs), a novel neural
network architecture exactly equivariant to these general linear symmetries.
ReLNs are designed to operate directly on a wide range of structured inputs,
including general n-by-n matrices. ReLNs introduce a novel adjoint-invariant
bilinear layer to achieve stable equivariance for both Lie-algebraic features
and matrix-valued inputs, without requiring redesign for each subgroup. This
architecture overcomes the limitations of prior equivariant networks that only
apply to compact groups or simple vector data. We validate ReLNs' versatility
across a spectrum of tasks: they outperform existing methods on algebraic
benchmarks with sl(3) and sp(4) symmetries and achieve competitive results on a
Lorentz-equivariant particle physics task. In 3D drone state estimation with
geometric uncertainty, ReLNs jointly process velocities and covariances,
yielding significant improvements in trajectory accuracy. ReLNs provide a
practical and general framework for learning with broad linear group symmetries
on Lie algebras and matrix-valued data. Project page:
https://reductive-lie-neuron.github.io/

</details>


### [369] [Adaptive Forests For Classification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22991)
*Dimitris Bertsimas,Yubing Cui*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Adaptive Forests (AF) learns input-dependent weights for an ensemble of CART trees to outperform standard RF and XGBoost.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: RF uses equal weights and XGBoost uses fixed sequential boosting; integrating input-specific weighting can improve predictive accuracy and robustness.

Method: AF uses Optimal Predictive-Policy Trees (OP2T) to assign input-dependent unequal weights to trees and employs Mixed Integer Optimization (MIO) to refine candidate weights dynamically, yielding an adaptive forest.

Result: Empirical evaluation on 20+ real-world datasets shows AF consistently outperforms RF, XGBoost, and other weighted RF methods in binary and multi-class classification.

Conclusion: Adaptive weighting via OP2T and MIO provides a promising approach to boosting ensemble performance; further exploration on scalability, interpretability, and theoretical guarantees could be pursued.

Abstract: Random Forests (RF) and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) are two of the
most widely used and highly performing classification and regression models.
They aggregate equally weighted CART trees, generated randomly in RF or
sequentially in XGBoost. In this paper, we propose Adaptive Forests (AF), a
novel approach that adaptively selects the weights of the underlying CART
models. AF combines (a) the Optimal Predictive-Policy Trees (OP2T) framework to
prescribe tailored, input-dependent unequal weights to trees and (b) Mixed
Integer Optimization (MIO) to refine weight candidates dynamically, enhancing
overall performance. We demonstrate that AF consistently outperforms RF,
XGBoost, and other weighted RF in binary and multi-class classification
problems over 20+ real-world datasets.

</details>


### [370] [Can Language Models Compose Skills In-Context?](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22993)
*Zidong Liu,Zhuoyan Xu,Zhenmei Shi,Yingyu Liang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: The paper studies how well language models can compose basic skills into composite tasks via in-context examples; finds negative effects from simple task demonstrations; alignment of demonstration steps matters; offers a probing method that improves performance and supports the claims.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand limitations of in-context learning for task composition and to guide prompt design/evaluation for models that must perform multi-step skills beyond what training covers.

Method: Systematic experiments on representative open-source LMs across linguistic and logical tasks designed to test composition; compares standard prompts vs Chain-of-Thought; theoretical analysis; introduces a probing-task method.

Result: Simple demonstrations can hurt performance; models struggle to recognize/assemble skills; alignment of demonstration steps with composition is crucial; the proposed probing tasks improve results.

Conclusion: Effective in-context composition requires careful alignment between examples and the compositional steps; results motivate better prompting strategies and evaluation methods, and suggest that composition remains challenging for current open-source models.

Abstract: Composing basic skills from simple tasks to accomplish composite tasks is
crucial for modern intelligent systems. We investigate the in-context
composition ability of language models to perform composite tasks that combine
basic skills demonstrated in in-context examples. This is more challenging than
the standard setting, where skills and their composition can be learned in
training. We conduct systematic experiments on various representative
open-source language models, utilizing linguistic and logical tasks designed to
probe composition abilities. The results reveal that simple task examples can
have a surprising negative impact on the performance, because the models
generally struggle to recognize and assemble the skills correctly, even with
Chain-of-Thought examples. Theoretical analysis further shows that it is
crucial to align examples with the corresponding steps in the composition. This
inspires a method for the probing tasks, whose improved performance provides
positive support for our insights.

</details>


### [371] [Softmax is $1/2$-Lipschitz: A tight bound across all $\ell_p$ norms](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23012)
*Pravin Nair*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Softmax is contractive with Lipschitz constant 1/2 under all Lp norms (p≥1), sharper than the common 1 bound; local constants are 1/2 for p=1 and p=∞, strictly below 1/2 for 1<p<∞ (approached only in the limit). The result is norm-uniform and improves robustness/convergence analyses; empirically validated on ViT, GPT-2, Qwen3-8B, and RL policies.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Robustness guarantees and convergence analyses often assume softmax has Lipschitz constant 1 (under L2); a sharper, norm-uniform bound would tighten theory and better reflect softmax behavior across norms.

Method: Theoretical analysis proving contractivity with constant 1/2 uniformly for all p≥1; analysis of local Lipschitz constants showing equality to 1/2 at p=1 and p=∞ and strict sub-1/2 for 1<p<∞ (limit attainment); empirical validation on attention-based architectures and stochastic policies.

Result: Softmax is 1/2-Lipschitz contractive across all Lp norms (p≥1). Local Lipschitz constants equal 1/2 for p=1 and p=∞; for 1<p<∞, the constant remains strictly below 1/2, with sup 1/2 only approached in the limit. This norm-uniform bound sharpens robustness/convergence results, and is corroborated by experiments on ViT, GPT-2, Qwen3-8B, and RL policies.

Conclusion: Provides a norm-uniform, sharp 1/2 Lipschitz bound for softmax, yielding tighter robustness and convergence guarantees; validated empirically on major architectures and reinforcement learning scenarios.

Abstract: The softmax function is a basic operator in machine learning and
optimization, used in classification, attention mechanisms, reinforcement
learning, game theory, and problems involving log-sum-exp terms. Existing
robustness guarantees of learning models and convergence analysis of
optimization algorithms typically consider the softmax operator to have a
Lipschitz constant of $1$ with respect to the $\ell_2$ norm. In this work, we
prove that the softmax function is contractive with the Lipschitz constant
$1/2$, uniformly across all $\ell_p$ norms with $p \ge 1$. We also show that
the local Lipschitz constant of softmax attains $1/2$ for $p = 1$ and $p =
\infty$, and for $p \in (1,\infty)$, the constant remains strictly below $1/2$
and the supremum $1/2$ is achieved only in the limit. To our knowledge, this is
the first comprehensive norm-uniform analysis of softmax Lipschitz continuity.
We demonstrate how the sharper constant directly improves a range of existing
theoretical results on robustness and convergence. We further validate the
sharpness of the $1/2$ Lipschitz constant of the softmax operator through
empirical studies on attention-based architectures (ViT, GPT-2, Qwen3-8B) and
on stochastic policies in reinforcement learning.

</details>


### [372] [MoEMeta: Mixture-of-Experts Meta Learning for Few-Shot Relational Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23013)
*Han Wu,Jie Yin*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MoEMeta is a meta-learning framework for few-shot KG relational learning that disentangles global knowledge from local task contexts using a mixture-of-experts for global relational prototypes and a task-tailored adaptation mechanism, achieving state-of-the-art results on three benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing meta-learning methods learn relation meta-knowledge in isolation and fail to capture cross-task relational patterns, while also underutilizing local, task-specific contexts crucial for rapid adaptation. This limits both generalization and fast adaptation to new relations.

Method: MoEMeta introduces two innovations: (i) a mixture-of-experts (MoE) module that learns globally shared relational prototypes to enhance generalization, and (ii) a task-tailored adaptation mechanism that captures local contexts for fast task-specific adaptation. It disentangles globally shared knowledge from task-specific contexts to balance generalization with adaptability.

Result: Extensive experiments on three KG benchmarks show that MoEMeta consistently outperforms existing baselines, achieving state-of-the-art performance.

Conclusion: By balancing global generalization with local adaptability through MoEMeta, the framework advances few-shot relational learning in knowledge graphs.

Abstract: Few-shot knowledge graph relational learning seeks to perform reasoning over
relations given only a limited number of training examples. While existing
approaches largely adopt a meta-learning framework for enabling fast adaptation
to new relations, they suffer from two key pitfalls. First, they learn relation
meta-knowledge in isolation, failing to capture common relational patterns
shared across tasks. Second, they struggle to effectively incorporate local,
task-specific contexts crucial for rapid adaptation. To address these
limitations, we propose MoEMeta, a novel meta-learning framework that
disentangles globally shared knowledge from task-specific contexts to enable
both effective generalization and rapid adaptation. MoEMeta introduces two key
innovations: (i) a mixture-of-experts (MoE) model that learns globally shared
relational prototypes to enhance generalization, and (ii) a task-tailored
adaptation mechanism that captures local contexts for fast task-specific
adaptation. By balancing global generalization with local adaptability, MoEMeta
significantly advances few-shot relational learning. Extensive experiments and
analyses on three KG benchmarks demonstrate that MoEMeta consistently
outperforms existing baselines, achieving state-of-the-art performance.

</details>
