### [373] [Sentinel: Dynamic Knowledge Distillation for Personalized Federated Intrusion Detection in Heterogeneous IoT Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23019)
*Gurpreet Singh,Keshav Sood,P. Rajalakshmi,Yong Xiang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Sentinel uses a dual-model personal+shared architecture with bidirectional distillation and balanced losses to improve federated IoT IDS under non-IID, imbalanced data while keeping communication low.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome class imbalance, non-IID data, and high communication costs in federated IDS for IoT networks, preserving privacy while achieving strong performance.

Method: Per-client dual-model (teacher on-device, student on-device) with bidirectional knowledge distillation (adaptive temperature), multi-faceted feature alignment, class-balanced loss; server performs normalized gradient aggregation with equal weighting; only student model transmitted to server.

Result: Empirical evaluation on IoTID20 and 5GNIDD shows Sentinel outperforms state-of-the-art FL methods, especially under severe data heterogeneity, with maintained communication efficiency.

Conclusion: Sentinel achieves strong personalized-global balance, improves IDS performance in heterogeneous IoT data settings, and provides a new benchmark for privacy-preserving, communication-efficient FL-based IDS.

Abstract: Federated learning (FL) offers a privacy-preserving paradigm for machine
learning, but its application in intrusion detection systems (IDS) within IoT
networks is challenged by severe class imbalance, non-IID data, and high
communication overhead.These challenges severely degrade the performance of
conventional FL methods in real-world network traffic classification. To
overcome these limitations, we propose Sentinel, a personalized federated IDS
(pFed-IDS) framework that incorporates a dual-model architecture on each
client, consisting of a personalized teacher and a lightweight shared student
model. This design effectively balances deep local adaptation with efficient
global model consensus while preserving client privacy by transmitting only the
compact student model, thus reducing communication costs. Sentinel integrates
three key mechanisms to ensure robust performance: bidirectional knowledge
distillation with adaptive temperature scaling, multi-faceted feature
alignment, and class-balanced loss functions. Furthermore, the server employs
normalized gradient aggregation with equal client weighting to enhance fairness
and mitigate client drift. Extensive experiments on the IoTID20 and 5GNIDD
benchmark datasets demonstrate that Sentinel significantly outperforms
state-of-the-art federated methods, establishing a new performance benchmark,
especially under extreme data heterogeneity, while maintaining communication
efficiency.

</details>


### [374] [Towards Stable and Effective Reinforcement Learning for Mixture-of-Experts](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23027)
*Di Zhang,Xun Wu,Shaohan Huang,Yaru Hao,Li Dong,Zewen Chi,Zhifang Sui,Furu Wei*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A router-aware importance-sampling rescaling method for off-policy RL in Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models stabilizes training by guiding IS weights with router logits, reducing gradient variance and improving convergence and final performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Mixture-of-Experts architectures pose training instability and high gradient variance in off-policy RL; MoE RL remains underexplored compared to dense models, limiting scalable training of large-scale expert systems.

Method: Introduce a router-aware rescaling strategy for IS weights guided by MoE router logits during off-policy RL training, aiming to reduce gradient variance and prevent divergence.

Result: Experiments show improved convergence stability and higher final performance for MoE models under RL training with the proposed router-aware IS rescaling.

Conclusion: RL algorithmic innovations tailored to MoE architectures, such as router-guided IS weighting, can significantly improve the efficiency and stability of training large-scale expert models.

Abstract: Recent advances in reinforcement learning (RL) have substantially improved
the training of large-scale language models, leading to significant gains in
generation quality and reasoning ability. However, most existing research
focuses on dense models, while RL training for Mixture-of-Experts (MoE)
architectures remains underexplored. To address the instability commonly
observed in MoE training, we propose a novel router-aware approach to optimize
importance sampling (IS) weights in off-policy RL. Specifically, we design a
rescaling strategy guided by router logits, which effectively reduces gradient
variance and mitigates training divergence. Experimental results demonstrate
that our method significantly improves both the convergence stability and the
final performance of MoE models, highlighting the potential of RL algorithmic
innovations tailored to MoE architectures and providing a promising direction
for efficient training of large-scale expert models.

</details>


### [375] [Sublinear Sketches for Approximate Nearest Neighbor and Kernel Density Estimation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23039)
*Ved Danait,Srijan Das,Sujoy Bhore*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Sublinear-space sketches for ANN in streaming and sublinear sketches for A-KDE in sliding-window, enabling efficient queries on dynamic data with near-optimal trade-offs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable accurate similarity search and density estimation over massive, dynamic data streams while using compact memory and fast queries.

Method: Develop two sketching schemes: (1) ANN in streaming/Turnstile model using a sublinear sample of inputs to build a sketch with memory O(n^{1+ρ-η}) and query-time, batch queries; (2) A-KDE in Sliding-Window using a sketch of size O(RW * 1/(sqrt{1+ε}-1) log^2 N). Both rely on LSH-based structures and theoretical analysis; experimental validation on real datasets.

Result: The ANN sketch achieves sublinear memory and query-time with near-optimal accuracy trade-offs, extending to Turnstile; the A-KDE sketch provides the first sublinear guarantee in Sliding-Window; experiments show lightweight sketches with low error.

Conclusion: The work delivers practical, theory-backed sketching tools for two core problems in dynamic data streams, enabling scalable ANN and KDE with provable guarantees and empirical performance benefits.

Abstract: Approximate Nearest Neighbor (ANN) search and Approximate Kernel Density
Estimation (A-KDE) are fundamental problems at the core of modern machine
learning, with broad applications in data analysis, information systems, and
large-scale decision making. In massive and dynamic data streams, a central
challenge is to design compact sketches that preserve essential structural
properties of the data while enabling efficient queries.
  In this work, we develop new sketching algorithms that achieve sublinear
space and query time guarantees for both ANN and A-KDE for a dynamic stream of
data. For ANN in the streaming model, under natural assumptions, we design a
sublinear sketch that requires only $\mathcal{O}(n^{1+\rho-\eta})$ memory by
storing only a sublinear ($n^{-\eta}$) fraction of the total inputs, where
$\rho$ is a parameter of the LSH family, and $0<\eta<1$. Our method supports
sublinear query time, batch queries, and extends to the more general Turnstile
model. While earlier works have focused on Exact NN, this is the first result
on ANN that achieves near-optimal trade-offs between memory size and
approximation error.
  Next, for A-KDE in the Sliding-Window model, we propose a sketch of size
$\mathcal{O}\left(RW \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\epsilon} - 1} \log^2 N\right)$,
where $R$ is the number of sketch rows, $W$ is the LSH range, $N$ is the window
size, and $\epsilon$ is the approximation error. This, to the best of our
knowledge, is the first theoretical sublinear sketch guarantee for A-KDE in the
Sliding-Window model.
  We complement our theoretical results with experiments on various real-world
datasets, which show that the proposed sketches are lightweight and achieve
consistently low error in practice.

</details>


### [376] [LLM Meets Diffusion: A Hybrid Framework for Crystal Material Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23040)
*Subhojyoti Khastagir,Kishalay Das,Pawan Goyal,Seung-Cheol Lee,Satadeep Bhattacharjee,Niloy Ganguly*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A hybrid LLM–diffusion framework (CrysLLMGen) combines a fine-tuned LLM for discrete atom types with an equivariant diffusion model for continuous coordinates and lattice parameters to generate crystal structures, improving validity, stability, and novelty, with strong conditional generation and released code.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LLMs handle discrete atomic types well but struggle with continuous features (positions, lattice parameters); diffusion models excel at continuous variables but have difficulty in generating correct compositions. A hybrid approach aims to leverage both strengths to design valid, novel crystal materials and meet user constraints.

Method: During sampling, a fine-tuned LLM first generates an intermediate representation of atom types, coordinates, and lattice. The atom types are retained, while coordinates and lattice are refined by a pre-trained equivariant diffusion model.

Result: The method outperforms state-of-the-art generative models on multiple benchmarks/datasets, achieving balanced structural/compositional validity, higher material stability and novelty, and strong conditional generation capabilities.

Conclusion: This work demonstrates that integrating LLMs with diffusion models can effectively bridge discrete and continuous facets of crystal design, offering a practical pathway for controllable material generation; code is publicly available.

Abstract: Recent advances in generative modeling have shown significant promise in
designing novel periodic crystal structures. Existing approaches typically rely
on either large language models (LLMs) or equivariant denoising models, each
with complementary strengths: LLMs excel at handling discrete atomic types but
often struggle with continuous features such as atomic positions and lattice
parameters, while denoising models are effective at modeling continuous
variables but encounter difficulties in generating accurate atomic
compositions. To bridge this gap, we propose CrysLLMGen, a hybrid framework
that integrates an LLM with a diffusion model to leverage their complementary
strengths for crystal material generation. During sampling, CrysLLMGen first
employs a fine-tuned LLM to produce an intermediate representation of atom
types, atomic coordinates, and lattice structure. While retaining the predicted
atom types, it passes the atomic coordinates and lattice structure to a
pre-trained equivariant diffusion model for refinement. Our framework
outperforms state-of-the-art generative models across several benchmark tasks
and datasets. Specifically, CrysLLMGen not only achieves a balanced performance
in terms of structural and compositional validity but also generates more
stable and novel materials compared to LLM-based and denoisingbased models
Furthermore, CrysLLMGen exhibits strong conditional generation capabilities,
effectively producing materials that satisfy user-defined constraints. Code is
available at https://github.com/kdmsit/crysllmgen

</details>


### [377] [Advantage Shaping as Surrogate Reward Maximization: Unifying Pass@K Policy Gradients](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23049)
*Christos Thrampoulidis,Sadegh Mahdavi,Wenlong Deng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Policy-gradient routes for Pass@K are unified: they optimize the same surrogate rewards; hard-example up-weighting is reward-level regularization; surrogate-objective derivations yield new shaping methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reconcile direct REINFORCE-style optimization and advantage-shaping approaches for Pass@K with verifiable rewards, to provide a unified theoretical perspective and practical recipe for RLVR.

Method: Reverse-engineer existing advantage-shaping algorithms to reveal their implicit surrogate rewards; reinterpret hard-example up-weighting as reward-level regularization; develop a recipe to derive both existing and new advantage-shaping methods from surrogate reward objectives.

Result: Shows the two approaches are two sides of the same coin; interprets practical modifiers as regularization; provides a practical recipe to derive shaping methods; broadens RLVR policy gradient optimization beyond Pass@K.

Conclusion: Offers a unified lens for policy-gradient optimization in RLVR, connecting direct and shaping methods and enabling systematic design of new algorithms.

Abstract: This note reconciles two seemingly distinct approaches to policy gradient
optimization for the Pass@K objective in reinforcement learning with verifiable
rewards: (1) direct REINFORCE-style methods, and (2) advantage-shaping
techniques that directly modify GRPO. We show that these are two sides of the
same coin. By reverse-engineering existing advantage-shaping algorithms, we
reveal that they implicitly optimize surrogate rewards. We specifically
interpret practical ``hard-example up-weighting'' modifications to GRPO as
reward-level regularization. Conversely, starting from surrogate reward
objectives, we provide a simple recipe for deriving both existing and new
advantage-shaping methods. This perspective provides a lens for RLVR policy
gradient optimization beyond our original motivation of Pass@K.

</details>


### [378] [SwiftTS: A Swift Selection Framework for Time Series Pre-trained Models via Multi-task Meta-Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23051)
*Tengxue Zhang,Biao Ouyang,Yang Shu,Xinyang Chen,Chenjuan Guo,Bin Yang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SwiftTS is a learning-guided framework that quickly selects the best time-series pre-trained model without costly fine-tuning, using dual-encoder embeddings, horizon-adaptive experts, and cross-task transfer to achieve state-of-the-art results on 14 datasets across 8 models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: With many pre-trained time-series models, exhaustive evaluation is expensive; a generalizable, efficient selection mechanism is needed that performs well across diverse datasets and prediction horizons and remains robust under distribution shifts.

Method: A lightweight dual-encoder that embeds time series and candidate models; computes patchwise compatibility scores for efficient selection; a horizon-adaptive expert composition module to adjust expert weights; transferable cross-task learning with cross-dataset and cross-horizon sampling to boost out-of-distribution robustness.

Result: Empirical evaluation on 14 downstream datasets and 8 pre-trained models shows SwiftTS achieves state-of-the-art performance in time-series pre-trained-model selection.

Conclusion: SwiftTS provides an efficient, robust approach for selecting time-series pre-trained models, scalable across datasets and horizons, with improved generalization and OOD robustness.

Abstract: Pre-trained models exhibit strong generalization to various downstream tasks.
However, given the numerous models available in the model hub, identifying the
most suitable one by individually fine-tuning is time-consuming. In this paper,
we propose \textbf{SwiftTS}, a swift selection framework for time series
pre-trained models. To avoid expensive forward propagation through all
candidates, SwiftTS adopts a learning-guided approach that leverages historical
dataset-model performance pairs across diverse horizons to predict model
performance on unseen datasets. It employs a lightweight dual-encoder
architecture that embeds time series and candidate models with rich
characteristics, computing patchwise compatibility scores between data and
model embeddings for efficient selection. To further enhance the generalization
across datasets and horizons, we introduce a horizon-adaptive expert
composition module that dynamically adjusts expert weights, and the
transferable cross-task learning with cross-dataset and cross-horizon task
sampling to enhance out-of-distribution (OOD) robustness. Extensive experiments
on 14 downstream datasets and 8 pre-trained models demonstrate that SwiftTS
achieves state-of-the-art performance in time series pre-trained model
selection.

</details>


### [379] [AirFed: Federated Graph-Enhanced Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Multi-UAV Cooperative Mobile Edge Computing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23053)
*Zhiyu Wang,Suman Raj,Rajkumar Buyya*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: AirFed introduces federated graph-enhanced multi-agent reinforcement learning for UAV-based MEC, enabling scalable coordination of trajectory planning and task offloading with strong QoS performance and reduced communication overhead.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses key challenges in multi-UAV MEC: coordinating trajectory planning, task offloading, and resource allocation under dynamic/uncertain environments; existing methods struggle with scalability, slow convergence, and knowledge sharing in large-scale IoT deployments with tight deadlines.

Method: 1) Dual-layer dynamic Graph Attention Networks to model spatial-temporal dependencies among UAVs and IoT devices; 2) Dual-Actor single-Critic architecture to jointly optimize continuous trajectory control and discrete offloading decisions; 3) Reputation-based decentralized federated learning with gradient-sensitive adaptive quantization for robust knowledge sharing across heterogeneous UAVs.

Result: AirFed achieves a 42.9% reduction in weighted cost vs. baselines, >99% deadline satisfaction, 94.2% IoT device coverage, and 54.5% reduction in communication overhead. Scalability analyses show robust performance across varying UAV counts, IoT densities, and system scales.

Conclusion: AirFed demonstrates practical applicability for large-scale UAV-MEC deployments, delivering significant QoS improvements and scalable, robust knowledge sharing under heterogeneity and dynamic conditions.

Abstract: Multiple Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) cooperative Mobile Edge Computing
(MEC) systems face critical challenges in coordinating trajectory planning,
task offloading, and resource allocation while ensuring Quality of Service
(QoS) under dynamic and uncertain environments. Existing approaches suffer from
limited scalability, slow convergence, and inefficient knowledge sharing among
UAVs, particularly when handling large-scale IoT device deployments with
stringent deadline constraints. This paper proposes AirFed, a novel federated
graph-enhanced multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that addresses
these challenges through three key innovations. First, we design dual-layer
dynamic Graph Attention Networks (GATs) that explicitly model spatial-temporal
dependencies among UAVs and IoT devices, capturing both service relationships
and collaborative interactions within the network topology. Second, we develop
a dual-Actor single-Critic architecture that jointly optimizes continuous
trajectory control and discrete task offloading decisions. Third, we propose a
reputation-based decentralized federated learning mechanism with
gradient-sensitive adaptive quantization, enabling efficient and robust
knowledge sharing across heterogeneous UAVs. Extensive experiments demonstrate
that AirFed achieves 42.9% reduction in weighted cost compared to
state-of-the-art baselines, attains over 99% deadline satisfaction and 94.2%
IoT device coverage rate, and reduces communication overhead by 54.5%.
Scalability analysis confirms robust performance across varying UAV numbers,
IoT device densities, and system scales, validating AirFed's practical
applicability for large-scale UAV-MEC deployments.

</details>


### [380] [Sampling from Energy distributions with Target Concrete Score Identity](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23106)
*Sergei Kholkin,Francisco Vargas,Alexander Korotin*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces TCSIS for sampling from unnormalized discrete densities by learning reverse CTMC dynamics via a Target Concrete Score Identity. Uses forward uniform diffusion to estimate a concrete score without target samples or partition functions, trains a neural network, and offers Self-Normalized and Unbiased TCSIS algorithms, demonstrated on statistical physics problems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Sampling from unnormalized discrete distributions is challenging due to unknown partition functions and intractable densities. Existing score-based or diffusion approaches often require gradients of the target or samples from it. The authors seek a diffusion-based method that avoids these requirements and applies to discrete state spaces.

Method: Define a forward CTMC with a uniform noising kernel. Derive the Target Concrete Score Identity that expresses the concrete score (gradient of log target probability with respect to state) as a ratio of expectations of Boltzmann factors under the forward diffusion. Estimate the concrete score with a neural network. Propose Self-Normalized TCSIS and Unbiased TCSIS algorithms for sampling from the target distribution without needing target samples or partition function values.

Result: Empirical demonstrations on problems from statistical physics show TCSIS can effectively sample from unnormalized discrete distributions by learning reverse dynamics; the approach avoids computing the partition function and does not require target samples.

Conclusion: TCSIS provides a new diffusion-based framework for discrete, unnormalized densities, enabling practical sampling via learned reverse CTMC dynamics and the Target Concrete Score Identity, with two concrete algorithms and demonstrated applicability to physics-inspired problems.

Abstract: We introduce the Target Concrete Score Identity Sampler (TCSIS), a method for
sampling from unnormalized densities on discrete state spaces by learning the
reverse dynamics of a Continuous-Time Markov Chain (CTMC). Our approach builds
on a forward in time CTMC with a uniform noising kernel and relies on the
proposed Target Concrete Score Identity, which relates the concrete score, the
ratio of marginal probabilities of two states, to a ratio of expectations of
Boltzmann factors under the forward uniform diffusion kernel. This formulation
enables Monte Carlo estimation of the concrete score without requiring samples
from the target distribution or computation of the partition function. We
approximate the concrete score with a neural network and propose two
algorithms: Self-Normalized TCSIS and Unbiased TCSIS. Finally, we demonstrate
the effectiveness of TCSIS on problems from statistical physics.

</details>


### [381] [Neural Emulator Superiority: When Machine Learning for PDEs Surpasses its Training Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23111)
*Felix Koehler,Nils Thuerey*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Low-fidelity-trained neural emulators can outperform high-fidelity solvers in multi-step rollouts against a higher-fidelity reference, due to favorable inductive biases and error properties.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Challenge the assumption that emulator fidelity is bounded by training data fidelity and re-evaluate emulator benchmarking in numerical PDEs.

Method: Theoretical analysis of emulator inductive biases, training objectives, and numerical error characteristics in a multi-step rollout framework; corroborated by empirical experiments across several PDEs using standard neural architectures.

Result: Neural emulators trained on low-fidelity data can achieve higher accuracy than the high-fidelity reference when evaluated on higher-fidelity data; emulators implicitly learn dynamics that are more regularized and exhibit more favorable error accumulation, potentially surpassing training data limitations and reducing numerical artifacts.

Conclusion: Prompts a re-evaluation of emulator benchmarking; neural emulators may attain greater physical fidelity than their training source in certain regimes, motivating broader exploration and regime-aware evaluation.

Abstract: Neural operators or emulators for PDEs trained on data from numerical solvers
are conventionally assumed to be limited by their training data's fidelity. We
challenge this assumption by identifying "emulator superiority," where neural
networks trained purely on low-fidelity solver data can achieve higher accuracy
than those solvers when evaluated against a higher-fidelity reference. Our
theoretical analysis reveals how the interplay between emulator inductive
biases, training objectives, and numerical error characteristics enables
superior performance during multi-step rollouts. We empirically validate this
finding across different PDEs using standard neural architectures,
demonstrating that emulators can implicitly learn dynamics that are more
regularized or exhibit more favorable error accumulation properties than their
training data, potentially surpassing training data limitations and mitigating
numerical artifacts. This work prompts a re-evaluation of emulator
benchmarking, suggesting neural emulators might achieve greater physical
fidelity than their training source within specific operational regimes.
Project Page: https://tum-pbs.github.io/emulator-superiority

</details>


### [382] [Seeing Structural Failure Before it Happens: An Image-Based Physics-Informed Neural Network (PINN) for Spaghetti Bridge Load Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23117)
*Omer Jauhar Khan,Sudais Khan,Hafeez Anwar*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PINNs and a new Physics-Informed Kolmogorov Arnold Network (PIKAN) are used to predict spaghetti-bridge weight with limited data; achieves high R^2 0.9603 and MAE 10.50 using 100 augmented samples; web interface provided.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address data scarcity in structural weight prediction and enable early-stage failure analysis in lightweight bridge models by incorporating physics.

Method: Leverages PINNs with physics constraints; introduces PIKAN architecture combining universal function approximation with physical insights; collects structural parameters via manual entry or computer vision; dataset of 15 real bridges augmented to 100; evaluation metrics; code and data GitHub; web interface.

Result: Model achieves R^2 0.9603 and MAE 10.50; demonstrates reliability of PINNs under limited data; possible practical tool for preliminary design and failure analysis.

Conclusion: PINNs and PIKAN show promise for data-scarce structural prediction; further work needed to validate generalization, discuss limitations, dataset size, and real-world applicability.

Abstract: Physics Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) are gaining attention for their
ability to embed physical laws into deep learning models, which is particularly
useful in structural engineering tasks with limited data. This paper aims to
explore the use of PINNs to predict the weight of small scale spaghetti
bridges, a task relevant to understanding load limits and potential failure
modes in simplified structural models. Our proposed framework incorporates
physics-based constraints to the prediction model for improved performance. In
addition to standard PINNs, we introduce a novel architecture named Physics
Informed Kolmogorov Arnold Network (PIKAN), which blends universal function
approximation theory with physical insights. The structural parameters provided
as input to the model are collected either manually or through computer vision
methods. Our dataset includes 15 real bridges, augmented to 100 samples, and
our best model achieves an $R^2$ score of 0.9603 and a mean absolute error
(MAE) of 10.50 units. From applied perspective, we also provide a web based
interface for parameter entry and prediction. These results show that PINNs can
offer reliable estimates of structural weight, even with limited data, and may
help inform early stage failure analysis in lightweight bridge designs.
  The complete data and code are available at
https://github.com/OmerJauhar/PINNS-For-Spaghetti-Bridges.

</details>


### [383] [A method for outlier detection based on cluster analysis and visual expert criteria](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23136)
*Juan A. Lara,David Lizcano,Víctor Rampérez,Javier Soriano*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Clustering-based outlier detection that incorporates domain experts' dispersion perception; shows strong accuracy and efficiency on stabilometry and EEG time-series data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Many outlier detectors ignore the inherent dispersion and expert visual cues used in different domains. A method that aligns with expert perception can improve reliability across applications, especially in medical and neurological data.

Method: Introduces four domain-specific criteria that reflect how experts visually identify outliers after clustering. The method augments traditional clustering with dispersion-aware, expert-like assessment rather than pure numerical analysis. Evaluated on time-series data from stabilometry and EEG, with attention to runtime. Regression analyses support performance.

Result: False positive rate < 2% and reliability > 99%. Satisfactory results across two domains, with efficient runtime.

Conclusion: The approach better captures domain dispersion and expert perception, yielding a robust, scalable outlier detector suitable for preliminary filtering in data mining workflows across medical and neurological applications.

Abstract: Outlier detection is an important problem occurring in a wide range of areas.
Outliers are the outcome of fraudulent behaviour, mechanical faults, human
error, or simply natural deviations. Many data mining applications perform
outlier detection, often as a preliminary step in order to filter out outliers
and build more representative models. In this paper, we propose an outlier
detection method based on a clustering process. The aim behind the proposal
outlined in this paper is to overcome the specificity of many existing outlier
detection techniques that fail to take into account the inherent dispersion of
domain objects. The outlier detection method is based on four criteria designed
to represent how human beings (experts in each domain) visually identify
outliers within a set of objects after analysing the clusters. This has an
advantage over other clustering-based outlier detection techniques that are
founded on a purely numerical analysis of clusters. Our proposal has been
evaluated, with satisfactory results, on data (particularly time series) from
two different domains: stabilometry, a branch of medicine studying
balance-related functions in human beings and electroencephalography (EEG), a
neurological exploration used to diagnose nervous system disorders. To validate
the proposed method, we studied method outlier detection and efficiency in
terms of runtime. The results of regression analyses confirm that our proposal
is useful for detecting outlier data in different domains, with a false
positive rate of less than 2% and a reliability greater than 99%.

</details>


### [384] [Rethinking GSPO: The Perplexity-Entropy Equivalence](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23142)
*Chi Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: GSPO’s length-normalized weight s(θ) is mathematically equivalent to the inverse perplexity ratio and to exp(ΔH), linking policy-gradient updates to information-theoretic quantities and explaining variance reduction and stability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To reframe GSPO’s length-normalized importance weights through information-theoretic quantities (perplexity, cross-entropy) to gain intuitive and empirical understanding of their behavior, especially in mixture-of-experts training.

Method: Derive exact equivalences: (π_θ/π_old)^(1/|y|) = PPL_old/PPL_θ and = exp(ΔH), using standard definitions; interpret GSPO’s weights as perplexity-based. Validate predictions via controlled experiments on mathematical reasoning tasks to test equivalences and variance behavior.

Result: Mathematical equivalences are established; variance predictions align with observed behavior; log-domain variance reduction via geometric averaging; improved stability in training mixture-of-experts models; experiments on mathematical reasoning tasks corroborate claims.

Conclusion: GSPO can be interpreted through an information-theoretic lens, with perplexity/entropy changes underpinning its weights; this explains empirical properties like variance reduction and training stability, and offers a principled viewpoint for using GSPO in mixture-of-experts settings.

Abstract: We provide a new perspective on GSPO's length-normalized importance ratios by
establishing their connection to information-theoretic quantities. We show that
GSPO's sequence-level weight $s(\theta) =
(\pi_\theta/\pi_{\theta_{\text{old}}})^{1/|y|}$ can be equivalently expressed
as the inverse perplexity ratio
$\text{PPL}_{\theta_{\text{old}}}/\text{PPL}_\theta$ and as the exponential
cross-entropy change $\exp(\Delta H)$. While the perplexity-entropy
relationship follows from standard definitions, this observation provides a
useful lens for understanding GSPO: the algorithm weights policy gradient
updates by perplexity ratios, offering an information-theoretic interpretation
of the importance weights. This perspective helps explain GSPO's empirical
properties, including log-domain variance reduction through geometric averaging
and stability in training mixture-of-experts models. We validate the
mathematical equivalences and variance predictions through controlled
experiments on mathematical reasoning tasks.

</details>


### [385] [Adapting Interleaved Encoders with PPO for Language-Guided Reinforcement Learning in BabyAI](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23148)
*Aryan Mathur,Asaduddin Ahmed*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Interleaved perception-decision transformer (PDiT) with CLIP-like alignment improves stability and cross-modal understanding in vision-language RL, outperforming standard PPO on BabyAI GoToLocal.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address inefficiency of separating perception and decision in reinforcement learning; enable policy feedback to perceptual modules and align multimodal representations for mission understanding.

Method: Introduce PDiT: alternate perception and decision layers within a single transformer; add a contrastive loss to align textual mission embeddings with visual scene features (CLIP-like). Evaluate on BabyAI GoToLocal and compare to a PPO baseline.

Result: PDiT achieves more stable rewards and stronger cross-modal alignment than PPO baseline on BabyAI GoToLocal.

Conclusion: Interleaved transformer encoders are a promising direction for integrated autonomous agents capable of vision-language reasoning, with potential applicability to broader vision-language RL tasks.

Abstract: Deep reinforcement learning agents often struggle when tasks require
understanding both vision and language. Conventional architectures typically
isolate perception (for example, CNN-based visual encoders) from
decision-making (policy networks). This separation can be inefficient, since
the policy's failures do not directly help the perception module learn what is
important. To address this, we implement the Perception-Decision Interleaving
Transformer (PDiT) architecture introduced by Mao et al. (2023), a model that
alternates between perception and decision layers within a single transformer.
This interleaving allows feedback from decision-making to refine perceptual
features dynamically. In addition, we integrate a contrastive loss inspired by
CLIP to align textual mission embeddings with visual scene features. We
evaluate the PDiT encoders on the BabyAI GoToLocal environment and find that
the approach achieves more stable rewards and stronger alignment compared to a
standard PPO baseline. The results suggest that interleaved transformer
encoders are a promising direction for developing more integrated autonomous
agents.

</details>


### [386] [Enabling Vibration-Based Gesture Recognition on Everyday Furniture via Energy-Efficient FPGA Implementation of 1D Convolutional Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23156)
*Koki Shibata,Tianheng Ling,Chao Qian,Tomokazu Matsui,Hirohiko Suwa,Keiichi Yasumoto,Gregor Schiele*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Energy-efficient vibration-based gesture recognition on low-power FPGAs using raw waveform input and two compact 1D CNNs; achieves real-time inference with sub-10 ms latency and under 1.2 mJ per inference, enabling edge deployment.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Non-intrusive vibration sensing for gesture recognition faces high energy cost and deployability barriers due to preprocessing complexity and large models. The work targets edge-friendly, real-time performance on low-power FPGAs.

Method: 1) Use raw waveform input to replace spectral preprocessing, reducing input size 21x. 2) Propose two lightweight architectures (1D-CNN and 1D-SepCNN) for embedded FPGAs, shrinking parameters from 369M to as few as 216. 3) Apply integer-only quantization and automated RTL generation; implement ping-pong buffering in 1D-SepCNN for memory constraints; extend hardware-aware search to balance accuracy, deployability, latency, and energy. 4) Validate on two swipe-direction datasets with multiple users on AMD Spartan-7 XC7S25, reporting accuracy, latency, and energy per inference.

Result: 6-bit 1D-CNN yields 0.970 average accuracy with 9.22 ms latency; 8-bit 1D-SepCNN yields 0.949 accuracy with 6.83 ms latency, offering ~53x CPU speedup. Both models consume <1.2 mJ per inference, demonstrating strong edge deployability.

Conclusion: The study demonstrates that end-to-end, energy-efficient, real-time gesture recognition is feasible on low-power FPGAs using raw waveform inputs and compact, hardware-aware neural networks, with favorable accuracy-latency-energy trade-offs and practical deployability.

Abstract: The growing demand for smart home interfaces has increased interest in
non-intrusive sensing methods like vibration-based gesture recognition. While
prior studies demonstrated feasibility, they often rely on complex
preprocessing and large Neural Networks (NNs) requiring costly high-performance
hardware, resulting in high energy usage and limited real-world deployability.
This study proposes an energy-efficient solution deploying compact NNs on
low-power Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) to enable real-time gesture
recognition with competitive accuracy. We adopt a series of optimizations: (1)
We replace complex spectral preprocessing with raw waveform input, eliminating
complex on-board preprocessing while reducing input size by 21x without
sacrificing accuracy. (2) We design two lightweight architectures (1D-CNN and
1D-SepCNN) tailored for embedded FPGAs, reducing parameters from 369 million to
as few as 216 while maintaining comparable accuracy. (3) With integer-only
quantization and automated RTL generation, we achieve seamless FPGA deployment.
A ping-pong buffering mechanism in 1D-SepCNN further improves deployability
under tight memory constraints. (4) We extend a hardware-aware search framework
to support constraint-driven model configuration selection, considering
accuracy, deployability, latency, and energy consumption. Evaluated on two
swipe-direction datasets with multiple users and ordinary tables, our approach
achieves low-latency, energy-efficient inference on the AMD Spartan-7 XC7S25
FPGA. Under the PS data splitting setting, the selected 6-bit 1D-CNN reaches
0.970 average accuracy across users with 9.22 ms latency. The chosen 8-bit
1D-SepCNN further reduces latency to 6.83 ms (over 53x CPU speedup) with
slightly lower accuracy (0.949). Both consume under 1.2 mJ per inference,
demonstrating suitability for long-term edge operation.

</details>


### [387] [The Benchmarking Epistemology: Construct Validity for Evaluating Machine Learning Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23191)
*Timo Freiesleben,Sebastian Zezulka*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A framework of construct validity for predictive benchmarking, demonstrated through three case studies to show how benchmark scores can support various scientific inferences when accompanied by explicit assumptions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Benchmark scores alone do not guarantee scientific inference; there is a need to articulate the theoretical assumptions about learning problems, evaluation metrics, and data distributions that underlie interpretations of benchmark results.

Method: Develop conditions of construct validity inspired by psychological measurement theory and apply them to three case studies (ImageNet-based engineering progress, WeatherBench policy-relevant weather predictions, and Fragile Families Challenge life-event predictability) to illustrate how benchmarks can support diverse inferences.

Result: The framework clarifies when benchmark scores can meaningfully support scientific claims, reframing predictive benchmarking as an epistemological practice and a site for theoretical and conceptual reasoning in machine learning.

Conclusion: Explicitly articulating measurement- and problem-structure assumptions is essential for robust scientific inferences from benchmark results; predictive benchmarking should be treated as a rigorous epistemic practice with explicit validity conditions.

Abstract: Predictive benchmarking, the evaluation of machine learning models based on
predictive performance and competitive ranking, is a central epistemic practice
in machine learning research and an increasingly prominent method for
scientific inquiry. Yet, benchmark scores alone provide at best measurements of
model performance relative to an evaluation dataset and a concrete learning
problem. Drawing substantial scientific inferences from the results, say about
theoretical tasks like image classification, requires additional assumptions
about the theoretical structure of the learning problems, evaluation functions,
and data distributions. We make these assumptions explicit by developing
conditions of construct validity inspired by psychological measurement theory.
We examine these assumptions in practice through three case studies, each
exemplifying a typical intended inference: measuring engineering progress in
computer vision with ImageNet; evaluating policy-relevant weather predictions
with WeatherBench; and examining limitations of the predictability of life
events with the Fragile Families Challenge. Our framework clarifies the
conditions under which benchmark scores can support diverse scientific claims,
bringing predictive benchmarking into perspective as an epistemological
practice and a key site of conceptual and theoretical reasoning in machine
learning.

</details>


### [388] [PTPP-Aware Adaptation Scaling Laws: Predicting Domain-Adaptation Performance at Unseen Pre-Training Budgets](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23198)
*Etienne Goffinet,Shane Bergsma,Avraham Sheinin,Natalia Vassilieva,Shaheer Muhammad,Preslav Nakov,Gurpreet Gosal*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PTPP-aware adaptation scaling laws treat the pre-training budget as an explicit variable, enabling prediction of adaptation loss across different tokens-per-parameter (PTPP). In a multilingual English/Arabic → French setup, early-stage data (PTPP=15,31) accurately predicts loss at PTPP=279 and surpasses a PTPP-agnostic baseline, with metrics like Huber-on-log and MAE_rel; full RMSE and MAPE are in the appendix. The framework also supports planning replay ratios and adaptation budgets under compute constraints.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing continual pre-training (CPT) scaling laws fix the pre-training budget, limiting their ability to forecast outcomes when PTPP varies. A PTPP-aware formulation aims to forecast adaptation loss across unseen PTPP values and enable practical budgeting under compute limits.

Method: Develop a PTPP-aware adaptation scaling law that parameterizes the pre-training budget as a variable. Train on early-stage data with PTPP values {15, 31} and predict target loss at PTPP=279. Evaluate on a multilingual setup (English/Arabic → French) and compare to a PTPP-agnostic DCPT baseline using metrics such as Huber-on-log, MAE_rel, and calibration slope (with RMSE and MAPE provided in the appendix). Demonstrate practical use by showing how to plan replay ratios and adaptation token budgets under compute limits.

Result: The PTPP-aware model yields more accurate predictions of target loss than the baseline across evaluated metrics (better calibration and lower error on Huber-on-log and MAE_rel). Early-stage training data suffices to forecast performance at a substantially higher PTPP, and full diagnostics (RMSE, MAPE) corroborate the improvement in the appendix.

Conclusion: Treating pre-training budget as an explicit variable enables accurate forecasting of adaptation outcomes across different PTPP values and supports practical resource planning (replay ratios and token budgets) under compute constraints. This approach broadens the utility of CPT scaling laws beyond fixed-budget scenarios.

Abstract: Continual pre-training (CPT) for domain adaptation must balance target-domain
gains with stability on the base domain. Existing CPT scaling laws typically
assume a fixed pre-training budget, which limits their ability to forecast
adaptation outcomes for models trained at different tokens-per-parameter
(PTPP). We present \emph{PTPP-aware} adaptation scaling laws that make the
pre-training budget an explicit variable, enabling accurate \emph{prediction}
of adaptation loss at unseen \ptpp. On a multilingual setup (English/Arabic
$\rightarrow$ French), PTPP-aware formulations trained on early stages
(\ptpp{}=\{15,31\}) predict target loss at \ptpp{}=279 and outperform a
PTPP-agnostic \dcpt{} transfer baseline on metrics (Huber-on-log,
MAE$_\mathrm{rel}$, calibration slope); full diagnostics (RMSE, MAPE) are in
the appendix. Beyond forecasting, we show a practical use case: planning replay
ratios and adaptation token budgets that satisfy target and forgetting
constraints under compute limits.

</details>


### [389] [Increasing LLM Coding Capabilities through Diverse Synthetic Coding Tasks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23208)
*Amal Abed,Ivan Lukic,Jörg K. H. Franke,Frank Hutter*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A scalable synthetic data pipeline generates ~800k instruction-reasoning-code-test quadruplets to train LLMs for coding with step-by-step reasoning. Fine-tuning on this data improves coding benchmarks, showing reasoning data can substitute for larger models and outperform open-source rivals at fixed budgets. The authors release the dataset and pipeline.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is a shortage of diverse, large-scale datasets that include intermediate reasoning trails for coding tasks. Many existing datasets pair problems with solutions but omit the reasoning steps that guide problem solving. This gap hinders LLMs from learning how to reason through coding problems.

Method: The pipeline combines four components: (1) curated contest problems (2) web-mined content filtered by relevance classifiers (3) data expansion guided by reasoning patterns (4) multi-stage execution-based validation. A genetic mutation algorithm increases task diversity while maintaining consistency between reasoning traces and code. Each sample includes a task, a step-by-step reasoning trace, a working solution, and executable tests.

Result: Fine-tuning LLMs on this dataset yields consistent improvements on coding benchmarks. Beyond raw accuracy, the reasoning-aware data can substitute for model scaling, generalize across architectures, and outperform leading open-source alternatives under identical sample budgets.

Conclusion: Reasoning-centered synthetic data generation is an efficient approach for advancing coding capabilities in LLMs. The dataset and generation pipeline are released to support further research.

Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have shown impressive promise in code
generation, yet their progress remains limited by the shortage of large-scale
datasets that are both diverse and well-aligned with human reasoning. Most
existing resources pair problems with solutions, but omit the intermediate
thought process that guides coding. To close this gap, we present a scalable
synthetic data generation pipeline that produces nearly 800k
instruction-reasoning-code-test quadruplets. Each sample combines a task, a
step-by-step reasoning trace, a working solution, and executable tests,
enabling models to learn not just the what but also the how of problem solving.
Our pipeline combines four key components: curated contest problems, web-mined
content filtered by relevance classifiers, data expansion guided by reasoning
patterns, and multi-stage execution-based validation. A genetic mutation
algorithm further increases task diversity while maintaining consistency
between reasoning traces and code implementations. Our key finding is that
fine-tuning LLMs on this dataset yields consistent improvements on coding
benchmarks. Beyond raw accuracy, reasoning-aware data can substitute for model
scaling, generalize across architectures, and outperform leading open-source
alternatives under identical sample budgets. Our work establishes
reasoning-centered synthetic data generation as an efficient approach for
advancing coding capabilities in LLMs. We publish our dataset and generation
pipeline to facilitate further research.

</details>


### [390] [Accelerating Eigenvalue Dataset Generation via Chebyshev Subspace Filter](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23215)
*Hong Wang,Jie Wang,Jian Luo,huanshuo dong,Yeqiu Chen,Runmin Jiang,Zhen huang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A novel method SCSF speeds up eigenvalue data generation by grouping similar operators via truncated FFT sorting and using a Chebyshev subspace filter to reuse eigenpairs, achieving up to 3.5x speedup over traditional solvers.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Neural eigenvalue methods require large labeled datasets of operators and eigenvalues; generating these datasets with standard solvers is computationally expensive. Exploiting similarities among related operators can reduce cost.

Method: Sorting Chebyshev Subspace Filter (SCSF): sort operators by eigenvalue distribution using truncated FFT, group similar operators, and build a Chebyshev subspace filter that reuses eigenpairs from solved problems to accelerate solving subsequent ones, reducing redundant work.

Result: Experimental results show up to 3.5x speedup over various numerical solvers; claims to be the first method to accelerate eigenvalue data generation.

Conclusion: SCSF significantly accelerates data generation for neural eigenvalue methods, potentially enabling training with less labeled data and enabling scaling to larger operator families.

Abstract: Eigenvalue problems are among the most important topics in many scientific
disciplines. With the recent surge and development of machine learning, neural
eigenvalue methods have attracted significant attention as a forward pass of
inference requires only a tiny fraction of the computation time compared to
traditional solvers. However, a key limitation is the requirement for large
amounts of labeled data in training, including operators and their eigenvalues.
To tackle this limitation, we propose a novel method, named Sorting Chebyshev
Subspace Filter (SCSF), which significantly accelerates eigenvalue data
generation by leveraging similarities between operators -- a factor overlooked
by existing methods. Specifically, SCSF employs truncated fast Fourier
transform sorting to group operators with similar eigenvalue distributions and
constructs a Chebyshev subspace filter that leverages eigenpairs from
previously solved problems to assist in solving subsequent ones, reducing
redundant computations. To the best of our knowledge, SCSF is the first method
to accelerate eigenvalue data generation. Experimental results show that SCSF
achieves up to a $3.5\times$ speedup compared to various numerical solvers.

</details>


### [391] [Grassmanian Interpolation of Low-Pass Graph Filters: Theory and Applications](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23235)
*Anton Savostianov,Michael T. Schaub,Benjamin Stamm*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a Grassmann-manifold-based interpolation of low-pass graph filters for parametric graphs, offering an error bound and two applications: translating temporal feature evolution into evolving topology via a homophily-adjusting similarity, and a dot-product graph family to enhance message passing for node classification.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Computing low-frequency subspaces for parametric graph families is computationally expensive due to repeated eigenvalue problems; interpolation aims to avoid repeated solves.

Method: Use Riemannian interpolation in normal coordinates on the Grassmann manifold to interpolate low-pass filter subspaces; derive an error bound for the interpolation; propose two induced parametric graph applications.

Result: Provided an error bound for subspace interpolation and established a framework for interpolating low-pass filters across parametric graphs, with two practical applications outlined.

Conclusion: The approach enables efficient low-pass filter interpolation over graph families and suggests practical uses for evolving graphs and improved graph-based learning through interpolated filters.

Abstract: Low-pass graph filters are fundamental for signal processing on graphs and
other non-Euclidean domains. However, the computation of such filters for
parametric graph families can be prohibitively expensive as computation of the
corresponding low-frequency subspaces, requires the repeated solution of an
eigenvalue problem. We suggest a novel algorithm of low-pass graph filter
interpolation based on Riemannian interpolation in normal coordinates on the
Grassmann manifold. We derive an error bound estimate for the subspace
interpolation and suggest two possible applications for induced parametric
graph families. First, we argue that the temporal evolution of the node
features may be translated to the evolving graph topology via a similarity
correction to adjust the homophily degree of the network. Second, we suggest a
dot product graph family induced by a given static graph which allows to infer
improved message passing scheme for node classification facilitated by the
filter interpolation.

</details>


### [392] [Robust Iterative Learning Hidden Quantum Markov Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23237)
*Ning Ning*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A robust learning framework for Hidden Quantum Markov Models under adversarial corruption, introducing AC-HQMM and the Robust Iterative Learning Algorithm (RILA) with RCR-EF for removing corrupted data and Lévi updates, plus L1 penalties to stabilize learning; shows improved convergence, resilience to corruption, and preservation of physical validity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: HQMM learners are highly sensitive to data corruption and lack robustness against adversarial perturbations. There is a need for robust learning methods that can tolerate corrupted observation sequences while maintaining physically valid quantum operations (Kraus operators).

Method: Define Adversarially Corrupted HQMM (AC-HQMM). Develop Robust Iterative Learning Algorithm (RILA) that combines Remove Corrupted Rows by Entropy Filtering (RCR-EF) with an iterative stochastic resampling procedure to update Kraus operators within physical validity constraints. Use derivative-free optimization with L1-penalized likelihood to improve stability and resist overfitting under non-differentiable conditions.

Result: Empirical evaluation across multiple HQMM and HMM benchmarks shows RILA achieves superior convergence stability, higher corruption resilience, and better preservation of physical validity relative to existing learning algorithms.

Conclusion: The paper presents a principled, efficient approach for robust quantum sequential learning under adversarial corruption, enabling reliable HQMM learning by integrating corruption filtering, stochastic, physically valid updates, and L1 regularization.

Abstract: Hidden Quantum Markov Models (HQMMs) extend classical Hidden Markov Models to
the quantum domain, offering a powerful probabilistic framework for modeling
sequential data with quantum coherence. However, existing HQMM learning
algorithms are highly sensitive to data corruption and lack mechanisms to
ensure robustness under adversarial perturbations. In this work, we introduce
the Adversarially Corrupted HQMM (AC-HQMM), which formalizes robustness
analysis by allowing a controlled fraction of observation sequences to be
adversarially corrupted. To learn AC-HQMMs, we propose the Robust Iterative
Learning Algorithm (RILA), a derivative-free method that integrates a Remove
Corrupted Rows by Entropy Filtering (RCR-EF) module with an iterative
stochastic resampling procedure for physically valid Kraus operator updates.
RILA incorporates L1-penalized likelihood objectives to enhance stability,
resist overfitting, and remain effective under non-differentiable conditions.
Across multiple HQMM and HMM benchmarks, RILA demonstrates superior convergence
stability, corruption resilience, and preservation of physical validity
compared to existing algorithms, establishing a principled and efficient
approach for robust quantum sequential learning.

</details>


### [393] [GCAO: Group-driven Clustering via Gravitational Attraction and Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23259)
*Qi Li,Jun Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: GCAO is a group-driven clustering approach that uses gravitational interactions among low-density boundary point groups to achieve stable, scalable clustering in high-dimensional data, outperforming 11 baselines across multiple metrics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: High-dimensional, non-uniform data cause boundary samples to be perturbed by neighboring clusters, leading to unstable clustering. A group-level mechanism aims to stabilize boundaries and improve cluster integrity.

Method: Form groups of low-density boundary points and model interactions as gravity-based forces between groups and surrounding data, combining local density estimation with neighborhood topology. Groups are the basic motion units and a gravitational contraction ensures globally stable convergence.

Result: Empirical evaluation on multiple high-dimensional datasets shows GCAO beats 11 representative clustering methods, with average improvements of 37.13% (NMI), 52.08% (ARI), 44.98% (Homogeneity), and 38.81% (ACC), while maintaining competitive efficiency and scalability.

Conclusion: GCAO enhances boundary clarity and structural consistency, preserves cluster integrity in complex distributions, and offers robust performance for high-dimensional clustering through group-level, gravity-inspired dynamics.

Abstract: Traditional clustering algorithms often struggle with high-dimensional and
non-uniformly distributed data, where low-density boundary samples are easily
disturbed by neighboring clusters, leading to unstable and distorted clustering
results. To address this issue, we propose a Group-driven Clustering via
Gravitational Attraction and Optimization (GCAO) algorithm. GCAO introduces a
group-level optimization mechanism that aggregates low-density boundary points
into collaboratively moving groups, replacing the traditional point-based
contraction process. By combining local density estimation with neighborhood
topology, GCAO constructs effective gravitational interactions between groups
and their surroundings, enhancing boundary clarity and structural consistency.
Using groups as basic motion units, a gravitational contraction strategy
ensures globally stable and directionally consistent convergence. Experiments
on multiple high-dimensional datasets demonstrate that GCAO outperforms 11
representative clustering methods, achieving average improvements of 37.13%,
52.08%, 44.98%, and 38.81% in NMI, ARI, Homogeneity, and ACC, respectively,
while maintaining competitive efficiency and scalability. These results
highlight GCAO's superiority in preserving cluster integrity, enhancing
boundary separability, and ensuring robust performance on complex data
distributions.

</details>


### [394] [Toward Interpretable Evaluation Measures for Time Series Segmentation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23261)
*Félix Chavelli,Paul Boniol,Michaël Thomazo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes two novel evaluation metrics for time-series segmentation: WARI and SMS, addressing limitations of current measures by incorporating error position and type, with empirical validation on synthetic and real data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current metrics focus on change-point accuracy or point-based measures like ARI; they fail to capture segment quality, error nature, and interpretability. There is a need for measures that reflect segmentation quality more richly and provide actionable insights.

Method: Introduce WARI (Weighted Adjusted Rand Index) that weights segmentation errors by their positions; introduce SMS (State Matching Score) that identifies and scores four fundamental segmentation error types with customizable weighting; empirical validation on synthetic and real-world benchmarks.

Result: WARI and SMS provide more accurate assessment and reveal error provenance and types, offering insights inaccessible to traditional measures.

Conclusion: WARI and SMS enrich time-series segmentation evaluation, enabling nuanced error analysis and interpretation; they complement or surpass traditional measures.

Abstract: Time series segmentation is a fundamental task in analyzing temporal data
across various domains, from human activity recognition to energy monitoring.
While numerous state-of-the-art methods have been developed to tackle this
problem, the evaluation of their performance remains critically limited.
Existing measures predominantly focus on change point accuracy or rely on
point-based measures such as Adjusted Rand Index (ARI), which fail to capture
the quality of the detected segments, ignore the nature of errors, and offer
limited interpretability. In this paper, we address these shortcomings by
introducing two novel evaluation measures: WARI (Weighted Adjusted Rand Index),
that accounts for the position of segmentation errors, and SMS (State Matching
Score), a fine-grained measure that identifies and scores four fundamental
types of segmentation errors while allowing error-specific weighting. We
empirically validate WARI and SMS on synthetic and real-world benchmarks,
showing that they not only provide a more accurate assessment of segmentation
quality but also uncover insights, such as error provenance and type, that are
inaccessible with traditional measures.

</details>


### [395] [PAHQ: Accelerating Automated Circuit Discovery through Mixed-Precision Inference Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23264)
*Xinhai Wang,Shu Yang,Liangyu Wang,Lin Zhang,Huanyi Xie,Lijie Hu,Di Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A new training-free method, PAHQ, accelerates Automated Circuit Discovery (ACDC) by aligning activation patching with mixed-precision quantization to reduce runtime and memory while preserving interpretability faithfulness; it integrates with edge-based circuit discovery and is code-released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Automated Circuit Discovery is crucial for mechanistic interpretability but scales poorly to large language models due to heavy runtime and memory demands. Existing accelerations mostly rely on linear approximations, which degrade the faithfulness of the analysis.

Method: PAHQ optimizes the efficiency of each activation patching operation. It leverages an alignment between activation patching and mixed-precision quantization (MPQ): interpretability via patching acts like targeted ablation studies. High precision is kept for the components under investigation while precision elsewhere is reduced. The approach modifies the attention computation and is training-free, allowing integration with other edge-based circuit discovery techniques.

Result: PAHQ-accelerated ACDC reduces runtime by up to 80% and memory consumption by up to 30% compared to unaccelerated ACDC, while maintaining faithfulness. It readily integrates with existing edge-based circuit discovery methods by adjusting the attention mechanism. The method is training-free and practical, with code available at the provided GitHub URL.

Conclusion: PAHQ provides a practical and novel pathway for accelerating mechanistic interpretability methods, enabling scalable circuit discovery in large language models without sacrificing faithfulness; it complements existing edge-based techniques and can be adopted readily.

Abstract: Circuit discovery, which involves identifying sparse and task-relevant
subnetworks in pre-trained language models, is a cornerstone of mechanistic
interpretability. Automated Circuit Discovery (ACDC) has emerged as a pivotal
methodology in circuit discovery, but its application to large language models
is severely limited by computational inefficiency and prohibitively high memory
requirements. Although several accelerated approaches have been proposed, they
primarily rely on linear approximations to ACDC, which significantly
compromises analytical faithfulness. Our proposed method for accelerating
automated circuit discovery, Per Attention Head Quantization (PAHQ), takes a
fundamentally different approach by optimizing the efficiency of each
individual patching operation. PAHQ leverages a fundamental alignment between
activation patching and mixed-precision quantization (MPQ): interpretability
analysis through patching essentially performs targeted ablation studies.
Therefore, we can maintain high precision exclusively for investigated
components while safely reducing precision elsewhere in the network.
PAHQ-accelerated ACDC reduces runtime by up to 80\% and memory consumption by
up to 30\% compared to unaccelerated ACDC while maintaining faithfulness.
Importantly, our method readily integrates with existing edge-based circuit
discovery techniques by modifying the attention computation mechanism. This
training-free approach provides a practical and novel pathway for accelerating
mechanistic interpretability methods. Our code is available at
https://github.com/626619403/PAHQ.

</details>


### [396] [A Novel Framework for Multi-Modal Protein Representation Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23273)
*Runjie Zheng,Zhen Wang,Anjie Qiao,Jiancong Xie,Jiahua Rao,Yuedong Yang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: DAMPE is a two-part framework that aligns intrinsic multimodal embeddings with Optimal Transport and fuses them via Conditional Graph Generation to robustly predict protein function, addressing cross-modal mismatch and noisy graphs with theoretical guarantees and consistent gains on GO benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Protein function prediction benefits from integrating intrinsic signals (sequence/structure) with extrinsic contexts (PPIs, GO annotations), but cross-modal distributional mismatch and noisy relational graphs hinder fusion. A principled, scalable method is needed to align modalities and robustly fuse information.

Method: 1) OT-based alignment to map intrinsic embeddings from different modalities into a common space, reducing cross-modal heterogeneity. 2) Conditional Graph Generation (CGG) to fuse aligned intrinsic embeddings by conditioning a graph generator, with a condition encoder that learns graph-aware protein representations. Theoretical analysis shows the CGG objective helps the condition encoder absorb graph-aware knowledge.

Result: DAMPE matches or outperforms state-of-the-art methods (e.g., DPFunc) on standard GO benchmarks, with AUPR gains of 0.002–0.013 pp and Fmax gains of 0.004–0.007 pp. Ablations show OT alignment contributes 0.043–0.064 pp AUPR, while CGG fusion adds 0.005–0.111 pp Fmax.

Conclusion: DAMPE provides a scalable, theoretically grounded framework for robust multi-modal protein representation learning, delivering improved protein function prediction by effectively aligning modalities and mitigating noisy extrinsic graphs.

Abstract: Accurate protein function prediction requires integrating heterogeneous
intrinsic signals (e.g., sequence and structure) with noisy extrinsic contexts
(e.g., protein-protein interactions and GO term annotations). However, two key
challenges hinder effective fusion: (i) cross-modal distributional mismatch
among embeddings produced by pre-trained intrinsic encoders, and (ii) noisy
relational graphs of extrinsic data that degrade GNN-based information
aggregation. We propose Diffused and Aligned Multi-modal Protein Embedding
(DAMPE), a unified framework that addresses these through two core mechanisms.
First, we propose Optimal Transport (OT)-based representation alignment that
establishes correspondence between intrinsic embedding spaces of different
modalities, effectively mitigating cross-modal heterogeneity. Second, we
develop a Conditional Graph Generation (CGG)-based information fusion method,
where a condition encoder fuses the aligned intrinsic embeddings to provide
informative cues for graph reconstruction. Meanwhile, our theoretical analysis
implies that the CGG objective drives this condition encoder to absorb
graph-aware knowledge into its produced protein representations. Empirically,
DAMPE outperforms or matches state-of-the-art methods such as DPFunc on
standard GO benchmarks, achieving AUPR gains of 0.002-0.013 pp and Fmax gains
0.004-0.007 pp. Ablation studies further show that OT-based alignment
contributes 0.043-0.064 pp AUPR, while CGG-based fusion adds 0.005-0.111 pp
Fmax. Overall, DAMPE offers a scalable and theoretically grounded approach for
robust multi-modal protein representation learning, substantially enhancing
protein function prediction.

</details>


### [397] [Learning from Frustration: Torsor CNNs on Graphs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23288)
*Daiyuan Li,Shreya Arya,Robert Ghrist*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes Torsor CNNs for graphs with local symmetries, tying local frame changes to edge potentials; provides a torsor conv layer and a frustration loss; unifies CNNs and Gauge CNNs; validated on multi-view 3D recognition.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Global-symmetry-only equivariant networks miss domains with local symmetries; a framework is needed to learn on graphs where local coordinate frames vary.

Method: Represent local frame relations with group-valued edge potentials; show equivalence to group synchronization; implement a Torsor Convolutional Layer that is provably equivariant to local coordinate changes; introduce frustration loss as a geometric regularizer; generalize to arbitrary graphs without requiring a global coordinate system or smooth manifold structure; connect to existing architectures like Gauge CNNs and classical CNNs.

Result: Established the mathematical foundations; derived a practical Torsor Convolutional Layer and a standalone frustration loss; shows a unified view of CNNs and Gauge CNNs; demonstrated applicability to multi-view 3D recognition where relative camera poses define edge potentials.

Conclusion: Modeling local symmetries via torsors enables equivariant learning on graphs without a global coordinate system, unifying and extending existing symmetry-aware architectures; broad applicability to domains with local frame changes (e.g., multi-view 3D recognition).

Abstract: Most equivariant neural networks rely on a single global symmetry, limiting
their use in domains where symmetries are instead local. We introduce Torsor
CNNs, a framework for learning on graphs with local symmetries encoded as edge
potentials -- group-valued transformations between neighboring coordinate
frames. We establish that this geometric construction is fundamentally
equivalent to the classical group synchronization problem, yielding: (1) a
Torsor Convolutional Layer that is provably equivariant to local changes in
coordinate frames, and (2) the frustration loss -- a standalone geometric
regularizer that encourages locally equivariant representations when added to
any NN's training objective. The Torsor CNN framework unifies and generalizes
several architectures -- including classical CNNs and Gauge CNNs on manifolds
-- by operating on arbitrary graphs without requiring a global coordinate
system or smooth manifold structure. We establish the mathematical foundations
of this framework and demonstrate its applicability to multi-view 3D
recognition, where relative camera poses naturally define the required edge
potentials.

</details>


### [398] [Predicting symbolic ODEs from multiple trajectories](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23295)
*Yakup Emre Şahin,Niki Kilbertus,Sören Becker*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A transformer-based MIO with MIL aggregates multiple observed trajectories to infer symbolic ODEs, improving generalization across dimensions and noise, and outperforming baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To recover underlying symbolic dynamical equations from multiple observations of the same system, leveraging repeated trajectories to enhance generalization.

Method: Combines transformer-based symbolic regression with multiple-instance learning; explores aggregation strategies (notably mean pooling) to fuse information from multiple trajectories; evaluated on 1–4D systems under varying noise.

Result: Outperforms existing baselines across tested dimensions and noise levels; simple mean aggregation yields substantial performance gains.

Conclusion: Leveraging repeated observations via MIL and simple aggregation in a transformer-based symbolic regressor yields robust, generalizable inference of ODE dynamics across modestly different system sizes and noise regimes.

Abstract: We introduce MIO, a transformer-based model for inferring symbolic ordinary
differential equations (ODEs) from multiple observed trajectories of a
dynamical system. By combining multiple instance learning with
transformer-based symbolic regression, the model effectively leverages repeated
observations of the same system to learn more generalizable representations of
the underlying dynamics. We investigate different instance aggregation
strategies and show that even simple mean aggregation can substantially boost
performance. MIO is evaluated on systems ranging from one to four dimensions
and under varying noise levels, consistently outperforming existing baselines.

</details>


### [399] [Towards Scaling Deep Neural Networks with Predictive Coding: Theory and Practice](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23323)
*Francesco Innocenti*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: This thesis analyzes predictive coding networks (PCNs) as optimization-based learning, reveals a trust-region–like learning dynamic using first-order updates, extends to higher-order information making learning landscapes more benign than MSE, and introduces muPC to train very deep networks with little tuning, while noting hardware co-design is needed for scale.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: BP is energy-inefficient and biologically implausible; PC offers a brain-inspired alternative. The work aims to understand PCN inference/learning, scale PCNs, and assess their practicality for deep networks.

Method: Theoretical analysis grounded in optimization theory showing PC learning behaves like an approximate trust-region method using second-order information; demonstration that PC can leverage higher-order information to create more favorable loss landscapes; introduction of muPC parameterization to enable stable training of 100+ layer PCNs.

Result: PC learning dynamics can be interpreted as an approximate trust-region method; higher-order information can further improve the effective landscape, making PC more robust to vanishing gradients; muPC enables stable training of very deep PCNs (100+ layers) with minimal tuning and competitive performance on simple tasks.

Conclusion: This work advances fundamental understanding of PCN inference and learning and highlights the need for hardware co-design to scale PC-based training to compete with backpropagation.

Abstract: Backpropagation (BP) is the standard algorithm for training the deep neural
networks that power modern artificial intelligence including large language
models. However, BP is energy inefficient and unlikely to be implemented by the
brain. This thesis studies an alternative, potentially more efficient
brain-inspired algorithm called predictive coding (PC). Unlike BP, PC networks
(PCNs) perform inference by iterative equilibration of neuron activities before
learning or weight updates. Recent work has suggested that this iterative
inference procedure provides a range of benefits over BP, such as faster
training. However, these advantages have not been consistently observed, the
inference and learning dynamics of PCNs are still poorly understood, and deep
PCNs remain practically untrainable. Here, we make significant progress towards
scaling PCNs by taking a theoretical approach grounded in optimisation theory.
First, we show that the learning dynamics of PC can be understood as an
approximate trust-region method using second-order information, despite
explicitly using only first-order local updates. Second, going beyond this
approximation, we show that PC can in principle make use of arbitrarily
higher-order information, such that for feedforward networks the effective
landscape on which PC learns is far more benign and robust to vanishing
gradients than the (mean squared error) loss landscape. Third, motivated by a
study of the inference dynamics of PCNs, we propose a new parameterisation
called ``$\mu$PC'', which for the first time allows stable training of 100+
layer networks with little tuning and competitive performance on simple tasks.
Overall, this thesis significantly advances our fundamental understanding of
the inference and learning dynamics of PCNs, while highlighting the need for
future research to focus on hardware co-design if PC is to compete with BP at
scale.

</details>


### [400] [GRAD: Real-Time Gated Recurrent Anomaly Detection in Autonomous Vehicle Sensors Using Reinforced EMA and Multi-Stage Sliding Window Techniques](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23327)
*Mohammad Hossein Jafari Naeimi,Ali Norouzi,Athena Abdi*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: GRAD is a real-time anomaly detection framework for autonomous vehicle sensor data that combines Reinforced Exponential Moving Average (REMA) with Multi-Stage Sliding Window (MS-SW) and a lightweight two-layer GRU, plus a recovery module; it achieves high accuracy and low overhead.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Ensure reliable, safe autonomous vehicle operation by detecting and classifying sensor anomalies in real time, while minimizing computational cost.

Method: Integrates REMA for adaptive smoothing and outlier thresholding, MS-SW to capture short- and long-term patterns, and a lightweight two-layer GRU for anomaly detection/classification by bias type.
