Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Proposes a robotic-stirring approach with trajectory optimization and adaptive-speed control to improve pest counting in yellow water traps by reducing occlusions and enabling more reliable detections.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Occlusion in image-based pest counting and the need for accurate density estimation in water traps. Stirring can redistribute pests to reveal occluded individuals. The work seeks optimal stirring trajectories and adaptive stirring speed to enhance counting reliability.

Method: An automated stirring system using a robotic arm is used to stir yellow water traps. Six trajectories (circle, square, triangle, spiral, four small circles, random lines) are tested to assess their impact on counting accuracy and confidence across pest densities. The best trajectory is selected. A counting-confidence-driven closed-loop control adjusts stirring speed based on frame-to-frame changes in counting confidence.

Result: Experimental results (not fully disclosed in the abstract) indicate that stirring trajectory affects counting performance; the optimal trajectory improves counting accuracy and confidence. The proposed adaptive-speed stirring via a closed-loop control further enhances robustness across densities.

Conclusion: This appears to be the first study to examine how stirring trajectories influence object counting in a dynamic liquid environment and to implement adaptive-speed stirring for this task. The approach offers promise for more reliable pest counting in precision agriculture, with future work needed to provide detailed quantitative results and real-world validation.

Abstract: Accurate monitoring of pest population dynamics is crucial for informed
decision-making in precision agriculture. Currently, mainstream image-based
pest counting methods primarily rely on image processing combined with machine
learning or deep learning for pest counting. However, these methods have
limitations and struggle to handle situations involving pest occlusion. To
address this issue, this paper proposed a robotic stirring method with
trajectory optimization and adaptive speed control for accurate pest counting
in water traps. First, we developed an automated stirring system for pest
counting in yellow water traps based on a robotic arm. Stirring alters the
distribution of pests in the yellow water trap, making some of the occluded
individuals visible for detection and counting. Then, we investigated the
impact of different stirring trajectories on pest counting performance and
selected the optimal trajectory for pest counting. Specifically, we designed
six representative stirring trajectories, including circle, square, triangle,
spiral, four small circles, and random lines, for the robotic arm to stir. And
by comparing the overall average counting error and counting confidence of
different stirring trajectories across various pest density scenarios, we
determined the optimal trajectory. Finally, we proposed a counting
confidence-driven closed-loop control system to achieve adaptive-speed
stirring. It uses changes in pest counting confidence between consecutive
frames as feedback to adjust the stirring speed. To the best of our knowledge,
this is the first study dedicated to investigating the effects of different
stirring trajectories on object counting in the dynamic liquid environment and
to implement adaptive-speed stirring for this type of task. Experimental
results show ...

</details>


### [511] [Force-Displacement Profiling for Robot-Assisted Deployment of a Left Atrial Appendage Occluder Using FBG-EM Distal Sensing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21734)
*Giovanni Battista Regazzo,Wim-Alexander Beckers,Xuan Thao Ha,Mouloud Ourak,Johan Vlekken,Emmanuel Vander Poorten*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A force-sensing, EM-tracked catheter for left atrial appendage occluder deployment enables radiation-free, real-time force and position sensing in a phantom, with a new force-displacement profiling method to characterize deployment steps and reduce tissue stress.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Atrial fibrillation increases stroke risk; LAAC reduces this risk, but current deployment relies on imaging with limitations (radiation, precision). The study aims to provide real-time, non-radiative feedback via force sensing and EM tracking to improve deployment accuracy and safety.

Method: Use a force-sensing delivery sheath with fiber Bragg gratings at the catheter–occluder interface, combined with electromagnetic tracking. Deploy the occluder in an anatomical phantom and develop a force-displacement profiling method to characterize deployment dynamics without ionizing radiation.

Result: Demonstrated real-time measurement of interaction forces and catheter tip position. The force profiles indicate low-magnitude forces, suggesting minimal mechanical stress on surrounding tissue, and reveal deployment dynamics. The approach provides enhanced intraoperative feedback in a radiation-free manner.

Conclusion: The sensing strategy shows promise for improving LAAC deployment outcomes and intraoperative feedback. Future work includes automating deployment-step classification and validating the method in dynamic, realistic environments.

Abstract: Atrial fibrillation (AF) increases the risk of thromboembolic events due to
impaired function of the left atrial appendage (LAA). Left atrial appendage
closure (LAAC) is a minimally invasive intervention designed to reduce stroke
risk by sealing the LAA with an expandable occluder device. Current deployment
relies on manual catheter control and imaging modalities like fluoroscopy and
transesophageal echocardiography, which carry limitations including radiation
exposure and limited positioning precision. In this study, we leverage a
previously developed force-sensing delivery sheath integrating fiber Bragg
gratings (FBGs) at the interface between the catheter and the occluder.
Combined with electromagnetic (EM) tracking, this setup enables real-time
measurement of interaction forces and catheter tip position during
robot-assisted LAAC deployment in an anatomical phantom. We present a novel
force-displacement profiling method that characterizes occluder deployment
dynamics and identifies key procedural steps without relying on ionizing
radiation. The force profiles reveal low-magnitude interaction forces,
suggesting minimal mechanical stress on the surrounding anatomy. This approach
shows promise in providing clinicians with enhanced intraoperative feedback,
improving deployment outcome. Future work will focus on automating deployment
steps classification and validating the sensing strategy in dynamic, realistic
environments.

</details>


### [512] [A phase-aware AI car-following model for electric vehicles with adaptive cruise control: Development and validation using real-world data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21735)
*Yuhui Liu,Shian Wang,Ansel Panicker,Kate Embry,Ayana Asanova,Tianyi Li*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Phase-Aware AI car-following (PAAI) model for EVs that blends physics-based car-following with AI to handle acceleration and regenerative braking phases; validated on ACC trajectory data showing improved predictive accuracy over traditional models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: EVs exhibit distinct driving dynamics not well captured by ICE-focused models; need an accurate, user-friendly analytic framework to model EV car-following for traffic simulations as EV adoption grows.

Method: Develop PAAI by integrating AI to recognize driving phases into a traditional physics-based car-following framework; train/validate using real-world ACC-equipped vehicle trajectory data; conduct simulations to compare prediction accuracy against traditional models.

Result: PAAI significantly improves prediction accuracy over traditional car-following models in validations with real-world data and simulations.

Conclusion: The PAAI model provides an effective, adaptable tool for representing EV behavior in traffic simulations, enabling more accurate modeling of EV dynamics in mixed traffic.

Abstract: Internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles and electric vehicles (EVs) exhibit
distinct vehicle dynamics. EVs provide rapid acceleration, with electric motors
producing peak power across a wider speed range, and achieve swift deceleration
through regenerative braking. While existing microscopic models effectively
capture the driving behavior of ICE vehicles, a modeling framework that
accurately describes the unique car-following dynamics of EVs is lacking.
Developing such a model is essential given the increasing presence of EVs in
traffic, yet creating an easy-to-use and accurate analytical model remains
challenging.
  To address these gaps, this study develops and validates a Phase-Aware AI
(PAAI) car-following model specifically for EVs. The proposed model enhances
traditional physics-based frameworks with an AI component that recognizes and
adapts to different driving phases, such as rapid acceleration and regenerative
braking. Using real-world trajectory data from vehicles equipped with adaptive
cruise control (ACC), we conduct comprehensive simulations to validate the
model's performance. The numerical results demonstrate that the PAAI model
significantly improves prediction accuracy over traditional car-following
models, providing an effective tool for accurately representing EV behavior in
traffic simulations.

</details>


### [513] [Learn2Drive: A neural network-based framework for socially compliant automated vehicle control](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21736)
*Yuhui Liu,Samannita Halder,Shian Wang,Tianyi Li*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A neural network–based, socially compliant ACC using LSTM and physics-informed constraints with social value orientation (SVO) to regulate traffic through AVs, aiming to reduce congestion and energy use while balancing individual and traffic-flow objectives.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current AV/ACC controllers mainly optimize individual vehicle performance or platoon metrics and largely ignore interactions with human-driven vehicles (HVs) and broader traffic dynamics, potentially causing congestion and inefficiency.

Method: An LSTM-based ACC integrated with physics-informed constraints and SVO. Utility functions for AVs and HVs are defined and optimized according to each AV's SVO to balance self-objectives with traffic-flow considerations. AVs act as mobile traffic regulators to influence HVs and overall flow, with simulations across varying conditions.

Result: Numerical results show the framework adapts to traffic conditions and enhances system-wide efficiency. When switching from energy-focused control to traffic-flow-focused control, following platoon members exhibit ~58.99% higher energy consumption and ~38.39% faster average speed, illustrating a trade-off between energy use and throughput.

Conclusion: The framework demonstrates the feasibility of socially-aware AV control using LSTM and physics-informed constraints to regulate traffic, improving efficiency and offering a tunable trade-off between energy consumption and traffic-flow performance.

Abstract: This study introduces a novel control framework for adaptive cruise control
(ACC) in automated driving, leveraging Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks
and physics-informed constraints. As automated vehicles (AVs) adopt advanced
features like ACC, transportation systems are becoming increasingly intelligent
and efficient. However, existing AV control strategies primarily focus on
optimizing the performance of individual vehicles or platoons, often neglecting
their interactions with human-driven vehicles (HVs) and the broader impact on
traffic flow. This oversight can exacerbate congestion and reduce overall
system efficiency. To address this critical research gap, we propose a neural
network-based, socially compliant AV control framework that incorporates social
value orientation (SVO). This framework enables AVs to account for their
influence on HVs and traffic dynamics. By leveraging AVs as mobile traffic
regulators, the proposed approach promotes adaptive driving behaviors that
reduce congestion, improve traffic efficiency, and lower energy consumption.
Within this framework, we define utility functions for both AVs and HVs, which
are optimized based on the SVO of each AV to balance its own control objectives
with broader traffic flow considerations. Numerical results demonstrate the
effectiveness of the proposed method in adapting to varying traffic conditions,
thereby enhancing system-wide efficiency. Specifically, when the AV's control
mode shifts from prioritizing energy consumption to optimizing traffic flow
efficiency, vehicles in the following platoon experience at least a 58.99%
increase in individual energy consumption alongside at least a 38.39%
improvement in individual average speed, indicating significant enhancements in
traffic dynamics.

</details>


### [514] [Next-Generation LLM for UAV: From Natural Language to Autonomous Flight](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21739)
*Liangqi Yuan,Chuhao Deng,Dong-Jun Han,Inseok Hwang,Sabine Brunswicker,Christopher G. Brinton*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Proposes NeLV, a five-component LLM-driven architecture to orchestrate multi-scale UAV missions and a five-level automation taxonomy toward autonomous LLM-based autopilots, demonstrated on three use cases.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To bridge the gap between advancing LLM capabilities and real-world, medium- to long-range UAV operations that must meet safety, regulatory, and multi-scale mission demands.

Method: NeLV consists of five components: LLM-as-Parser, Route Planner (POIs), Path Planner (waypoints), Control Platform (trajectory execution), and UAV monitoring. The authors also introduce a five-level automation taxonomy (Levels 1–5) and demonstrate feasibility with three use cases: multi-UAV patrol, multi-POI delivery, and multi-hop relocation.

Result: Feasibility demonstrated through representative use cases and a staged automation taxonomy. The work outlines technical prerequisites and challenges at each level, providing a roadmap rather than a fully autonomous system.

Conclusion: The paper offers a comprehensive roadmap and architecture for integrating LLMs into multi-scale UAV operations, identifying key research challenges and prerequisites for progressing from LLM-assisted parsing to fully autonomous, LLM-driven autopilots.

Abstract: With the rapid advancement of Large Language Models (LLMs), their
capabilities in various automation domains, particularly Unmanned Aerial
Vehicle (UAV) operations, have garnered increasing attention. Current research
remains predominantly constrained to small-scale UAV applications, with most
studies focusing on isolated components such as path planning for toy drones,
while lacking comprehensive investigation of medium- and long-range UAV systems
in real-world operational contexts. Larger UAV platforms introduce distinct
challenges, including stringent requirements for airport-based take-off and
landing procedures, adherence to complex regulatory frameworks, and specialized
operational capabilities with elevated mission expectations. This position
paper presents the Next-Generation LLM for UAV (NeLV) system -- a comprehensive
demonstration and automation roadmap for integrating LLMs into multi-scale UAV
operations. The NeLV system processes natural language instructions to
orchestrate short-, medium-, and long-range UAV missions through five key
technical components: (i) LLM-as-Parser for instruction interpretation, (ii)
Route Planner for Points of Interest (POI) determination, (iii) Path Planner
for waypoint generation, (iv) Control Platform for executable trajectory
implementation, and (v) UAV monitoring. We demonstrate the system's feasibility
through three representative use cases spanning different operational scales:
multi-UAV patrol, multi-POI delivery, and multi-hop relocation. Beyond the
current implementation, we establish a five-level automation taxonomy that
charts the evolution from current LLM-as-Parser capabilities (Level 1) to fully
autonomous LLM-as-Autopilot systems (Level 5), identifying technical
prerequisites and research challenges at each stage.

</details>


### [515] [FORGE-Tree: Diffusion-Forcing Tree Search for Long-Horizon Robot Manipulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21744)
*Yanjia Huang,Shuo Liu,Sheng Liu,Qingxiao Xu,Mingyang Wu,Xiangbo Gao,Zhengzhong Tu*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: FORGE-Tree introduces a plug-in, segment-aware refinement via diffusion forcing and Monte Carlo Tree Diffusion for long-horizon VLA policies, enabling localized denoising with adjustable compute.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Long-horizon manipulation tasks in VLA policies suffer from drift and exposure bias. Fixed denoising hyperparameters cause small geometric errors to accumulate and prevent allocating extra test-time compute where tight clearances exist.

Method: Introduce FORGE-Tree: a plug-in control layer that couples a stage-aligned Diffusion Forcing (DF) head with test-time Monte Carlo Tree Diffusion (MCTD). Freeze the VLA encoder; align timesteps to subtask stages; during inference, partially denoise only a target segment while keeping other tokens frozen; apply Monte Carlo Tree Diffusion to select the next segment to refine; use a scene graph to provide priors for expansion and geometry-aware scoring for rollouts; yields tree-structured denoising that scales with search budget while preserving the executed prefix.

Result: On LIBERO, FORGE-Tree improves success rate by 13.4 to 17.2 percentage points over native VLA baselines with OpenVLA and Octo-Base. Gains remain consistent under comparable compute budgets, especially on long-horizon variants.

Conclusion: FORGE-Tree effectively couples diffusion-based segment refinement with search to mitigate drift and exposure bias in long-horizon VLA tasks, yielding scalable gains with search budget while preserving the trajectory prefix.

Abstract: Long-horizon robot manipulation tasks remain challenging for
Vision-Language-Action (VLA) policies due to drift and exposure bias, often
denoise the entire trajectory with fixed hyperparameters, causing small
geometric errors to compound across stages and offering no mechanism to
allocate extra test-time compute where clearances are tight. To address these
challenges, we introduce FORGE-Tree, a plug-in control layer that couples a
stage-aligned Diffusion Forcing (DF) head with test-time Monte Carlo Tree
Diffusion (MCTD). With a frozen VLA encoder, DF aligns timesteps to subtask
stages; during inference we partially denoise only a target segment while
keeping other tokens frozen, turning trajectory refinement into a sequence of
local edits. We then apply Monte Carlo Tree Diffusion to select the next
segment to refine. A scene graph supplies priors for expansion and geometry
relation-aware scoring for rollouts, yielding tree-structured denoising whose
performance scales with search budget while preserving the executed prefix.
Evaluation on LIBERO, FORGE-Tree improves success rate by 13.4 to 17.2 pp over
the native VLA baselines with both OpenVLA and Octo-Base. Gains remain
consistent under comparable compute budgets, especially on long-horizon
variants. Videos available at: https://taco-group.github.io/FORGE-Tree/

</details>


### [516] [Avi: Action from Volumetric Inference](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21746)
*Harris Song,Long Le*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Avi reframes robotic action generation as 3D perception and spatial reasoning, using 3D point clouds and language-grounded scene understanding to compute actions via classical geometric transformations, without training on previous action tokens, leveraging a 3D multi-modal LLM to predict the next point cloud; preliminary results suggest robust, viewpoint-invariant behavior.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing VLA models rely on 2D inputs and end-to-end policy learning, which can be brittle under occlusions and viewpoint changes. There is a need to ground actions in 3D geometry and language for robust, generalizable robotic behavior.

Method: The architecture uses 3D point clouds and language-grounded scene understanding to perform action computation through classical geometric transformations. It does not train on previous action tokens; instead it uses a 3D Multi-modal Large Language Model to generate the next point cloud and derives actions via explicit geometric operations, effectively treating decision-making as 3D structured reasoning.

Result: Preliminary results indicate potential for scalable, robust robotic systems, with claimed advantages in occlusion robustness and viewpoint invariance; evaluation details are not provided in the abstract.

Conclusion: Viewing robotic decision-making as 3D vision-language reasoning can provide a scalable foundation that bridges high-level language instructions and low-level actuation without opaque policy learning.

Abstract: We propose Avi, a novel 3D Vision-Language-Action (VLA) architecture that
reframes robotic action generation as a problem of 3D perception and spatial
reasoning, rather than low-level policy learning. While existing VLA models
primarily operate on 2D visual inputs and are trained end-to-end on
task-specific action policies, Avi leverages 3D point clouds and
language-grounded scene understanding to compute actions through classical
geometric transformations. Most notably, Avi does not train on previous action
tokens, rather, we build upon a 3D Multi-modal Large Language Model (MLLM) to
generate the next point cloud and explicitly calculate the actions through
classical transformations. This approach enables generalizable behaviors that
are robust to occlusions, camera pose variations, and changes in viewpoint. By
treating the robotic decision-making process as a structured reasoning task
over 3D representations, Avi bridges the gap between high-level language
instructions and low-level actuation without requiring opaque policy learning.
Our preliminary results highlight the potential of 3D vision-language reasoning
as a foundation for scalable, robust robotic systems. Check it out at
https://avi-3drobot.github.io/.

</details>


### [517] [Real-time Mixed-Integer Quadratic Programming for Driving Behavior-Inspired Speed Bump Optimal Trajectory Planning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21751)
*Van Nam Dinh,Van Vy Phan,Thai Son Dang,Van Du Phan,The Anh Mai,Van Chuong Le,Sy Phuong Ho,Dinh Tu Duong,Hung Cuong Ta*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A unified MIQP-based MPC framework for autonomous-vehicle trajectory planning that explicitly handles speed bumps to mimic human driving, achieving smooth transitions and real-time performance in urban scenarios.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Urban driving requires safe, comfortable trajectories that navigate speed bumps and complex road features while remaining computationally tractable for real-time control. Existing methods often treat feature handling separately or fail to capture human-like behavior within a single optimization.

Method: Formulate a Model Predictive Control problem with a Mixed-Integer Quadratic Programming structure that includes speed-bump handling constraints (designed to resemble human braking/acceleration patterns) alongside broader road navigation constraints. Solve in a receding horizon to generate smooth, comfortable trajectories with real-time feasibility.

Result: Simulations across varied urban environments show smooth speed profiles over speed bumps, maintained passenger comfort, and computational efficiency compatible with real-time deployment. The framework can handle both static features and dynamic constraints, aligning with expert human driving in tested scenarios.

Conclusion: The paper advances urban AV trajectory planning by integrating speed-bump handling into a single MIQP-MPC framework, delivering comfort, safety, and real-time performance, and representing a step toward closer imitation of human driving in complex urban settings.

Abstract: This paper proposes a novel methodology for trajectory planning in autonomous
vehicles (AVs), addressing the complex challenge of negotiating speed bumps
within a unified Mixed-Integer Quadratic Programming (MIQP) framework. By
leveraging Model Predictive Control (MPC), we develop trajectories that
optimize both the traversal of speed bumps and overall passenger comfort. A key
contribution of this work is the formulation of speed bump handling constraints
that closely emulate human driving behavior, seamlessly integrating these with
broader road navigation requirements. Through extensive simulations in varied
urban driving environments, we demonstrate the efficacy of our approach,
highlighting its ability to ensure smooth speed transitions over speed bumps
while maintaining computational efficiency suitable for real-time deployment.
The method's capability to handle both static road features and dynamic
constraints, alongside expert human driving, represents a significant step
forward in trajectory planning for urban

</details>


### [518] [Taxonomy and Trends in Reinforcement Learning for Robotics and Control Systems: A Structured Review](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21758)
*Kumater Ter,RexCharles Donatus,Ore-Ofe Ajayi,Daniel Udekwe*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A comprehensive survey linking reinforcement learning (RL) and deep RL (DRL) to robotics practice, outlining fundamentals, key algorithms, a domain taxonomy, training and deployment considerations, and maturation trends toward real-world autonomous systems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To synthesize theoretical advances in RL/DRL with practical robotic applications, addressing deployment challenges and providing a unified perspective for researchers and practitioners.

Method: Systematic literature review and synthesis. The paper presents the MDP formalism, core RL strategies (actor-critic, value-based, policy gradient), highlights modern DRL methods (DDPG, TD3, PPO, SAC), and introduces a taxonomy of robotic applications (locomotion, manipulation, multi-agent coordination, human-robot interaction) along with training and deployment readiness considerations.

Result: A structured taxonomy and consolidated perspective that connects theory to practice. The review identifies design patterns, technical trends, and the growing maturity of RL in real-world robotics, offering guidance for bridging research and real deployments.

Conclusion: RL and DRL are maturing as enabling technologies for autonomous robotics. The review emphasizes bridging theory with practice through considered training methodologies and deployment readiness, providing a roadmap for future work and adoption in robots.

Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has become a foundational approach for enabling
intelligent robotic behavior in dynamic and uncertain environments. This work
presents an in-depth review of RL principles, advanced deep reinforcement
learning (DRL) algorithms, and their integration into robotic and control
systems. Beginning with the formalism of Markov Decision Processes (MDPs), the
study outlines essential elements of the agent-environment interaction and
explores core algorithmic strategies including actor-critic methods,
value-based learning, and policy gradients. Emphasis is placed on modern DRL
techniques such as DDPG, TD3, PPO, and SAC, which have shown promise in solving
high-dimensional, continuous control tasks. A structured taxonomy is introduced
to categorize RL applications across domains such as locomotion, manipulation,
multi-agent coordination, and human-robot interaction, along with training
methodologies and deployment readiness levels. The review synthesizes recent
research efforts, highlighting technical trends, design patterns, and the
growing maturity of RL in real-world robotics. Overall, this work aims to
bridge theoretical advances with practical implementations, providing a
consolidated perspective on the evolving role of RL in autonomous robotic
systems.

</details>


### [519] [J-ORA: A Framework and Multimodal Dataset for Japanese Object Identification, Reference, Action Prediction in Robot Perception](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21761)
*Jesse Atuhurra,Hidetaka Kamigaito,Taro Watanabe,Koichiro Yoshino*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Introduces J-ORA, a Japanese human-robot dialogue multimodal dataset with rich object-attribute annotations to improve perception tasks; evaluation with VLMs shows attributes help, but gaps remain between proprietary and open-source models; analysis of affordances across VLMs; project page provided.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Robot perception in dynamic environments and dialogue interactions requires explicit, context-sensitive object attributes; current VLMs have limitations, especially in Japanese dialogue contexts; bridging gap between perception tasks.

Method: Construct J-ORA with templates for attributes (category, color, shape, size, material, spatial relations) integrated into dialogue-driven scenarios; evaluate using proprietary and open-source VLMs on object identification, reference resolution, and next-action prediction; analyze object affordances to assess functionality contextual reasoning.

Result: Detailed attributes substantially improve multimodal perception performance versus attribute-absent baselines; still a performance gap between proprietary and open-source VLMs; affordance analysis shows varying abilities across models; highlights need for richer annotations.

Conclusion: Rich, context-sensitive object attributes are crucial for robust robot perception; J-ORA enables improved performance and motivates further work to close VLM gaps; project page link provided.

Abstract: We introduce J-ORA, a novel multimodal dataset that bridges the gap in robot
perception by providing detailed object attribute annotations within Japanese
human-robot dialogue scenarios. J-ORA is designed to support three critical
perception tasks, object identification, reference resolution, and next-action
prediction, by leveraging a comprehensive template of attributes (e.g.,
category, color, shape, size, material, and spatial relations). Extensive
evaluations with both proprietary and open-source Vision Language Models (VLMs)
reveal that incorporating detailed object attributes substantially improves
multimodal perception performance compared to without object attributes.
Despite the improvement, we find that there still exists a gap between
proprietary and open-source VLMs. In addition, our analysis of object
affordances demonstrates varying abilities in understanding object
functionality and contextual relationships across different VLMs. These
findings underscore the importance of rich, context-sensitive attribute
annotations in advancing robot perception in dynamic environments. See project
page at https://jatuhurrra.github.io/J-ORA/.

</details>


### [520] [Improving the performance of AI-powered Affordable Robotics for Assistive Tasks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21771)
*Dharunish Yugeswardeenoo*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A low-cost assistive robotic arm leverages imitation learning with a Phased Action Chunking Transformer (PACT) and Temporal Ensemble to achieve high accuracy with small models, enabling accessible assistance at scale.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Rising global demand for assistive care by 2050 outstrips caregiver supply; existing robotic solutions remain expensive and require technical expertise, limiting accessibility.

Method: Hardware: six servo motors, dual cameras, and 3D-printed dexterous grippers. Data collection via teleoperation with a leader arm, yielding 50,000 video frames across feeding, spill-cleaning, and medicine-fetching tasks. Learning pipeline uses imitation learning from demonstration videos (no task-specific programming or manual labeling). Introduced Phased Action Chunking Transformer (PACT) to capture temporal dependencies and segment motion dynamics, plus a Temporal Ensemble (TE) to refine trajectories for improved accuracy and smoothness. Evaluation across five model sizes and four architectures with ten hours of real-world testing. 

Result: Achieved over 90% task accuracy, outperforming baselines by up to 40%. PACT enabled a 5x reduction in model size while maintaining about 75% accuracy. Saliency analysis indicated reliance on key visual cues, and phase token gradients peaked at critical trajectory moments, suggesting effective temporal reasoning.

Conclusion: Future work will explore bimanual manipulation and mobility to expand assistive capabilities.

Abstract: By 2050, the global demand for assistive care is expected to reach 3.5
billion people, far outpacing the availability of human caregivers. Existing
robotic solutions remain expensive and require technical expertise, limiting
accessibility. This work introduces a low-cost robotic arm for assistive tasks
such as feeding, cleaning spills, and fetching medicine. The system uses
imitation learning from demonstration videos, requiring no task-specific
programming or manual labeling. The robot consists of six servo motors, dual
cameras, and 3D-printed grippers. Data collection via teleoperation with a
leader arm yielded 50,000 video frames across the three tasks. A novel Phased
Action Chunking Transformer (PACT) captures temporal dependencies and segments
motion dynamics, while a Temporal Ensemble (TE) method refines trajectories to
improve accuracy and smoothness. Evaluated across five model sizes and four
architectures, with ten hours of real-world testing, the system achieved over
90% task accuracy, up to 40% higher than baselines. PACT enabled a 5x model
size reduction while maintaining 75% accuracy. Saliency analysis showed
reliance on key visual cues, and phase token gradients peaked at critical
trajectory moments, indicating effective temporal reasoning. Future work will
explore bimanual manipulation and mobility for expanded assistive capabilities.

</details>


### [521] [Real-Time QP Solvers: A Concise Review and Practical Guide Towards Legged Robots](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21773)
*Van Nam Dinh*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Benchmarking study of QP solvers for legged robotics comparing interior-point, active-set, operator splitting, and augmented Lagrangian methods; provides guidance on solver choice for MPC and WBC on embedded platforms.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-time legged robotics relies on solving convex QPs within tight timing and energy constraints. Understanding how solvers perform on hardware and with problem structure is essential for reliable, agile locomotion.

Method: Classify four solver families; examine algorithmic structure, computational characteristics, and structure/warm-start capabilities; evaluate on public benchmarks using metrics like computation time, constraint satisfaction, robustness; produce feature tables; analyze synergies with task and hardware; discuss extensions to nonconvex/distributed QP.

Result: Trade-offs observed: sparse IPMs offer efficiency for long-horizon MPC; dense active-set methods excel for high-rate WBC; overall, solver performance depends on problem structure, warm-starting, and hardware; robustness and energy considerations noted; emerging extensions to nonconvex and distributed QP highlighted.

Conclusion: Provide practical guidelines for solver selection in agile legged systems, emphasizing matching solver to task and hardware; anticipate future directions in nonconvex and distributed QP.

Abstract: Quadratic programming (QP) underpins real-time robotics by enabling
efficient, constrained optimization in state estimation, motion planning, and
control. In legged locomotion and manipulation, essential modules like inverse
dynamics, Model Predictive Control (MPC), and Whole-Body Control (WBC) are
inherently QP-based, demanding reliable solutions amid tight timing, energy,
and computational limits on embedded platforms. This paper presents a
comprehensive analysis and benchmarking study of cutting-edge QP solvers for
legged robotics. We begin by formulating the standard convex QP and classify
solvers into four principal algorithmic approaches, including interior-point
methods, active-set strategies, operator splitting schemes, and augmented
Lagrangian approaches. Each solver is examined in terms of algorithmic
structure, computational characteristics, and its ability to exploit problem
structure and warm-starting. Performance is evaluated using publicly available
benchmarks, focusing on metrics such as computation time, constraint
satisfaction, and robustness under perturbations. Feature tables and
comparisons yield practical guidance for solver selection, underscoring
trade-offs in speed, accuracy, and energy efficiency. Our findings emphasize
the synergy between solver, task, and hardware, sparse IPMs for long-horizon
MPC, and dense active-set for high frequency WBC to advance agile, autonomous
legged systems, with emerging extensions to nonconvex and distributed QP.

</details>


### [522] [VITA-E: Natural Embodied Interaction with Concurrent Seeing, Hearing, Speaking, and Acting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21817)
*Xiaoyu Liu,Chaoyou Fu,Chi Yan,Chu Wu,Haihan Gao,Yi-Fan Zhang,Shaoqi Dong,Cheng Qian,Bin Luo,Xiuyong Yang,Guanwu Li,Yusheng Cai,Yunhang Shen,Deqiang Jiang,Haoyu Cao,Xing Sun,Caifeng Shan,Ran He*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: VITA-E introduces a dual-model VLA framework (Active and Standby) enabling concurrent perception, speech, and action with interruptibility, plus a model-as-controller mechanism for direct system commands; validated on a physical humanoid with high interruption handling.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current Vision-Language-Action models are rigid and fail to support concurrent sensing, speaking, acting, and real-time interruptions; this limits seamless embodied collaboration. The work aims to enable human-like multitasking and interruptible control in embodied agents.

Method: Proposes a dual-model architecture (Active Model and Standby Model) that run in parallel for observation, listening, speaking, and acting. Introduces a model-as-controller paradigm by fine-tuning the VLM to emit special tokens that act as system-level commands, thereby coupling reasoning with system behavior. Evaluates on a physical humanoid platform across complex interactive scenarios.

Result: Demonstrates extremely high success rates for emergency stops and speech interruptions while also enabling concurrent speech and action. The approach is compatible with various dual-system VLA models and improves natural, responsive embodied interaction.

Conclusion: VITA-E represents a significant advancement toward natural, capable embodied assistants by enabling concurrent perception, speech, and action with interruptibility and a tight model-system integration via special control tokens.

Abstract: Current Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models are often constrained by a rigid,
static interaction paradigm, which lacks the ability to see, hear, speak, and
act concurrently as well as handle real-time user interruptions dynamically.
This hinders seamless embodied collaboration, resulting in an inflexible and
unresponsive user experience. To address these limitations, we introduce
VITA-E, a novel embodied interaction framework designed for both behavioral
concurrency and nearly real-time interruption. The core of our approach is a
dual-model architecture where two parallel VLA instances operate as an ``Active
Model'' and a ``Standby Model'', allowing the embodied agent to observe its
environment, listen to user speech, provide verbal responses, and execute
actions, all concurrently and interruptibly, mimicking human-like multitasking
capabilities. We further propose a ``model-as-controller'' paradigm, where we
fine-tune the VLM to generate special tokens that serve as direct system-level
commands, coupling the model's reasoning with the system's behavior.
Experiments conducted on a physical humanoid platform demonstrate that VITA-E
can reliably handle complex interactive scenarios. Our framework is compatible
with various dual-system VLA models, achieving an extremely high success rate
on emergency stops and speech interruptions while also successfully performing
concurrent speech and action. This represents a significant step towards more
natural and capable embodied assistants.

</details>


### [523] [A Literature Review On Stewart-Gough Platform Calibrations A Literature Review On Stewart-Gough Platform Calibrations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21854)
*Sourabh Karmakar,Cameron J. Turner*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A survey of inverse-kinematics-based calibration for Stewart-Gough (hexapod) platforms, summarizing calibration methodologies, outcomes, and error considerations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To achieve micro/nano-level 3D motion accuracy in parallel robots across critical applications, necessitating robust calibration given the complexity of forward kinematics.

Method: Review and synthesis of various calibration techniques using external instruments, motion constraints, and extra sensors for auto/self-calibration; emphasis on inverse kinematics-based calibration and analysis of error sources.

Result: Consolidates state-of-the-art calibration methodologies, their outcomes, and important details; notes focus on reducing errors from one or multiple sources, predominantly considering kinematic and structural errors, with occasional environmental factors.

Conclusion: Inverse-kinematics-based calibration enhances platform position and orientation accuracy; most work is conducted under no-load conditions; highlights need for broader error modeling and consideration of loaded conditions in future research.

Abstract: Researchers have studied Stewart-Gough platforms, also known as Gough-Stewart
platforms or hexapod platforms extensively for their inherent fine control
characteristics. Their studies led to the potential deployment opportunities of
Stewart-Gough Platforms in many critical applications such as the medical
field, engineering machines, space research, electronic chip manufacturing,
automobile manufacturing, etc. Some of these applications need micro and
nano-level movement control in 3D space for the motions to be precise,
complicated, and repeatable; a Stewart-Gough platform fulfills these challenges
smartly. For this, the platform must be more accurate than the specified
application accuracy level and thus proper calibration for a parallel robot is
crucial. Forward kinematics-based calibration for these hexapod machines
becomes unnecessarily complex and inverse kinematics complete this task with
much ease. To experiment with different calibration techniques, various
calibration approaches were implemented by using external instruments,
constraining one or more motions of the system, and using extra sensors for
auto or self-calibration. This survey paid attention to those key
methodologies, their outcome, and important details related to inverse
kinematic-based parallel robot calibrations. It was observed during this study
that the researchers focused on improving the accuracy of the platform position
and orientation considering the errors contributed by one source or multiple
sources. The error sources considered are mainly kinematic and structural, in
some cases, environmental factors also are reviewed, however, those
calibrations are done under no-load conditions. This study aims to review the
present state of the art in this field and highlight the processes and errors
considered for the calibration of Stewart-Gough platforms.

</details>


### [524] [Butter-Bench: Evaluating LLM Controlled Robots for Practical Intelligence](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21860)
*Callum Sharrock,Lukas Petersson,Hanna Petersson,Axel Backlund,Axel Wennström,Kristoffer Nordström,Elias Aronsson*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Butter-Bench isolates LLM reasoning from low-level robotic control and shows LLMs lag humans in practical embodied tasks; particularly weak in multi-step spatial planning and social understanding; even embodied-reasoning fine-tuning does not improve scores.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Assess how well LLMs can handle practical intelligence in embodied robotics when the visual-language-action loop is decoupled, and quantify gaps relative to human performance.

Method: Introduce Butter-Bench benchmark evaluating the LLM component in isolation from Vision-Language-Action (VLA) control; compare performance of state-of-the-art LLMs (including those fine-tuned for embodied reasoning) against human baselines across tasks requiring planning and social understanding.

Result: LLMs score about 40% on Butter-Bench, while humans average around 95%; LLMs struggle most with multi-step spatial planning and social understanding; fine-tuning for embodied reasoning does not improve Butter-Bench scores.

Conclusion: LLMs remain far from human-level practical intelligence in embodied settings when decoupled from low-level control; current embodied-reasoning fine-tuning is insufficient under this benchmark; suggests need for better integration, reasoning capabilities, or training paradigms to close the gap.

Abstract: We present Butter-Bench, a benchmark evaluating large language model (LLM)
controlled robots for practical intelligence, defined as the ability to
navigate the messiness of the physical world. Current state-of-the-art robotic
systems use a hierarchical architecture with LLMs in charge of high-level
reasoning, and a Vision Language Action (VLA) model for low-level control.
Butter-Bench evaluates the LLM part in isolation from the VLA. Although LLMs
have repeatedly surpassed humans in evaluations requiring analytical
intelligence, we find humans still outperform LLMs on Butter-Bench. The best
LLMs score 40% on Butter-Bench, while the mean human score is 95%. LLMs
struggled the most with multi-step spatial planning and social understanding.
We also evaluate LLMs that are fine-tuned for embodied reasoning and conclude
that this training does not improve their score on Butter-Bench.

</details>


### [525] [A Physics-Informed Neural Network Approach for UAV Path Planning in Dynamic Environments](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21874)
*Shuning Zhang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A PINN-based UAV trajectory planner learns feasible, collision-free, energy-efficient paths under wind disturbances without labeled data, outperforming A* and Kino-RRT* in energy use, smoothness, and safety margins while maintaining efficiency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Traditional planners struggle with dynamic wind fields, discretization limits, and non-smooth paths, motivating a physics-informed, data-efficient approach that unifies model-based dynamics with learning.

Method: A physics-informed neural network encodes UAV dynamics, wind disturbances, and obstacle avoidance into the loss function, minimizes physics residuals and risk-aware objectives, and trains without supervised data to produce dynamically feasible, collision-free trajectories.

Result: Simulations show the PINN method outperforms A* and Kino-RRT* in control energy, trajectory smoothness, and safety margin, while achieving similar flight efficiency.

Conclusion: Physics-informed learning can unify model-based and data-driven planning, offering a scalable, physically consistent framework for UAV trajectory optimization under environmental disturbances.

Abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) operating in dynamic wind fields must
generate safe and energy-efficient trajectories under physical and
environmental constraints. Traditional planners, such as A* and kinodynamic
RRT*, often yield suboptimal or non-smooth paths due to discretization and
sampling limitations. This paper presents a physics-informed neural network
(PINN) framework that embeds UAV dynamics, wind disturbances, and obstacle
avoidance directly into the learning process. Without requiring supervised
data, the PINN learns dynamically feasible and collision-free trajectories by
minimizing physical residuals and risk-aware objectives. Comparative
simulations show that the proposed method outperforms A* and Kino-RRT* in
control energy, smoothness, and safety margin, while maintaining similar flight
efficiency. The results highlight the potential of physics-informed learning to
unify model-based and data-driven planning, providing a scalable and physically
consistent framework for UAV trajectory optimization.

</details>


### [526] [Two-Steps Diffusion Policy for Robotic Manipulation via Genetic Denoising](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.21991)
*Mateo Clemente,Leo Brunswic,Rui Heng Yang,Xuan Zhao,Yasser Khalil,Haoyu Lei,Amir Rasouli,Yinchuan Li*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Diffusion policies for robotic manipulation can work effectively with very few inference steps when the denoising process is tailored to the structured, low-dimensional action distributions of embodied AI tasks. The authors introduce genetic denoising, a population-based sampling method that selects trajectories with low out-of-distribution risk to improve performance and stability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Diffusion models adapted from vision tasks to control often transfer inference strategies without adaptation. Embodied AI tasks have structured, low-dimensional action spaces and require efficient, stable sampling. The work aims to close the gap by reducing inference steps and improving robustness.

Method: Introduce genetic denoising, a population-based sampling strategy that evolves denoising trajectories to minimize out-of-distribution risk. Demonstrate that diffusion policies can operate with as few as 5 neural function evaluations (NFE), and even 2 NFE on some tasks, across 14 robotic manipulation benchmarks from D4RL and Robomimic.

Result: Outperforms standard diffusion-based policies across the benchmarks, achieving up to 20% performance gains while using significantly fewer inference steps. Evaluated over 2 million total evaluations.

Conclusion: Tailoring the denoising process to embodied AI task characteristics enables efficient diffusion policies. The population-based genetic denoising approach improves performance and stability with fewer inference steps, suggesting diffusion models can be practical for real-time robotic manipulation.

Abstract: Diffusion models, such as diffusion policy, have achieved state-of-the-art
results in robotic manipulation by imitating expert demonstrations. While
diffusion models were originally developed for vision tasks like image and
video generation, many of their inference strategies have been directly
transferred to control domains without adaptation. In this work, we show that
by tailoring the denoising process to the specific characteristics of embodied
AI tasks -- particularly structured, low-dimensional nature of action
distributions -- diffusion policies can operate effectively with as few as 5
neural function evaluations (NFE).
  Building on this insight, we propose a population-based sampling strategy,
genetic denoising, which enhances both performance and stability by selecting
denoising trajectories with low out-of-distribution risk. Our method solves
challenging tasks with only 2 NFE while improving or matching performance. We
evaluate our approach across 14 robotic manipulation tasks from D4RL and
Robomimic, spanning multiple action horizons and inference budgets. In over 2
million evaluations, our method consistently outperforms standard
diffusion-based policies, achieving up to 20\% performance gains with
significantly fewer inference steps.

</details>


### [527] [Estimation of Minimum Stride Frequency for the Frontal Plane Stability of Bipedal Systems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22030)
*Harsha Karunanayaka,Siavash Rezazadeh*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Feeds forward stabilization (retraction/extension) can stabilize frontal-plane bipedal walking with hip offset without feedback control; the study links minimum stride frequency to mass, stiffness, leg length, hip width and natural frequency, offering a predictive method and validation on random models, to reduce control effort and improve robustness.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Understand how key physical parameters and the system's natural frequency affect frontal-plane stability and the minimum stride frequency needed to sustain stable gait; enable energy-efficient, robust locomotion via feedforward stabilization.

Method: Develop an analytical/framework to link model parameters (mass, stiffness, leg length, hip width) and natural frequency to a minimum stride frequency. Propose a predictive method for minimum stride frequency and validate it by comparing predictions with simulations on randomly generated models.

Result: Proposed method can predict the minimum stride frequency; predicted values align with actual values from randomly generated models. Demonstrates that hip-offset–driven feedforward strategies can stabilize gait with reduced control effort and energy expenditure.

Conclusion: Gives insight into frontal-plane stability mechanisms and demonstrates the potential of feedforward stabilization to reduce control effort; provides groundwork for design and control of energy-efficient, robust bipedal locomotion.

Abstract: Stability of bipedal systems in frontal plane is affected by the hip offset,
to the extent that adjusting stride time using feedforward retraction and
extension of the legs can lead to stable oscillations without feedback control.
This feedforward stabilization can be leveraged to reduce the control effort
and energy expenditure and increase the locomotion robustness. However, there
is limited understanding of how key parameters, such as mass, stiffness, leg
length, and hip width, affect stability and the minimum stride frequency needed
to maintain it. This study aims to address these gaps through analyzing how
individual model parameters and the system's natural frequency influence the
minimum stride frequency required to maintain a stable cycle. We propose a
method to predict the minimum stride frequency, and compare the predicted
stride frequencies with actual values for randomly generated models. The
findings of this work provide a better understanding of the frontal plane
stability mechanisms and how feedforward stabilization can be leveraged to
reduce the control effort.

</details>


### [528] [RaycastGrasp: Eye-Gaze Interaction with Wearable Devices for Robotic Manipulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22113)
*Zitiantao Lin,Yongpeng Sang,Yang Ye*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: An egocentric gaze-guided manipulation interface using a wearable MR headset improves assistive robotic manipulation, achieving >88% single-pass recognition accuracy and reduced latency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Joystick-based control for reach-and-grab tasks is burdensome due to high precision demands and awkward reference frames; prior HRI approaches rely on external screens or restrictive schemes, limiting intuitiveness and accessibility for users with mobility impairments; a natural, accessible interface is needed.

Method: Employ a wearable Mixed Reality headset to capture first-person, egocentric gaze and present augmented cues. The system uses natural gaze fixation for intent recognition and object interaction, supported by a pretrained vision model and a robotic arm to perform manipulation tasks.

Result: The approach yields significantly better manipulation accuracy, lower system latency, and single-pass intention and object recognition accuracy above 88% across multiple real-world scenarios.

Conclusion: The egocentric, gaze-guided MR interface enhances intuitiveness and accessibility for assistive robotics, demonstrating practical value for real-world object retrieval tasks.

Abstract: Robotic manipulators are increasingly used to assist individuals with
mobility impairments in object retrieval. However, the predominant
joystick-based control interfaces can be challenging due to high precision
requirements and unintuitive reference frames. Recent advances in human-robot
interaction have explored alternative modalities, yet many solutions still rely
on external screens or restrictive control schemes, limiting their
intuitiveness and accessibility. To address these challenges, we present an
egocentric, gaze-guided robotic manipulation interface that leverages a
wearable Mixed Reality (MR) headset. Our system enables users to interact
seamlessly with real-world objects using natural gaze fixation from a
first-person perspective, while providing augmented visual cues to confirm
intent and leveraging a pretrained vision model and robotic arm for intent
recognition and object manipulation. Experimental results demonstrate that our
approach significantly improves manipulation accuracy, reduces system latency,
and achieves single-pass intention and object recognition accuracy greater than
88% across multiple real-world scenarios. These results demonstrate the
system's effectiveness in enhancing intuitiveness and accessibility,
underscoring its practical significance for assistive robotics applications.

</details>


### [529] [EasyUUV: An LLM-Enhanced Universal and Lightweight Sim-to-Real Reinforcement Learning Framework for UUV Attitude Control](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22126)
*Guanwen Xie,Jingzehua Xu,Jiwei Tang,Yubo Huang,Shuai Zhang,Xiaofan Li*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: An LLM-enhanced, universal, lightweight sim-to-real RL framework (EasyUUV) for robust UUV attitude control, combining parallel RL with an adaptive S-Surface low-level controller and runtime LLM-based parameter tuning, plus a low-cost 6-DoF UUV and extensive simulation-to-real validation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Generalization gaps, disturbance robustness, and deployment efficiency in UUV attitude control motivate a unified framework that leverages learning, adaptive control, and language-model guidance for training-free adaptation to unmodeled dynamics.

Method: Parallelized RL training produces high-level attitude corrections; an adaptive S-Surface controller executes corrections; a multimodal LLM tunes controller parameters at runtime using visual and textual feedback; development of a low-cost 6-DoF UUV; validation through extensive simulations and real-world experiments; code release.

Result: Robust and adaptive attitude control demonstrated across diverse underwater conditions in both simulation and real-world tests; strong performance claims; code released.

Conclusion: EasyUUV demonstrates a robust, adaptable, and efficient sim-to-real RL approach for UUV attitude control, enabling training-free adaptation to unmodeled dynamics via LLM-guided parameter tuning within a hybrid control framework.

Abstract: Despite recent advances in Unmanned Underwater Vehicle (UUV) attitude
control, existing methods still struggle with generalizability, robustness to
real-world disturbances, and efficient deployment. To address the above
challenges, this paper presents EasyUUV, a Large Language Model (LLM)-enhanced,
universal, and lightweight simulation-to-reality reinforcement learning (RL)
framework for robust attitude control of UUVs. EasyUUV combines parallelized RL
training with a hybrid control architecture, where a learned policy outputs
high-level attitude corrections executed by an adaptive S-Surface controller. A
multimodal LLM is further integrated to adaptively tune controller parameters
at runtime using visual and textual feedback, enabling training-free adaptation
to unmodeled dynamics. Also, we have developed a low-cost 6-DoF UUV platform
and applied an RL policy trained through efficient parallelized simulation.
Extensive simulation and real-world experiments validate the effectiveness and
outstanding performance of EasyUUV in achieving robust and adaptive UUV
attitude control across diverse underwater conditions. The source code is
available from the following website: https://360zmem.github.io/easyuuv/

</details>


### [530] [LT-Exosense: A Vision-centric Multi-session Mapping System for Lifelong Safe Navigation of Exoskeletons](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22164)
*Jianeng Wang,Matias Mattamala,Christina Kassab,Nived Chebrolu,Guillaume Burger,Fabio Elnecave,Marine Petriaux,Maurice Fallon*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Vision-based multi-session mapping for exoskeleton navigation; incremental fusion across sessions to build a persistent map; enables adaptive planning; sub-5 cm P2P error vs laser ground-truth.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Need reliable perception and long-term robustness for exoskeletons in changing environments to support semi-autonomous navigation.

Method: LT-Exosense uses a vision-centric approach to incrementally fuse spatial knowledge across multiple sessions, detects environmental changes, updates a persistent global map, and supports intelligent path planning with obstacle adaptation and route recovery.

Result: Real-world experiments validate a scalable multi-session map achieving average point-to-point error below 5 cm against ground-truth laser scans; demonstrates adaptive path planning in dynamic indoor environments.

Conclusion: LT-Exosense enables reliable long-term navigation for exoskeleton users in changing environments and shows promise for practical deployment of semi-autonomous capabilities.

Abstract: Self-balancing exoskeletons offer a promising mobility solution for
individuals with lower-limb disabilities. For reliable long-term operation,
these exoskeletons require a perception system that is effective in changing
environments. In this work, we introduce LT-Exosense, a vision-centric,
multi-session mapping system designed to support long-term (semi)-autonomous
navigation for exoskeleton users. LT-Exosense extends single-session mapping
capabilities by incrementally fusing spatial knowledge across multiple
sessions, detecting environmental changes, and updating a persistent global
map. This representation enables intelligent path planning, which can adapt to
newly observed obstacles and can recover previous routes when obstructions are
removed. We validate LT-Exosense through several real-world experiments,
demonstrating a scalable multi-session map that achieves an average
point-to-point error below 5 cm when compared to ground-truth laser scans. We
also illustrate the potential application of adaptive path planning in
dynamically changing indoor environments.

</details>


### [531] [ACG: Action Coherence Guidance for Flow-based VLA models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22201)
*Minho Park,Kinam Kim,Junha Hyung,Hyojin Jang,Hoiyeong Jin,Jooyeol Yun,Hojoon Lee,Jaegul Choo*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: ACG is a training-free, test-time guidance method that improves action coherence in diffusion/flow matching Vision-Language-Action policies, yielding higher success rates on various robotic manipulation benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Imitation-learned VLA models are highly expressive but sensitive to noise in human demonstrations (jerks, pauses, jitter), causing instability and trajectory drift that can lead to failures in fine-grained manipulation.

Method: A training-free test-time guidance algorithm applied during inference to enhance action coherence of VLA models, without additional training.

Result: Empirical evaluation on RoboCasa, DexMimicGen, and real-world SO-101 tasks shows consistent improvements in action coherence and higher success rates across diverse manipulation tasks.

Conclusion: ACG provides a simple, effective mechanism to boost the reliability of diffusion/flow matching VLA policies; code and project pages are publicly available.

Abstract: Diffusion and flow matching models have emerged as powerful robot policies,
enabling Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models to generalize across diverse
scenes and instructions. Yet, when trained via imitation learning, their high
generative capacity makes them sensitive to noise in human demonstrations:
jerks, pauses, and jitter which reduce action coherence. Reduced action
coherence causes instability and trajectory drift during deployment, failures
that are catastrophic in fine-grained manipulation where precision is crucial.
In this paper, we present Action Coherence Guidance (ACG) for VLA models, a
training-free test-time guidance algorithm that improves action coherence and
thereby yields performance gains. Evaluated on RoboCasa, DexMimicGen, and
real-world SO-101 tasks, ACG consistently improves action coherence and boosts
success rates across diverse manipulation tasks. Code and project page are
available at https://github.com/DAVIAN-Robotics/ACG and
https://DAVIAN-Robotics.github.io/ACG , respectively.

</details>


### [532] [Bridging Perception and Reasoning: Dual-Pipeline Neuro-Symbolic Landing for UAVs in Cluttered Environments](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22204)
*Weixian Qian,Sebastian Schroder,Yao Deng,Jiaohong Yao,Linfeng Liang,Xiao Cheng,Richard Han,Xi Zheng*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: NeuroSymLand integrates offline LLM-guided symbolic synthesis with online perception to create a scalable, interpretable UAV landing system that robustly handles cluttered, map-poor environments, outperforming baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Autonomous landing in unstructured environments is essential for UAVs, but purely vision-based or deep learning models struggle under covariate shift and offer limited interpretability; there is a need for explainable, verifiable decision-making.

Method: Two pipelines: offline: LLMs with human-in-the-loop refine Scallop code from diverse landing scenarios, distilling generalizable symbolic knowledge. online: a lightweight foundation-based semantic segmentation model generates probabilistic Scallop facts; these are composed into semantic scene graphs for real-time deductive reasoning. Node attributes and edge relations are computed with geometric routines (flatness, area, adjacency, containment, proximity) rather than learned. The resulting Scallop program encodes landing principles (avoid water/obstacles; prefer large, flat, accessible regions) and yields calibrated safety scores with ranked Regions of Interest (ROIs) and human-readable justifications.

Result: Higher accuracy and stronger robustness to covariate shift, with superior efficiency compared with state-of-the-art baselines; validated across diverse datasets, simulation maps, and real UAV hardware.

Conclusion: A neuro-symbolic framework that combines perceptual strengths of foundation models with interpretable, verifiable symbolic reasoning to improve UAV landing safety and reliability in challenging environments.

Abstract: Autonomous landing in unstructured (cluttered, uneven, and map-poor)
environments is a core requirement for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), yet
purely vision-based or deep learning models often falter under covariate shift
and provide limited interpretability. We propose NeuroSymLand, a neuro-symbolic
framework that tightly couples two complementary pipelines: (i) an offline
pipeline, where Large Language Models (LLMs) and human-in-the-loop refinement
synthesize Scallop code from diverse landing scenarios, distilling
generalizable and verifiable symbolic knowledge; and (ii) an online pipeline,
where a compact foundation-based semantic segmentation model generates
probabilistic Scallop facts that are composed into semantic scene graphs for
real-time deductive reasoning. This design combines the perceptual strengths of
lightweight foundation models with the interpretability and verifiability of
symbolic reasoning. Node attributes (e.g., flatness, area) and edge relations
(adjacency, containment, proximity) are computed with geometric routines rather
than learned, avoiding the data dependence and latency of train-time graph
builders. The resulting Scallop program encodes landing principles (avoid water
and obstacles; prefer large, flat, accessible regions) and yields calibrated
safety scores with ranked Regions of Interest (ROIs) and human-readable
justifications. Extensive evaluations across datasets, diverse simulation maps,
and real UAV hardware show that NeuroSymLand achieves higher accuracy, stronger
robustness to covariate shift, and superior efficiency compared with
state-of-the-art baselines, while advancing UAV safety and reliability in
emergency response, surveillance, and delivery missions.

</details>


### [533] [Breaking the Static Assumption: A Dynamic-Aware LIO Framework Via Spatio-Temporal Normal Analysis](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22313)
*Chen Zhiqiang,Le Gentil Cedric,Lin Fuling,Lu Minghao,Qiao Qiyuan,Xu Bowen,Qi Yuhua,Lu Peng*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A dynamic-aware Lidar-Inertial Odometry method that integrates dynamic handling into point-cloud registration to robustly estimate motion in dynamic and geometrically sparse environments, using spatio-temporal normals and spatial consistency for static-map construction; shows superior performance to state-of-the-art LIO methods; code available.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LIO struggles in dynamic environments where the static-world assumption fails, and distinguishing dynamic objects from static features is hard, especially in sparse geometry; breaking the circular dependency between needing static features and ensuring accurate pose estimation is essential.

Method: Introduce a dynamic-aware ICP variant that uses spatio-temporal normal analysis to detect and downweight dynamic points during registration, plus a spatial consistency verification step to build a robust static map, effectively integrating dynamic awareness into the registration process.

Result: Experimental evaluations demonstrate significant performance gains over state-of-the-art LIO systems in challenging dynamic contexts with limited geometric structure.

Conclusion: Dynamic awareness embedded in the registration step can break the dependency between pose estimation and static-feature identification, enabling robust LIO in dynamic and sparsely-featured environments; dataset and code are released.

Abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of Lidar-Inertial Odometry (LIO) in
dynamic environments, where conventional methods often fail due to their
static-world assumptions. Traditional LIO algorithms perform poorly when
dynamic objects dominate the scenes, particularly in geometrically sparse
environments. Current approaches to dynamic LIO face a fundamental challenge:
accurate localization requires a reliable identification of static features,
yet distinguishing dynamic objects necessitates precise pose estimation. Our
solution breaks this circular dependency by integrating dynamic awareness
directly into the point cloud registration process. We introduce a novel
dynamic-aware iterative closest point algorithm that leverages spatio-temporal
normal analysis, complemented by an efficient spatial consistency verification
method to enhance static map construction. Experimental evaluations demonstrate
significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art LIO systems in
challenging dynamic environments with limited geometric structure. The code and
dataset are available at https://github.com/thisparticle/btsa.

</details>


### [534] [Toward Humanoid Brain-Body Co-design: Joint Optimization of Control and Morphology for Fall Recovery](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22336)
*Bo Yue,Sheng Xu,Kui Jia,Guiliang Liu*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: RoboCraft offers a scalable brain-body co-design framework for humanoid fall recovery that jointly optimizes control policies and morphology; it uses a shared policy across designs and a priority-buffer-guided morphology search; yielding ~44.6% average gains across seven robots, with morphology driving substantial improvements.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enhance safety, resilience, and autonomy of humanoid robots by integrating fall recovery with locomotion through brain-body co-design; address the need for efficient cross-design adaptation and scalable optimization.

Method: Iterative co-design loop: train a shared policy across multiple morphologies, then fine-tune on top-performing morphologies; concurrently search morphologies using human-inspired priors and optimization, guided by a priority buffer to balance reevaluation of promising candidates with exploration of novel designs.

Result: Average performance gain of 44.55% on seven public humanoid robots; morphology optimization drives at least 40% of improvements in co-designing four humanoid robots.

Conclusion: Demonstrates the effectiveness and scalability of brain-body co-design for fall recovery in humanoids; underscores the critical role of morphology optimization in improving fall recovery across designs.

Abstract: Humanoid robots represent a central frontier in embodied intelligence, as
their anthropomorphic form enables natural deployment in humans' workspace.
Brain-body co-design for humanoids presents a promising approach to realizing
this potential by jointly optimizing control policies and physical morphology.
Within this context, fall recovery emerges as a critical capability. It not
only enhances safety and resilience but also integrates naturally with
locomotion systems, thereby advancing the autonomy of humanoids. In this paper,
we propose RoboCraft, a scalable humanoid co-design framework for fall recovery
that iteratively improves performance through the coupled updates of control
policy and morphology. A shared policy pretrained across multiple designs is
progressively finetuned on high-performing morphologies, enabling efficient
adaptation without retraining from scratch. Concurrently, morphology search is
guided by human-inspired priors and optimization algorithms, supported by a
priority buffer that balances reevaluation of promising candidates with the
exploration of novel designs. Experiments show that \ourmethod{} achieves an
average performance gain of 44.55% on seven public humanoid robots, with
morphology optimization drives at least 40% of improvements in co-designing
four humanoid robots, underscoring the critical role of humanoid co-design.

</details>


### [535] [Estimating Continuum Robot Shape under External Loading using Spatiotemporal Neural Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22339)
*Enyi Wang,Zhen Deng,Chuanchuan Pan,Bingwei He,Jianwei Zhang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A learning-based spatiotemporal fusion framework estimates the 3D shape of flexible continuum robots under external loads by fusing history of tendon displacements with RGB data to produce point clouds, then fits Bezier curves for continuous reconstruction, achieving high accuracy (0.08 mm unloaded, 0.22 mm loaded) and outperforming state-of-the-art methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Accurate 3D shape sensing of tendon-driven continuum robots under external loads is challenging due to complex deformations, requiring robust perceptual capabilities that can integrate temporal dynamics and multi-modal cues.

Method: A spatiotemporal neural network architecture with (i) a recurrent module for temporal feature extraction from historical tendon displacement data, (ii) an encoding module for spatial feature extraction from inputs, and (iii) a multi-modal fusion module that combines visual (RGB) features with actuator-derived temporal features. The network outputs point clouds of the deformed configuration, which are then fitted with Bezier curves to obtain continuous 3D shapes. The approach uses current and historical tendon displacement data along with RGB images as inputs and is validated experimentally under unloaded and loaded conditions.

Result: Mean shape estimation errors: 0.08 mm (unloaded) and 0.22 mm (loaded). The method outperforms state-of-the-art TDCR shape sensing methods, demonstrating effective spatiotemporal data fusion for precise shape estimation under loading.

Conclusion: Deep learning-based spatiotemporal fusion is effective for precise 3D shape estimation of flexible continuum robots under external loads, enabling continuous shape reconstruction through Bezier fitting and showing superior performance to existing techniques.

Abstract: This paper presents a learning-based approach for accurately estimating the
3D shape of flexible continuum robots subjected to external loads. The proposed
method introduces a spatiotemporal neural network architecture that fuses
multi-modal inputs, including current and historical tendon displacement data
and RGB images, to generate point clouds representing the robot's deformed
configuration. The network integrates a recurrent neural module for temporal
feature extraction, an encoding module for spatial feature extraction, and a
multi-modal fusion module to combine spatial features extracted from visual
data with temporal dependencies from historical actuator inputs. Continuous 3D
shape reconstruction is achieved by fitting B\'ezier curves to the predicted
point clouds. Experimental validation demonstrates that our approach achieves
high precision, with mean shape estimation errors of 0.08 mm (unloaded) and
0.22 mm (loaded), outperforming state-of-the-art methods in shape sensing for
TDCRs. The results validate the efficacy of deep learning-based spatiotemporal
data fusion for precise shape estimation under loading conditions.

</details>


### [536] [BLIP-FusePPO: A Vision-Language Deep Reinforcement Learning Framework for Lane Keeping in Autonomous Vehicles](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22370)
*Seyed Ahmad Hosseini Miangoleh,Amin Jalal Aghdasian,Farzaneh Abdollahi*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A multimodal RL framework BLIP-FusePPO for autonomous lane-keeping that fuses vision-language semantic embeddings with geometric and control signals in PPO, enabling robust, efficient, and generalizable lane-keeping with a hybrid reward.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To combine high-level semantic scene understanding with low-level control signals to improve LK robustness and generalization while reducing runtime burden of relying solely on vision models.

Method: Integrates semantic embeddings from a vision-language model (BLIP) into the RL state alongside geometric states, LiDAR, and PID feedback; trains with PPO; uses a hybrid reward including semantic alignment, LK accuracy, obstacle avoidance, and speed regulation; evaluation in simulation with public code release.

Result: Outperforms strong vision-based and multimodal RL baselines in diverse driving scenarios, with improved LK stability and adaptability; demonstrates efficiency due to direct state embedding of semantic features.

Conclusion: BLIP-FusePPO enables robust, semantically informed policy learning for autonomous lane-keeping by directly fusing semantic and geometric cues in the state, with practical benefits of efficiency and generalization.

Abstract: In this paper, we propose Bootstrapped Language-Image Pretraining-driven
Fused State Representation in Proximal Policy Optimization (BLIP-FusePPO), a
novel multimodal reinforcement learning (RL) framework for autonomous
lane-keeping (LK), in which semantic embeddings generated by a vision-language
model (VLM) are directly fused with geometric states, LiDAR observations, and
Proportional-Integral-Derivative-based (PID) control feedback within the agent
