observation space. The proposed method lets the agent learn driving rules that
are aware of their surroundings and easy to understand by combining high-level
scene understanding from the VLM with low-level control and spatial signals.
Our architecture brings together semantic, geometric, and control-aware
representations to make policy learning more robust. A hybrid reward function
that includes semantic alignment, LK accuracy, obstacle avoidance, and speed
regulation helps learning to be more efficient and generalizable. Our method is
different from the approaches that only use semantic models to shape rewards.
Instead, it directly embeds semantic features into the state representation.
This cuts down on expensive runtime inference and makes sure that semantic
guidance is always available. The simulation results show that the proposed
model is better at LK stability and adaptability than the best vision-based and
multimodal RL baselines in a wide range of difficult driving situations. We
make our code publicly available.

</details>


### [537] [A Novel Multi-Timescale Stability-Preserving Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning Controller Framework for Adaptive Control in High-Dimensional Dynamical Systems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22420)
*Mohammad Ali Labbaf Khaniki,Fateme Taroodi,Benyamin Safizadeh*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: MTLHRL presents a hierarchical, multi-timescale reinforcement learning framework with neural Lyapunov stability guarantees for high-dimensional stochastic systems, showing superior stability and performance in simulations of an 8D hyperchaotic system and a 5-DOF robotic manipulator.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome the curse of dimensionality, lack of temporal abstraction, and absence of guarantees for stochastic stability in controlling high-dimensional stochastic systems common in robotics and autonomous systems.

Method: Integrates a hierarchical policy within a semi-Markov Decision Process (SMDP) with a high-level planner and low-level controller. Enforces stability via a neural Lyapunov function optimized through Lagrangian relaxation and multi-timescale actor-critic updates, using trust-region constraints and decoupled optimization.

Result: Empirical results show superior performance and stability compared to baselines, achieving faster convergence and lower error indices (IAE: 3.912 for hyperchaos, 1.623 for robotics) on an 8D system and a 5-DOF manipulator; better disturbance rejection.

Conclusion: MTLHRL offers a theoretically grounded and practically viable approach for robust control of complex stochastic systems, effectively addressing dimensionality, temporal abstraction, and stability challenges.

Abstract: Controlling high-dimensional stochastic systems, critical in robotics,
autonomous vehicles, and hyperchaotic systems, faces the curse of
dimensionality, lacks temporal abstraction, and often fails to ensure
stochastic stability. To overcome these limitations, this study introduces the
Multi-Timescale Lyapunov-Constrained Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
(MTLHRL) framework. MTLHRL integrates a hierarchical policy within a
semi-Markov Decision Process (SMDP), featuring a high-level policy for
strategic planning and a low-level policy for reactive control, which
effectively manages complex, multi-timescale decision-making and reduces
dimensionality overhead. Stability is rigorously enforced using a neural
Lyapunov function optimized via Lagrangian relaxation and multi-timescale
actor-critic updates, ensuring mean-square boundedness or asymptotic stability
in the face of stochastic dynamics. The framework promotes efficient and
reliable learning through trust-region constraints and decoupled optimization.
Extensive simulations on an 8D hyperchaotic system and a 5-DOF robotic
manipulator demonstrate MTLHRL's empirical superiority. It significantly
outperforms baseline methods in both stability and performance, recording the
lowest error indices (e.g., Integral Absolute Error (IAE): 3.912 in
hyperchaotic control and IAE: 1.623 in robotics), achieving faster convergence,
and exhibiting superior disturbance rejection. MTLHRL offers a theoretically
grounded and practically viable solution for robust control of complex
stochastic systems.

</details>


### [538] [A short methodological review on social robot navigation benchmarking](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22448)
*Pranup Chhetri,Alejandro Torrejon,Sergio Eslava,Luis J. Manso*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A concise review of benchmarking trends in Social Robot Navigation (2020–2025), analyzing metrics, algorithms, human surveys, and how conclusions are drawn.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is no de facto standard for benchmarking Social Robot Navigation, risking slowed progress and inconsistent conclusions.

Method: Literature survey of IEEE Xplore; 130 papers identified, 85 included; examined benchmarking metrics, algorithms, use of human surveys, and the basis for drawn conclusions.

Result: Summarizes current benchmarking practices, reveals reliance on diverse metrics and algorithms, varying use of human surveys, and how conclusions are drawn; identifies gaps and areas for standardization.

Conclusion: Highlights the need for standardized benchmarking guidelines in social robot navigation to enable comparisons and accelerate progress.

Abstract: Social Robot Navigation is the skill that allows robots to move efficiently
in human-populated environments while ensuring safety, comfort, and trust.
Unlike other areas of research, the scientific community has not yet achieved
an agreement on how Social Robot Navigation should be benchmarked. This is
notably important, as the lack of a de facto standard to benchmark Social Robot
Navigation can hinder the progress of the field and may lead to contradicting
conclusions. Motivated by this gap, we contribute with a short review focused
exclusively on benchmarking trends in the period from January 2020 to July
2025. Of the 130 papers identified by our search using IEEE Xplore, we analysed
the 85 papers that met the criteria of the review. This review addresses the
metrics used in the literature for benchmarking purposes, the algorithms
employed in such benchmarks, the use of human surveys for benchmarking, and how
conclusions are drawn from the benchmarking results, when applicable.

</details>


### [539] [Forward Kinematics Solution For A General Stewart Platform Through Iteration Based Simulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22465)
*Sourabh Karmakar,Cameron J. Turner*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: An iterative IK-based method using a modified DH convention yields a single, feasible forward-kinematic solution for the Stewart platform, enabling direct use in materials-testing workflows.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Parallel-kinematic machines (e.g., Stewart platforms) have multiple FK solutions; a unique, verifiable FK and directly usable kinematics (calibrated to the as-built hardware) are needed for high-precision, multi-axis force control in six degrees of freedom.

Method: Compute valid workspace data and actuator lengths via inverse kinematics, then apply a simple iterative algorithm with a modified Denavit–Hartenberg convention to obtain a single forward-kinematic solution for each valid pose.

Result: The approach delivers one feasible FK solution per valid pose without manual verification, with solved DH parameters suitable for direct use in calculations and control.

Conclusion: This enables in situ calibration of as-built Stewart Gough platforms, facilitating accurate, automated material characterization under complex loading conditions.

Abstract: This paper presents a method to generate feasible, unique forward-kinematic
solutions for a general Stewart platform. This is done by using inverse
kinematics to obtain valid workspace data and corresponding actuator lengths
for the moving platform. For parallel kinematic machines, such as the Stewart
Platform, inverse kinematics are straight forward, but the forward kinematics
are complex and generates multiple solutions due to the closed loop structure
of the kinematic links. In this research, a simple iterative algorithm has been
used employing modified Denavit-Hartenberg convention. The outcome is
encouraging as this method generates a single feasible forward kinematic
solution for each valid pose with the solved DH parameters and unlike earlier
forward kinematics solutions, this unique solution does not need to be manually
verified. Therefore, the forward kinematic solutions can be used directly for
further calculations without the need for manual pose verification. This
capability is essential for the six degree of freedom materials testing system
developed by the authors in their laboratory. The developed system is aimed at
characterizing additively manufactured materials under complex combined
multiple loading conditions. The material characterization is done by enabling
high precision force control on the moving platform via in situ calibration of
the as-built kinematics of the Stewart Gough Platform.

</details>


### [540] [On Steerability Factors for Growing Vine Robots](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22504)
*Ciera McFarland,Antonio Alvarez,Sarah Taher,Nathaniel Hanson,Margaret McGuinness*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Vine robots' steerability is governed by tip load, pressure, length, and actuator fabrication; optimized parameter choices improve curvature performance over ad hoc designs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how design and control choices affect steerability in vine robots for potential field deployment (e.g., urban search and rescue).

Method: Two experimental groups: (1) varying tip load, chamber pressure, length, and diameter for a gravity-supported robot; (2) comparing fabrication method and actuator-to-chamber pressure ratio for a ground-supported robot.

Result: Steerability decreases with increasing tip load; optimal steerability at moderate chamber pressure; steerability increases with length; diameter has little effect. Robots with exterior-attached actuators begin curving at low pressure ratios with saturation at high ratios; robots with actuators embedded in the body require higher pressure ratios to start curving but achieve higher overall curvature.

Conclusion: Design choices guided by these factors enable optimized vine robots to outperform ad hoc-parameter robots in mobility tasks that require upward and horizontal curvatures.

Abstract: Vine robots extend their tubular bodies by everting material from the tip,
enabling navigation in complex environments with a minimalist soft body.
Despite their promise for field applications, especially in the urban search
and rescue domain, performance is constrained by the weight of attached sensors
or tools, as well as other design and control choices. This work investigates
how tip load, pressure, length, diameter, and fabrication method shape vine
robot steerability--the ability to maneuver with controlled curvature--for
robots that steer with series pouch motor-style pneumatic actuators. We conduct
two groups of experiments: (1) studying tip load, chamber pressure, length, and
diameter in a robot supporting itself against gravity, and (2) studying
fabrication method and ratio of actuator to chamber pressure in a robot
supported on the ground. Results show that steerability decreases with
increasing tip load, is best at moderate chamber pressure, increases with
length, and is largely unaffected by diameter. Robots with actuators attached
on their exterior begin curving at low pressure ratios, but curvature saturates
at high pressure ratios; those with actuators integrated into the robot body
require higher pressure ratios to begin curving but achieve higher curvature
overall. We demonstrate that robots optimized with these principles outperform
those with ad hoc parameters in a mobility task that involves maximizing upward
and horizontal curvatures.

</details>


### [541] [Ant-inspired Walling Strategies for Scalable Swarm Separation: Reinforcement Learning Approaches Based on Finite State Machines](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22524)
*Shenbagaraj Kannapiran,Elena Oikonomou,Albert Chu,Spring Berman,Theodore P. Pavlic*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Decentralized swarm controllers (FSM and FSM+DQN) maintain spatial separation in heterogeneous robot swarms; DQN extension yields 40-50% less mixing and faster convergence.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Natural systems show emergent walls to balance competing tasks; apply this to robotic swarms to prevent interference during concurrent tasks.

Method: Develop two decentralized controllers: (1) FSM-based with encounter-triggered transitions producing rigid walls; (2) FSM + DQN to optimize separation via emergent 'demilitarized zones'; evaluate in simulation.

Result: Both controllers reduce mixing between subgroups; DQN-enhanced controller offers better adaptability and reduces mixing by 40-50% with faster convergence.

Conclusion: Decentralized FSM and FSM+DQN controllers can effectively maintain spatial separation in heterogeneous swarms; DQN adds adaptability for dynamic environments; promising for scalable multi-task robotics.

Abstract: In natural systems, emergent structures often arise to balance competing
demands. Army ants, for example, form temporary "walls" that prevent
interference between foraging trails. Inspired by this behavior, we developed
two decentralized controllers for heterogeneous robotic swarms to maintain
spatial separation while executing concurrent tasks. The first is a
finite-state machine (FSM)-based controller that uses encounter-triggered
transitions to create rigid, stable walls. The second integrates FSM states
with a Deep Q-Network (DQN), dynamically optimizing separation through emergent
"demilitarized zones." In simulation, both controllers reduce mixing between
subgroups, with the DQN-enhanced controller improving adaptability and reducing
mixing by 40-50% while achieving faster convergence.

</details>


### [542] [SPIRAL: Self-Play Incremental Racing Algorithm for Learning in Multi-Drone Competitions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22568)
*Onur Akgün*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: SPIRAL is a self-play incremental learning framework for multi-agent drone racing that trains drones against progressively stronger copies of themselves, enabling growth from basic flight to cooperative racing and is compatible with any DRL algorithm; simulations show improved performance and insights.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To develop robust, adaptive autonomous drone racing agents in dynamic, multi-agent environments, by automatically generating escalating challenges that drive skill acquisition and cooperative strategies.

Method: A self-play loop where drones repeatedly race against increasingly proficient versions of themselves within a dynamic simulation, providing an incremental curriculum; SPIRAL is designed to be compatible with any state-of-the-art DRL algorithm within its self-play framework and can integrate with existing DRL methods; evaluation includes simulations benchmarking numerous DRL algorithms within SPIRAL.

Result: Simulations demonstrate significant advantages of SPIRAL and benchmark the performance of various DRL algorithms operating within it, indicating the framework’s versatility, scalability, and self-improving nature in autonomous drone racing.

Conclusion: SPIRAL offers a versatile, scalable framework that enables autonomous drones to autonomously generate escalating challenges and progressively acquire complex racing and cooperative strategies, opening new directions for robust performance and reliability in multi-agent drone racing and potentially other multi-agent tasks.

Abstract: This paper introduces SPIRAL (Self-Play Incremental Racing Algorithm for
Learning), a novel approach for training autonomous drones in multi-agent
racing competitions. SPIRAL distinctively employs a self-play mechanism to
incrementally cultivate complex racing behaviors within a challenging, dynamic
environment. Through this self-play core, drones continuously compete against
increasingly proficient versions of themselves, naturally escalating the
difficulty of competitive interactions. This progressive learning journey
guides agents from mastering fundamental flight control to executing
sophisticated cooperative multi-drone racing strategies. Our method is designed
for versatility, allowing integration with any state-of-the-art Deep
Reinforcement Learning (DRL) algorithms within its self-play framework.
Simulations demonstrate the significant advantages of SPIRAL and benchmark the
performance of various DRL algorithms operating within it. Consequently, we
contribute a versatile, scalable, and self-improving learning framework to the
field of autonomous drone racing. SPIRAL's capacity to autonomously generate
appropriate and escalating challenges through its self-play dynamic offers a
promising direction for developing robust and adaptive racing strategies in
multi-agent environments. This research opens new avenues for enhancing the
performance and reliability of autonomous racing drones in increasingly complex
and competitive scenarios.

</details>


### [543] [Curriculum-Based Iterative Self-Play for Scalable Multi-Drone Racing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22570)
*Onur Akgün*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: CRUISE is a curriculum-based self-play RL framework that enables scalable, competitive multi-drone racing, outperforming baselines and a state-of-the-art planner in high-fidelity simulations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the scalability and coordination challenges of multiple autonomous agents in high-speed, competitive environments and to achieve robust, competitive policies beyond standard RL baselines.

Method: CRUISE combines a progressive difficulty curriculum with an efficient self-play mechanism, trained in high-fidelity quadrotor dynamics simulations, to foster robust competitive behaviors and scalable training.

Result: Policies significantly outperform a standard RL baseline and a state-of-the-art game-theoretic planner, achieving nearly twice the planner's mean racing speed, high success rates, and robust scalability with increasing agent density; ablation shows curriculum structure is critical.

Conclusion: CRUISE offers a scalable, effective training methodology for dynamic, competitive autonomous systems and serves as a blueprint for real-world deployment.

Abstract: The coordination of multiple autonomous agents in high-speed, competitive
environments represents a significant engineering challenge. This paper
presents CRUISE (Curriculum-Based Iterative Self-Play for Scalable Multi-Drone
Racing), a reinforcement learning framework designed to solve this challenge in
the demanding domain of multi-drone racing. CRUISE overcomes key scalability
limitations by synergistically combining a progressive difficulty curriculum
with an efficient self-play mechanism to foster robust competitive behaviors.
Validated in high-fidelity simulation with realistic quadrotor dynamics, the
resulting policies significantly outperform both a standard reinforcement
learning baseline and a state-of-the-art game-theoretic planner. CRUISE
achieves nearly double the planner's mean racing speed, maintains high success
rates, and demonstrates robust scalability as agent density increases. Ablation
studies confirm that the curriculum structure is the critical component for
this performance leap. By providing a scalable and effective training
methodology, CRUISE advances the development of autonomous systems for dynamic,
competitive tasks and serves as a blueprint for future real-world deployment.

</details>


### [544] [RoGER-SLAM: A Robust Gaussian Splatting SLAM System for Noisy and Low-light Environment Resilience](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22600)
*Huilin Yin,Zhaolin Yang,Linchuan Zhang,Gerhard Rigoll,Johannes Betz*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: RoGER-SLAM proposes a robust 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) SLAM framework designed to resist noise and low-light degradation. It combines a structure-preserving fusion of appearance, depth, and edges, an adaptive tracking objective, and a CLIP-based enhancement module activated under degradations, achieving improved trajectory accuracy and map quality over existing 3DGS-SLAM systems, especially under adverse conditions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: 3DGS-SLAM offers high-quality mapping under clean conditions but is vulnerable to noise and poor illumination. The original 3DGS rendering acts as an implicit low-pass filter, attenuating high-frequency noise yet risking over-smoothing and loss of structure. A robust, structure-aware, and semantically informed SLAM is needed for degraded scenes.

Method: Threefold innovation: (1) SP-RoFusion: structure-preserving fusion of rendered appearance, depth, and edge cues; (2) adaptive tracking objective with residual balancing regularization to maintain robust optimization under perturbations; (3) CLIP-based enhancement module that is selectively activated under compounded degradations to restore semantic and structural fidelity.

Result: Empirical evaluation on Replica, TUM, and real-world sequences shows consistent improvements in trajectory accuracy and reconstruction quality compared with other 3DGS-SLAM systems, with the most pronounced gains under adverse imaging conditions.

Conclusion: RoGER-SLAM demonstrates that combining structure-preserving fusion, adaptive optimization, and CLIP-based semantic enhancement yields robust 3DGS-SLAM performance under noise and low-light, suggesting practical viability for challenging robotic perception tasks.

Abstract: The reliability of Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) is severely
constrained in environments where visual inputs suffer from noise and low
illumination. Although recent 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) based SLAM
frameworks achieve high-fidelity mapping under clean conditions, they remain
vulnerable to compounded degradations that degrade mapping and tracking
performance. A key observation underlying our work is that the original 3DGS
rendering pipeline inherently behaves as an implicit low-pass filter,
attenuating high-frequency noise but also risking over-smoothing. Building on
this insight, we propose RoGER-SLAM, a robust 3DGS SLAM system tailored for
noise and low-light resilience. The framework integrates three innovations: a
Structure-Preserving Robust Fusion (SP-RoFusion) mechanism that couples
rendered appearance, depth, and edge cues; an adaptive tracking objective with
residual balancing regularization; and a Contrastive Language-Image Pretraining
(CLIP)-based enhancement module, selectively activated under compounded
degradations to restore semantic and structural fidelity. Comprehensive
experiments on Replica, TUM, and real-world sequences show that RoGER-SLAM
consistently improves trajectory accuracy and reconstruction quality compared
with other 3DGS-SLAM systems, especially under adverse imaging conditions.

</details>


### [545] [Uncertainty-Aware Autonomous Vehicles: Predicting the Road Ahead](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22680)
*Shireen Kudukkil Manchingal,Armand Amaritei,Mihir Gohad,Maryam Sultana,Julian F. P. Kooij,Fabio Cuzzolin,Andrew Bradley*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: RS-NNs provide uncertainty-aware classification for autonomous driving by predicting belief functions over class sets, enabling dynamic speed control. In a real-world ROS-based AV stack, RS-NN outperforms CNNs and Bayesian NNs in accuracy and uncertainty calibration, improving safety by reducing speed in uncertain scenarios while maintaining high speed when confident.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Perception errors in AVs often arise from out-of-distribution or rare events, where overconfident predictions can cause unsafe behavior. A model that can quantify and signal uncertainty is needed to modulate control decisions safely.

Method: Use Random-Set Neural Networks (RS-NNs) to output belief functions over sets of road-layout classes. Integrate RS-NN into a ROS-based autonomous racing vehicle software stack to classify the road ahead and provide associated uncertainty. Compare RS-NN performance to traditional CNNs and Bayesian NNs under varied road conditions.

Result: RS-NN achieved higher accuracy and superior calibration of predictive uncertainty than CNN and Bayesian NN baselines. The uncertainty signaling enabled dynamic speed modulation, keeping high speed when predictions are confident and reducing speed in uncertain scenarios, enhancing safety.

Conclusion: Uncertainty-aware RS-NNs offer a practical, deployable enhancement for safer, more robust autonomous driving, by explicitly quantifying and leveraging prediction uncertainty within the vehicle control loop.

Abstract: Autonomous Vehicle (AV) perception systems have advanced rapidly in recent
years, providing vehicles with the ability to accurately interpret their
environment. Perception systems remain susceptible to errors caused by
overly-confident predictions in the case of rare events or out-of-sample data.
This study equips an autonomous vehicle with the ability to 'know when it is
uncertain', using an uncertainty-aware image classifier as part of the AV
software stack. Specifically, the study exploits the ability of Random-Set
Neural Networks (RS-NNs) to explicitly quantify prediction uncertainty. Unlike
traditional CNNs or Bayesian methods, RS-NNs predict belief functions over sets
of classes, allowing the system to identify and signal uncertainty clearly in
novel or ambiguous scenarios. The system is tested in a real-world autonomous
racing vehicle software stack, with the RS-NN classifying the layout of the
road ahead and providing the associated uncertainty of the prediction.
Performance of the RS-NN under a range of road conditions is compared against
traditional CNN and Bayesian neural networks, with the RS-NN achieving
significantly higher accuracy and superior uncertainty calibration. This
integration of RS-NNs into Robot Operating System (ROS)-based vehicle control
pipeline demonstrates that predictive uncertainty can dynamically modulate
vehicle speed, maintaining high-speed performance under confident predictions
while proactively improving safety through speed reductions in uncertain
scenarios. These results demonstrate the potential of uncertainty-aware neural
networks - in particular RS-NNs - as a practical solution for safer and more
robust autonomous driving.

</details>


### [546] [RL-AVIST: Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Visual Inspection of Space Targets](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22699)
*Matteo El-Hariry,Andrej Orsula,Matthieu Geist,Miguel Olivares-Mendez*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A model-based RL framework (DreamerV3) for autonomous 6-DOF proximity maneuvers around large space targets, trained on SRB with generalized and specialized agents; shows improved trajectory fidelity and sample efficiency over model-free baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Autonomous on-orbit servicing requires adaptable, robust control under model uncertainties, multi-spacecraft configurations, and evolving mission contexts; traditional control systems struggle to generalize.

Method: Simulate high-fidelity 6-DOF spacecraft dynamics on the Space Robotics Bench; train DreamerV3 (model-based RL) and compare with PPO and TD3 baselines; task involves 3D proximity maneuvering around targets like the Lunar Gateway; two regimes: generalized agents trained on randomized velocity vectors and specialized agents trained to follow fixed inspection-like trajectories; assess robustness/generalization across multiple spacecraft morphologies and mission domains.

Result: Model-based RL demonstrates promising trajectory fidelity and sample efficiency, enabling scalable, retrainable control solutions across domains; preliminary evidence suggests advantages over model-free baselines.

Conclusion: RL-AVIST offers a scalable framework for autonomous space inspection missions, with strong generalization potential across morphologies and mission contexts, highlighting model-based RL as a viable approach for future space operations.

Abstract: The growing need for autonomous on-orbit services such as inspection,
maintenance, and situational awareness calls for intelligent spacecraft capable
of complex maneuvers around large orbital targets. Traditional control systems
often fall short in adaptability, especially under model uncertainties,
multi-spacecraft configurations, or dynamically evolving mission contexts. This
paper introduces RL-AVIST, a Reinforcement Learning framework for Autonomous
Visual Inspection of Space Targets. Leveraging the Space Robotics Bench (SRB),
we simulate high-fidelity 6-DOF spacecraft dynamics and train agents using
DreamerV3, a state-of-the-art model-based RL algorithm, with PPO and TD3 as
model-free baselines. Our investigation focuses on 3D proximity maneuvering
tasks around targets such as the Lunar Gateway and other space assets. We
evaluate task performance under two complementary regimes: generalized agents
trained on randomized velocity vectors, and specialized agents trained to
follow fixed trajectories emulating known inspection orbits. Furthermore, we
assess the robustness and generalization of policies across multiple spacecraft
morphologies and mission domains. Results demonstrate that model-based RL
offers promising capabilities in trajectory fidelity, and sample efficiency,
paving the way for scalable, retrainable control solutions for future space
operations

</details>


### [547] [SCAL for Pinch-Lifting: Complementary Rotational and Linear Prototypes for Environment-Adaptive Grasping](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22738)
*Wentao Guo,Wenzeng Zhang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Two PLA-printed, environment-adaptive fingers (SCAL-R and SCAL-L) enable reliable pinch-lifting and enveloping with simple actuation, supported by closed-form fingertip-force models for design guidance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Demonstrate robust, adaptable grasping for varied, thin/low-profile objects using simple actuation and minimal sensing, addressing limitations of rigid, non-adaptive grippers.

Method: Design SCAL-R (rotational-drive, active fingertip that folds inward to form an envelope) and SCAL-L (linear-drive, passive opening upon contact). Both can follow surfaces to lift upward while preserving fingertip orientation. Fabricated via PLA 3D printing. Experimental evaluation includes contact-preserving sliding/pinch-lifting on tabletops, ramp negotiation then lift, and handling bulky objects via active enveloping (SCAL-R) or passive opening (SCAL-L). A quasi-static analysis yields closed-form fingertip-force models for linear pinching and two-point enveloping.

Result: Both designs achieve consistent grasps across dozens of trials on small parts, boxes, jars, and tape rolls with limited tuning. SCAL-R and SCAL-L cover complementary operating regimes (envelopment vs passive opening) and enable environment-adaptive grasping with simple actuation. A quasi-static model provides geometry-aware guidance for design and operation.

Conclusion: Environment-adaptive grasping with simple actuation is practical; two complementary finger designs offer mode-specific strengths and a clear path to robust, low-complexity grasping, aided by analytic fingertip-force models for design guidance.

Abstract: This paper presents environment-adaptive pinch-lifting built on a
slot-constrained adaptive linkage (SCAL) and instantiated in two complementary
fingers: SCAL-R, a rotational-drive design with an active fingertip that folds
inward after contact to form an envelope, and SCAL-L, a linear-drive design
that passively opens on contact to span wide or weak-feature objects. Both
fingers convert surface following into an upward lifting branch while
maintaining fingertip orientation, enabling thin or low-profile targets to be
raised from supports with minimal sensing and control. Two-finger grippers are
fabricated via PLA-based 3D printing. Experiments evaluate (i)
contact-preserving sliding and pinch-lifting on tabletops, (ii) ramp
negotiation followed by lift, and (iii) handling of bulky objects via active
enveloping (SCAL-R) or contact-triggered passive opening (SCAL-L). Across
dozens of trials on small parts, boxes, jars, and tape rolls, both designs
achieve consistent grasps with limited tuning. A quasi-static analysis provides
closed-form fingertip-force models for linear parallel pinching and two-point
enveloping, offering geometry-aware guidance for design and operation. Overall,
the results indicate complementary operating regimes and a practical path to
robust, environment-adaptive grasping with simple actuation.

</details>


### [548] [Policies over Poses: Reinforcement Learning based Distributed Pose-Graph Optimization for Multi-Robot SLAM](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22740)
*Sai Krishna Ghanta,Ramviyas Parasuraman*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A scalable, outlier-robust distributed pose-graph optimization (PGO) framework using multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) for multi-robot SLAM, employing edge-conditioned GNNs and a consensus step to achieve efficient, globally consistent estimates with improved robustness and scalability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: PGO is highly non-convex and multi-robot SLAM demands robust, scalable, and communication-efficient optimization. Traditional iterative linearization often yields local minima and is sensitive to noisy edges. A learning-based, distributed approach can denoise edges, leverage partial observability, and scale to larger robot teams.

Method: Cast distributed PGO as a partially observable Markov game. A graph partitioner decomposes the global pose graph. Each robot runs a recurrent edge-conditioned Graph Neural Network (GNN) encoder with adaptive edge-gating to denoise edges. Actions refine a single edge's pose. Robots refine poses sequentially via a hybrid policy that uses prior action memory and graph embeddings. After local correction, a consensus step reconciles inter-robot disagreements to produce a global estimate.

Result: Extensive experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets show the MARL-based actors reduce the global objective by 37.5% on average compared to the state-of-the-art distributed PGO framework, and inference efficiency is improved by at least 6x. Actor replication enables the learned policy to scale to larger teams without retraining.

Conclusion: A MARL-driven, edge-denoising, graph-neural-PGO framework yields significant improvements in accuracy and efficiency, with scalable deployment through actor replication. Public code release enables reproducibility and broader adoption; future work could address generalization across environments and robustness to diverse sensing conditions.

Abstract: We consider the distributed pose-graph optimization (PGO) problem, which is
fundamental in accurate trajectory estimation in multi-robot simultaneous
localization and mapping (SLAM). Conventional iterative approaches linearize a
highly non-convex optimization objective, requiring repeated solving of normal
equations, which often converge to local minima and thus produce suboptimal
estimates. We propose a scalable, outlier-robust distributed planar PGO
framework using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL). We cast distributed
PGO as a partially observable Markov game defined on local pose-graphs, where
each action refines a single edge's pose estimate. A graph partitioner
decomposes the global pose graph, and each robot runs a recurrent
edge-conditioned Graph Neural Network (GNN) encoder with adaptive edge-gating
to denoise noisy edges. Robots sequentially refine poses through a hybrid
policy that utilizes prior action memory and graph embeddings. After local
graph correction, a consensus scheme reconciles inter-robot disagreements to
produce a globally consistent estimate. Our extensive evaluations on a
comprehensive suite of synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate that our
learned MARL-based actors reduce the global objective by an average of 37.5%
more than the state-of-the-art distributed PGO framework, while enhancing
inference efficiency by at least 6X. We also demonstrate that actor replication
allows a single learned policy to scale effortlessly to substantially larger
robot teams without any retraining. Code is publicly available at
https://github.com/herolab-uga/policies-over-poses.

</details>


### [549] [TWC-SLAM: Multi-Agent Cooperative SLAM with Text Semantics and WiFi Features Integration for Similar Indoor Environments](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22754)
*Chunyu Li,Shoubin Chen,Dong Li,Weixing Xue,Qingquan Li*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: TWC-SLAM fuses text semantics and WiFi signals with a FAST-LIO2-based front-end to improve multi-agent cooperative SLAM in repetitive indoor environments, enabling reliable location identification and loop closure across agents.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Indoor environments with repetitive structures (e.g., corridors, rooms) create place-ambiguity in shared localization; integrating textual cues and WiFi features can disambiguate locations and enhance global consistency.

Method: Front-end odometry via FAST-LIO2; a location identification and loop closure module that leverages text semantics and WiFi features to align agents in a common location; global mapping; sensors capture text data and WiFi signals; correlating these modalities to establish shared locations and perform loop closures with global optimization.

Result: Evaluated on an indoor dataset with similar corridors, rooms, and text signs; the approach significantly improves cooperative SLAM performance in environments with repetitive architectural features.

Conclusion: Text semantics and WiFi-based cues effectively augment multi-agent SLAM, enabling more robust location identification and loop closure; TWC-SLAM demonstrates improved mapping in challenging indoor environments and offers a viable approach for cross-agent alignment.

Abstract: Multi-agent cooperative SLAM often encounters challenges in similar indoor
environments characterized by repetitive structures, such as corridors and
rooms. These challenges can lead to significant inaccuracies in shared location
identification when employing point cloud-based techniques. To mitigate these
issues, we introduce TWC-SLAM, a multi-agent cooperative SLAM framework that
integrates text semantics and WiFi signal features to enhance location
identification and loop closure detection. TWC-SLAM comprises a single-agent
front-end odometry module based on FAST-LIO2, a location identification and
loop closure detection module that leverages text semantics and WiFi features,
and a global mapping module. The agents are equipped with sensors capable of
capturing textual information and detecting WiFi signals. By correlating these
data sources, TWC-SLAM establishes a common location, facilitating point cloud
alignment across different agents' maps. Furthermore, the system employs loop
closure detection and optimization modules to achieve global optimization and
cohesive mapping. We evaluated our approach using an indoor dataset featuring
similar corridors, rooms, and text signs. The results demonstrate that TWC-SLAM
significantly improves the performance of cooperative SLAM systems in complex
environments with repetitive architectural features.

</details>


### [550] [PIP-LLM: Integrating PDDL-Integer Programming with LLMs for Coordinating Multi-Robot Teams Using Natural Language](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22784)
*Guangyao Shi,Yuwei Wu,Vijay Kumar,Gaurav S. Sukhatme*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: PIP-LLM decouples team-level planning from robot-level task assignment, using PDDL for team plans and IP for subtask allocation, resulting in scalable, efficient multi-robot coordination with higher plan success and lower travel costs than baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enabling natural-language commands to be executed by robot teams is challenging due to brittle task decomposition, poor scalability, and inefficient coordination in existing LLM+PDDL approaches for multi-robot scenarios.

Method: Translate a language command into a team-level PDDL problem to obtain a team plan (subtasks, abstracted from robot assignments); build a dependency graph from the plan; formulate IP-based allocation for each subtask to optimize travel cost and workload while respecting capabilities and user constraints; separate planning from assignment to improve scalability and avoid syntax-based decomposition.

Result: Empirical evaluation across diverse tasks shows higher plan success, and lower maximum/average travel costs with better load balancing compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

Conclusion: PIP-LLM provides a scalable and efficient framework for natural-language controlled multi-robot planning by leveraging team-level PDDL planning plus IP-based subtask allocation, addressing brittleness and scalability issues in prior approaches.

Abstract: Enabling robot teams to execute natural language commands requires
translating high-level instructions into feasible, efficient multi-robot plans.
While Large Language Models (LLMs) combined with Planning Domain Description
Language (PDDL) offer promise for single-robot scenarios, existing approaches
struggle with multi-robot coordination due to brittle task decomposition, poor
scalability, and low coordination efficiency.
  We introduce PIP-LLM, a language-based coordination framework that consists
of PDDL-based team-level planning and Integer Programming (IP) based
robot-level planning. PIP-LLMs first decomposes the command by translating the
command into a team-level PDDL problem and solves it to obtain a team-level
plan, abstracting away robot assignment. Each team-level action represents a
subtask to be finished by the team. Next, this plan is translated into a
dependency graph representing the subtasks' dependency structure. Such a
dependency graph is then used to guide the robot-level planning, in which each
subtask node will be formulated as an IP-based task allocation problem,
explicitly optimizing travel costs and workload while respecting robot
capabilities and user-defined constraints. This separation of planning from
assignment allows PIP-LLM to avoid the pitfalls of syntax-based decomposition
and scale to larger teams. Experiments across diverse tasks show that PIP-LLM
improves plan success rate, reduces maximum and average travel costs, and
achieves better load balancing compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

</details>


### [551] [Learning Neural Observer-Predictor Models for Limb-level Sampling-based Locomotion Planning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22789)
*Abhijeet M. Kulkarni,Ioannis Poulakakis,Guoquan Huang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A learning-based observer-predictor for full-body motion in legged robots; uses a neural observer with UUB guarantees to estimate latent state from proprioception, feeding a fast predictor for thousands of trajectories; integrated into an MPPI planner for a Vision 60 quadruped; hardware experiments show limb-aware, collision-aware planning in narrow passages and over small objects.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Full-body motion prediction must capture closed-loop dynamics and low-level controllers; conventional simplified models fail in cluttered environments; need robust, accurate predictions to support safe autonomous navigation of legged robots.

Method: Neural observer with provable Uniform Ultimate Boundness (UUB) guarantees to estimate latent state from history of proprioceptive measurements; a fast predictor initialized from the observer for rapid parallel evaluation of many trajectories; integrated into an MPPI-based planner.

Result: Hardware validation on Vision 60 quadruped; successful limb-aware planning in challenging narrow passages and over small objects; demonstrates robustness and practicality for high-performance, collision-aware planning on dynamic platforms.

Conclusion: The observer-predictor provides a stable, scalable foundation for collision-aware planning on dynamic legged robots, enabling high-performance navigation in cluttered environments.

Abstract: Accurate full-body motion prediction is essential for the safe, autonomous
navigation of legged robots, enabling critical capabilities like limb-level
collision checking in cluttered environments. Simplified kinematic models often
fail to capture the complex, closed-loop dynamics of the robot and its
low-level controller, limiting their predictions to simple planar motion. To
address this, we present a learning-based observer-predictor framework that
accurately predicts this motion. Our method features a neural observer with
provable UUB guarantees that provides a reliable latent state estimate from a
history of proprioceptive measurements. This stable estimate initializes a
computationally efficient predictor, designed for the rapid, parallel
evaluation of thousands of potential trajectories required by modern
sampling-based planners. We validated the system by integrating our neural
predictor into an MPPI-based planner on a Vision 60 quadruped. Hardware
experiments successfully demonstrated effective, limb-aware motion planning in
a challenging, narrow passage and over small objects, highlighting our system's
ability to provide a robust foundation for high-performance, collision-aware
planning on dynamic robotic platforms.

</details>


### [552] [Analytical Swarm Chemistry: Characterization and Analysis of Emergent Swarm Behaviors](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22821)
*Ricardo Vega,Connor Mattson,Kevin Zhu,Daniel S. Brown,Cameron Nowzari*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Analytical Swarm Chemistry offers a chemistry-inspired, phase-diagram–driven framework to predict and inspect emergent swarm behaviors from simple local rules; it maps parameter regions to behaviors (e.g., milling, diffusion) and validates on real robots, enabling more reliable real-world swarms.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome unpredictability of emergent behaviors in swarm robotics and unify top-down engineering design with bottom-up exploratory approaches using a principled, interpretable space (macrostate and phase diagrams).

Method: Introduce Analytical Swarm Chemistry; define macrostates; apply phase diagram analysis; treat control parameters as thermodynamic-like variables; explore parameter space to identify sufficient conditions for target behaviors; validate with minimal-capability agents and real robots.

Result: Identified sufficient conditions for milling and diffusion; mapped parameter regions that reliably produce these behaviors; preliminary real-robot validation shows the regions correspond to observable behaviors.

Conclusion: Provides a principled, interpretable framework linking parameters to emergent behaviors, paving the way for predictable and reliable real-world swarm systems.

Abstract: Swarm robotics has potential for a wide variety of applications, but
real-world deployments remain rare due to the difficulty of predicting emergent
behaviors arising from simple local interactions. Traditional engineering
approaches design controllers to achieve desired macroscopic outcomes under
idealized conditions, while agent-based and artificial life studies explore
emergent phenomena in a bottom-up, exploratory manner. In this work, we
introduce Analytical Swarm Chemistry, a framework that integrates concepts from
engineering, agent-based and artificial life research, and chemistry. This
framework combines macrostate definitions with phase diagram analysis to
systematically explore how swarm parameters influence emergent behavior.
Inspired by concepts from chemistry, the framework treats parameters like
thermodynamic variables, enabling visualization of regions in parameter space
that give rise to specific behaviors. Applying this framework to agents with
minimally viable capabilities, we identify sufficient conditions for behaviors
such as milling and diffusion and uncover regions of the parameter space that
reliably produce these behaviors. Preliminary validation on real robots
demonstrates that these regions correspond to observable behaviors in practice.
By providing a principled, interpretable approach, this framework lays the
groundwork for predictable and reliable emergent behavior in real-world swarm
systems.

</details>


### [553] [Kinematically Controllable Cable Robots with Reconfigurable End-effectors](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22825)
*Nan Zhang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Introduce a simple reconfigurable end-effector for cable-driven robots that uses a spring, a helical-grooved shaft, a matching nut, and a bearing to convert linear motion into rotational motion, expanding rotational workspace and enabling purely kinematic control without tension sensing.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enlarge the translational workspace of cable-driven robots by adding more cables, but this also causes significant cable interference that reduces rotational workspace and leads to non-unique cable tensions, complicating control. A non-redundant, purely kinematic solution is desired.

Method: Design structurally simple reconfigurable end-effectors incorporating a spring, a helical-grooved shaft, and a matching nut to convert relative linear motions into relative rotations; introduce a bearing to provide an additional rotational degree of freedom, making the mechanism non-redundant; enable control of motion via kinematics without extra tension sensing or control.

Result: The end-effectors expand the rotational workspace, render the mechanism non-redundant, and allow the robot's motion to be controlled purely through kinematics without requiring tension sensing or active tension control.

Conclusion: The proposed end-effectors offer a simpler, non-redundant, fully kinematic solution for cable-driven robots that increases usable workspace and eliminates the need for tension sensing in control.

Abstract: To enlarge the translational workspace of cable-driven robots, one common
approach is to increase the number of cables. However, this introduces two
challenges: (1) cable interference significantly reduces the rotational
workspace, and (2) the solution of tensions in cables becomes non-unique,
resulting in difficulties for kinematic control of the robot. In this work, we
design structurally simple reconfigurable end-effectors for cable robots. By
incorporating a spring, a helical-grooved shaft, and a matching nut, relative
linear motions between end-effector components are converted into relative
rotations, thereby expanding the rotational workspace of the mechanism.
Meanwhile, a bearing is introduced to provide an additional rotational degree
of freedom, making the mechanism non-redundant. As a result, the robot's motion
can be controlled purely through kinematics without additional tension sensing
and control.

</details>


### [554] [Never Too Rigid to Reach: Adaptive Virtual Model Control with LLM- and Lyapunov-Based Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22892)
*Jingzehua Xu,Yangyang Li,Yangfei Chen,Guanwen Xie,Shuai Zhang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: An adaptive Virtual Model Control (VMC) framework augmented with Large Language Model (LLM) guidance and Lyapunov-based reinforcement learning (RL) to achieve stable, flexible control of a 7-DoF robotic arm in uncertain environments, preserving interpretability while enabling online adaptation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Conventional control pipelines become rigid under perturbations or incomplete information. VMC with fixed parameters has limited adaptability and coordination among virtual components. There is a need for stability-guaranteed online adaptation that remains physically interpretable as task objectives evolve.

Method: Combine Adaptive VMC with LLM-based structured priors to improve coordination among virtual components and sample efficiency. Use Lyapunov-based RL to enforce theoretical stability constraints during adaptation. Validate via extensive simulations on a 7-DoF Panda arm to demonstrate improved balancing of competing objectives and the synergy between LLM guidance and Lyapunov-constrained adaptation.

Result: Simulations show the method effectively balances competing objectives in dynamic tasks and achieves superior performance. The study highlights the synergistic benefits of integrating LLM-guided priors with Lyapunov-constrained reinforcement learning, while preserving VMC’s physical interpretability.

Conclusion: The proposed approach enables online, stability-guaranteed adaptation without sacrificing the interpretability of VMC, enabling more robust and flexible robotic control under uncertainty. It demonstrates the value of combining LLM-driven high-level reasoning with safety-oriented RL in dynamic manipulation tasks.

Abstract: Robotic arms are increasingly deployed in uncertain environments, yet
conventional control pipelines often become rigid and brittle when exposed to
perturbations or incomplete information. Virtual Model Control (VMC) enables
compliant behaviors by embedding virtual forces and mapping them into joint
torques, but its reliance on fixed parameters and limited coordination among
virtual components constrains adaptability and may undermine stability as task
objectives evolve. To address these limitations, we propose Adaptive VMC with
Large Language Model (LLM)- and Lyapunov-Based Reinforcement Learning (RL),
which preserves the physical interpretability of VMC while supporting
stability-guaranteed online adaptation. The LLM provides structured priors and
high-level reasoning that enhance coordination among virtual components,
improve sample efficiency, and facilitate flexible adjustment to varying task
requirements. Complementarily, Lyapunov-based RL enforces theoretical stability
constraints, ensuring safe and reliable adaptation under uncertainty. Extensive
simulations on a 7-DoF Panda arm demonstrate that our approach effectively
balances competing objectives in dynamic tasks, achieving superior performance
while highlighting the synergistic benefits of LLM guidance and
Lyapunov-constrained adaptation.

</details>


### [555] [HyPerNav: Hybrid Perception for Object-Oriented Navigation in Unknown Environment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22917)
*Zecheng Yin,Hao Zhao,Zhen Li*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: HyPerNav merges egocentric RGB-D perception with top-down maps using Vision-Language Models to jointly reason about local and global cues for ObjNav, achieving state-of-the-art in simulation and real-world tests.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: ObjNav in unknown environments is challenging due to limited global context and reliance on a single sensing modality. Humans naturally integrate local and global information; VLMs offer robust cross-modal reasoning to fuse these cues, motivating a hybrid perception approach.

Method: Propose Hybrid Perception Navigation (HyPerNav) that leverages Vision-Language Models to jointly perceive local (egocentric RGB-D) and global (top-down map) information, enabling a unified reasoning process to guide navigation toward a target object in unknown environments. Evaluation includes large-scale simulations and real-world validation, with ablations showing the contribution of each modality.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance against popular baselines in both extensive simulations and real-world tests. The hybrid perception approach yields richer cues and improves object-finding efficiency by leveraging both egocentric and map-based information. Ablation studies confirm that both modalities contribute to performance gains.

Conclusion: Hybrid perception that combines local and global information via VLM-based reasoning boosts ObjNav performance. This approach demonstrates the value of integrating multiple perceptual streams, potentially motivating further research into efficient, scalable cross-modal navigation systems.

Abstract: Objective-oriented navigation(ObjNav) enables robot to navigate to target
object directly and autonomously in an unknown environment. Effective
perception in navigation in unknown environment is critical for autonomous
robots. While egocentric observations from RGB-D sensors provide abundant local
information, real-time top-down maps offer valuable global context for ObjNav.
Nevertheless, the majority of existing studies focus on a single source, seldom
integrating these two complementary perceptual modalities, despite the fact
that humans naturally attend to both. With the rapid advancement of
Vision-Language Models(VLMs), we propose Hybrid Perception Navigation
(HyPerNav), leveraging VLMs' strong reasoning and vision-language understanding
capabilities to jointly perceive both local and global information to enhance
the effectiveness and intelligence of navigation in unknown environments. In
both massive simulation evaluation and real-world validation, our methods
achieved state-of-the-art performance against popular baselines. Benefiting
from hybrid perception approach, our method captures richer cues and finds the
objects more effectively, by simultaneously leveraging information
understanding from egocentric observations and the top-down map. Our ablation
study further proved that either of the hybrid perception contributes to the
navigation performance.

</details>


### [556] [End-to-End Design and Validation of a Low-Cost Stewart Platform with Nonlinear Estimation and Control](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22949)
*Benedictus C. G. Cinun,Tua A. Tamba,Immanuel R. Santjoko,Xiaofeng Wang,Michael A. Gunarso,Bin Hu*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A complete, low-cost Stewart platform testbed integrating design, control, and validation with real-time state estimation for education and research.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To provide an affordable, versatile 6-DOF robotic platform for research and teaching, bridging gaps between modeling, control, and hardware validation.

Method: Develop a full hardware-software platform using off-the-shelf parts, 3D-printed and custom components; six linear actuators for 6-DOF; dynamic model; feedback linearization with LQR for trajectory tracking; Extended Kalman Filter fusing IMU and encoder data for state estimation; unified software framework for modeling, data acquisition, and control; validation via simulations and experiments on static/dynamic trajectories.

Result: Demonstrates accurate trajectory tracking and reliable real-time state estimation; validates that the platform performs well in both static and dynamic tests; shows cost-effectiveness and versatility as a research/education tool.

Conclusion: The platform offers a complete, affordable hardware-software solution for 6-DOF manipulation, enabling advanced research and education; the approach facilitates further extensions and benchmarking against other platforms.

Abstract: This paper presents the complete design, control, and experimental validation
of a low-cost Stewart platform prototype developed as an affordable yet capable
robotic testbed for research and education. The platform combines off the shelf
components with 3D printed and custom fabricated parts to deliver full six
degrees of freedom motions using six linear actuators connecting a moving
platform to a fixed base. The system software integrates dynamic modeling, data
acquisition, and real time control within a unified framework. A robust
trajectory tracking controller based on feedback linearization, augmented with
an LQR scheme, compensates for the platform's nonlinear dynamics to achieve
precise motion control. In parallel, an Extended Kalman Filter fuses IMU and
actuator encoder feedback to provide accurate and reliable state estimation
under sensor noise and external disturbances. Unlike prior efforts that
emphasize only isolated aspects such as modeling or control, this work delivers
a complete hardware-software platform validated through both simulation and
experiments on static and dynamic trajectories. Results demonstrate effective
trajectory tracking and real-time state estimation, highlighting the platform's
potential as a cost effective and versatile tool for advanced research and
educational applications.

</details>


### [557] [An Intelligent Water-Saving Irrigation System Based on Multi-Sensor Fusion and Visual Servoing Control](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23003)
*ZhengKai Huang,YiKun Wang,ChenYu Hui,XiaoCheng*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Intelligent water-saving irrigation system using embedded vision, multi-sensor stabilization, and lightweight perception to cut water use by 30-50% while maintaining high accuracy and stability across varied terrains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address inefficient water use and poor terrain adaptability in precision agriculture, leveraging real-time perception, robotics, and stabilization to improve irrigation efficiency.

Method: A multi-sensor fusion framework combining computer vision, robotic control, and active leveling. Key components include a lightweight YOLO model on an embedded K210 for real-time plant container detection (>96% accuracy under variable lighting), a handheld-camera–tailored hand-eye calibration with >90% success, and an STM32F103ZET6–based active leveling system using JY901S IMU data to stabilize the platform on slopes up to 10 degrees (1.8 s response).

Result: Three simulated environments showed a 30-50% reduction in water consumption versus conventional flood irrigation, with water-use efficiency exceeding 92% in all test cases; detection and calibration accuracies meet stated thresholds under diverse conditions.

Conclusion: The integrated system demonstrates substantial improvements in irrigation efficiency and terrain adaptability, validating that embedded vision, precise manipulation, and real-time stabilization can enable effective, water-saving precision irrigation in varied agricultural scenarios.

Abstract: This paper introduces an intelligent water-saving irrigation system designed
to address critical challenges in precision agriculture, such as inefficient
water use and poor terrain adaptability. The system integrates advanced
computer vision, robotic control, and real-time stabilization technologies via
a multi-sensor fusion approach. A lightweight YOLO model, deployed on an
embedded vision processor (K210), enables real-time plant container detection
with over 96% accuracy under varying lighting conditions. A simplified hand-eye
calibration algorithm-designed for 'handheld camera' robot arm
configurations-ensures that the end effector can be precisely positioned, with
a success rate exceeding 90%. The active leveling system, driven by the
STM32F103ZET6 main control chip and JY901S inertial measurement data, can
stabilize the irrigation platform on slopes up to 10 degrees, with a response
time of 1.8 seconds. Experimental results across three simulated agricultural
environments (standard greenhouse, hilly terrain, complex lighting) demonstrate
a 30-50% reduction in water consumption compared to conventional flood
irrigation, with water use efficiency exceeding 92% in all test cases.

</details>


### [558] [ManiDP: Manipulability-Aware Diffusion Policy for Posture-Dependent Bimanual Manipulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23016)
*Zhuo Li,Junjia Liu,Dianxi Li,Tao Teng,Miao Li,Sylvain Calinon,Darwin Caldwell,Fei Chen*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: ManiDP is a diffusion-based imitation learning framework for bimanual manipulation that explicitly models and leverages posture-dependent manipulability to guide dual-arm motion generation, improving dexterity and adaptability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing diffusion-based bimanual skill learning ignores posture-dependent task features crucial for mapping dual-arm configurations to force/velocity requirements in dexterous manipulation. There is a need to incorporate posture priors into learning to improve adaptability.

Method: Extract bimanual manipulability from expert demonstrations and encode posture features with Riemannian probabilistic models. Integrate these encoded features into a conditional diffusion process to steer the generation of task-compatible bimanual trajectories. Evaluate on six real-world tasks.

Result:  ManiDP achieves a 39.33% increase in average manipulation success rate and a 0.45 improvement in task compatibility over baseline methods.

Conclusion: Incorporating posture-relevant robotic priors into diffusion-based bimanual learning enhances adaptability and dexterity, enabling more human-like performance across diverse tasks.

Abstract: Recent work has demonstrated the potential of diffusion models in robot
bimanual skill learning. However, existing methods ignore the learning of
posture-dependent task features, which are crucial for adapting dual-arm
configurations to meet specific force and velocity requirements in dexterous
bimanual manipulation. To address this limitation, we propose
Manipulability-Aware Diffusion Policy (ManiDP), a novel imitation learning
method that not only generates plausible bimanual trajectories, but also
optimizes dual-arm configurations to better satisfy posture-dependent task
requirements. ManiDP achieves this by extracting bimanual manipulability from
expert demonstrations and encoding the encapsulated posture features using
Riemannian-based probabilistic models. These encoded posture features are then
incorporated into a conditional diffusion process to guide the generation of
task-compatible bimanual motion sequences. We evaluate ManiDP on six real-world
bimanual tasks, where the experimental results demonstrate a 39.33$\%$ increase
in average manipulation success rate and a 0.45 improvement in task
compatibility compared to baseline methods. This work highlights the importance
of integrating posture-relevant robotic priors into bimanual skill diffusion to
enable human-like adaptability and dexterity.

</details>


### [559] [Seq-DeepIPC: Sequential Sensing for End-to-End Control in Legged Robot Navigation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23057)
*Oskar Natan,Jun Miura*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A sequential end-to-end model for legged robot navigation that fuses RGB-D and GNSS with temporal data; demonstrates improved perception and control on diverse terrains using EfficientNet-B0 and GNSS-based heading.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Robust perception-to-control for legged robots in real-world environments requires integrating multi-modal sensing and temporal information. IMU-based heading can be noisy; edge deployment demands efficient models; diverse terrain data is needed to generalize to road and grass. The paper aims to improve planning/control by joint perception tasks with temporal fusion and lightweight encoders.

Method: Seq-DeepIPC is a sequential end-to-end perception-to-control model that fuses RGB-D and GNSS with temporal data. It jointly predicts semantic segmentation and depth estimation, providing richer spatial features for planning. An EfficientNet-B0 encoder reduces computation. Heading is computed from consecutive GNSS positions rather than using IMU. A larger, diverse dataset (road and grass) is collected and tested on a robot dog. The study includes comparative and ablation analyses of sequential inputs.

Result: Sequential inputs improve perception and control in this framework; baselines do not gain from sequencing. Seq-DeepIPC achieves competitive or superior performance with a reasonable model size. GNSS-based heading is robust in open areas but less reliable near tall buildings; performance in urban canyons may lag behind GNSS-dependent methods. The method extends end-to-end navigation to legged robots and supports edge deployment.

Conclusion: Seq-DeepIPC broadens end-to-end navigation from wheeled robots to legged, temporally-aware systems. The authors plan to release code on GitHub to enable further research. The work highlights the benefits of joint perception and temporal fusion for navigation and sets a path toward more versatile autonomous agents in real-world environments.

Abstract: We present Seq-DeepIPC, a sequential end-to-end perception-to-control model
for legged robot navigation in realworld environments. Seq-DeepIPC advances
intelligent sensing for autonomous legged navigation by tightly integrating
multi-modal perception (RGB-D + GNSS) with temporal fusion and control. The
model jointly predicts semantic segmentation and depth estimation, giving
richer spatial features for planning and control. For efficient deployment on
edge devices, we use EfficientNet-B0 as the encoder, reducing computation while
maintaining accuracy. Heading estimation is simplified by removing the noisy
IMU and instead computing the bearing angle directly from consecutive GNSS
positions. We collected a larger and more diverse dataset that includes both
road and grass terrains, and validated Seq-DeepIPC on a robot dog. Comparative
and ablation studies show that sequential inputs improve perception and control
in our models, while other baselines do not benefit. Seq-DeepIPC achieves
competitive or better results with reasonable model size; although GNSS-only
heading is less reliable near tall buildings, it is robust in open areas.
Overall, Seq-DeepIPC extends end-to-end navigation beyond wheeled robots to
more versatile and temporally-aware systems. To support future research, we
will release the codes to our GitHub repository at
https://github.com/oskarnatan/Seq-DeepIPC.

</details>


### [560] [Awakening Facial Emotional Expressions in Human-Robot](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23059)
*Yongtong Zhu,Lei Li,Iggy Qian,WenBin Zhou,Ye Yuan,Qingdu Li,Na Liu,Jianwei Zhang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: This work presents an end-to-end learning framework for autonomous facial expression generation in humanoid robots, powered by a biomimetic robotic face and a Kolmogorov-Arnold Network with attention, plus an automated pipeline to build the first open-source facial dataset for humanoid robots, achieving accurate and diverse facial mimicry.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Humanoid robots currently rely on manually coded expressions, which are costly and limit natural interaction; there is a need for autonomous, generalized expressive capabilities and open data resources.

Method: Design of a biomimetic facial platform and an end-to-end learning framework using Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) and attention mechanisms; automated data collection guided by expert facial motion primitives to construct a dataset; evaluation across test subjects.

Result: Empirical evaluations show accurate and diverse facial mimicry across subjects; the approach reduces manual scripting and demonstrates generalized expression learning; dataset is open-source.

Conclusion: This approach moves toward autonomous expressive competence in humanoid robots and provides a valuable open dataset to accelerate research in robot emotion expression and human-robot interaction.

Abstract: The facial expression generation capability of humanoid social robots is
critical for achieving natural and human-like interactions, playing a vital
role in enhancing the fluidity of human-robot interactions and the accuracy of
emotional expression. Currently, facial expression generation in humanoid
social robots still relies on pre-programmed behavioral patterns, which are
manually coded at high human and time costs. To enable humanoid robots to
autonomously acquire generalized expressive capabilities, they need to develop
the ability to learn human-like expressions through self-training. To address
this challenge, we have designed a highly biomimetic robotic face with
physical-electronic animated facial units and developed an end-to-end learning
framework based on KAN (Kolmogorov-Arnold Network) and attention mechanisms.
Unlike previous humanoid social robots, we have also meticulously designed an
automated data collection system based on expert strategies of facial motion
primitives to construct the dataset. Notably, to the best of our knowledge,
this is the first open-source facial dataset for humanoid social robots.
Comprehensive evaluations indicate that our approach achieves accurate and
diverse facial mimicry across different test subjects.

</details>


### [561] [Breaking the Circle: An Autonomous Control-Switching Strategy for Stable Orographic Soaring in MAVs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23084)
*Sunyou Hwang,Christophe De Wagter,Bart Remes,Guido de Croon*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: SAOS switches between horizontal and vertical axis control during orographic soaring to avoid circling; adds AoA to INDI; simulations and wind tunnel tests show improved convergence, lower throttle, and reduced roll oscillations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To extend MAV endurance by exploiting orographic updrafts, but circling caused by control conflicts leads to energy waste and instability; a method that handles underactuation during soaring is needed.

Method: Introduce Switched Control for Autonomous Orographic Soaring (SAOS); selectively actuate either horizontal or vertical axis to transform from underactuated to fully actuated during soaring; incorporate angle of attack into the INDI controller for better force estimation.

Result: Simulations with randomized initial positions and wind tunnel experiments on two MAVs show SAOS improves position convergence, reduces throttle usage, and mitigates roll oscillations from pitch-roll coupling, enhancing energy efficiency and flight stability in constrained soaring environments.

Conclusion: SAOS effectively mitigates circling and energy waste in MAVs during orographic soaring, enabling more robust, efficient soaring; validated by simulations and wind tunnel tests and likely broadly applicable to energy-constrained flight in complex wind fields.

Abstract: Orographic soaring can significantly extend the endurance of micro aerial
vehicles (MAVs), but circling behavior, arising from control conflicts between
the longitudinal and vertical axes, increases energy consumption and the risk
of divergence. We propose a control switching method, named SAOS: Switched
Control for Autonomous Orographic Soaring, which mitigates circling behavior by
selectively controlling either the horizontal or vertical axis, effectively
transforming the system from underactuated to fully actuated during soaring.
Additionally, the angle of attack is incorporated into the INDI controller to
improve force estimation. Simulations with randomized initial positions and
wind tunnel experiments on two MAVs demonstrate that the SAOS improves position
convergence, reduces throttle usage, and mitigates roll oscillations caused by
pitch-roll coupling. These improvements enhance energy efficiency and flight
stability in constrained soaring environments.

</details>


### [562] [An Automated Tape Laying System Employing a Uniaxial Force Control Device](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23109)
*Bernhard Rameder,Hubert Gattringer,Ronald Naderer,Andreas Mueller*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Cost-effective automated tape laying (ATL) system with integrated force and temperature control, robot-assisted handling for complex shapes; experimentally validated with carbon fiber reinforced HDPE tape.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To achieve reliable consolidation, proper tape compaction, and temperature management in ATL processes, while enabling complex geometries.

Method: Design includes tape storage spool, guiding roller, processing unit, heating zone, consolidation unit; uniaxial force control; precise substrate and tape temperature control; robot-based motion with fixed tape lay device; experimental validation using CF-reinforced HDPE tape.

Result: Subsystems and the taping process demonstrated; successful experiments show viability for compact/complex shapes; temperature and force control enable proper consolidation.

Conclusion: The integrated force and temperature-controlled ATL with robot-assisted shaping offers a cost-effective solution for complex geometries in fiber-reinforced thermoplastics, validated experimentally.

Abstract: This paper deals with the design of a cost effective automated tape laying
system (ATL system) with integrated uniaxial force control to ensure the
necessary compaction forces as well as with an accurate temperature control to
guarantee the used tape being melted appropriate. It is crucial to control the
substrate and the oncoming tape onto a specific temperature level to ensure an
optimal consolidation between the different layers of the product. Therefore,
it takes several process steps from the spooled tape on the coil until it is
finally tacked onto the desired mold. The different modules are divided into
the tape storage spool, a tape-guiding roller, a tape processing unit, a
heating zone and the consolidation unit. Moreover, a special robot control
concept for testing the ATL system is presented. In contrast to many other
systems, with this approach, the tape laying device is spatially fixed and the
shape is moved accordingly by the robot, which allows for handling of rather
compact and complex shapes. The functionality of the subsystems and the taping
process itself was finally approved in experimental results using a carbon
fiber reinforced HDPE tape.

</details>


### [563] [OmniDexGrasp: Generalizable Dexterous Grasping via Foundation Model and Force Feedback](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23119)
*Yi-Lin Wei,Zhexi Luo,Yuhao Lin,Mu Lin,Zhizhao Liang,Shuoyu Chen,Wei-Shi Zheng*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: OmniDexGrasp is a generalizable framework that uses foundation models to enable omni-capable prompting and dexterous grasping, transferring human demonstrations to robot actions, and employing a force-aware grasp strategy; validated in simulation and on real robots across diverse prompts and dexterous hands, with extensibility to dexterous manipulation tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is a generalization gap in dexterous grasping due to limited semantic datasets. Foundation models offer broad knowledge but bridging them to physically executable robot actions is challenging; a cohesive framework is needed to enable omni-capable prompting, embodiment, and grasping.

Method: Three modules: (i) foundation models generate human grasp imagery to support omni-prompting and task generalization; (ii) a human-image-to-robot-action transfer strategy converts demonstrations into executable robot actions for omni dexterous embodiment; (iii) a force-aware adaptive grasp strategy for robust and stable grasps.

Result: Experiments in simulation and on real robots show effectiveness across diverse prompts, grasp tasks, and dexterous hands, and indicate extensibility to dexterous manipulation tasks.

Conclusion: OmniDexGrasp provides a generalizable framework that combines foundation-model–driven generalization with transfer and control strategies to achieve omni-capabilities in prompting, embodiment, and grasping for dexterous robots.

Abstract: Enabling robots to dexterously grasp and manipulate objects based on human
commands is a promising direction in robotics. However, existing approaches are
