challenging to generalize across diverse objects or tasks due to the limited
scale of semantic dexterous grasp datasets. Foundation models offer a new way
to enhance generalization, yet directly leveraging them to generate feasible
robotic actions remains challenging due to the gap between abstract model
knowledge and physical robot execution. To address these challenges, we propose
OmniDexGrasp, a generalizable framework that achieves omni-capabilities in user
prompting, dexterous embodiment, and grasping tasks by combining foundation
models with the transfer and control strategies. OmniDexGrasp integrates three
key modules: (i) foundation models are used to enhance generalization by
generating human grasp images supporting omni-capability of user prompt and
task; (ii) a human-image-to-robot-action transfer strategy converts human
demonstrations into executable robot actions, enabling omni dexterous
embodiment; (iii) force-aware adaptive grasp strategy ensures robust and stable
grasp execution. Experiments in simulation and on real robots validate the
effectiveness of OmniDexGrasp on diverse user prompts, grasp task and dexterous
hands, and further results show its extensibility to dexterous manipulation
tasks.

</details>


### [564] [Reliable Robotic Task Execution in the Face of Anomalies](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23121)
*Bharath Santhanam,Alex Mitrevski,Santosh Thoduka,Sebastian Houben,Teena Hassan*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A framework combines anomaly detection with a three-stage recovery to robustly deploy learned robot policies in open environments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Policy-based robotic systems are powerful but fragile in real-world, open contexts; need mechanisms to recognize deviations and recover safely to prevent failures.

Method: Train an anomaly detector on nominal policy executions; integrate it into online policy execution; trigger a three-level recovery: (i) pause, (ii) local state perturbation, (iii) reset to a safe state via a learned execution success model; validate on two tasks: Kinova Gen3 door-handle reaching (sim-to-real) and UFactory xArm 6 object placing with a general policy.

Result: Incorporating anomaly detection and sequential recovery increases execution success rates under various anomalies such as trajectory deviations and adversarial human interventions.

Conclusion: Coupling anomaly detection with a structured, multi-step recovery framework enhances the robustness, reliability, and safety of learned policies in open-world robotic deployment.

Abstract: Learned robot policies have consistently been shown to be versatile, but they
typically have no built-in mechanism for handling the complexity of open
environments, making them prone to execution failures; this implies that
deploying policies without the ability to recognise and react to failures may
lead to unreliable and unsafe robot behaviour. In this paper, we present a
framework that couples a learned policy with a method to detect visual
anomalies during policy deployment and to perform recovery behaviours when
necessary, thereby aiming to prevent failures. Specifically, we train an
anomaly detection model using data collected during nominal executions of a
trained policy. This model is then integrated into the online policy execution
process, so that deviations from the nominal execution can trigger a
three-level sequential recovery process that consists of (i) pausing the
execution temporarily, (ii) performing a local perturbation of the robot's
state, and (iii) resetting the robot to a safe state by sampling from a learned
execution success model. We verify our proposed method in two different
scenarios: (i) a door handle reaching task with a Kinova Gen3 arm using a
policy trained in simulation and transferred to the real robot, and (ii) an
object placing task with a UFactory xArm 6 using a general-purpose policy
model. Our results show that integrating policy execution with anomaly
detection and recovery increases the execution success rate in environments
with various anomalies, such as trajectory deviations and adversarial human
interventions.

</details>


### [565] [Combining High Level Scheduling and Low Level Control to Manage Fleets of Mobile Robots](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23129)
*Sabino Francesco Roselli,Ze Zhang,Knut Åkesson*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Two-layer coordination for multi-robot material handling: a high-level ComSat scheduler provides time-parameterized routes, while a distributed MPC at run-time computes safe local trajectories. The system is scalable, robust to disruptions, and validated in simulations showing high task completion under varying congestion.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the need for scalable, real-time coordination of large fleets of mobile robots in dynamic industrial environments, where static/dynamic obstacles and disruptions threaten safety and efficiency.

Method: A two-layer framework: (1) high-level scheduling using ComSat to generate time-parameterized routes for each robot; (2) distributed Model Predictive Control (MPC) at run-time to compute local reference trajectories that respect obstacles and mutual interactions, enabling real-time re-planning and rapid rescheduling in case of failures or environmental changes.

Result: Simulations in 2D environments with varied road capacities and traffic conditions show high task completion rates and robust behavior under congestion, with safe, collision-free operation and quick rescheduling.

Conclusion: The modular framework is computationally tractable and flexible, making it suitable for deployment in complex, real-world industrial settings where large robot fleets require scalable, resilient coordination.

Abstract: The deployment of mobile robots for material handling in industrial
environments requires scalable coordination of large fleets in dynamic
settings. This paper presents a two-layer framework that combines high-level
scheduling with low-level control. Tasks are assigned and scheduled using the
compositional algorithm ComSat, which generates time-parameterized routes for
each robot. These schedules are then used by a distributed Model Predictive
Control (MPC) system in real time to compute local reference trajectories,
accounting for static and dynamic obstacles. The approach ensures safe,
collision-free operation, and supports rapid rescheduling in response to
disruptions such as robot failures or environmental changes. We evaluate the
method in simulated 2D environments with varying road capacities and traffic
conditions, demonstrating high task completion rates and robust behavior even
under congestion. The modular structure of the framework allows for
computational tractability and flexibility, making it suitable for deployment
in complex, real-world industrial scenarios.

</details>


### [566] [TARC: Time-Adaptive Robotic Control](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23176)
*Arnav Sukhija,Lenart Treven,Jin Cheng,Florian Dörfler,Stelian Coros,Andreas Krause*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Adaptive-frequency reinforcement learning for robotics that jointly learns control actions and their application durations, enabling automatic modulation of control frequency to balance efficiency and robustness. Demonstrated in zero-shot sim-to-real on a high-speed RC car and a quadrupedal robot, matching or surpassing fixed-frequency baselines while reducing frequency and showing adaptive behavior in real-world conditions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Fixed-frequency control enforces a trade-off between low-frequency efficiency and high-frequency robustness. Biological systems adaptively modulate control frequency, suggesting that allowing robots to vary frequency could improve performance and robustness without manual tuning.

Method: A reinforcement learning policy outputs both the control action and its application duration (i.e., the control frequency). The policy is trained in simulation and deployed to real robots (zero-shot sim-to-real). Experiments are conducted on two platforms: a high-speed RC car and a quadrupedal robot, comparing against fixed-frequency baselines.

Result: The proposed method achieves rewards on par with or better than fixed-frequency baselines while significantly reducing average control frequency. The controller exhibits adaptive frequency behavior in real-world scenarios, demonstrating robustness across environments in zero-shot transfer.

Conclusion: Jointly learning actions and their durations enables adaptive control frequencies that inherit the robustness of high-frequency control and the efficiency of low-frequency control. This approach bridges the gap between fixed-frequency limits and biologically inspired adaptation, showing practical viability across distinct hardware.

Abstract: Fixed-frequency control in robotics imposes a trade-off between the
efficiency of low-frequency control and the robustness of high-frequency
control, a limitation not seen in adaptable biological systems. We address this
with a reinforcement learning approach in which policies jointly select control
actions and their application durations, enabling robots to autonomously
modulate their control frequency in response to situational demands. We
validate our method with zero-shot sim-to-real experiments on two distinct
hardware platforms: a high-speed RC car and a quadrupedal robot. Our method
matches or outperforms fixed-frequency baselines in terms of rewards while
significantly reducing the control frequency and exhibiting adaptive frequency
control under real-world conditions.

</details>


### [567] [If They Disagree, Will You Conform? Exploring the Role of Robots' Value Awareness in a Decision-Making Task](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23204)
*Giulia Pusceddu,Giulio Antonio Abbo,Francesco Rea,Tony Belpaeme,Alessandra Sciutti*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Value-aware social robots attract more attention and can influence decision-making, with ethical risks but potential to promote reflection.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how perceived value-awareness affects human-robot interaction and decision influence.

Method: Experimental study with two Furhat robots (Value-Aware vs Non-Value-Aware) during a labeling task for images representing human values; measured explicit choices, gaze, perceived loyalty, conformity, and decision time.

Result: Participants could distinguish the two robots; no strong explicit preference, but gaze biased toward the Value-Aware robot; it was perceived as more loyal; about 25% conformity when robots disagreed with the participant; longer response times in disagreement cases.

Conclusion: Value awareness in social robots can shape influence and decision processes, but raises ethical concerns about manipulation; it may also promote participant reflection and accountability in ambiguous situations.

Abstract: This study investigates whether the opinions of robotic agents are more
likely to influence human decision-making when the robots are perceived as
value-aware (i.e., when they display an understanding of human principles). We
designed an experiment in which participants interacted with two Furhat robots
- one programmed to be Value-Aware and the other Non-Value-Aware - during a
labeling task for images representing human values. Results indicate that
participants distinguished the Value-Aware robot from the Non-Value-Aware one.
Although their explicit choices did not indicate a clear preference for one
robot over the other, participants directed their gaze more toward the
Value-Aware robot. Additionally, the Value-Aware robot was perceived as more
loyal, suggesting that value awareness in a social robot may enhance its
perceived commitment to the group. Finally, when both robots disagreed with the
participant, conformity occurred in about one out of four trials, and
participants took longer to confirm their responses, suggesting that two robots
expressing dissent may introduce hesitation in decision-making. On one hand,
this highlights the potential risk that robots, if misused, could manipulate
users for unethical purposes. On the other hand, it reinforces the idea that
social robots might encourage reflection in ambiguous situations and help users
avoid scams.

</details>


### [568] [Workspace Registration and Collision Detection for Industrial Robotics Applications](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23227)
*Klaus Zauner,Josef El Dib,Hubert Gattringer,Andreas Mueller*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A comparative study of sensors for robotic workspace modeling using point clouds, applying region growing segmentation and VCCS to extract collision objects and enable robot-environment collision checking.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Accurate knowledge of the workspace is essential for motion planning to define restricted areas and to account for collision objects.

Method: Collect point clouds from multiple sensors to capture the workspace; apply region growing segmentation and VCCS to identify and cluster collision objects; approximate clusters (e.g., bounding representations); construct a collision-environment model and test robot-environment collisions.

Result: Sensor comparison results are presented; the workflow from object detection to a finished collision environment is demonstrated; collisions between the robot and the modeled environment are detected.

Conclusion: The workflow enables effective reconstruction of collision environments from sensor data and shows how sensor choice influences detection accuracy, providing a practical framework for integrating perception with motion planning.

Abstract: Motion planning for robotic manipulators relies on precise knowledge of the
environment in order to be able to define restricted areas and to take
collision objects into account. To capture the workspace, point clouds of the
environment are acquired using various sensors. The collision objects are
identified by region growing segmentation and VCCS algorithm. Subsequently the
point clusters are approximated. The aim of the present paper is to compare
different sensors, to illustrate the process from detection to the finished
collision environment and to detect collisions between the robot and this
environment.

</details>


### [569] [Optimal Dimensioning of Elastic-Link Manipulators regarding Lifetime Estimation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23234)
*Klaus Zauner,Hubert Gattringer,Andreas Mueller*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A methodology for estimating the lifetime of elastic-link robotic manipulators and using it to guide geometry optimization, balancing lifetime with vibration, demonstrated on a 3-DOF manipulator for pick-and-place.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable sustainable, lightweight, time- and energy-efficient industrial automation by integrating design and control in the presence of mechanical compliance, using fatigue-based lifetime estimation to inform design optimization.

Method: Fatigue analysis combining rainflow counting with the method of critical cutting plane, using Tresca-equivalent stress and linear damage accumulation. Geometry optimization of flexible serial manipulators is performed with the objective of minimizing weight while controlling vibration; final design selected from a Pareto front on lifetime versus vibration. Demonstrated on a 3-DOF articulated manipulator.

Result: A Pareto-front-based design approach that trades off lifetime (fatigue life) and vibration characteristics, with the best geometry chosen from the Pareto set. The method is illustrated on a three-degree-of-freedom robotic arm.

Conclusion: The proposed lifetime-informed design method provides a practical framework for joint design and control of lightweight, compliant robotic manipulators, enabling informed trade-offs between durability and dynamic performance; demonstrated on a 3-DOF manipulator.

Abstract: Resourceful operation and design of robots is key for sustainable industrial
automation. This will be enabled by lightweight design along with time and
energy optimal control of robotic manipulators. Design and control of such
systems is intertwined as the control must take into account inherent
mechanical compliance while the design must accommodate the dynamic
requirements demanded by the control. As basis for such design optimization, a
method for estimating the lifetime of elastic link robotic manipulators is
presented. This is applied to the geometry optimization of flexible serial
manipulators performing pick-and-place operations, where the optimization
objective is a combination of overall weight and vibration amplitudes. The
lifetime estimation draws from a fatigue analysis combining the rainflow
counting algorithm and the method of critical cutting plane. Tresca hypothesis
is used to formulate an equivalent stress, and linear damage accumulation is
assumed. The final robot geometry is selected from a Pareto front as a tradeoff
of lifetime and vibration characteristic. The method is illustrated for a three
degrees of freedom articulated robotic manipulator.

</details>


### [570] [Deep Active Inference with Diffusion Policy and Multiple Timescale World Model for Real-World Exploration and Navigation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23258)
*Riko Yokozawa,Kentaro Fujii,Yuta Nomura,Shingo Murata*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A diffusion-based policy with a multi-timescale world model is proposed to minimize expected free energy for unified exploration and goal-directed navigation; real-world tests show improved success and fewer collisions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world robotic navigation requires balancing exploration with goal-directed goals. Active inference and the free-energy principle offer a principled framework to unify these behaviors, but practical implementation for long-horizon planning and diverse actions remains challenging.

Method: A deep active inference framework that uses a diffusion policy as the policy model and a multiple timescale recurrent state-space model (MTRSSM) as the world model. The diffusion policy generates diverse candidate actions; the MTRSSM performs latent imagination to predict long-horizon outcomes. Action selection minimizes expected free energy (EFE) to integrate epistemic (exploration) and extrinsic (goal-directed) values.

Result: Real-world navigation experiments show higher success rates and fewer collisions compared with baselines, particularly in exploration-demanding scenarios.

Conclusion: Active inference based on EFE minimization can unify exploration and goal-directed navigation in real-world robotic settings, with the diffusion policy and MTRSSM providing effective integration of planning and perception.

Abstract: Autonomous robotic navigation in real-world environments requires exploration
to acquire environmental information as well as goal-directed navigation in
order to reach specified targets. Active inference (AIF) based on the
free-energy principle provides a unified framework for these behaviors by
minimizing the expected free energy (EFE), thereby combining epistemic and
extrinsic values. To realize this practically, we propose a deep AIF framework
that integrates a diffusion policy as the policy model and a multiple timescale
recurrent state-space model (MTRSSM) as the world model. The diffusion policy
generates diverse candidate actions while the MTRSSM predicts their
long-horizon consequences through latent imagination, enabling action selection
that minimizes EFE. Real-world navigation experiments demonstrated that our
framework achieved higher success rates and fewer collisions compared with the
baselines, particularly in exploration-demanding scenarios. These results
highlight how AIF based on EFE minimization can unify exploration and
goal-directed navigation in real-world robotic settings.

</details>


### [571] [Precise Time Delay Measurement and Compensation for Tightly Coupled Underwater SINS/piUSBL Navigation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23286)
*Jin Huang,Yingqiang Wang,Haoda Li,Zichen Liu,Zhikun Wang,Ying Chen*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A tightly coupled piUSBL-SINS-depth navigation system with synchronized timing and a novel delay estimation strategy converts latency into a learnable parameter, yielding substantial accuracy gains in underwater navigation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Time delays and vertical observability limitations hinder underwater acoustic positioning; explicit delay estimation and precise time alignment are needed to improve fusion accuracy.

Method: Integrate a passive inverted USBL (piUSBL) with a strapdown inertial navigation system (SINS) and a depth gauge under precise time synchronization; fuse azimuth and slant range from piUSBL with depth data; introduce a delay measurement strategy that jointly estimates acoustic propagation delay and system processing delay, treating delay as an estimable parameter.

Result: Simulation and field experiments validate the approach; delay-compensated navigation reduces RMSE by 40.45% and maximum error by 32.55% compared to baseline.

Conclusion: Accurate delay measurement and compensation substantially improve underwater navigation accuracy and offer a generalizable framework for acoustic-positioning integration and time-alignment in latency-sensitive multi-sensor fusion.

Abstract: In multi-sensor systems, time synchronization between sensors is a
significant challenge, and this issue is particularly pronounced in underwater
integrated navigation systems incorporating acoustic positioning. Such systems
are highly susceptible to time delay, which can significantly degrade accuracy
when measurement and fusion moments are misaligned. To address this challenge,
this paper introduces a tightly coupled navigation framework that integrates a
passive inverted ultra-short baseline (piUSBL) acoustic positioning system, a
strapdown inertial navigation system (SINS), and a depth gauge under precise
time synchronization. The framework fuses azimuth and slant range from the
piUSBL with depth data, thereby avoiding poor vertical-angle observability in
planar arrays. A novel delay measurement strategy is introduced, combining
synchronized timing with acoustic signal processing, which redefines
delay-traditionally an unobservable error-into a quantifiable parameter,
enabling explicit estimation of both acoustic propagation and system processing
delays. Simulations and field experiments confirm the feasibility of the
proposed method, with delay-compensated navigation reducing RMSE by 40.45% and
maximum error by 32.55%. These findings show that precise delay measurement and
compensation not only enhance underwater navigation accuracy but also establish
a generalizable framework for acoustic positioning integration, offering
valuable insights into time alignment and data fusion in latency-sensitive
multi-sensor systems.

</details>


### [572] [Transferable Deep Reinforcement Learning for Cross-Domain Navigation: from Farmland to the Moon](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23329)
*Shreya Santra,Thomas Robbins,Kazuya Yoshida*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: PPO-trained DRL policy in terrestrial farmland generalizes to a lunar-like environment in zero-shot transfer, achieving ~50% success without extra training, indicating cross-domain DRL transfer is promising for planetary navigation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address brittleness of traditional navigation methods and explore cross-domain generalization of DRL policies to support efficient planetary exploration with reduced retraining.

Method: Train a 3D simulated agricultural rover using PPO for goal-directed navigation and obstacle avoidance in farmland; evaluate zero-shot in a lunar-like simulated environment.

Result: Policies trained under terrestrial conditions achieved close to 50% success in lunar simulations without additional training, indicating some cross-domain transfer capability.

Conclusion: Cross-domain DRL policy transfer is a promising approach for adaptable autonomous navigation in planetary missions and could reduce retraining costs, though transfer is not complete and may benefit from domain adaptation strategies.

Abstract: Autonomous navigation in unstructured environments is essential for field and
planetary robotics, where robots must efficiently reach goals while avoiding
obstacles under uncertain conditions. Conventional algorithmic approaches often
require extensive environment-specific tuning, limiting scalability to new
domains. Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) provides a data-driven alternative,
allowing robots to acquire navigation strategies through direct interactions
with their environment. This work investigates the feasibility of DRL policy
generalization across visually and topographically distinct simulated domains,
where policies are trained in terrestrial settings and validated in a zero-shot
manner in extraterrestrial environments. A 3D simulation of an agricultural
rover is developed and trained using Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) to
achieve goal-directed navigation and obstacle avoidance in farmland settings.
The learned policy is then evaluated in a lunar-like simulated environment to
assess transfer performance. The results indicate that policies trained under
terrestrial conditions retain a high level of effectiveness, achieving close to
50\% success in lunar simulations without the need for additional training and
fine-tuning. This underscores the potential of cross-domain DRL-based policy
transfer as a promising approach to developing adaptable and efficient
autonomous navigation for future planetary exploration missions, with the added
benefit of minimizing retraining costs.

</details>


### [573] [Large language model-based task planning for service robots: A review](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23357)
*Shaohan Bian,Ying Zhang,Guohui Tian,Zhiqiang Miao,Edmond Q. Wu,Simon X. Yang,Changchun Hua*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A survey of integrating large language models (LLMs) into service robotics to enhance task planning, covering foundational LLM techniques, their role as the robot's cognitive core, multi-modal planning, and the challenges and future directions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To synthesize how advances in LLMs can improve autonomous planning and decision-making in service robots, and to provide a structured reference for researchers and practitioners.

Method: Systematic literature review and synthesis of existing work on LLM-driven task planning in service robotics, including taxonomy of approaches, modalities, and integration strategies (pre-training, fine-tuning, RAG, prompts).

Result: Provides a comprehensive taxonomy and analysis of current approaches, highlighting how LLMs support autonomy and decision-making, summarizing progress across text, visual, audio, and multimodal inputs, and identifying key challenges such as reliability, safety, and domain transfer, along with gaps and potential best practices.

Conclusion: A resource for researchers and practitioners that outlines practical directions and considerations for advancing LLM-based task planning in unstructured domestic environments, emphasizing the need for robust evaluation, real-world deployment, and future research avenues.

Abstract: With the rapid advancement of large language models (LLMs) and robotics,
service robots are increasingly becoming an integral part of daily life,
offering a wide range of services in complex environments. To deliver these
services intelligently and efficiently, robust and accurate task planning
capabilities are essential. This paper presents a comprehensive overview of the
integration of LLMs into service robotics, with a particular focus on their
role in enhancing robotic task planning. First, the development and
foundational techniques of LLMs, including pre-training, fine-tuning,
retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and prompt engineering, are reviewed. We
then explore the application of LLMs as the cognitive core-`brain'-of service
robots, discussing how LLMs contribute to improved autonomy and
decision-making. Furthermore, recent advancements in LLM-driven task planning
across various input modalities are analyzed, including text, visual, audio,
and multimodal inputs. Finally, we summarize key challenges and limitations in
current research and propose future directions to advance the task planning
capabilities of service robots in complex, unstructured domestic environments.
This review aims to serve as a valuable reference for researchers and
practitioners in the fields of artificial intelligence and robotics.

</details>


### [574] [T-ESKF: Transformed Error-State Kalman Filter for Consistent Visual-Inertial Navigation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23359)
*Chungeng Tian,Ning Hao,Fenghua He*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Introduces Transformed ESKF (T-ESKF) for visual-inertial navigation to address inconsistency due to observability mismatch by applying a linear time-varying transformation to the error-state; preserves the observability of the transformed system across linearization points and enables faster covariance propagation; validated by simulations and experiments; code available on GitHub.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In VINS, the standard error-state Kalman filter (ESKF) can become inconsistent due to observability mismatch; the unobservable subspace may depend on the state and linearization point, leading to incorrect uncertainty propagation.

Method: Apply a linear time-varying transformation to the error-state in the ESKF to obtain a transformed error-state whose unobservable subspace is independent of the state. Develop the Transformed ESKF (T-ESKF) as a consistent VINS estimator. Derive an efficient covariance propagation technique using the relationship between the transition and accumulated matrices of T-ESKF and ESKF to accelerate computation.

Result: Extensive simulations and real experiments show that T-ESKF achieves better or competitive performance compared with state-of-the-art methods, while maintaining consistency. The approach is validated and the code is publicly available.

Conclusion: T-ESKF provides a consistent and efficient VINS estimator by decoupling observability from the state through a time-varying transformation of the error-state, with faster covariance propagation and competitive results; code release enables reproducibility.

Abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to address the inconsistency problem
caused by observability mismatch in visual-inertial navigation systems (VINS).
The key idea involves applying a linear time-varying transformation to the
error-state within the Error-State Kalman Filter (ESKF). This transformation
ensures that \textrr{the unobservable subspace of the transformed error-state
system} becomes independent of the state, thereby preserving the correct
observability of the transformed system against variations in linearization
points. We introduce the Transformed ESKF (T-ESKF), a consistent VINS estimator
that performs state estimation using the transformed error-state system.
Furthermore, we develop an efficient propagation technique to accelerate the
covariance propagation based on the transformation relationship between the
transition and accumulated matrices of T-ESKF and ESKF. We validate the
proposed method through extensive simulations and experiments, demonstrating
better (or competitive at least) performance compared to state-of-the-art
methods. The code is available at github.com/HITCSC/T-ESKF.

</details>


### [575] [Full-Dynamics Real-Time Nonlinear Model Predictive Control of Heavy-Duty Hydraulic Manipulator for Trajectory Tracking Tasks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23386)
*Alvaro Paz,Mahdi Hejrati,Pauli Mustalahti,Jouni Mattila*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A real-time nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) framework at 1 kHz for heavy-duty hydraulic manipulators, ensuring constraint satisfaction (forces, velocities, positions) at both joint and end-effector levels, validated experimentally with a robust VDC-based low-level controller.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Safety-critical operation of heavy-duty hydraulic manipulators requires strict adherence to actuator limits and feasible trajectories in the full nonlinear dynamics, which is challenging to guarantee in real time.

Method: Developed a real-time NMPC framework using a multiple-shooting strategy and real-time sensor feedback, complemented by a low-level virtual decomposition control (VDC) scheme for precise joint tracking; the controller enforces actuator constraints in joint and Cartesian space.

Result: Experimental validation on a full-scale hydraulic manipulator shows the NMPC enforces joint-level actuator constraints and yields constraint-compliant end-effector Cartesian motion, achieving high-accuracy trajectory tracking at 1 kHz.

Conclusion: The proposed NMPC framework demonstrates real-time, constraint-satisfying control for large-scale hydraulic manipulators, establishing a benchmark for real-time, safe operation under nonlinear dynamics and safety-critical limits.

Abstract: Heavy-duty hydraulic manipulators (HHMs) operate under strict physical and
safety-critical constraints due to their large size, high power, and complex
nonlinear dynamics. Ensuring that both joint-level and end-effector
trajectories remain compliant with actuator capabilities, such as force,
velocity, and position limits, is essential for safe and reliable operation,
yet remains largely underexplored in real-time control frameworks. This paper
presents a nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) framework designed to
guarantee constraint satisfaction throughout the full nonlinear dynamics of
HHMs, while running at a real-time control frequency of 1 kHz. The proposed
method combines a multiple-shooting strategy with real-time sensor feedback,
and is supported by a robust low-level controller based on virtual
decomposition control (VDC) for precise joint tracking. Experimental validation
on a full-scale hydraulic manipulator shows that the NMPC framework not only
enforces actuator constraints at the joint level, but also ensures
constraint-compliant motion in Cartesian space for the end-effector. These
results demonstrate the method's capability to deliver high-accuracy trajectory
tracking while strictly respecting safety-critical limits, setting a new
benchmark for real-time control in large-scale hydraulic systems.

</details>


### [576] [COOPERA: Continual Open-Ended Human-Robot Assistance](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23495)
*Chenyang Ma,Kai Lu,Ruta Desai,Xavier Puig,Andrew Markham,Niki Trigoni*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: COOPERA is a framework for continual, open-ended human-robot collaboration using simulated humans driven by psychological traits and long-term intents; it provides a benchmark and personalization methods, enabling long-term HRC across tasks and time scales.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Robotic assistants often lack a human model and long-term adaptability, focusing on predefined tasks in structured environments. There is a need to account for individual human traits, habits, and evolving contexts over time to enable effective, ongoing collaboration.

Method: Introduce COOPERA, a simulated-human framework where agents are shaped by psychological traits and long-term intents, interacting with robots in complex environments. Incorporate continuous human feedback to study long-term, open-ended HRC. Develop a benchmark and a method to personalize robot actions by learning human traits and context-dependent intents.

Result: Demonstrates that simulated humans can reflect realistic human behaviors and that inferring and personalizing to human intents improves open-ended, long-term HRC across tasks and time scales. A project page provides further details.

Conclusion: COOPERA enables systematic study of long-term, open-ended HRC by modeling humans with traits and intents, enabling personalized robot collaboration and providing benchmarks for evaluation.

Abstract: To understand and collaborate with humans, robots must account for individual
human traits, habits, and activities over time. However, most robotic
assistants lack these abilities, as they primarily focus on predefined tasks in
structured environments and lack a human model to learn from. This work
introduces COOPERA, a novel framework for COntinual, OPen-Ended human-Robot
Assistance, where simulated humans, driven by psychological traits and
long-term intentions, interact with robots in complex environments. By
integrating continuous human feedback, our framework, for the first time,
enables the study of long-term, open-ended human-robot collaboration (HRC) in
different collaborative tasks across various time-scales. Within COOPERA, we
introduce a benchmark and an approach to personalize the robot's collaborative
actions by learning human traits and context-dependent intents. Experiments
validate the extent to which our simulated humans reflect realistic human
behaviors and demonstrate the value of inferring and personalizing to human
intents for open-ended and long-term HRC. Project Page:
https://dannymcy.github.io/coopera/

</details>


### [577] [Deductive Chain-of-Thought Augmented Socially-aware Robot Navigation World Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23509)
*Weizheng Wang,Obi Ike,Soyun Choi,Sungeun Hong,Byung-Cheol Min*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: NaviWM augments LLM-based social navigation with a structured world model and a logic-based reasoning module, improving safety and social compliance in dynamic crowds.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LLMs alone often produce unsafe or unpredictable plans due to weak physical grounding and inconsistent reasoning in dynamic human spaces; a grounded, interpretable framework is needed.

Method: Two main components: (1) a spatial-temporal world model that tracks agents’ positions, velocities, and activities; (2) a deductive reasoning module that guides the LLM through multi-step, logic-based inference. Social norms are encoded as first-order logic for interpretable, verifiable decisions, enabling navigation under constraints like personal space, collision avoidance, and timing.

Result: Empirical evaluation shows higher success rates and fewer social violations, especially in crowded environments, validating the benefit of combining formal reasoning with LLMs for robust social navigation.

Conclusion: Integrating formal reasoning with LLMs yields more robust, interpretable social navigation; the approach surpasses prompting/fine-tuning baselines and highlights the value of grounding LLMs with a formal world model.

Abstract: Social robot navigation increasingly relies on large language models for
reasoning, path planning, and enabling movement in dynamic human spaces.
However, relying solely on LLMs for planning often leads to unpredictable and
unsafe behaviors, especially in dynamic human spaces, due to limited physical
grounding and weak logical consistency. In this work, we introduce NaviWM, a
socially-aware robot Navigation World Model that augments LLM reasoning with a
structured world model and a logic-driven chain-of-thought process. NaviWM
consists of two main components: (1) a spatial-temporal world model that
captures the positions, velocities, and activities of agents in the
environment, and (2) a deductive reasoning module that guides LLMs through a
multi-step, logic-based inference process. This integration enables the robot
to generate navigation decisions that are both socially compliant and
physically safe, under well-defined constraints such as personal space,
collision avoidance, and timing. Unlike previous methods based on prompting or
fine-tuning, NaviWM encodes social norms as first-order logic, enabling
interpretable and verifiable reasoning. Experiments show that NaviWM improves
success rates and reduces social violations, particularly in crowded
environments. These results demonstrate the benefit of combining formal
reasoning with LLMs for robust social navigation. Additional experimental
details and demo videos for this work can be found at:
https://sites.google.com/view/NaviWM.

</details>


### [578] [Dexbotic: Open-Source Vision-Language-Action Toolbox](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23511)
*Bin Xie,Erjin Zhou,Fan Jia,Hao Shi,Haoqiang Fan,Haowei Zhang,Hebei Li,Jianjian Sun,Jie Bin,Junwen Huang,Kai Liu,Kaixin Liu,Kefan Gu,Lin Sun,Meng Zhang,Peilong Han,Ruitao Hao,Ruitao Zhang,Saike Huang,Songhan Xie,Tiancai Wang,Tianle Liu,Wenbin Tang,Wenqi Zhu,Yang Chen,Yingfei Liu,Yizhuang Zhou,Yu Liu,Yucheng Zhao,Yunchao Ma,Yunfei Wei,Yuxiang Chen,Ze Chen,Zeming Li,Zhao Wu,Ziheng Zhang,Ziming Liu,Ziwei Yan,Ziyu Zhang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Dexbotic is an open-source PyTorch-based Vision-Language-Action toolbox that provides a one-stop research environment for embodied intelligence, supporting multiple VLA policies, an experiment-centric workflow, and strong pretrained models with ongoing updates.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is a need for a unified, reproducible, and scalable platform to develop, compare, and reproduce VLA methods across policies in embodied AI.

Method: Dexbotic utilizes a PyTorch-based toolbox architecture that integrates multiple mainstream VLA policies, offers an Exp script for rapid experiment development, and provides strong pretrained models, with ongoing updates to include latest foundation models and cutting-edge VLA models.

Result: The paper claims that users can reproduce various VLA methods within a single environment, develop experiments quickly via the Exp script, and achieve performance gains from strong pretrained models, with continuous updates.

Conclusion: Dexbotic aims to accelerate VLA research by delivering an open-source, policy-agnostic, experiment-centric platform with strong pretrained models and regular updates.

Abstract: In this paper, we present Dexbotic, an open-source Vision-Language-Action
(VLA) model toolbox based on PyTorch. It aims to provide a one-stop VLA
research service for professionals in the field of embodied intelligence. It
offers a codebase that supports multiple mainstream VLA policies
simultaneously, allowing users to reproduce various VLA methods with just a
single environment setup. The toolbox is experiment-centric, where the users
can quickly develop new VLA experiments by simply modifying the Exp script.
Moreover, we provide much stronger pretrained models to achieve great
performance improvements for state-of-the-art VLA policies. Dexbotic will
continuously update to include more of the latest pre-trained foundation models
and cutting-edge VLA models in the industry.

</details>


### [579] [Localising under the drape: proprioception in the era of distributed surgical robotic system](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23512)
*Martin Huber,Nicola A. Cavalcanti,Ayoob Davoodi,Ruixuan Li,Christopher E. Mower,Fabio Carrillo,Christoph J. Laux,Francois Teyssere,Thibault Chandanson,Antoine Harlé,Elie Saghbiny,Mazda Farshad,Guillaume Morel,Emmanuel Vander Poorten,Philipp Fürnstahl,Sébastien Ourselin,Christos Bergeles,Tom Vercauteren*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Marker-free proprioception for fully draped surgical robots using stereo RGB cameras and transformer-based models on a 1.4M-image multi-centre dataset, enabling holistic robot-and-scene tracking with 25% visibility improvement over marker-based systems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Surgical robots currently lack robust spatial awareness, leading to collisions and workflow disruptions. Traditional tracking relies on bulky infrared cameras and markers, which are impractical in crowded or fully-draped operating rooms. A marker-free, robust, and scalable tracking solution is needed to enhance safety and enable multi-robot interaction.

Method: Transformer-based deep learning models trained on the largest available multi-centre dataset (1.4 million self-annotated stereo-RGB images from cadaveric and preclinical in vivo studies) to track the entire robot and surgical scene using only lightweight stereo cameras, offering marker-free proprioception under sterility constraints.

Result: Accurate localization under sterile draping with robustness to occlusions; elimination of markers and a 25% improvement in tracking visibility compared with existing systems; demonstrates feasibility of marker-free proprioception for fully draped robots, reducing setup complexity and enabling context-aware, multi-robot interaction; potential clinical benefits illustrated via in vivo breathing compensation and tissue dynamics.

Conclusion: Marker-free proprioception for fully draped surgical robots is feasible and advantageous, reducing hardware burden, improving safety, and enabling modular/autonomous robotic surgery. This work lays groundwork for scalable, occlusion-resilient scene understanding in surgical robotics.

Abstract: Despite their mechanical sophistication, surgical robots remain blind to
their surroundings. This lack of spatial awareness causes collisions, system
recoveries, and workflow disruptions, issues that will intensify with the
introduction of distributed robots with independent interacting arms. Existing
tracking systems rely on bulky infrared cameras and reflective markers,
providing only limited views of the surgical scene and adding hardware burden
in crowded operating rooms. We present a marker-free proprioception method that
enables precise localisation of surgical robots under their sterile draping
despite associated obstruction of visual cues. Our method solely relies on
lightweight stereo-RGB cameras and novel transformer-based deep learning
models. It builds on the largest multi-centre spatial robotic surgery dataset
to date (1.4M self-annotated images from human cadaveric and preclinical in
vivo studies). By tracking the entire robot and surgical scene, rather than
individual markers, our approach provides a holistic view robust to occlusions,
supporting surgical scene understanding and context-aware control. We
demonstrate an example of potential clinical benefits during in vivo breathing
compensation with access to tissue dynamics, unobservable under state of the
art tracking, and accurately locate in multi-robot systems for future
intelligent interaction. In addition, and compared with existing systems, our
method eliminates markers and improves tracking visibility by 25%. To our
knowledge, this is the first demonstration of marker-free proprioception for
fully draped surgical robots, reducing setup complexity, enhancing safety, and
paving the way toward modular and autonomous robotic surgery.

</details>


### [580] [Explicit Memory through Online 3D Gaussian Splatting Improves Class-Agnostic Video Segmentation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23521)
*Anthony Opipari,Aravindhan K Krishnan,Shreekant Gayaka,Min Sun,Cheng-Hao Kuo,Arnie Sen,Odest Chadwicke Jenkins*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Introduces an online 3D Gaussian Splatting memory to store object-level video segments and fuses it with FastSAM/SAM2 (as FastSAM-Splat and SAM2-Splat), yielding more accurate and consistent segmentation compared to memoryless or purely implicit-memory baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the lack of explicit object-level memory in class-agnostic video segmentation and to improve temporal consistency and accuracy by remembering previously predicted segments in 3D space across video frames.

Method: Develop 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) to accumulate predicted object segments over time; propose fusion strategies FastSAM-Splat and SAM2-Splat to leverage the 3DGS memory to refine foundation-model predictions.

Result: Ablation studies validate design choices; experiments on real-world and simulated benchmarks show that using explicit 3D memory yields more accurate and consistent predictions than models with no memory or with only implicit memory.

Conclusion: Explicit 3D memory via 3DGS improves class-agnostic video segmentation performance and temporal consistency and can augment existing segmentation foundations without requiring changes to their core architectures.

Abstract: Remembering where object segments were predicted in the past is useful for
improving the accuracy and consistency of class-agnostic video segmentation
algorithms. Existing video segmentation algorithms typically use either no
object-level memory (e.g. FastSAM) or they use implicit memories in the form of
recurrent neural network features (e.g. SAM2). In this paper, we augment both
types of segmentation models using an explicit 3D memory and show that the
resulting models have more accurate and consistent predictions. For this, we
develop an online 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) technique to store predicted
object-level segments generated throughout the duration of a video. Based on
this 3DGS representation, a set of fusion techniques are developed, named
FastSAM-Splat and SAM2-Splat, that use the explicit 3DGS memory to improve
their respective foundation models' predictions. Ablation experiments are used
to validate the proposed techniques' design and hyperparameter settings.
Results from both real-world and simulated benchmarking experiments show that
models which use explicit 3D memories result in more accurate and consistent
predictions than those which use no memory or only implicit neural network
memories. Project Page: https://topipari.com/projects/FastSAM-Splat/

</details>


### [581] [RobotArena $\infty$: Scalable Robot Benchmarking via Real-to-Sim Translation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23571)
*Yash Jangir,Yidi Zhang,Kashu Yamazaki,Chenyu Zhang,Kuan-Hsun Tu,Tsung-Wei Ke,Lei Ke,Yonatan Bisk,Katerina Fragkiadaki*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A scalable, reproducible benchmark for evaluating real-world robot policies by creating digital twins in large-scale simulators, combining automated VLM scoring and human preferences to assess generalist manipulation policies across varied environments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome the bottlenecks of real-world testing and narrow simulation benchmarks, by enabling broad, nuanced evaluation of vision-language-aligned robot policies using scalable human feedback and diverse scenarios.

Method: Convert real video demonstrations into simulated twins using vision-language models, 2D-to-3D generative modeling, and differentiable rendering; deploy policies in large-scale simulated environments; evaluate with automated VLM-guided scoring and crowdworker preference judgments; perturb environments along axes like textures and object placements to test robustness.

Result: A continuously evolving, reproducible benchmark framework that can evaluate real-world trained robot manipulation policies at scale, with reduced need for manual supervision to preference judgments, enabling robust generalization testing.

Conclusion: Provides a missing capability for scalable, safe, and reproducible evaluation of robot generalists, accelerating progress toward versatile, real-world-performing agents.

Abstract: The pursuit of robot generalists - instructable agents capable of performing
diverse tasks across diverse environments - demands rigorous and scalable
evaluation. Yet real-world testing of robot policies remains fundamentally
constrained: it is labor-intensive, slow, unsafe at scale, and difficult to
reproduce. Existing simulation benchmarks are similarly limited, as they train
and test policies within the same synthetic domains and cannot assess models
trained from real-world demonstrations or alternative simulation environments.
As policies expand in scope and complexity, these barriers only intensify,
since defining "success" in robotics often hinges on nuanced human judgments of
execution quality. In this paper, we introduce a new benchmarking framework
that overcomes these challenges by shifting VLA evaluation into large-scale
simulated environments augmented with online human feedback. Leveraging
advances in vision-language models, 2D-to-3D generative modeling, and
differentiable rendering, our approach automatically converts video
demonstrations from widely used robot datasets into simulated counterparts.
Within these digital twins, we assess VLA policies using both automated
VLM-guided scoring and scalable human preference judgments collected from
crowdworkers, transforming human involvement from tedious scene setup,
resetting, and safety supervision into lightweight preference comparisons. To
measure robustness, we systematically perturb simulated environments along
multiple axes, such as textures and object placements, stress-testing policy
generalization under controlled variation. The result is a continuously
evolving, reproducible, and scalable benchmark for real-world trained robot
manipulation policies, addressing a critical missing capability in today's
robotics landscape.

</details>


### [582] [UrbanVLA: A Vision-Language-Action Model for Urban Micromobility](https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23576)
*Anqi Li,Zhiyong Wang,Jiazhao Zhang,Minghan Li,Yunpeng Qi,Zhibo Chen,Zhizheng Zhang,He Wang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: UrbanVLA is a route-conditioned Vision-Language-Action framework for scalable, long-horizon urban navigation that explicitly aligns route waypoints with visual observations and uses a two-stage training pipeline (SFT on simulated/web data followed by RFT on mixed sim/real data) to achieve robust real-world performance, outperforming baselines by over 55% on MetaUrban's SocialNav and demonstrating scalable, uncertainty-robust navigation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Urban micromobility navigation in real-world cities requires reliable, long-horizon navigation across large-scale, dynamic, and unstructured environments. Existing methods largely address short-scale, controllable scenarios and lack integrated low-level (goal-reaching/obstacle avoidance) and high-level (route-visual alignment) capabilities.

Method: UrbanVLA is a route-conditioned Vision-Language-Action framework. It explicitly aligns noisy route waypoints with visual observations during execution and plans trajectories to drive the robot. The training uses a two-stage pipeline: (1) Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) in simulated environments with trajectories parsed from web videos; (2) Reinforcement Fine-Tuning (RFT) on a mixture of simulation and real-world data to boost safety and adaptability.

Result: Empirical results show UrbanVLA surpasses strong baselines by more than 55% on the SocialNav task in MetaUrban; it exhibits reliable real-world navigation, scalability to large urban environments, and robustness to real-world uncertainties.

Conclusion: UrbanVLA demonstrates the feasibility of scalable, robust long-horizon urban navigation by integrating low-level navigation skills with high-level route-visual alignment, and by leveraging a two-stage training regime to transfer from simulation and web data to real-world settings.

Abstract: Urban micromobility applications, such as delivery robots, demand reliable
navigation across large-scale urban environments while following long-horizon
route instructions. This task is particularly challenging due to the dynamic
and unstructured nature of real-world city areas, yet most existing navigation
methods remain tailored to short-scale and controllable scenarios. Effective
urban micromobility requires two complementary levels of navigation skills:
low-level capabilities such as point-goal reaching and obstacle avoidance, and
high-level capabilities, such as route-visual alignment. To this end, we
propose UrbanVLA, a route-conditioned Vision-Language-Action (VLA) framework
designed for scalable urban navigation. Our method explicitly aligns noisy
route waypoints with visual observations during execution, and subsequently
plans trajectories to drive the robot. To enable UrbanVLA to master both levels
of navigation, we employ a two-stage training pipeline. The process begins with
Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) using simulated environments and trajectories
parsed from web videos. This is followed by Reinforcement Fine-Tuning (RFT) on
a mixture of simulation and real-world data, which enhances the model's safety
and adaptability in real-world settings. Experiments demonstrate that UrbanVLA
surpasses strong baselines by more than 55% in the SocialNav task on MetaUrban.
Furthermore, UrbanVLA achieves reliable real-world navigation, showcasing both
scalability to large-scale urban environments and robustness against real-world
uncertainties.

</details>
